PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Carlton proceeding to address a question to the Minister for Health-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! This question goes very much to the personal affairs of the Minister and not to those matters under his public administration. I think the honourable member should reword his question to bring it within the Standing Orders.
—Mr Speaker, may I address that on a point of order?
—Yes, I will listen to your point of order.

—I submit that the Minister is responsible directly for the delivery of medical and hospital services within the Australian Capital Territory through the Capital Territory Health Commission, and this matter relates to actions of the Minister that are very much at the heart of his administration.

—It does not seem to question a public act of the Minister. I fail to see the question so far as relating to an act of administration; it has been a matter of the personal actions of the Minister. I ask the honourable member to reword his question so that it is in accord with the Standing Orders.

—I ask: Has any member of the Government in recent times declined the services of a rostered surgeon at the Royal Canberra Hospital and asked the hospital authorities to contact a surgeon of his choice? Did the surgeon of that person's choice come from his home in the middle of the night to perform the operation? Does the Minister believe that the exercise of this choice was in accordance with the spirit of Medicare, or was this person manipulating the system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear that the approach of an election brings out the more despicable side of this Opposition. I am only disappointed that the honourable member for Mackellar should stoop to seek to make this kind of cheap political capital. Most of his assertions are incorrect and I think it is important that the situation be put clearly on the record. Approximately a month ago my daughter was taken ill late at night with acute appendicitis. It was diagnosed by a local general practitioner whom I called in. That GP then checked with a surgeon to conduct the operation at the Woden Valley Hospital. There was no interference with hospital authorities whatsoever. Simply, the GP discussed with me a surgeon to undertake this operation.
—What about the hospital surgeon?

—I will come to that point in a moment. I discussed it with him. We took my daughter to the hospital and the surgeon was there, I think, when we arrived. I would point out that in those choices I exercised simply what is open to every citizen in Canberra.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me just point out an advertisement which under my authority was placed in the Canberra papers in the first weeks of Medicare. It is headed 'Doctor of choice in Canberra-these are the facts'. The advertisement states:
You can have your doctor of choice as a Medicare patient in a public hospital in Canberra.
The doctor that admits you to a public hospital for any pre-arranged service can continue to treat you in hospital.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nowhere else in Australia.
—If the right honourable member understood he would know that the same right exists in most country towns if the doctors will co-operate. The advertisement continues:

ANSWER.PARA: The Capital Territory Health Commission will allow this and will pay the doctor under the Medicare arrangements.

So I simply exercised a right of choice that every Canberra resident has and, of course, which many residents in country towns have, if their doctors agree, and, of course, many doctors do. The one additional point I used insofar as I exercised this preference was simply to ensure that my daughter was treated by a fully salaried public doctor, that is, a person who is committed wholly and totally to the public hospital system and who is available regularly to Medicare only patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. In view of the current Liberal Party of Australia advertising campaign, I ask the Prime Minister: What role do the personal income tax reductions announced in the Budget play in the Government's overall economic strategy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the tax cuts are a crucial part of the overall Government economic strategy. They will play, first, a very important part in stimulating consumer demand and in that way keeping the momentum of the recovery going. Of course, very importantly, secondly, the tax cuts will ensure continued income restraint under the accord and in that sense will underpin the accord which is recognised now universally-perhaps with one exception-as having been fundamental to the success of the recovery in this country. The tax cuts are, therefore, obviously good economics.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important to understand that they are real tax cuts. The cost of the tax cuts in a full year will be $2.1 billion. Full tax indexation would have cost only $1.2 billion in a full year. So any claim that has been made in this spurious advertisement that these are not real tax cuts, of course, is just another part of the Opposition's mosaic of misrepresentation.

During the last election campaign the Deputy Opposition Leader claimed that this Party would be a high tax government. The facts have shown that, of course, he was wrong during the campaign, and he will continue to be proved wrong. It is very important, let me say in answer to the honourable member's question, that we understand-and perhaps to some extent in some areas on the other side there is a glimmering of hope that they may understand it-that there is a need for reform of the Australian tax system. It needs to be reformed on the basis of considerations of efficiency and equity. I made it quite clear when I spoke in Sydney last week, and I repeat in this House, that when there is tax reform aggregate tax levels should not go up. They will not go up under this Government .

I have referred to the place of the tax cuts in the economic strategy of this Government. It is appropriate, in the light of the honourable member's question, to ask ourselves: What of the Opposition's tax policy? It is a legitimate question. Although the Liberal Opposition talks about its tax policy by way of advertisements, it has not announced it yet. We do not know what the policy is.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would love to know.

—On the contrary. I have gladly to this point put up with the indications of what it is because we are not without some indications from some spokespersons on the other side as to what they believe is an appropriate policy . In this context I remind the House of what the shadow Treasurer had to say on 19 March. Honourable members opposite do not like it. It remains true.
—You would not know anything about context.
—If I were the Leader of the National Party I would not start talking about context. On 19 March the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party said:

ANSWER.PARA: I think if the Government is faced with a choice between giving a tax cut of, say, $1 billion and having a deficit that is one billion lower than it might otherwise be, I think it ought to choose the latter.

Those were the words of the shadow Treasurer. We all know, do we not, the dilemma of the Leader of the Opposition? Because of his irresponsible spending promises he has already developed a massive credibility gap in this area. To dissolve his dilemma of the $15 billion deficit that would be involved in his spending proposals, the only way out for him would be significant tax increases. When the mob opposite talks about taxes we do not have to think about what its tax policy for the future might be. All we have to do is look at what the Opposition did when it was in government. That Government was the greatest phoney of all time. What did it do? In 1977 it went to an election and said to the people: 'Here is your great tax cut'. When the Government got back into power what did the present shadow Treasurer do? The Government was not back a matter of weeks before it said 'Thanks. We gave you the tax cuts for the election. Bye bye, electorate', and grabbed the money back. That is the record of the former Government in the area of tax cuts. The Opposition has shown, in the area of economic management generally and fiscal policy in particular, that it simply cannot and will not be trusted. Against that, the record of this Government is clear. We have produced the tax cuts that were promised. They are real. If one wants to talk in advertising terms, the record shows simply this: Liberals talk; Labor delivers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COSTIGAN ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. Has the Minister or the Prime Minister recently received correspondence from Commissioner Costigan? Has Commissioner Costigan expressed to the Minister or the Prime Minister the view that, because of the haste of the Government in winding down the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the fight against organised crime has been severely hampered? Has Commissioner Costigan also expressed to the Minister or the Prime Minister the view that the transition between the Costigan Commission and the National Crime Authority has not been successful? Will the Minister table the correspondence between himself, the Prime Minister and the Commissioner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that correspondence has taken place between the Government and Commissioner Costigan and between Commissioner Costigan and Mr Justice Stewart. Let me say this: The closedown of the Costigan Commission has not been rushed. I take honourable members back to February-March of this year when I spoke with Commissioner Costigan about the timetable for the closing down of the Costigan Commission and the transition from the Costigan Commission to the National Crime Authority. It was at the request of Commissioner Costigan that we met and it was with his approval that the timetable was set. That timetable was that his work would be completed by the end of June, when we set up the National Crime Authority, that he would require one month, the month of July, to see that the transition took place and a further eight weeks to see that his report was completed.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable members know, as a result of the legislation which has passed both Houses, the National Crime Authority is in place. The three people who form the National Crime Authority-Mr Justice Stewart as the Chairman, and Mr Dwyer and Mr Bingham as the commissioners-are now in place. There may have been some problems in the transitionary period, in moving from the Costigan Commission to the National Crime Authority. The material from the Costigan Commission has been handed over via the Attorney-General for the National Crime Authority to look at .

I do not expect that we will face any grave problems in terms of the National Crime Authority being able to reach its conclusions about what references it will require from the first meeting of the intergovernmental committee, upon which the Commonwealth, of course, will play its part. As a result of the actions of this Government, I think that in future we will be in a far better position than previously to play our role in order to bring down the crime rate in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters aware of claims that over the first two years of the Hawke Government Australian Public Service staff numbers will grow by 10 per cent? Can the Minister inform the House of the Government's estimates of Australian Public Service staffing trends and explain its general approach to Public Service staffing matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. It is true that some curious calculations have been made. Indeed, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition made another of his famous calculations just the other week. I quote from his speech to the National Press Club:

ANSWER.PARA: My calculations are that staffing levels in the public service will rise by about 10 per cent under the Hawke Government's first two Budgets. This is a dramatically greater increase than occurred under the previous Government.

He is way out in both respects. It is not the first time that I have had to give him a little assistance with his arithmetic, and I will happily do so again. The fact is that in the last year of the Fraser Government, in the last discredited Budget of the present Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the increase in the size of the Public Service was 5.3 per cent. As a consequence of that very large increase in that year there was a further increase, directly related to the decisions of our predecessors, of 2.2 per cent. Therefore, there was an increase directly attributable to the present Deputy Leader of the Opposition of 7.5 per cent in his last Budget.

By comparison, in our first two Budgets the increase has been 2.5 per cent and 2.1 per cent; that is, 4.6 per cent. Not only is the 4.6 per cent miles less than the 10 per cent that the calculations of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would suggest; as well, it is miles less than his own tarnished record. But we are used to these kinds of calculations. I do not have to remind the House of his predictions about the size of the deficit in 1983-84 when he suggested that it would be $6 billion but when one of his heroes, the soon to retire head of the Treasury, told us that it would be $9.6 billion.

The fact is that it is a bit more complicated even than that, because if we look at the way in which our predecessors handled the whole question of staff numbers we find that during their period of office the number of officers in the Second Division increased by a substantial 19 per cent, whilst the rest of the clerical work force increased by 12 per cent. The way in which they were able to offset that increase was to reduce by 50 per cent the numbers in the day labour force of the Department of Housing and Construction. The result was that, whilst this reduction limited the amount of funds that they spent on repairs and maintenance of government housing, it has left us with a most evil inheritance of houses which in many cases are almost uninhabitable. So as the result of some cosmetic treatment of the statistics not only were our predecessors unable properly to manage the size of the Public Service but also they were able effectively to damage the infrastructure which is required to house many of the people working for the Government.

We have adopted an entirely different approach. We do not use the crude approach of staff ceilings so beloved of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Rather we have used a process of proper personnel management and proper resources budgeting which has ensured that we have been able to contain the size of the Public Service but at the same time has ensured that there are adequate resources to provide the important services which are made available to the people of Australia. I think the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that Sir Humphrey would have been pleased with this Budget. I think Sir Humphrey would have been very disappointed that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was not able to undertake a simple arithmetic exercise without taking off his shoes and socks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Special Minister of State, in the light of his answer to my colleague the Leader of the Opposition a moment ago. Is it a fact that the head of the National Crime Authority, Mr Justice Stewart, has not had a briefing from Commissioner Costigan although he might have had some correspondence? Will Mr Justice Stewart be absent from Australia for at least six weeks during the balance of this year? Has the head of the team charged with transferring material from Mr Costigan to the National Crime Authority, Mr Phillip Cummins QC, been occupied with other work until last week and probably will be again from next week? Are the transition team, the commissioners and the staff of the National Crime Authority all employed on a part time basis? If not, how many are full time? How does the Minister reconcile these circumstances with his claim that the National Crime Authority is better placed than Mr Costigan in the pursuit of organised crime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —One would want a better memory than Billy McMahon to remember all that. In terms of what briefings Mr Justice Stewart may or may not have received, I would think it very competent to lay it upon his shoulders to seek out what information he requires. He does have access to all the senior personnel from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union at the same time as Mr Costigan is writing his final report. The problem I referred to earlier in reply to the Leader of the Opposition was that in some instances Commissioner Costigan in writing his final report may need some of the facilities and personnel to assist him that otherwise would be working with the National Crime Authority during this period. Of course, those services and facilities will transfer immediately to the Crime Authority once Commissioner Costigan has completed his work. We are not aware of any major barrier in this transition period. There may have been difficulties, but that is not a matter which has been raised with us by the National Crime Authority people.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of those working with the Commissioner, I noted the question the right honourable member asked about Mr Cummins QC. As I understand it he will be absent for one or two weeks between now and the end of the year, but basically the whole of his time will be given over to the National Crime Authority. In relation to the question the right honourable member asked about other staff, I know that Mr Justice Stewart was anxious to look at the make-up and levels of the staff that would be available to the National Crime Authority coming across from the Costigan Commission. When we set the budget for the National Crime Authority, while we gave it the same resources that the Costigan Commission had, it was on the basis that we would look favourably upon any further request that was made of us by the National Crime Authority. That was something which Mr Justice Stewart wanted to flush out, in his experience as head of the National Crime Authority, rather than having the Government prejudge what staff and at what levels he required for the Authority which he was going to run.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. In view of the Opposition's continued criticisms of the pensions assets test, could the Prime Minister advise the House what would be the consequences of the repeal of the assets test on pensions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for his question. There are two quite obvious results. First, there would be an unnecessary further blow-out in the level of expenditure on pensions. As we know, with the aging of the population that area is something which requires careful monitoring. That is the first thing that would happen if we abandoned the assets test. The second thing, which, of course, would not worry the people opposite but would nevertheless worry the overwhelming majority of Australian people, is that we would have a highly inequitable pension system. It would simply mean that very many very wealthy pensioners could so arrange their affairs that they would be able to get a full pension as against those who were significantly less well off but who, because of their position, would not get a full pension under the income test. That would be highly inequitable and something which, of course, would be welcomed by those opposite. I remind the House of the unbridled hypocrisy of the people on the other side of the House on this issue.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. You have ruled on that word when I have used it on a number of occasions. I ask you to do the same in regard to the Prime Minister.
—Order! The ruling on that word has been made when it has been used in regard to a specific individual, not when it has been used in its generality.

—Mr Speaker, one can understand the tenderness opposite on this issue. I want to remind the House that the Leader of the Opposition has in the past been more eloquent on this issue than anyone else I can recall. I remind the House of what the Leader of the Opposition-of course, he was not in that exalted position then-had to say when he addressed the National Press Club in Canberra on 16 September 1981. That is when he was doing his sulk up the back here; that is when he thought he could speak as the truth hit him. Let me tell the people of Australia what the Leader of the Opposition at the National Press Club in Canberra said on 16 September. I ask honourable members and the people of Australia to listen very closely to the words that the Leader of the Opposition, then a private member, said on this issue. I ask honourable members to savour the words; they are indeed delectable. I know that the Leader of the Opposition would not want to listen to this. We can understand that he wants to forget that he ever said it. He never wants to hear the words again, but he will hear them today and I can assure him that he will hear them day after day and week after week for a long time to come. On 16 September 1981, a memorable date, almost three years ago to the day, he said:
—Order!
—The Prime Minister knows very well--
—The honourable member for Maranoa knows what happens if he ignores the warnings of the Chair. I suggest that he be quiet.
—The Leader of the Opposition said:

ANSWER.PARA: What I have said in regard to that burgeoning area of expenditure, social welfare for example, 27 per cent of our outlays, that it has to be cut. The way to cut it-
said the Leader of the Opposition-
is to ensure that it goes to those who are in genuine human need, and not-
said the Leader of the Opposition-
to those I've described as demonstrably not needing it.
He went on-and it gets better:
Now that means perhaps some form of income or means testing-
Ah, ha! But it gets better. It is like a good meal: One has the entree first and then the fish course. We are coming up to the main course. He said:
I am not in a position to implement the change but if I ever become in a position to implement change I will certainly be seeking to see that the sort of things--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is going to look good in our election advertising.
—Oh, now, come on. Really! Wait a minute. We are used to that from the Opposition side. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I am not in a position to implement the change but if I ever become in a position to implement change I will certainly be seeking to see that the sort of things I am giving voice to . . . will become a reality.
I am not engaging in rhetoric for its own sake.

Having made it quite clear in September 1981 that he was totally committed to the concept of testing so that pensions should not go to those who do not need them, he has now become an opportunist of the first order. Let me at least say this, because one always desperately looks for a bit of decency from the Opposition benches: I give credit to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, because he has always made it clear that he supports the concept of an assets test.

I conclude by reminding the House that in September last year the Opposition promised to repeal the assets test as part of a total co-ordinated approach to retirement income policy. That was a year ago. We are still waiting for that co- ordinated retirement income policy. It is probably reasonable to come to the conclusion that we have not yet seen that policy because we had Mr Peacock, a private member as he was then, saying he supported the concept of an assets test ; we have the current Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the shadow Treasurer, quite consistently saying that he supports the concept; and we have Senator Chaney saying that he supports it. As if it were not enough to have those who are currently within this Parliament challenging the Leader of the Opposition, we have outside the House Mr Elliott, a senior official of the Liberal Party, also supporting the concept of an assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In the light of the importance that his Government has attached to the fight against organised crime -this was reiterated today by the Special Minister of State-and because of the great community concern about it and in the light of the Prime Minister's own statements about the value of the Costigan Commission and with regard to his declared support of open government, will he give the House a guarantee that it will be able to receive and debate the final report of Commissioner Costigan? Will he assure the House that the Government will not suppress the report or seek to avoid discussion of it before the election?
—The question of the Costigan report is quite straightforward. I understand that we will be receiving it--

—If I were a member of the Opposition I would not be trying to gloat about the Costigan report. If ever members opposite want to have something written in their hearts-one name which has been devastating to their cause-I suggest that they write the word 'Costigan' because Costigan was the name which exposed the infamy of the conservative parties of this country. I know members opposite do not like to hear this but I remind them and the people of Australia of the substance of the major interim report of Commissioner Costigan in which he talked about the fastest growing industry in Australia. What was the fastest growing industry in Australia? It was the industry of tax avoidance and he identified it as having grown and prospered under the stewardship of the Liberal Government. I would think that members opposite should not be talking too much about the name of Costigan because he has exposed them. As far as this Government is concerned, we have nothing to hide--
—Ha, ha!

—The inane haw-haws of the Leader of the Opposition are no substitute for rational analysis. We expect to receive the report of Commissioner Costigan I understand approximately at the end of September. When we receive that report it will undergo the normal processes that any government must--
—Wait a minute; it will undergo the normal processes of examination which were undertaken by the previous Government when it received reports.
—And not tabled.

—As has been pointed out, so many of the reports to the previous Government were not tabled. We will receive the report and will undertake that examination which is necessary to see that appropriate security or privacy matters are properly dealt with-as would be done by those opposite if they were in government, an experience that they will not savour for very many years to come. Of course after those processes have been undertaken the report will be made available.
—I ask the Minister for Primary Industry when details of the national soil conservation program will be announced and what progress has been achieved in policy development in this area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to report to the House that considerable progress has been made in the development and implementation of the national soil conservation program. In terms of this year's allocation of funds, I can inform the honourable member that details of projects announced under the national component will be released today and an announcement of projects funded under the State component will occur in a week's time. The national soil conservation program is emerging as an effective package for conserving the land resource of this country. On coming to government, attempts to institute a national approach to dealing with the widespread land degradation afflicting rural Australia were hindered by the complete dismantling of soil conservation policy that had occurred under the previous Government.

ANSWER.PARA: A national policy is being developed in consultation with the States. We have had two secondees from departments in New South Wales and Queensland and, as in all the Government's rural policies, there is an approach of consultation and quiet policy development that is gaining so much support in rural Australia. This approach is contrasted by the Opposition's confused approach to policy development. As we are aware, the Opposition recently brought out its primary industry policy, a wish list which would cost $312m extra. I see that there is to be another policy. I read from the latest edition of the National Farmer:

Signs that the National Party is keen to develop a distinctive policy profile from its coalition partner, the Liberals, were given by Primary Industry spokesman Tom McVeigh, who said the party was preparing a separate farming policy from the coalition paper issued earlier to woo country voters.
'Ours will be a lot better than theirs,' he said. 'It will be a lot more specific.'

That is what the honourable member said. The problem is that he wrote theirs. I do not know whether the Liberal Party will come out with its own primary industry policy. After all, I think the Leader of the Opposition gave us seven sentences on rural industry in his reply to the Budget; so perhaps the Liberal Party has some interest in the primary industries. But how could the Liberals say his policy is better than theirs? What if there is a contradiction between these two policies? Will the Leader of the Opposition run with both policies in the time honoured coalition tradition of hypocrisy or will he put out his own policy? It is apparent that there will be two policies, and 'ours will be a lot better than theirs' according to the Opposition spokesman. What he is really saying is that his policy will be better than his. That is pretty confusing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State said in answer to an earlier question that he was not aware of any major difficulties in the transition between Mr Justice Stewart, the National Crime Authority and Commissioner Costigan. Is it not a fact, however, that Commissioner Costigan has written to the Prime Minister saying that the transition has not worked? If this is so-and we understand it to be so-will he table the correspondence to reveal why there is a discrepancy between Commissioner Costigan's letter and his answer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Extra information has been made available to me during Question Time. It might be in relation to both questions asked earlier.
—Ah!

—That is all right, because the Leader of the National Party asked a whole series of questions and I wish to pick up some of them in answer to this. I understand that in late July Commissioner Costigan wrote to the Prime Minister raising issues relating to the transition from his Royal Commission--
—Ah!
—Woof, woof!
—There's a lot to come out of this.

—Wait for the next one. It has three syllables. In late July, Commissioner Costigan wrote to the Prime Minister raising issues relating to the transition from his Royal Commission to the National Crime Authority. He indicated that he would like to brief Mr Justice Stewart and officers of the National Crime Authority. At the same time he wrote to Mr Justice Stewart in similar terms. Mr Justice Stewart responded by saying that such briefings would not be necessary.

ANSWER.PARA: Subsequently Commissioner Costigan wrote again to the Prime Minister saying that, having received Mr Justice Stewart's letter, the matters he had previously raised no longer applied. Just recently Commissioner Costigan has again written to the Prime Minister raising the question of the transition, briefings and an extension. A response to this further letter is being considered by the Government at the moment.

Finally, the Government is later this week meeting with Mr Justice Stewart and the other two members of the National Crime Authority. Mr Justice Stewart will be absent from Australia for only two weeks during the balance of the year. He is travelling in the United States in his capacity as Royal Commissioner inquiring into Nugan Hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In view of conservative political commentary in this country describing so-called South African constitutional changes as a dramatic step and the friendly tribute from the Capetown Argus about statements of a similar nature as giving a strong hint that the Liberal Party in Australia will develop a more accommodating policy towards South Africa, what vindication does the Minister see in the conduct of the recent South African elections for such commentary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the conduct of the recent South African elections would convince members of the Opposition, should they have harboured the belief that there had been constitutional improvement in that country, that no such improvement had taken place. On those grounds I urge members of the Opposition to reconsider the policy declarations it has made in that area. I seek particularly to appeal to their better nature in view of the repression which has been taking place in the course of electoral processes in South Africa in recent times.

ANSWER.PARA: First of all, the processes, which were presented as a constitutional advance, represent nothing more than a shabby manipulation of the electoral processes. The first and major deficiency is that more than 70 per cent of the population of South Africa, the black people, are completely excluded from any participation in the electoral processes.

In the course of the actual election processes the authorities, mainly the police forces of South Africa, were brutally repressive against Indians, coloureds and blacks, particularly against Indians and coloureds who were political activists but activists in a sense which we would recognise as a legitimate right in a country such as this.

As a consequence of all this, the very widespread disenchantment and alienation of the non-white people of South Africa were reflected in the voting participation rates, less than 20 per cent for Indians and less than 30 per cent for coloureds. Without going into further detail there, I recall an article I read quite recently in the 10 September issue of the New Republic. I will give some quotes to illustrate the nature of the repression, of the cruel brutality, that takes place in South Africa. I do so, asking for the patience of honourable members and in the hope that, if the quotations are listened to, members of the Opposition might reconsider the statements they have made which have been described in the South African media as more accommodating of apartheid. The article states:

Consider the following cases, which occurred during the last fifteen months: A white youth who battered a black man to death with karate sticks was ordered to serve 1,200 hours in prison on weekends. According to trial testimony, 20-year- old Ronnie Johannes Van Der Merwe was walking down the street with his girlfriend and bragged that he felt like killing a 'houtkop' (blockhead)-a derogatory term some Afrikaners apply to blacks. He brutally beat to death the next black man he encountered. The judge said Van Der Merwe could be partially excused for his actions because he was upset that his parents were considering a divorce.
I ask honourable members to consider this case:

. . . two black musicians were sent to jail for four years because the security police detected that during a concert they included in their music some verses praising Nelson Mandela, the leader of the outlawed African National Congress . . .
In another case a few months ago, a black factory worker was given an eighteen- month jail sentence because his tea mug was inscribed with an A.N.C. slogan.

I have asked the Department of Foreign Affairs to see whether it can verify these accounts and it has been able to verify immediately a number of them and others it is checking-there is no doubt as to the authenticity of others-but I quote only those which have been verified. Above and beyond that, the Department has given me a number of other cases which are just as bad but which are not included in this article. The next case is as follows:
Mrs Suzman cited evidence, brought out in a related trial, that the organization-
that is, the Afrikaner Weerstandbeweging, the AWB or Afrikaner Resistance Movement-
had planned the assassination of black churchmen, including Bishop Desmond Tutu, an outspoken opponent of apartheid and head of the South African Council of Churches.

The A.W.B is a violent white supremacist organization, she said, with a swastika-like symbol and a salute modeled on that of the Nazis. But Justice Van Dyk had ruled that no useful purpose would be served by sending the defendants to jail since they are 'civilized and decent people'.

South Africa is a powderkeg under present circumstances. There is an understandable bitterness on the part of the non-white population. Apartheid is a slur and a moral crime against the dignity and rights of a very large number of people. That country deserves to be repudiated. I urge the Opposition to reconsider the more accommodating commitment it has given to the policy of apartheid in South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the answer that he gave to the Leader of the Opposition regarding the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Is it a fact that the final report of Commissioner Costigan is to be delivered to the Government by 30 September 1984? If that is a fact, will the Prime Minister undertake to the House that the normal processes of which he spoke in his answer to the Leader of the Opposition will be attended to before the Parliament is dissolved for the forthcoming election?
—I have nothing to add to my previous answer. This Government, as distinct from its predecessor, will handle this matter with total propriety.

—I refer the Minister for Transport to the recent need for the Australian National Line to withdraw from its coastal shipping services to Cairns, Townsville and Mackay. Would the Minister give the background to this decision? Is it the case that ANL was virtually bankrupt when the Government took office and now requires major restructuring? What alternative transport services are available to the people of north Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that the honourable member for Leichhardt raises is an important one. When we came to government, ANL found itself in the position of being virtually bankrupt as a result of a policy instituted as far back as when the Leader of the National Party of Australia decided that ANL should perform its functions as an instrument of political policy. From that time ANL continued to go downhill. In simple terms the reason for ANL's withdrawal from the far north and north Queensland is that the revenue it gathers from that service barely covers the shore costs associated with it. The Australian National Line, like any prudent responsible business enterprise, is in the position of having to pay its way.

ANSWER.PARA: Given that it is battling to survive in these very difficult conditions, the Australian Shipping Commission has undertaken a service by service review of its operations to ascertain those services that have the prospect of paying their way and those services that have no prospect of even meeting the expenses involved. I have to say that ANL is losing in excess of $500,000 a month on its far north Queensland services. In total, since the service began in 1978, ANL has lost in real terms in excess of some $42m. As I said, the service continues to lose half a million dollars a month.

The simple fact is that the people of the far north of Queensland have shown over the past six years that they much prefer the cheaper and more frequent road and rail services that are available. It was in those circumstances that I went to north Queensland last week at the invitation of the honourable member for Leichhardt, the honourable member for Herbert and Senator Reynolds to discuss the difficulty of ANL's decision with the people there. We discussed with business, community and union leaders in Townsville and Cairns the prospects facing ANL and the expenditures and revenues involved. Clearly, in Townsville the consensus was that the course being followed by ANL, considering all the circumstances, was the correct one. Similarly, in Cairns, it was understood that there was no way that ANL could continue to bear those losses and carry on.

We have this continuing disarray in respect of what is the Opposition's policy. It seems to me that we have four different Opposition spokesmen on transport. We have the shadow Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Hume, who says that the line-meaning ANL-was justified in withdrawing its services to Cairns and Townsville if the service was unprofitable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that.
—Yes, you did.
—Show me the quote.
—I will show the honourable member that later. He has said on numerous other occasions that there is no requirement for the Government to own a shipping line. They are his words.
—Order! I suggest that the Minister for Transport resume his seat until the House comes to order and conversations cease.
—A total fabrication.
—I warn the honourable member for Hume.

—Those words are on record. As well as that, the honourable member for Hume has made it quite clear in debate in this chamber that this Government should not own a shipping line, that there is no place for ANL--
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. If the Minister is quoting me, is he prepared to authenticate the quote that he made?
—Order! That is not a point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.
—What is he going to do-stand here and make allegations about what I have--
—Order! The honourable member has been told that there is no point of order. He will resume his seat.

—Then we have the honourable member for Dawson, the shadow Minister for northern development, or no development really for the north of Queensland. He sent me a telegram on 8 August, asking that I urgently intervene to require ANL to continue the service. One section, the old pork barrellers represented by the honourable member for Dawson, wants the service to continue regardless of the cost. Then we have the honourable member for Hume, the economic dry of the National Party, who says that we should not be in the business at all. Then the Leader of the Opposition got into the act. He went to Townsville and said: 'Well, if ANL cannot do it effectively it has to review its operations and perhaps bow out'. That is exactly what ANL is doing. It cannot afford to carry this rate of loss.

ANSWER.PARA: But let us get back to the responsibility for the provision of intrastate transport services in Queensland. Again, that is a responsibility of the National Party in Queensland. National Party Ministers of the Queensland Government were invited to meetings which were called last week in Townsville and Cairns. True, the Queensland Parliament was meeting. However, neither of the Queensland Ministers involved saw those meetings as being important enough to attend.

We were there. I was there to explain the position. But where was the National Party? One month after a decision was made on this matter, which is very important to the people of the far north of Queensland, the honourable member for Dawson has been stirred finally to raise the matter in this chamber by way of notice of motion. He could have raised the matter during the previous sitting week. He could have asked a question, as could the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Hume. Nobody did, because it is not a matter of accord or importance to them.

The responsibility for intrastate services in Queensland rests fairly and squarely with the Queensland Government, a National Party Government. If that Government wants that service to be provided it is up to it either to contract the service out to a company which will provide it or to contract the vessels from ANL. The Queensland Government can do what the Labor Government in Western Australia is doing. In Western Australia the Labor Government services the people of the far north of that State with its own shipping service. If the National Party is one iota fair dinkum-those who sit opposite and those in Queensland-it can provide the service.

TALK.START.PARA: —No responsibility to any State.
—You are the architect of ANL's disaster. You are the man who set about destroying the Line, and you dare to interrupt. You are the architect of the disruption of the service.
—Order! The Minister should address the House and not an individual member.
—What about what Charlie Jones did?
—Please, George, you and Charlie Jones I do not want to know about. You were a disaster.
—Order! I ask the Minister to address the House, not an individual member.

—In conclusion, I repeat that responsibility for this matter, which is important to the people of the north and far north of Queensland even if it is not important to the National Party, rests fairly and squarely with the National Party Government of Queensland. I suggest to National Party members opposite that they take the matter up with their Party colleagues in Queensland. If a loss is incurred by the Queensland Government in providing that service, then the Queensland Government can take its case to the Commonwealth Grants Commission as do other State governments in respect of transport services.

That the House take note of the papers.

I make the point, though, that I seek the assurance of the Minister for Finance that he will in due course make a full statement on what the Government proposes to do in regard to the legislative reform of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust and give the Parliament the opportunity to debate in full the range of allegations which have been made on this matter. Notwithstanding that we are well aware that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations is inquiring into the matter, the fact is that there have been no fewer than five inquiries in regard to this matter and the 300,000 people who are investing in the fund want to know what is going on. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later date.

The report was made available to honourable members during the adjournment.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Leader of the Opposition claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—He may proceed.

—During Question Time today the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) referred to my speech to the National Press Club in 1981 and quoted my remarks in regard to 'an incomes or means test'. He sought to relate that, as he has done in the past -I have said this sort of thing before-to the assets test. He knows, or ought to know, that an incomes test is different to an assets test. He has imposed not merely an incomes test on those aged over 70 but, in addition, an assets test. We have undertaken to remove the assets test because of its inequity. The incomes test will, of course, remain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also claim to have been misrepresented by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).
—Does the honourable member wish to make a personal explanation?

—I do. For the fourth time in as many months, Madam Deputy Speaker, the Prime Minister quoted, to use his own expression, out of context something that I had said about the trade-off between tax cuts and a reduction in the deficit, and for the fourth time I correct the misleading way in which the Prime Minister quoted my remarks. I remind him that on the AM program on 19 March 1984 I said:

SPEECH.PARA: But if you are asking me from an economic point of view what is the better thing to do quite clearly the better thing to do is to give a greater priority to reducing the deficit and that if the Government wishes on top of that to give taxation cuts then it should cut further into its own expenditures to find the room.

My point all along has been that there was room both to reduce the deficit further and to give a tax cut. That has been clearly demonstrated in the Budget Papers and the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) continue to mislead the Parliament and the people on the subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. The latter part of the content of the Deputy Leader's contribution did not deal with a misrepresentation; it was argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I claim to have been misrepresented.
—He may proceed.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has gone to some extraordinary lengths to try to drive a wedge between my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and me in a statement which he released on 31 August and in Question Time again today. Honourable members on this side of the House will be aware of the Minister's repetitious and mosquito-like tactics--
—Would the honourable member get to the point where he has been misrepresented.

—These tactics are characterised by his singular small-mindedness. On this occasion the Minister seeks to draw a difference between my colleague and me in relation to the Australian National Line and one of its services. He has made unsubstantiated allegations about what I am supposed to have said in relation to north Queensland services. In Townsville I said that it is not so much a question of who provides the service but whether the service is provided at all. If the Government is concerned about north Queensland, which it obviously is not, it is within its capacity to call tenders for the operation of a service to north Queensland. I have expressed views about ANL, and they are obviously--
—The honourable member will not debate the issue. He will finish by showing where he has been misrepresented.
—I am not going to debate the issue but I seek leave to table a statement which has been made by my colleague the honourable member for Dawson and which starts off by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no difference of opinion between Mr Lusher and me.
Leave granted.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Sex Discrimination Legislation

To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedom;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.
Deny to parents their rights to have their children enjoy single-sex sporting activities e.g., boys cricket team, boys football team, etc.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament assembled: should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr John Brown,Mr Coleman,Mr Ian Robinson,Mr Ruddock and Mr West.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax: Confectionery
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that the current discriminatory application of sales tax on confectionery at the rate of 20% is an unfair and unjust burden on this important manufacturing industry and your petitioners therefore pray that confectionery be treated in a similar fashion to all other foods, including snack foods, which are exempt from sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr John Brown,Mr Goodluck,Mr Humphreys,Mr Punch and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth: that Regulations and an Ordinance now before the Parliament amend the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the Customs (Cinematographic Films) Regulations and supersede the A.C.T. Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth law
the power to prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography (e.g. X- rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
the power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy;
the power to require imported video tapes/discs for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled: should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure
that the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
that Censors more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes;
that further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and
that, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Goodluck,Mr Hurford,Mr Newman,Mr Rocher and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled; should disallow the new Customs and Objectionable Publications Ordinance and that:
The Attorney-General enforce laws to prevent the importation and sale of hard- core pornography (e.g. X-rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
The importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy be prevented;
Imported video tapes/discs for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board;
Censors more appropriately reflect responsible attitudes;
Further measures be taken in association with States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and
That, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to reject the recommendations of the Commonwealth Schools Commission contained in 'Funding Policies for Australian Schools', concerning proposed increases in State aid to private schools and the proposed community standard for education funding.

2. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to declare a three year moratorium (1985-1987) on increases in State aid to private schools and on grants for new private schools and increased private school enrolments.

3. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to re-affirm their primary obligation to government schools and to implement all 1983 ALP election promises for increased funding to government schools.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duffy,Mr McVeigh,Mr Peacock and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia , namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation' s historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ''the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change.''
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Hicks and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows :
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropratic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Hawker and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife,Mr Peacock and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CADMAN; CARLTON; DRUMMOND; EDWARDS; GOODLUCK; LUSHER; RUDDOCK
PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Carlton,Mr Drummond,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Goodluck,Mr Lusher and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ''the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duffy,Mr Kent,Mr Lloyd and Mr Macphee.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government.

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognize that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
i. a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
ii. subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
iii. farmer unrest at seed prices,
iv. monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
v. increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Brumby and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Omega Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that.

1. Omega by sending low frequency signals, penetrating sea water enables hunter -killer submarines to establish their position and to launch a ''first strike'' attack. Omega is also used by AWACs, the flying radar stations, and for other military purposes.
2. Omega is an important U.S. military base and a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Omega would have a disastrous effect on Victoria and Melbourne .

3. Omega and other U.S. bases in Australia endanger, rather than protect us. They add a new unnecessary menace to a nuclear arms race that must be stopped, if we are to survive. Your petitioners pray that Members and the House assembled will close Omega.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent and Mr Steedman.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That grave concern be expressed and decisive action be taken to prevent the lifting of the barriers to the importation, and publication of hard core pornography (including urolagnia, coprophilia, necrophilia and bestiality) and publications which incite the use of hard drugs.

We the undersigned believe that this will cause enormous damage to the moral strength of our people, particularly the young and strongly and urgently request the Government to abandon its 1983 decision to alter the A.C.T. Classification and Publications Ordinance forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That all persons are entitled to protection from exposure to unsolicited material that they find offensive, and therefore: That adult persons should not permit to be displayed in public any material which offends public morality. Public morality should be determined by references to public committees comprising of significant groups within the community particularly at Local and State Government level. Significant groups would include Employer and Employee organisations, Consumer organisations, Law Associations and Church organisations .
We, the undersigned request the Government abandon its 1983 decision to alter the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

(1) That we unreservedly oppose the Federal Government's proposals in relation to the censorship laws designed for the Australian Capital Territory; and further we oppose any such proposal on censorship laws becoming law in any State in Australia.
(2) That we consider it right and proper that the citizens of this nation be consulted, and their views and desires respected in the formulation of law in censorship and similar areas.

(3) That it is with alarm the proposed censorship laws are regarded by citizens living in a society based on Christian ethics. In essence Australia is a Christian nation and our nation's laws must reflect and uphold our established values. Legislation which sanctions behaviour repugnant to Christians, is legislation not appropriate to Australia. Moreover, it is legislation which condones the destruction of the very fabric of our society. Legislation which promotes the degradation, abasement and exploitation of people, both young and old, and of our nation, is unacceptable.

(4) That we the undersigned request the Government to heed the points in this petition, and abandon its 1983 decision to alter the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that because videocassettes are a particularly powerful media form now easily accessible to the general public for private home viewing, and believing that the likelihood of minors obtaining or otherwise viewing obscene and pornographic videocassettes is very high even with careful parental oversight, we the undersigned protest at the removal of previously existing censorship bans, and in particular request the Government to abandon its 1983 decision to alter the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance forthwith, which now allows into the community such pictorial material as '' relished descriptions of violence'' and ''publications which mildly advocate the use of soft drugs such as marijuana'' (Category 1), and ''sado-masochism'', '' extreme fetishism'' (e.g. necrophilia), ''anal intercourse with consent'' ( Category 2), and other such depraved and repugnant activities; and non-pictorial material referred to as ''hardcore'' paperbacks containing ''relished child pornography, e.g. incest, and school teacher/student'' and ''extreme sexual torture'' (both Category 2), in the conviction that the ready availability and increasing public consumption of same will be a blight on our society, stimulating individual dissoluteness and leading to unlawful behaviour with innocent persons.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that we believe that there are unresolved economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental, technical and ethical problems associated with the mining of uranium and the Development of Nuclear power, in particular:
(a) to the proven contribution of the nuclear power industry to the proliferation of nuclear weapons and the increased risk of nuclear war; and
(b) the absence of procedures for the storage and disposal of radioactive wastes to ensure that any danger posed by such wastes to human life and the environment is eliminated.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that:
(1) No new Uranium mines be commenced;
(2) No new contracts for the sale of Uranium be approved;
(3) Uranium mines presently in production cease with the fulfilment of current contracts;
(4) No new Uranium is supplied to countries making or testing nuclear weapons.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We assert that TAFE, with over 1 million students, requires greatly improved resources if it is to continue to train Australia's skilled workforce effectively.

2. We call upon the Commonwealth Government to provide greatly increased funds to ensure that TAFE is accessible to all Australians, unlike the present time when thousands of people are turned away from TAFE colleges each year.

3. We urge the Commonwealth Government to equip TAFE workshops with the advanced technology used in modern Australian industries, and to expand TAFE's capital works program so that sufficient quality accommodation is available for TAFE teachers and students.
4. We ask that the Commonwealth Government greatly increase TAFE's recurrent expenditure, so that TAFE can respond quickly and flexibly to industry, Government and community demands.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. The Federal Labor Government's retirement income policies are piecemeal, inconsistent and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirement; and
2. the Government's proposed assets test legislation is iniquitous and, if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. scrap its proposed assets test legislation;
2. either institute a broad enquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems or await the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter; and
3. following the report of such a wide inquiry institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non-discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian flag reflects Australia's membership of the Commonwealth of Nations, her position in the southern hemisphere, and her federation of original colonies, and
recognises that the flag is a symbol of pride for most Australians, such that several organisations, including the ALP, incorporate the flag in their motifs.
Your petitioners therefor humbly pray that the Australian Government will resist moves to change the Australian flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Orthoptic Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the petitioners respectively request that Orthoptic Services be included in the Medicare Health Scheme.

Your Petitioners pray that the Medicare Health Scheme be revised to include Orthoptic Services as these services are an integral part of specialist eye care . Currently patients referred for Orthoptic consultations must rely on private health insurance if they are to receive any rebate on fees charged.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vessel 'Krait'
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain concerned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the Motor Vessel KRAIT remain as a Dedicated Operational War Memorial in the care and maintenance of the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol as has been the case for the past nineteen and a half years, on behalf of the people of Australia, and that your petitioners consider that the monies raised in the recent public appeal have been so raised for restoration to ensure the continuing seaworthiness of the KRAIT for the purposes of it remaining afloat and continuing to be used in the community service, and that the current proposal to remove KRAIT from the care and maintenance of the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol to the National War Memorial in Canberra, ACT would, if implemented, seem to represent a breach of faith upon which the aforesaid monies were raised.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Committee on Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that the Attorney-General with the agreement of Federal Executive Council amended the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations under the Customs Act (1901), to permit the importation of obscene and indecent pornography into Australia without reference to the Australian people or the Australian Parliament.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will establish a Parliamentary Committee to take evidence from the people of Australia, such as the Judiciary, the Police, Welfare workers and Youth workers, the video industry , the media, those engaged in public health, private citizens, civic organisations, churches and other community groups, and report to Parliament on the effects of all pornography.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Cadet Corps
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Legislative Assembly of the Commonwealth Government of Australia in Parliament of Australia. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Country of Australia, respectively ask:

That the Government of Australia be responsible for the staffing and financing of the Australian Cadet Corps as run in Government Schools. The undersigned pray that the Law be changed so as to allow all students who wish to take part, the opportunity to participate, regardless of their financial position.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth respectfully request that the Australian Government negotiate with the Australian Council of Trade Unions significant taxation relief for lower and middle income earners together with improvements in the social wage with particular emphasis on improving the position of those reliant on social security payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Personal Care Workers Study, Northcote, Victoria
