PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

We, the undersigned, are horrified at the prospect that the Personal Care Workers Study in Northcote, Victoria may cease for lack of funding. Such an action would cause severe disruption to the lives of disabled people using the scheme, would prematurely sack the workers involved and waste the research being undertaken.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives will ensure that funding for the Personal Care Workers Study is continued without interruption.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, Parliament House, Canberra, ACT. 2600. We, your petitioners, humbly showeth:

That permitting kangaroos to be commercially exploited when permissible cropping rates are unknown and the means of enforcing controls or protective laws are completely ineffective in this land, is allowing this unique animal to follow the path to rarity or extinction along which all wild animals have gone when subjected to exploitation in similar circumstances.
We Australians, have the right to see kangaroos in reasonable numbers on the landscape: we find the commercial slaughter of the kangaroo to be abhorrent and unjustified.
Commercialisation of wildlife should be stopped, particularly as exemplified by the kangaroo industry.
We your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will:
1. Ban the export of products made from kangaroos.
2. Take action to see that State Governments prohibit the commercial killing of kangaroos.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Recent X rated violent pornography allowed legal distribution, particularly with regard to distribution through sale and hire of video cassette recordings through commercial and retail outlets, is detrimental to the community at large because it gives wide circulation to concepts of human exploitation and victimisation, sexual pleasure through violence to others, and explicit details of violent sexual assault namely rape.

Your petitioners humbly pray that Censors be asked to give due regard to the social effect of the release of violent pornography and that a weighting factor for this be included in the rating of films.

Producers, distributors, and the owners of cinemas concerned with the production, distribution and showing of violent pornography be required to register with the Federal government and give full disclosure of their financial interests to the government with the proviso that such disclosures will be open to the public.
The Federal Government pursue ways of achieving the best effect for the community as a whole that is the abolition of violent pornography.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament for the Commonwealth of Australia assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned would call upon our government to introduce or amend legislation
(1) To place controls over video-cassettes so as to provide for the open availability through sale and hire outlets only of G. NRC, and M Rated video- cassettes.
(2) To prohibit the availability through sale and hire outlets of R rated video -cassettes and restrict their use to adult theatres.

(3) To prohibit completely the concept of X rated video-cassettes by the revision of the Customs and/or Censorship Regulations so that the production, import and distribution of such pornographic and sadistically violent material be prevented.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Coleman and Mr Punch.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty-two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Employee Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That we object to the granting of benefits such as bereavement leave, removal expenses and other such entitlements to homosexual partners of public servants employed by the A.B.C. We the undersigned request the Government to establish legislation to disallow such practice.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we object to the sale of pornographic material, that is, explicit material designed to be sexually stimulating in which women (and children) are portrayed as objects or commodities and are subjected to degradation, domination, dehumanisation, sexual violence, torture and murder.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House halt any attempts to legalise sale and rental of ''X rated'' pornographic video movies, and remove ''X rated'' violent and hardcore pornographic videos which are currently ''illegally'' available for sale and rental at video outlets and sex shops.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Dr J. Martinick
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are patients, colleagues and friends of Dr J. Martinick.
That she is apparently being victimised by the Department of Health and the Federal Police regarding itemisation in 1983.
That at no time in the last year the Department of Health Liaison officer or investigator had approached Dr Martinick to discuss any apparent problems.
That the Federal Police who are not a representative of the Department of Health made the first contact with her.

That we are perturbed that the normal procedure of investigating an irregularity was not adhered to in this case and we request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should clarify this situation and amend the Health Insurance Act if necessary to ensure that the Medical Practitioners in future receive a fair and just hearing.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Residential Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That the phasing out of the recurrent grant to residential colleges will be detrimental to the ability of disadvantaged and country students to receive a tertiary education.
That alternative arrangements to fund needy students will be of no net benefit to those students, owing to the higher costs of administering such arrangements.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the recurrent grant to residential colleges be maintained as the most efficient and equitable means of ensuring that all citizens, irrespective of background, have equal opportunity to receive a tertiary education.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
that the introduction of Medicare has not resulted in a cheaper, fairer system of health care as promised by the Federal Government.
Rather, it is an expensive, bureaucratic scheme, depersonalising medical services and conducive to medical mediocrity.
While recognising the responsibility which exists to assist those in need, we humbly request the Government to review this system which moves towards the nationalisation of Australian medicine.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lindsay and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local authorities in Australia shows considerable concern that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program Levy, at 2 cents per litre of petrol and diesel, was indexed in the 1984 budget, but that funds raised from indexation of the levy will go into consolidated revenue, and not specifically into expenditure on road funds.
It has been estimated that indexation of the levy will raise $491 million over the next six years to 1988-89, of which Local Government could have expected to receive $58 million.
This is a further denial of funds to Local Government, following $13 million lost this year from Personal Income Tax Sharing entitlements.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will amend the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act, such that funds raised through indexation of the levy will be placed in the Trust Fund, and used for much needed road construction work.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled:

The humble petition of Riker Laboratories Australia Pty Limited located in the Division of Berowra New South Wales respectively showeth that the pharmaceutical industry in Australia views with concern the trend in Government policy to pay insufficient attention to the importance of brand-name products.
Since the progress in development of new, safe and effective drugs is vitally dependent on the economic viability of a research-based pharmaceutical industry;
Since the viability is a pre-condition for continued employment of our well educated and skilled workforce in all aspects of the industry activity;

Since full information and reliable technical back-up can only be provided in easily accessible form from product information supplied by the research-based companies which are product originators, your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government initiate policies which ensure that continued access of Australians to safe and effective drugs is secured.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petitioner of the undersigned citizens of the State of Western Australia showeth that the Attorney-General amended the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations under the Customs Act 1901, to permit the importation of obscene and indecent pornography into Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that: the Government will restore the former section 4A of the Customs regulation to prohibit the importation of material that is obscene, indecent or blasphemous.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Franklin respectfully showeth:
1. Although Australia is endowed with vast quantities of natural gas, Tasmanians are denied reasonably priced access to those resources. It should be shared equally between all Australians.
2. The Tasmanian householder using liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) pays $35.40 for an average household cylinder. In Melbourne, the same cylinder can be purchased for as little as $23.77.
3. A Tasmanian family on reticulated gas supply pays double the price paid by a Melbourne family on natural gas.
4. Tasmanian commercial and industrial users, paying high prices for their gas, are penalized.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government gas subsidy of $20.31 per tonne should be increased to Tasmania to compensate for Bass Strait freight charges. The subsidy should be raised so that Tasmanian users pay no more than the average of Australian users.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bank Account Debits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria showeth our concern over the continuing taxation of Parents' Club bank accounts by way of the Bank Account Debit Tax.
Your petitioners therefore pray that-

Parent clubs being set up by Government Regulation in the State of Victoria ( Regulation XLII) be recognised by the Australian Government as education auxiliaries, in the same way as are School Councils.
The Treasurer move immediately to exempt Parent Clubs from the tax in the same way as are School Councils.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Queensland respectfully show:
last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
alcohol is a factor in 50% of road deaths;
alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
alcohol advertisements are glamorous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's continuing attack on taxpayers in the 1984-85 Budget.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of all the broken promises and the phoney self-congratulations about being responsible for the fragile recovery, one sorry fact stands out. After 18 months, two Budgets and a mini- Budget, the average Australian is worse off today than when Labor came to office . Let me repeat that damning fact: Average Australians and their families are worse off now than they were 18 months ago. I shall seek leave to table details of the deterioration at the end of my comments. This Labor Government is engaged in a massive redistribution of income, aimed not at the wealthy but at moving income away from those average people who make up middle Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course whenever the facts are laid on the table honourable members opposite, and particularly the Treasurer (Mr Keating), immediately resort to bluster and rhetoric. Take, for example, the Australian Labor Party's 31 per cent tax on lump sum superannuation. When questioned about the side effects of the Government's slug on super, the Treasurer invented the fiction that this tax would affect only a few privileged fat cats. The most recent example of this program of misinformation by the Government came when I presented figures calculated by the superannuation industry which showed that a person aged 45 entering a superannuation scheme today with a view to achieving a modest enough after tax lump sum benefit of a little over $150,000 at age 65-in 20 years time- would have to pay an extra $5 a week in contributions for the rest of his or her working life because of Labor's 31 per cent tax on lump sum superannuation. There goes most of the phoney tax cut right out of the window before we even look at the rest of the Labor tax machine.

What did the Treasurer have to say about the facts on lump sum superannuation? He first made the ridiculous statement that these computations applied to people who would get $500,000 lump sum pay-outs-a blatant misrepresentation of what the coalition and the industry had said. He then went on to say that our figures were nonsense because 'only a minority of Australians are members of a superannuation scheme'. He might call it a minority, but let us just remember the size and the make-up of the minority that Labor has slugged. Two years ago there were 2.6 million Australians contributing to superannuation schemes. Of course the numbers have grown since 1982 and more are to come, with a further possible 430,000 from the construction industry alone. So while the Treasurer dismisses more than 2.6 million Australians as a minority, the fact is that Labor's super tax will hit hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians.

It is the same with income taxation. I remind the House of what the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said. Of course he has scuttled out of the House to avoid hearing the truth about what he is doing to disadvantage ordinary people. On 16 February 1983 when he opened Labor's election campaign he said that there would be 'immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million Australian taxpayers with the greatest cuts going to those on the lowest incomes'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Immediate!

—Yes, 'immediate' was the critical word associated with the income tax cuts. He said that Labor would raise the tax threshold from $4,595 to $5,000 in order to 'free tens of thousands of low income earners from all tax'. He said that Labor would raise the dependent spouse rebate where there were dependent children from $1,030 a year to $1,134 in order to provide additional benefits to families. 'Families' is the word which the Prime Minister has not used since February 1983. It is just not in his vocabulary.
—Rubbish!

—The Minister says 'Rubbish': When did he last hear the Prime Minister talk about the family? When did he last hear him talk about the average Australian? When did he last hear him talk about the worker? Those words are not in his vocabulary. The Minister knows it and he knows that those are the people who are suffering today, and no obfuscation from second rate interjections can move that to one side. It is a fact and it remains a fact.
—The Prime Minister asked me about my family yesterday.

—And that is about all the molly coddling we will get within that incestuous little group. He will ask the Minister about his family. Perhaps he wants to check on whether the Minister intends to take the right to travel overseas with a de facto or not. That is another entitlement Labor has introduced. It has de factos in its program. That is what the Prime Minister might be asking about. I do not know. The Minister leads with his chin. The Prime Minister talks enough about de factos but not about families.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor said also that it would raise the 46c tax threshold from $19,500 to $19, 750. Well, Labor's mini-Budget came and went with no tax promises in it. Of course Labor did hit those on superannuation and the over 70-year-olds with the means test. Labor's first Budget came and went with no tax promises in it at all . Of course it did hit the elderly, and it hit them again, with the assets test. Tens of thousands of low income earners paid tax for the first time. The real value of the dependent spouse rebate was allowed to erode and 400,000 workers, whom nobody would call wealthy, for the first time found almost half of every extra dollar they earned going to Canberra. As I said, following an interjection from the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), the Prime Minister has given new meaning to the word ' immediate'.

In this Budget there is seemingly a new found urgency in the Government's attempt to live up to some of its tax promises before the early election, and so we have the so-called tax cuts brought down in the Treasurer's Budget. But what is the reality of these election sweeteners? Before taking account of the recent Budget changes, Labor had left average wage earners and their families $22 a week worse off in tax and family allowances. Then, up pops the Treasurer two weeks ago, having ripped off 22 bucks, saying he will give back $7.60. It is as phoney as the nonsense which the Prime Minister paraded in the Pacific on a nuclear free zone. We would have a nuclear free zone but with nuclear powered and nuclear armed vessels going around and around in it. We are to have a tax cut, but it will cost $15. Next week the Prime Minister will be in north Queensland making a speech on conservation. I will tell honourable members what he will do. He will chop down a tree, then mount the stump and make a speech in favour of conservation. That is the sort of nonsense that comes out of members of the Government. We have a tax cut-after the Government has taken $22 from people, they will get $7.60 back!

According to the Treasurer's own definition, the minority of Australians will benefit. For many Australians the illusory tax cuts did not even make up for the extra tax dollar Labor is taking through fiscal drag. In the process, this Government has ensured that one million Australians-I repeat, one million Australians-will move into higher tax brackets during 1984-85.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they are getting jobs.

—The honourable member would not know. He can interject because he is making so much from the starting price bookies that the tax man cannot even get close to him. The tax free threshold and the 46c threshold have not been changed and the Prime Minister has yet to honour his totally empty words of 16 February 1983. The real value of the dependent spouse rebate continues to decline. Labor' s tax strategy ensures that more and more Australians find themselves in the 46 per cent and the new 48 per cent tax brackets.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordinary Australians-a term not in the vocabulary of this Government and a group certainly not addressed by this Government unless it is to slug them-are picking up the bill for this Labor Government's big spending programs. Just the week before last the Treasurer released figures which show that a taxpayer on average ordinary time earnings, with a dependent spouse and two children, would have a lower real disposable income in December 1984 than he or she had two years earlier. That was revealed by the Treasurer's own figures. He comes in here and disputes my figures but has not been able to nail any of the component parts of those figures. He simply says they are wrong, brings in his own figures and releases them. They show that the people I have referred to will have a lower real disposable income than they had two years earlier, in December 1982. That is what the Treasurer showed.

What has all this squeezing of ordinary wage earners achieved over Labor's 18 months in office? Of course the answer is nothing; we have gone backwards. In a year of windfall government receipts-receipts are up by $8.6 billion-this big spending, undisciplined, socialist Government has missed a one-off opportunity to restrain the growth in public debt.

The Secretary to the Treasury, John Stone, said in his recent Shann lecture that failing to restrain the growth in the public debt serves only 'to defer further the day when meaningful reductions in taxation can be made and, above all, defer if not fundamentally impair the chances of lasting recovery in the longer run'. What a damning indictment of this Government's Budget and its big spending, big taxing economic strategy! Mr Stone knew what it was like, announced publicly his resignation days before the Budget and then poured it all over the Government days after the Budget. He is the Government's principal adviser to whom the Treasurer pledged so much faith and from whom he stated he had total support only the day before he announced his resignation.

I repeat: Government receipts are up a mammoth $8.6 billion. Yet the deficit, despite those receipts being up $8.6 billion, is down only $1.2 billion. Where has the money gone? We have been asking that question about the New South Wales Labor Party for a long while. The answer is that the Government has spent it like there is no tomorrow on its pet projects over the last two Budgets. Total government outlays rose nearly 8 per cent in 1983-84, followed by over 6 per cent in 1984-85-despite no increases in major Budget items such as family allowances. Let us remember that payments to the States fell in real terms. Real increases in spending by this Government in just two Budgets exceed the total for the previous six years of the coalition Government. The majority of Labor's spending increases were on Medicare and in paying the interest on the public debt. Every taxpayer now pays $17 a week just to service the interest on the public debt. Yet the actions of the Government in this Budget have locked Australians into a big Budget deficit next year.

What has the spending splurge achieved? There is no fundamental tax reform. There is no reform of spending priorities. There is no restraint. There is of course hurt. We should ask the average person and the elderly, just for starters . There is the hurt. The bottom line of Labor's economic mismanagement is that the average wage earner with a dependent spouse and two children will have a lower real disposable income in December 1984 than in December 1982. The Government admits that during this financial year unemployment will remain unacceptably high. There is a massive public debt burden which Labor has increased. We have seen the lowest real increase in defence spending for six years and a reduction in the number of service personnel. All this has been achieved. There have been major cuts in scientific and industrial research and development and real cuts in grants for drug education, in Aboriginal housing and in coastal surveillance. The list goes on and on.

At a time when the Government has $8.6 billion more than it anticipated the cuts and the hurt that extend throughout the community go into almost every area of governmental activity other than the areas where the socialists wish to get control of the direction and movement of people which is endemic to their philosophy. They have cut the areas which are essential to our security and to sustained recovery, but they have spent up big in other areas; and that is where the ordinary Australians' money is going. If the Treasurer comes back with more of his second-rate bluff and his second-rate rhetoric, recycles them and charges on to this train of misinformation, he will show that he is unable to cope with the facts. The facts show that he has no answer. I seek leave to table this document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time of the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Peacock) never even arrived and it has now truly expired because he has never had the intellectual discipline or the intelligence to be able to put to the Australian Parliament and the Australian electorate a coherent view about the national economy, about taxation or about anything else. He has just been complimented by the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt) on a good speech. All I can say about the Deputy Leader of the National Party is that his quality of observation has declined dramatically since the time he was a Minister and I can assure him and his colleagues that that will bring no more of them to this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just make this point: The Leader of the Opposition has had only one domestic portfolio, industrial relations, from which he spat out the dummy very quickly. He then took his bat home, sat on the back bench and never at any stage tried to grapple with the national economy. In fact he left it to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), now the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, to carry the can for a great shambles of a taxation policy, and carry the can he did when the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union exposed the massive tax avoidance which went on under his Government in those years. More importantly, he sat and watched the national economy fall apart in front of his eyes because of the tremendous fiscal imbalance over the last three years of his treasurership.

The Leader of the Opposition talked about large spending and deficits. Where did the $9.6 billion come from? How did we get from a deficit of $1 billion two years ago to a deficit of $9.6 billion? I will tell the House how we got there. We got there because of the incompetence of the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party and his colleague the Leader of the Opposition who were Ministers in the Fraser Government. Of course, the mark of their incompetence was not just the extra quarter of a million people who had no jobs, the quarter of a million they pushed into the unemployment queues-they did not have to worry about tax cuts because they had no income-but also the other unfortunate people in Australia who were belted around with taxation and the dismal rates of growth over the period of their office. That is their contribution to Australia's economic performance. How dare the Leader of the Opposition talk about workers and families? He has never met a worker in his life. (Quorum formed) It is very interesting that the Opposition regards the matter it has raised as important but then calls a quorum during debate on it. In other words, the brain-damaged honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) made his first parliamentary contribution since being elected by calling a quorum to silence me for three minutes. For the Opposition to treat so frivolously a matter which it proposed for debate by calling a quorum shows that it must regard it very seriously and as a matter of great public moment!

Madam Deputy Speaker, let me continue with the remarks I was making by indicating the total fallacy of the attack made by the Leader of the Opposition on the Government's taxation policy. It is worth observing the tax policies of the former Government. Let me give honourable members some of that Government's history. In the 1977 election campaign it promised a tax cut. Remember the ring up and find out how much your tax cut is, the fistful of dollars tax cut, election. Numbers in every capital city were given and people could ring up and find out how much their tax cut was. In May of the following year the Government took it away. It introduced an income tax surcharge to wipe the tax cuts out. Honestly, the cynicism of it would make a cat laugh. Here members of the Opposition are now talking about principles, equity and justice but they would not have a principle among them.

Take the 1982 tax cut. The honourable member for Bennelong, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, was the person who took the tax cut away. As Treasurer in 1978 he introduced the tax surcharge to wipe out the 1977 tax cut.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't give it, though.

—He says that he did not give it. What a retreat. He did not give the tax cut so he could wipe it away. His Party went to the election and gave the tax cut and five months later it wiped the cut out, but now he says that he did not give it. He was not the Treasurer, it was Sir Phillip Lynch who was in bed and who had been cut down by the former Prime Minister. He did not give it but he could take it away because he was the new Treasurer. That will give honourable members some idea of the morality of the Liberal Party. That is a very important comment on the standards of morality of the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue was the tax cut of 1982-$2 billion with a $1.4 billion increase in indirect taxes. That is the tax performance of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition-give $2 billion and in the same Budget take away $1.4 billion. The net cut was $600m.

Madam Deputy Speaker, take no notice of the Liberals on tax. They are rip-off merchants. The Liberal Government was the highest taxing government in Australian history. It let the tax system fall to pieces under the massive onslaught of tax avoidance schemes and was forced to do something about it only when Commissioner Costigan exposed it. That is its record on tax policy. The most important thing is that on this occasion the public have got a real tax cut of $7.60 a week, costing $2.1 billion in a full year which is almost twice as much as tax indexation. Tax indexation this year would have cost $1.2 billion in a full year, but we are giving $2.1 billion in a full year, almost twice as much as tax indexation. Even if we had indexed the scales it would have meant that somebody on a lower income would have got $2.30 a week. As it is, that person gets $7.60 a week as a result of the tax cut which this Government has given him .

The Leader of the Opposition comes in here talking about $22 tax increases. We exposed that nonsense a week ago. The simple statistic about that is that if taxpayers were $22 a week worse off the Government would be $6 billion better off. Obviously we are not, so that indicates what nonsense such a claim is. Fancy the Opposition attacking our tax policy. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition made it quite clear-he tries to wheedle out of it every Question Time -that given the choice between tax cuts or a lower deficit he would have taken the lower deficit. In other words, if he had been the Treasurer there would have been no tax cuts this year. Let us get that well and truly clear; there would have been no tax cuts under the Liberals.

Fancy coming in here and trying to make a case about living standards. Look at the living standards which prevail in this country at the moment: Job security, a quarter of a million people in extra work, 260,000 in fact; a public health insurance system for everybody, Medicare; the first home owners scheme which would never have been given to those 130,000 Australians who now have roofs over their heads; wage indexation which is worth $25 a week to the average income earner and which is opposed by the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy would have wiped it out; they would not have given this tax cut. That is another $7.60 a week. Of course they failed to mention the $5 to $6 a week saving in interest rates on home mortgages because this Government has got interest rates down from the record 20 per cent which we saw with the former Government when the Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy were in charge. How can they get up in this Parliament and talk about living standards and the promises of this Government?

The Leader of the Opposition even had the hide to say that the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) promised a tax cut before the last election but he omitted to mention that we promised it believing that the deficit would be about $6 billion in 1983 -84 and found that it would be $9.6 billion. Because of the deceit of the former Government there was no possibility of giving tax cuts in 1983-84, and that is why this year the tax cuts were given when the economy started to improve and when the Government was able to get the deficit down.

The Leader of the Opposition said that one million Australians have a higher marginal tax rate. Let me inform him that, as a result of this Budget, two and a quarter million Australians have a lower marginal tax rate and six million taxpayers-that is, all of them-have a tax cut. So if the Opposition wants to bandy any statistics around, they are the ones to focus on. It is no good saying that we never increased the spouse rebate. We assisted families by a $7.60 tax cut and we assisted those families not in employment. The Opposition says that we never spoke about families. What a mistruth that is. In this Budget a pensioner with three children and living in rented accommodation will be $15.50 a week better off. So we assisted those out of employment through the social security system, which the Opposition also opposed, and we assisted those in employment with a tax cut of $7.60 for most Australian taxpayers-particularly those in employment and with families. There was no adjustment to the spouse rebate, because we cannot give an increase in the spouse rebate at the same time as a $7.60 tax cut to a family while we increase pensions and benefits alike. It is just not possible to do all those things at any one time.

We reject out of hand the phoney proposal raised by the Opposition on the question of taxation. It has no tax policy. Its policy was one of rip-offs, of protecting tax avoidance and evasion over the years. It was simply ripping people off through the massive inflation it had operating through the tax scales , with no adjustments. The only adjustment was in 1977, and that was taken back five months later with a tax surcharge. The Opposition does not have a leg to stand on. It is deluding itself if it thinks that some proposition here, written by some staffer in the office of the Leader of the Opposition, because he is incapable of delivering this sort of speech off the cuff, and full of mealy mouthed charges against the Government, will cut any ice whatsoever with any member of the public who sees a stronger economy, lower inflation, lower interest rates, more job security, more employment, higher wages and a public health insurance system. Is that a contrast to the years of misery under the Liberals, of mounting unemployment, high inflation, high interest rates and no security for anybody? Everyone's job was threatened in their days.

The Opposition's proposal is simply a joke. The Government rejects it out of hand for the sham which it is. When the test comes, as indeed it always does, for any political party to face up to the public and say 'This is what we did, this is why we did it and this is how successful it has been', I know the judgment will come in very strongly on the part of the Government. This Government inherited an Australian economy in a shambles and in the deepest recession since the Great Depression. In coming out of it we have given not only those increases in living standards which I mentioned but also a substantial tax cut of $7.60 a week, costing over $2 billion in a full year, and at the same time we brought the Budget deficit down from the $9.6 billion left to us by the honourable member for Bennelong to $6.7 billion, $3 billion lower, despite the fact that we are wearing the massive cost of those unemployment beneficiaries who were lumped on to the Budget by his policies when unemployment galloped in this country. When we look at the burden of public debt interest, which we carried because of the failure of the former Government's policies and high unemployment, to reduce the deficit by $3 billion in two years and to give tax cuts are indicators of a good performance on the Government's part.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reminded of an old axiom from my sporting days that when a person constantly complains that he was not out leg before he should go and have a look at the scorebook. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) ought to do just that in relation to this hairy old matter about the $9.6 billion deficit. Quite clearly when we look at the scorebook the answer for the year is $4.4 billion, not $9.6 billion, the estimate made at the time when the Government came to power one on which it then cashiered every promise that it had made around Australia in that campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: It said that the whole of Australia would get a tax cut, that there would be no wine tax, that there would be increases in the public sector and that there would be increases in terms of security for families through Medicare. It said that this whole retinue of promises would not cost the community money.

The Treasurer in Opposition was a sparkling performer. There is no doubt about that. But since he has become Treasurer of the nation he has been increasingly less receptive to economic argument. In fact, very seldom at Question Time does he come to the point on economic questions. He relies substantially on rhetoric. I really do wonder at the Treasurer's claim that the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Peacock) would make a cat laugh.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I just make this point of order: The Opposition today called this matter on and then called a quorum. By all accounts the Government should have suspended this matter. I simply make the point that I was not even asked one question on the Budget during Question Time.
—There is no point of order.

—I think that probably points to what I was just saying, that he does not have much regard for economics at all and that he is much stronger on rhetoric than on anything else. As for making a cat laugh, we should think of the President of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales and the poor old cat. Wran's cat got lost. I wonder what it swallowed. There is a lot of corruption down there so I guess something happened to it as it disappeared out the window. The response from the Treasurer was totally one of rhetoric. The realities are that the Budget was drawn up as a straightforward exercise in squaring off business. On the one hand, big business had to be squared off. What did we do for it? We resurrected the old chain companies so that expenditure incurred in a totally unrelated field could be written off against current income expenditure. That squared that lot off. What did we do for government? Big government was squared off by a vast increase in the amount of revenue dug up from the Australian taxpayers. Not satisfied with that, we added to it a substantial deficit so that we could carry on a wide-sweeping government spending program. That is what we did for big government. What did we do for big unions? We met their demands by giving them a tax cut. They do not seem to quite understand the difference between taking $22 out and giving $7 back. They cannot be much good at business. I am not surprised that the Australian Council of Trade Unions' efforts in business have failed if that is its level of understanding. However, the trinity of bigness was all squared away.

SPEECH.PARA: What occurred in this particular area? If we look at the Budget Papers we find that this vast increase in government revenue is to be achieved partly by way of personal contributions from citizens. In fact, 53 per cent of all government moneys raised this year will come by way of personal income tax. The amount has vastly increased from 51 per cent in two years. This is an area in which the Government is saying that it is taking less. However, the figures show quite dramatically that that is not the case. On top of that, all of the Government's revenue estimates are based on the supposition that the economy is strong, that the balance of payments will continue at its current level and that international trade will continue to recover.

At Question Time today the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that the cut in personal taxation will do an enormous amount of good for the economy, particularly in the area of consumer demand. The Confederation of Australian Industry issued a paper on 3 September which contained an analysis of the level of consumer demand on a quarterly basis. The paper shows a growth in consumer demand of 2 per cent in September 1983; 1.1 per cent in December 1983; 0.3 per cent in March 1984; and 0.2 per cent in June 1984. One would be concerned on that basis alone that the income projections within the Budget will be met, given the tax cuts that are involved and the ability of the Government in the framework of the Budget to deliver anything in the coming year. Therefore, those who are charged with the responsibility of framing the next Budget certainly will be left with very little to build on.

Let us look at the question of spending. In this area we see not only the vast increase to which the Leader of the Opposition referred but also the components within it. We will certainly not escape from this area. A lot has been made by the Treasurer about the deficits that were left to him. But what do the figures show? In 1980-81 the deficit was $1.1 billion; in 1981-82 it was $500m; in 1982- 83 it was $4.4 billion. Now we see the real truth of the matter. In 1983-84 the deficit was $7.9 billion. The projection for 1984-85-I say 'projection' because there are many doubts in respect of this matter-is $6.7 billion. When exactly did this huge growth take place in the Government deficit? It has come in the last three years. I return now to the percentage outlaid in spending in terms of funding the debt. It is interesting to note that 8.8 per cent of total outlays is now going in funding the Government deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—I said 8.8 per cent. Honourable members opposite might be interested to know that the Government is to spend a total of 7.1 per cent on education. So the debt is more than expenditure on education. It is just short of the expenditure on defence of 9.1 per cent. We are looking at a total social security payment of 28.8 per cent and that is the sort of figure the Government will be getting towards if the deficits are not brought under control.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget was framed in a totally opportunist approach to electioneering, without any regard to the national interest or the future decade economic management of this country. The Government has let the opportunity pass at a time in which it claims that the economy is in good shape, at a time when it could have managed to restrain Government spending without an impact on the economy. When the Government looks back, especially in 1985-86 and 1986-87 when the projections of economic activity are substantially less than they are today, it will not be in a position to rectify some of the huge structural problems that are built into this Budget and with which no effort has been made to come to grips.

I think the citizens of Australia ought to be aware of the increasing concern that most of us have about this situation. Just to underscore that, something like 25 per cent to 28 per cent of gross domestic product today is underwritten by government securities on the market. A frightening amount is taken up in funding that area. If deficits continue to grow in this way-we can look forward to a deficit of substantially the same size or even greater in the next Budget- they will increase the proportion of GDP in the public sector. This certainly underscores once again the proposition that this Budget does absolutely nothing for individual incentive, private enterprise or the ability of Australians to improve their own lot within the economic system. I think that this Budget has done enormous harm to the citizens of Australia, to the families of Australia and to private enterprise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an absurd matter of public importance to bring forward in this Parliament at this time. It has done nothing but waste the time of the Parliament. It is clear that some of the Opposition's own back benchers even think that because they called quorums on the Opposition's own matter of public importance. To hear the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) in the speech that he has just made-it was the second of two poor speeches on this matter from the Opposition-talk about the cat of the Premier of New South Wales and other such matters just adds insult to injury. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) claimed that this Government had reduced living standards. This absurd matter of public importance has been built around that false and phoney claim, because that claim is nothing more than arrant nonsense. It is symptomatic indeed of what the Liberals and their National Party colleagues are peddling around the country at present. It can be summed up as peddling the specious in place of the solid, the plausible in place of the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: I bring to the attention of the House how the Opposition's analysis-for want of a better word-from the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is just so selective and distorted. They peddle figures that living standards have been reduced by $22 a week. First of all, they choose to include in their figures the abolition of the highly inequitable, ineffective and regressive mortgage interest rebates, but they choose to exclude the replacement of rebates with what is now the better targeted and highly effective first home owners scheme grant. The grant has gone up to $7,000 over five years, which represents an average payment of $44.87 a week. Members of the Opposition ignore all of that. Further they ignore the savings of all home buyers. I am using some illustrations from my own portfolio area of housing and construction. In these phoney assessments and analyses of theirs they ignore the savings of all home buyers as housing interest rates fall. Repayments on a typical $30,000 savings bank housing loan are down by no less than by $22 a month. They ignore that fact in their phoney figures. The situation is very different now from what it was when they were in office. Interest rates have gone down virtually three percentage points from what they were when this country was presided over by the Fraser Government. In other words, the Fraser Government would have taken $55 a month from the pockets of typical housing loan borrowers in this country by way of increased interest rates. I repeat that the Opposition's claims about living standards are phoney.

Let me illustrate why this is so. The Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy have overlooked altogether what has gone into the social wage due to the policies of the Hawke Labor Government. In what they have put forward they have overlooked the provision of $623m for the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement in the 1984-85 financial year. An amount of $623m will be provided from the Commonwealth Parliament. The figure is up 9 per cent on that for 1983-84. The figure for 1983-84 was 50 per cent higher than the figure for the 1982-83 financial year when a mere pitiful $264m was appropriated through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement for public housing in this country. I do not think that many members of this Parliament would have thought that even this Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy could produce analyses that are just so phoney, so wrong, so slipshod, so loose, so puerile and so lacking in grasp as those that have been produced by the present Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy. In summary, their mediocrity is superb.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you have been a member of this Parliament for a while. You will know that an assessment of a Budget is best gained in one's own electorate office. One is able to gauge, from the phone calls which one receives, how the Budget has been received. I might say that as a member of this Parliament for 15 years I have never known the people of my electorate to be more satisfied with a Budget than they are with this Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember you saying that in the Whitlam years. That very analogy was used.

—The honourable member's memory about that is as good as his memory and knowledge about the living standards of people in this country. He has just made that up as he made up the figures which stated that living standards have reduced by $22 a week. I have already put that matter in its proper place. We are entitled to ask: What would these carping critics have done? What would these moaners and groaners be up to if, God forbid, the country was being run by them? It is fair to say that they would want a deficit of at least $1.5 billion less than the deficit that we have been running. It is also fair to say-the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was honest enough to say so-that that reduced deficit would have been created by not giving the tax cuts that this Government has given to the people of Australia. The tax cuts amount to $2.1 billion in a full year and $1.3 billion in this year. The average taxpayer will have $7.60 a week more in his pocket.

SPEECH.PARA: What would the Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy have done with the economy of this country? Instead of having created 270,000 jobs, as the Hawke Labor Government has done since 1983, they would have run lower deficits. They would have cut the civil and defence works programs of this country. They would have ensured that those 270,000 and more would have been unemployed. The history of the last year of office of the Fraser Government, which was administered by people such as the present Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy, shows that 270,000 jobs were lost in that year. It is fair to say that the former Government would have continued with those policies. There would not have been the great growth in the economy and the great result in improved living standards which have come with the growth that we have had under the Hawke Labor Government. It is also fair to say that under the former Government there would have been a continuing protection of the tax evaders of this country.

I remind the House and the people, when we are talking about an attack on taxpayers, as do the terms of this phoney matter of public importance, of what these people in the Opposition have done in relation to our attack on the tax evaders of this country. The fact of the matter is that the Opposition remains the friend of the tax evaders. The only growth industry while the Opposition was in government was the tax evasion industry. Now the present Opposition continues to protect the tax evaders. Members of the Opposition have refused to pass bottom of the harbour taxation legislation on three occasions. Twice they have refused to pass the cherry-pickers legislation. We will give them another opportunity shortly to allow that legislation to pass. They have refused to pass the income equalisation deposits legislation.

As a result of all this, the ordinary honest taxpayer in this country has to bear an increased burden. Revenue worth $285m has been lost because the present Opposition has had to protect its Liberal tax dodging mates. Yet the Opposition has introduced this absurd matter of public importance about the Government attacking taxpayers. Members of the Opposition are the attackers of taxpayers. We are seeking to help the taxpayers by what we have done and what we hope to do in attacking the tax evaders. We have been prevented from doing so by the actions of members of the Opposition. What the taxpayers want and what we all want is a continuation of that growth which the Hawke Labor Government has already initiated. That means more people in jobs. We want those extra people in jobs not only for social reasons but also, of course, because when they receive an income they contribute to taxation and thus reduce the burden on other taxpayers of this country.

I feel sorry for these people. They have so few feathers to fly with that even though one is called Peacock I regret to say that the hawk has plucked the peacock's wings. It is so absurd that the result is this pathetic matter of public importance which was brought forward today. Members of the Opposition do not have any feathers to fly with. Therefore, they come up with these sorts of things. I extend personal thanks to the Leader of the Opposition, who is at the table, for raising this subject today. We were worried that the Budget had been forgotten. He has helped us to remind the people of how good it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Speaker, I present the report of the Australian Delegation to the seventy-first Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference held in Geneva, Switzerland from 2 to 7 April 1984, and seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. In a foreword to the report of the Australian delegation to the Inter-Parliamentary Union meetings in 1983, at Helsinki and Seoul, I expressed views, as Leader of the delegation, on the necessity to provide continuing support for the Union and its achievements. In April this year I had the privilege and pleasure of leading the Australian delegation to the first of the conferences to be held under the reorganised procedure adopted in 1983. The procedures now provide for two six-day conferences each year, in April and September, at each of which two study committees meet, with provision for a third committee to meet on any supplementary item agreed to by the Conference under its amended rules.

SPEECH.PARA: In accordance with the new procedures, the seventy-first Conference was held in Geneva from 1 to 7 April, organised and paid for by the Union's Secretariat. The venue for the Conference, and again for the next Conference in Geneva in September, reflects problems currently facing the Union. Despite the decisions reached in Seoul in 1983, which were at least partially directed at easing the pressures of size and cost, no offers to hold the April Conference were received . The Secretariat of the Union subsequently agreed to hold the Conference on a limited budget and on the understanding, consistent with the decisions in Seoul, that certain previously customary features would not apply or would apply to a lesser extent. Being a member of the Executive, I can say that it took quite some time to sort out precisely what the procedures would be. The lack of offers from member countries to act as host to coming conferences continued at Geneva, where none was received for either September 1984 or April 1985, and the only longer term offer relates to the September 1985 Conference, which will be held in Ottawa, at the invitation of the Canadian group.

In addition to the problems of cost and availability of facilities, which understandably restrict the capacity of many members to hold conferences, a political problem arises when national groups find it impossible to adhere to a fundamental rule of the Union that host groups must issue invitations to all member groups to attend conferences-I do not want to canvass that issue, for obvious reasons-a rule which the Australian group has always strongly supported, and I trust will continue to do so. The current state of international affairs, particularly with respect to the participation of certain member groups, is regrettably such that there exists a further restriction on the number of potential host countries. These problems are of considerable concern to the Union and its Executive Committee is giving close consideration to them. For member groups such as Australia it is important that they be overcome and that the Union should continue to provide the opportunity for legislative members of the over 100 national groups to meet and discuss subjects of national and international importance.

I acknowledge and express the delegation's thanks-that is, on behalf of all members-for the co-operation and work of the many people involved in running the Conference, but particularly the Secretariat of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, which had to accept the considerably greater than normal work load of organising the Conference, with extremely limited resources. The thanks of all delegates are due to the Secretary-General, Mr Terenzio, and all his staff members, who made the Conference the success it undoubtedly was. I express the Australian delegation's very sincere appreciation of the generous and significant assistance provided by the Australian Ambassador at the permanent mission to the office of the United Nations in Geneva, Mr David Sadleir, and to the Australian Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Richard Butler, who is also based in Geneva. Both were generous in extending briefings and hospitality to the delegation. David Sadleir, who as we all know, had previously had significant experience as a former Foreign Affairs officer attached to Inter-Parliamentary Union delegations , provided the highest possible level of assistance to the delegation, including the attachment to the delegation of a First Secretary, Mr Noel Campbell. I warmly express the delegation's thanks for all their help and also for that extended to members of the delegation by the Australian Ambassador to Switzerland, Mr Pierre Hutton.

I conclude by expressing my very sincere thanks and appreciation for the wonderful support that I received at this Conference in particular from my deputy, Senator John Watson, but also from the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Adermann), the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman), the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) and also my very good friend Senator Peter Cook . I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will not recapitulate what the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) has said, except to say that I thoroughly endorse the comments that he has made and express the same appreciation. I express appreciation also to this Parliament for the opportunity of being a delegate to the Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference. We express our appreciation to the honourable member for Hawker for his leadership and for the manner in which he tried to involve all of the delegates. We very much appreciated his experience and also that of his deputy, Senator Watson. Those of us who were fortunate enough to have our wives with us also give thanks for the courtesies that the leaders showed to them. I believe the members of the delegation worked together. There was a conscious effort by all members of the delegation to work in accord and I think that that was achieved. It was a happy delegation.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention only one concern and one disappointment. Of course, this is no reflection on our delegation or its leaders. I admire Mr Cumming Thom and our officers, who have to queue for many hours to try to get speakers on the lists at these conferences. It seems that there is no effective organisation. Despite the fact that they queued for hours, there seemed to be queue jumping and real problems. It is disappointing that if many speakers are on a list we have either to drop a speaker or to curtail the contribution that delegates who speak are able to make. As I say, it is not the fault of any of our leaders. It seems to be a problem of organisation. I hope that it is a problem that can be resolved, although I know that it will not be easy because there are so many countries that send delegates, and we welcome them. The more countries that send delegates , the more effective are such conferences. So many countries send delegates and all of those delegates, of course, want to make their contribution, so it is not an easy problem to solve. I do not know the solution but it seems to be a problem of organisation, and I hope we can solve it. Once again, I express my appreciation to the Parliament for the opportunity to attend the Conference and to those who led us at that Conference, and I pay tribute to their excellent leadership.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I was a member of the Australian delegation to the seventy-first Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference, and I join with other members in paying tribute to the people who helped us, especially the leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi). When speaking in Geneva on the topic of the contribution of parliaments to the success of current and future negotiations leading to the cessation of the arms race, arms control and world disarmament, aimed at ensuring peace, I was critical of the IPU. Amongst other things, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the parliaments represented here are not representative parliaments. They are representatives of one party and often of one person or of a small clique. I believe the threat to peace comes from the non-democratic nations, not because their citizens want war but because they have no say.

Later on I gave some examples and mentioned the war between Iraq and Iran. The current dispute on the siting of the intermediate range missiles in Europe was to me an excellent example of what I was discussing. I said:

We have detailed and to some extent rational discussion in the United States and the Western European countries, but where is the discussion in the Eastern Bloc? We know that the Americans, the British, the Dutch and the West Germans are divided on the issue, but surely there would be divisions of opinion amongst the Russians, East Germans, Czechs, etc., if they were allowed to discuss the siting of the SS20's.
I continued:

What a farce this organisation is when the 10 million Poles who joined the free Solidarity trade union have nobody in their parliament or at the I.P.U. What a farce that all those Czechs who supported Dubcek and Socialism with a human face are excluded. What a farce that Chile is excluded whilst Vietnam is accepted as having anything resembling a parliament. Neither should be here.

I criticised the IPU secretariat which in order to get more contributions ignored the absence of democracy and representativeness of most of the affiliated countries. I more or less concluded by saying that I felt that war and aggression went hand in hand with dictatorial regimes because only they can start them without having to justify them to their people. I continued:

Let us forget all the hypocrisy of right and left. Are religious dictatorships like Iran preferable to para-military dictatorships such as Iraq or vice versa? Let those of us who do represent fairly open and pluralist societies emphasise that there is a relationship between aggressive war, a closed society and the absence of democracy.

Since making that speech, I have received a letter from Mr Pio-Carlo Terenzio, who is the Secretary-General of the IPU. He commented on my allegations relating to the unparliamentary nature of many of the affiliated countries. I feel it is only fair, since the letter arrived too late for its inclusion in the report of the Australian delegation, to seek leave for the letter to be tabled.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will quote one sentence from the letter which refers to my comments that most of the parliaments represented at the IPU were not parliaments as we understand them. Mr Terenzio makes the following point:

SPEECH.PARA: If we take Parliaments for which candidates, having various political affiliations, run separately for elections . . . then the figure is 53 out of 102 member Parliaments of IPU.

The point he is making is that the majority of parliaments-53 out of 102 member parliaments-do have elections. I think this is fair enough. My view would be that the other 49 should have no entitlement whatever to be represented at something called an Inter-Parliamentary Union. There is some doubt in my mind as to whether we could really find 53 member countries of that organisation which have opposition parties and parliaments whose members are chosen in democratic competitive elections through which a government can be voted in and out. It is important for us to remember that.

If other people in the organisation feel the same way, it may be appropriate for Australia to try to encourage an IPU which, rather than going for an imitation of the United Nations, should try to concentrate, because it is a different sort of organisation, on having parliaments represented at its meetings, parliaments by implication being bodies which send to the IPU members who are speaking not necessarily for their governments but for themselves or the political parties they represent. Such parliaments should have a number of opposing points of view represented. This is a matter that I have raised before. I do not think it means that we should disaffiliate from the IPU but if something worthwhile is to come from a meeting of parliamentarians it would be much more appropriate to have a meeting of people whom all of us would consider to be parliamentarians, in other words people who have to defend their points of view and who can be attacked by those who hold different points of view in our country. I thank the House for allowing me the time to present my point of view.

CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (INTERCHANGE OF POWERS) BILL 1984]

That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Interchange of Powers) Bill 1984 as they are related matters. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering the two measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to state the coalition's firm opposition to this Government's two referenda proposals, the Constitution Alteration (Terms of Senators Bill) 1984 entitled 'A Bill for An Act to change the terms of senators so that they are no longer of fixed duration and to provide that Senate elections and House of Representatives elections are always held on the same day', and the Constitution Alteration (Interchange of Powers) Bill 1984 entitled 'A Bill for An Act to enable the Commonwealth and the States voluntarily to refer powers to each other'.

SPEECH.PARA: I propose to dwell on the first of these referenda proposals in more detail as its consequences have far-reaching significance for the future of Government in this nation. Once again, it is the coalition's task to strip away the blatantly hypocritical mask of this Government. For what the referendum on simultaneous elections is really about is nothing more than a fraud on the Australian people. It is aimed at undermining the role of the Senate, and strengthening that of the Prime Minister.

This Government seeks to convince the Australian people that it is improving the Constitution, that it is remedying an oversight, some minor technical defect relating to joint elections for the two Houses. That is the Australian Labor Party confidence trick. The reality is that at the moment senators have a fixed term of six years which can be brought to an end only when pursuant to section 57 of the Constitution, a double dissolution is granted for the House of Representatives and the whole Senate.

The founding fathers did not give the Prime Minister or the Executive the power to dissolve half the Senate at will. They did not do this deliberately. The successful passage of this referendum would effectively give the Prime Minister just this power. The Government says that this is unimportant, that it is an improvement in electoral arrangements, but that is not what this proposed referendum is really about. What Labor is plotting is the undermining of the independence of the Senate.

This is part of a long term Labor strategy, a long held Labor goal, of doing away with the Upper House altogether as well as State governments. The Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) said before coming to office:
The way to abolish the Senate, or at least to muzzle it, is to white-ant it from within.

That was reported in the Canberra Times of 2 July 1978. That is what the first of these Bills is all about. We are talking about not technical modifications, but radical change to our governmental system. We are talking about upsetting a carefully crafted system of checks and balances on the authoritarian tendencies of government. This proposal in effect is about increasing the power of a power hungry Prime Minister.

It helps to expose the hypocrisy and the cynical intentions of this Government to look at the brief history of its proposed changes to the Constitution since coming to office. In May 1983 the Attorney-General introduced a package of referenda proposals into the Senate. The package had at its core a proposal for fixed term parliaments. It also included proposals for the interchange of powers , advisory opinions, and removal of what the Attorney was wont to describe as outmoded provisions of the Constitution. The coalition directed its attention primarily to the proposal for fixed term parliaments. This we opposed in fairly strong terms.

In relation to other measures in the package, although we were sceptical as to their virtues, we did not, in fact, oppose them. Then, having introduced this package of changes, the Labor Government, in what is becoming a typically cynical fashion, concluded that if the referendum on fixed terms was passed it would compromise its ability to call an early election. As we all know, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would not want to do that despite all his promises in February 1983. The Government belatedly realised that its proposed change would have required it to see out almost its full term of office.

With the first opportunity for an election being in November 1985, under its fixed term proposal, the Prime Minister, having fallen under the influence of the shady elements of the New South Wales right wing of the Labor Party, did not even have the integrity to admit that he was abandoning the fixed term proposal. Instead, he announced that the referendum to be held in August 1983 was to be postponed. Following that decision, or more aptly non-decision, the Government announced that it would proceed with the referenda containing proposals for a four-year parliamentary term and simultaneous elections for both Houses of Parliament.

The Opposition was attracted to these proposals as a package. We indicated our interest in the package. We thought the proposal for a four-year parliamentary term was an important one which would give stability to government in Australia. As there could well have been public objections to the Senate having a fixed eight-year term, we thought the proposal for simultaneous elections for both Houses was a satisfactory way of modifying the possible effect of an eight-year term for senators. The Government then proposed that the referenda on these matters be held in February 1984. We were going to vote on them in February 1984 . Of course, if that referendum on four-year terms had passed, it would have avoided the need for an election for half of the Senate by 30 June 1985. Certainly, it would have avoided any need for the consideration of an early election for the House of Representatives. Once again, the devious mind of the Prime Minister and his shady advisers from the New South Wales Right woke up to the reality that their devious plans would be upset. So the minders from New South Wales examined the matter and its consequences and woke up to the fact that their excuse for an early election would be eliminated if they pursued this proposal.

Despite this, the Attorney-General, always slow to understand the political intrigues in his own Party, was still boring the Senate with the virtues of the watered down February proposals. At the end of last year the Government was anxiously searching for some excuse to abandon its second attempt-it had not even been governing for 12 months-at a referenda package. As was to be expected with this Government, political self-interest was winning out again. The Government then proposed to the Parliament the spending of $2.5m of taxpayers' money on the Yes case for the February referenda-no money for the No case, but $ 2.5m for the Yes case. It knew that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats- the latter on this issue, at least-would take a principled stand and oppose this grotesque misuse of taxpayers' money. When, as anticipated, this proposal to squander taxpayers' money was defeated, it provided the deviant occupant of the Prime Ministership at the moment with the excuse that he was desperately seeking and searching for to abandon the February referenda and the limitations they may have imposed on his ability as Prime Minister to call an early election.

The Government has now produced its third referenda package, the most cynical of the three. In fact, it bears little, if any, relation to what was originally proposed. It is a proposal for so-called simultaneous elections. To try to give it some hint of respectability, the Government adds to it the proposal for the interchange of powers. As the Opposition has previously stated, although we recognise the strong arguments against simultaneous election proposals, we nevertheless believe that when coupled with a measure to include the stability of government in this country, such as the four-year term, we could perhaps support it. Our support was always predicated on increasing the stability of government. We are not prepared to support a simultaneous elections proposal on its own, for this is an ugly and cynical attempt by the Prime Minister to extend his powers and those of the Executive by removing one of the checks in the Constitution.

The Opposition has witnessed in a short period this Government's deceitful and expedient approach to constitutional reform. It amounts to an attempt to remake the Constitution in a way to benefit the Labor Party electorally and to remake the Parliament according to the Labor Party's authoritarian preconceptions. A question that must also be addressed is why this Government is putting these referenda proposals to the Australian people at the same time as a general election. The answer to me is quite clear and obvious. The ordinary Australian in 1974 and again in 1977 rejected this proposal for simultaneous elections. The Government is hoping that by burying the referenda issues within the general election campaign they will go unchallenged and largely unnoticed.

This Government is hoping to sneak them past the Australian public. Well, the average Australia will not fall for that confidence trick.
