People are already very tired of the shabby tricks of the right wing of the New South Wales Labor Party and I am sure we shall hear more of them as we come to receive Mr Costigan 's report. They are waking up to the fact that the Prime Minister having thrown in his lot with this grouping-the crooks from New South Wales-is fast losing his last vestiges of fabricated integrity.

The Government said that it would give the people plenty of opportunity to assess alternatives for constitutional reform. The Prime Minister is reported in the Western Australian Press as opposing the joining referenda proposals with an election, as it could make things too complicated. The Government's argument for an early election is that it wants to put the elections for both Houses back into synchronisation. However, if it put through these referenda proposals on their own, at an early date, it would run the risk of losing what little justification it has for an early election. The whole history of this Government 's approach to constitutional reform reveals that there is no intention, no goal , other than to keep its options open for an early election while increasing the power of the Prime Minister.

Let me look briefly at the arguments the Government uses in support of the Bill to give the Prime Minister the power to call a half Senate election at his will. The Government argues that by eliminating separate half Senate elections the number of elections will be reduced. The House should need no reminding that we will soon have the thirty-fourth House of Representatives election and it will be the twenty-eighth simultaneous election of the two Houses-28 out of 34. Since Federation, there have been very few single House elections-six in the House of Representatives and only four separate elections for the Senate. To say that there is a problem about simultaneous elections under the existing Constitution is to perpetrate a great hoax.

Where is the problem? It is very simple to have simultaneous elections. The Prime Minister can have a simultaneous election as late as May next year, as the Opposition has suggested to him. If by some mischance, he was re-elected, he could then run a full term of three years and have another simultaneous election in late 1987 or early 1988. Let me make this very clear; there is no problem at all about conducting simultaneous elections under the present Constitution.

The Government argues that the passage of this referendum proposal will eliminate half Senate elections being held independent of a lower House election , and therefore eliminate so-called unnecessary elections. Again, what is the problem? Since Federation there have only been four such half Senate elections. The average Federal term in Australia is about 2.4 years. This will not be changed by this Bill. Indeed, elections may be more frequent under these proposals as it would make it easier for governments to hold early elections.

The Government also claims that its proposal will ensure that the composition of the Senate reflects the current wishes of the people. It is stating the obvious that there will be an election for half the Senate every three years. By comparative international standards this is a short term and the Senate will always be reflective of popular opinion in Australia.

Lastly, the Government says that it will provide greater accountability of the Senate to the extent that senators will have to face the people if the senators' actions lead to a premature House of Representatives election. We have here an important point. But what the Government really means by this argument is that whenever the Prime Minister wants to have an early election he should be able to use the Senate as justification for doing so and going early. This is a very different matter altogether. This is what the simultaneous elections issue is all about. As Malcolm Mackerras the very well-known political commentator stated in a national radio broadcast on 1 February 1984 about this proposal:

In the case of so-called simultaneous elections my view is that it is quite the most dishonest proposal ever put to the Australian people; the public case in its favour is a series of lies, and it has already been twice rejected, in 1974 and 1977.
It is not the purpose of that proposal to give the Australian people the benefit of joint elections for the two Houses.
Its purpose is to give more power to the Prime Minister and to weaken the independence of the Senate.

These quotations were from Notes on the News, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, 1 February 1984. It is absolutely crucial to the integrity of the legislature and its role in the democratic system that it have some separation from the manipulative powers of a Prime Minister. This is why the founding fathers gave to the States House-the Senate-a fixed term. It is part of those checks and balances which are so important as barriers to the concentration of powers in the hands of one man or his party. The Senate fulfils a vital role as a House of review. The Coalition fully supports that role as set out in the Constitution.

Let me make it clear, this proposal is not about simultaneous or less frequent elections. This is a misleading and deceptive argument. It is an attempt to impinge upon the legitimate role of the Senate by giving the Prime Minister greater powers with which to threaten and cajole it into submission. It is the first stage of a concerted attack on the constitutional independence of the Senate and the thin end of the wedge of denying the legitimate role of the Senate in representing the States. The Australian people have had the good sense to reject these proposals twice. I am fully confident that they will reject them again and deny the Prime Minister the power to dissolve the House of Representatives and half the Senate at any time and without Parliamentary reason .

Finally, I turn my attention to the proposal for the interchange of powers. This proposal is going before the Australian people in an attempt to give an element of respectability to the Government's other referendum proposal. There are provisions in the Constitution for the reference of powers to the States by the Commonwealth. Possibly these could be improved and there may be some merit in this proposal. But in reality what this is about is to enable the Commonwealth Government to give the States the power to impose excise duties on their people. Labor supports the exchange of powers so that the States can impose indirect taxes on their population. I believe that people should be made aware of the implications of this proposal. The States currently have the right to refer powers under the Constitution as it exists. That they do not do so has less to do with any difficulties about referring those powers than it has to do with their natural reluctance to relinquish powers.

We will oppose this particular referendum proposal because it is camouflage for the dishonest proposal to undermine the independence of the Senate, and because it is only for the benefit of Labor politicians who seek to change the Constitution without consulting the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset there are a couple of observations we should make about the Opposition with respect to matters of constitutional amendment and constitutional propriety. First, the Opposition's record on constitutional propriety does not ring very well in the Australian political scene and the electorate knows that well. The electorate that had to go through the experiences of 1974 and 1975 would well remember that the Opposition's record in terms of being the people designed to protect the Constitution is a pretty shoddy one. Really, if we cut through all the verbiage we have just heard from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), we see that the conservative parties have been portrayed as constitutional hit men when it suits them.

SPEECH.PARA: The second observation I would make about the Opposition in this context is that it really is clear in terms of the history of Australian politics that the conservative parties have always painted themselves as the great defenders of propriety and the Constitution until it happens that that propriety or that Constitution does not suit them. Then they very quickly break the rules. We saw it in 1974 and 1975. We see it when we are asked to refer matters in Australia to the constitutional umpires in the case of Mr Justice Cross.

We found very quickly that the Opposition was not prepared to accept the umpire 's decision in the case of Mr Justice Cross. We found very clearly that in 1974 and 1975 the Opposition was prepared to use the Constitution for its own ends rather than be the great protector of the Constitution. So the people listening to this debate have to understand that members of the Opposition cannot come into this place and be the defenders of constitutional propriety, because their record is too dirty.

The Leader of the Opposition said that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been cynical with regard to these constitutional matters. Those of us who remember 1982 will recall the situation concerning the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. When we were to have an election depended on whether his back would give out, whether his mind would give out or whether his political will would give out. So it is just not good enough for the Opposition to ask us to forget that two years ago we were on again-off again in regard to an election. So members of the Opposition cannot paint that picture because the electorate remembers what happened. The electorate remembers also that as defenders of constitutional propriety the Opposition's record is very bad indeed. It should not try on the arguments it puts forward because the community will not accept them and neither will we.

The first of these pieces of legislation which will lead to a referendum will do a couple of things. First of all, it will reduce the total number of elections. The record shows that the Australian community does not particularly welcome having to go to the polls all the time. In fact, the experience is that we now have a very untidy system. It is a system that was made more untidy as a result of the premature election in 1983. This Bill is designed to bring together the terms of the Senate and the House of Representatives so that every time there is a House of Representatives election half the Senate will go to that election. That is very important because it means a great saving of money. I am sure that the people in the community will understand that. Let us look at what separate half Senate elections cost. The Opposition has ignored this point in the debate. At present, a separate half Senate election costs approximately $ 21.8m and a separate House election costs $23m. Thus, the total cost of separate elections for the two Houses is now $44.8m. It is a very expensive process. Considering the low esteem in which the Australian community holds politicians- it believes that politicians are generally very expensive people-it is difficult to justify spending that type of money. This proposal would reduce the incidence of elections. If simultaneous elections are held the total cost reduces from $44 .8m to $27m. As a consequence of this measure we would be saving taxpayers' money. That is the first comment I wish to make. It will mean a saving of something like $17.8m.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not arguing about that.
—Postpone it.

—I hear those opposite making comments but, as I said earlier, their record on constitutional propriety is so bad that I am amazed they are even here during this debate. They are just not seen as defenders of the Constitution and they are not seen as people who have a good record in the Australian political scene.

SPEECH.PARA: The extra point to make about the referendum proposal in this Bill is that we are also trying to bring the Australian electorate into a position whereby it can vote simultaneously on the House of Representatives and the Senate. At the moment the complexion of both chambers can be quite out of key in terms of the mood of the electorate but even more seriously we have the possibility of the Senate behaving in that irresponsible fashion in which it behaved in 1975, causing the House of Representatives to go to the polls with no risk to the Senate itself. I know it suits those people opposite, those people of great constitutional propriety, but that is a very strange system to try to defend in a democracy.

The other observation to make in the context of this debate is that it has been very difficult to establish just where the Opposition stands. These proposals have arisen out of constitutional conventions. There has been support for them at constitutional conventions but the present Opposition parties opposed the simultaneous elections proposal in 1974, put it forward in government in 1977, vacillated but supported it in Parliament in 1983, and now they return to their opposition of 1974. Where do these people of great constitutional propriety stand?

TALK.START.PARA: —They cannot make up their minds.

—As the honourable member for Melbourne says, they cannot make up their minds. Not only can they not make up their minds but also, as I said earlier, the whole history of Australian politics shows that the conservative parties see themselves as political hit men in Australian politics. They want to use the system to suit themselves and not try to design a system which contains anything about fairness or anything about reducing the cost to the taxpayers. They are two things that we are trying to establish with this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Another issue I want to develop concerns the interchange of powers amendment. This was addressed by the Leader of the Opposition. The interchange of powers amendment, in a nutshell, is designed to enable both Commonwealth and State governments to interchange powers where it would make sense for those powers to be shared in a different way. What are two examples of where it would be sensible for the Commonwealth and the States to have an interchange of powers? One clear example that comes to mind is in the area of conciliation and arbitration. At the moment we have a dual system. It is expensive and its coverage is not complete. I take just one instance within the system of conciliation and arbitration, and that is the role of industrial inspectorates. At the moment we have enormous confusion about the roles of industrial inspectorates. We need to combine the roles of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the respective State commissions so that those inspectorates can work together to police awards. That would be a sensible way to behave. We believe that it should happen and that it has great implications in terms of industrial relations. It is something that this measure would make more possible.

The other area is insurance. I refer particularly to workers compensation insurance. There could not be an area of greater burden for the community at the moment, particularly small business, than the absolutely astronomical cost of workers compensation. We want to work towards a single system of workers compensation throughout Australia that would reduce administrative costs. It would certainly go a long way towards eliminating the great cost burden borne by business at the moment. This interchange of powers arrangement would make it far more possible for us to get towards a single system of workers compensation. It would be a sensible system and one that would result in a reduction of costs.

I have chosen two examples of where an interchange of powers would make sense. I have given the example of the conciliation and arbitration area where Federal and State commissions could work together in areas of joint operation. That would certainly simplify some of the current procedures. The second area concerned workers compensation where clearly a great burden is being borne by the community. It is a burden that causes many small businesses to be at great risk. This would simplify that situation and we would be able to get towards a single workers compensation system throughout Australia.

Let me quickly go over what I have said as time for this debate is limited. In the first of these constitutional amendments we are trying to limit the number of elections in Australia in a sensible way. We do not seek to remove the chance of voters having a say, but seek to eliminate the enormous number of elections we have had. The figures are quite damaging. In the 39 years since the end of the Second World War there have been no fewer than 20 Federal elections of one kind or another-seven combined House of Representatives and half Senate elections, five House of Representatives elections, four separate half Senate elections and four double dissolutions. When we start talking about double dissolutions those opposite should feel uncomfortable. In the last 20 years the pace has increased. We have had 11 elections. Only two were combined, and we have had three House of Representatives elections, three half Senate elections and three double dissolutions. So we are now having a situation in which we have an enormous number of elections. This first proposal is designed to tie together Senate and House of Representatives elections.

The second thing we are trying to do is reduce the cost burden. The cost burden on taxpayers is enormous. Why should we continue to impose those sorts of burdens on the electorate? I wish members of the Opposition, as the people of constitutional propriety, could make up their minds clearly over a long period where they stand. Clearly they have some difficulty with that because they are looking for opportunities to score political points rather than to make some sensible constitutional amendments.

With the second proposal, the interchange of powers proposal, our intention clearly is to arrange a sensible situation in which the Commonwealth and State governments can interchange powers. I have referred to two areas-conciliation and arbitration and workers compensation-which I believe to be sensible.

To sum up, these Bills leading to referenda are about making the machinery of government more sensible. If there is one thing towards which we in this place ought to work if we are to get the respect of people in the community, it is government having some common sense to it, and these proposals are based on common sense ideas about the way Australia should be governed. I am pleased to support these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence by taking up some of the points made by the last speaker, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). He spoke of verbiage from the Opposition. Has he looked at the reasons put forward by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in the Senate? I am sure he has not. I will take him to them. He then spoke of a constitutional umpire and, if I heard him correctly, referred to Mr Justice Cross. Mr Justice Cross was running an inquiry in that racket-infested State from which I must say I come, New South Wales, under the auspices of the New South Wales Government. How he can possibly say that he was a constitutional umpire and portray any understanding of the Constitution is something that I simply cannot understand. Then he cried crocodile tears about costs of elections. The costs are coming from this Labor Government, which has added to the size of the House of Representatives and the Senate and thereby greatly increased the cost of government and the cost of running elections. It is as though democracy can be measured in dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: What real weight does the Government place upon these issues? We heard a 30- second speech from the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) representing the Attorney-General in this place and on the speakers list we see that speakers for the Government are to be the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) and the honourable member for Stirling, from whom we have just heard. The babies are being sent in to bat. They are big babies, but babies they certainly are. Not one member of the Government's front bench is to deal with what are meant to be two serious constitutional issues. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), who has spoken, and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), who will be speaking, demonstrate by being here that we regard these matters as important, just as the absence of any Ministers from the other side demonstrates the view that the Government has of these issues.

The Leader of the Opposition in addressing this House referred to some of the history of the proposals now before the House. It is worth while taking one or two minutes on the history. The House will recall that on 24 November 1983 the Attorney-General referred to referendum proposals which were to be put forward and issued a public statement on the subject. There were five proposals: Simultaneous elections, parliamentary terms-a four-year term-interchange of powers, the advisory jurisdiction of the High Court of Australia and the removal of outmoded and expended provisions. We know what happened. We know that this package was scheduled for February 1984, so it was said. We know that there was objection by the Australian Democrats and by the Opposition in the Senate to the Government's putting forward a one-sided case only. It was proper objection because if the people of Australia are to make decisions on referenda proposals they should have both cases put before them. Nevertheless, that was taken by the Government as a cop-out, as an excuse for not proceeding.

Next we see that two proposals are to be put to the people of Australia. These are described by the Attorney-General in the statement of 11 June 1984 as the most important of the five which were to be put to referendum last February. Has he forgotten the four-year term and is that not indicative of what Mr Mackerras has called the tissue of lies which the Government has used to advance its case in relation to the so-called simultaneous elections proposals?

If one goes to what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did not say and to what the Attorney-General has said, one sees that the Government destroys its own case by what it says; and this is where we come to the Government's verbiage. Let us start with the Attorney-General. He said in the debate in the Senate that a package was to be put to the electors in February. He then said:

As you will no doubt recall, the Government decided not to proceed with the referendums in February because of the action taken in the Senate by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to block government advertising in support of the proposals.

Was that really the only reason? Is he running away from important constitutional changes simply because he is not able to get the funding for one case only? Does anybody really accept that the Government is putting the case truthfully to the Australian people? Then what did he say? He said:
To put all five of the original machinery of government proposals in conjunction with an election would have been too complex.
Oh, really? Why can they not be put separately? They can be. He then said:
It is vital that electors have a proper understanding of the issues involved in a referendum so that they can cast informed votes and thereby play a meaningful role in constitutional reform.

Oh, really? That came from an Attorney-General and a government who were going to put one case only to the electors. Is that how they inform the electors? Do the electors make a meaningful and informed decision by not being given both cases? Referring to the fact that he really wants to have the electorate informed on these subjects, he then said:
That is why the Government is only proceeding with two of the proposals at this time.

What arrant and demonstrable nonsense! But that is not all. We have been given by the Attorney-General a statement of the Government's reasons why it is going forward with the so-called simultaneous election provisions. I remind those who would put forward the argument that the two Houses are out of synchronisation that it is perfectly competent for this Government, as the Leader of the Opposition has pointed out, to call an election at any time before 30 June and to put the House and the Senate back into synchronisation. But that is not to be done. I also remind the House that, if these proposals go forward, by force of section 128 of the Constitution they must be put to the Australian people, once they have passed both Houses, in not less than two nor more than six months from their passage. If they go through the House today, 4 November is the first date on which an election can be held and these proposals put and 4 March is the last date. In short, the Government has deliberately limited its own options so that it can go to the Australian people with a perfectly specious argument at a later stage and say: 'We are bringing this election forward because amongst other reasons we want you to consider these very important constitutional proposals'. Does anybody think that in an election, when the issues are concentrated upon the future of this country, upon economic matters and upon matters of great moment, the average elector will give a damn about constitutional proposals and the arguments about constitutional proposals? Of course he will not.

Let me go on to examine the reasons which were given by the Attorney-General in the Senate but which were not repeated here by the Deputy Prime Minister. I know that the Deputy Prime Minister is a man of somewhat tender sensibilities and I can well understand his flinching from repeating what the Attorney-General said in the Senate. Let us look at some of the reasons given by the Attorney-General. In dealing with the question of simultaneous elections he spoke of the number of elections. That matter has already been dealt with by the Leader of the Opposition. Then he went on to talk about money. We know how acutely conscious Labor governments are of spending money. It gets down to weighing democracy in dollars and cents.

What a disgusting basis on which to put forward an argument that we should alter the Constitution and have fewer elections. Why? Because it will save a few dollars. Next the Attorney-General went on to say that the fact is:

. . . that the elections which are being eliminated are the unnecessary separate half Senate elections, which cannot change governments and which, as is indicated by their much lower level of voter turnout, do not really come to grips with the issues of the day.

Of course they cannot change governments but they can and do change the composition of the Senate and the Senate can and does influence, alter, amend or reject Bills put up by this House. It is spurious nonsense to say that for that reason they are in some way unimportant. What was his next reason? He went on to say this about the simultaneous elections proposal:

It will ensure that the composition of the Senate at any given time reflects the current wishes of the people more accurately than under the present system and, by ensuring that the people's will is reflected simultaneously in both Houses, it will provide a more satisfactory electoral basis upon which the government of the country can proceed.

Translated that means that he hopes to have an upper House which is more responsive to the wishes of the Executive in the lower House. Is that in the long term interests of this country? Is that in accordance with the views of the Constitution which we have held for so many years? Does that support a system of review? Does that support a system of checks and balances? No, it does not, but it most certainly supports the power of the Prime Minister and the power of the lower House at the expense of the Senate. The Attorney-General went on to say:

It will also provide greater accountability of the Senate to the extent that Senators themselves will have to face the people if the Senate's actions lead to a premature House of Representatives election.

Once more, let me give honourable members a translation. That means that he hopes by this means to place the Prime Minister of the day in a position where he can put a gun at the head of the Senate and say: 'Unless you give me the answer that I propose to get I will force an election'. My view is that it is a very wise thing that we have a House of review and that we should not do anything which would in any way erode the strength of that House because it is central to our system. We do not have here, as in other countries, a democracy which is effectively a dictatorship of the lower House, nor should we ever have that kind of situation in this country. He then said this:
A small minority of Honourable Senators opposite have suggested that the Bill is really aimed at undermining the independence of the Senate.

Is that not Senator Evans's long term goal? Is that not the goal he has proposed for many years? Is that not the view which is espoused by members of this Government and is that not absolutely and in all ways consistent with the platform of the Australian Labor Party as adopted at the last conference? I will come to that platform in one or two minutes. Senator Evans went on to give the game away, so to speak, in a throwaway line in his second reading speech in the Senate. When referring to the Senate he said:
. . . it will retain, for better or worse, all its present power to review, amend or reject legislation.

That is the power which has been in the Constitution since Federation and the power which most people believe should be there because most people do not believe that there should be unfettered power in the House of Representatives. What we are now seeing is a step down the road to securing the aims of the Australian Labor Party as espoused in its conference. It is a pity that Senator Evans is not here. We on this side of the House understand that he is making some moves to transmit himself from the Senate down to the House. I would be delighted to see him here. I understand from some New South Wales members of the power-broking fraternity on the Government side of the House that his chances of getting down here are slim. It is a shame but one can understand his reasons for wanting to do so because a person who has such a complete contempt for the Senate would not wish to stay there for very much longer, certainly for any longer than he could. Let me now come to the Australian Labor Party's conference and its constitutional and legal platform. We have a photograph of the Attorney- General, who is looking his best, and next to that we see the heading ' Constitutional Reform'. Let me quote items 4, 5 and 6. Item 4 states:
To ensure that the Senate has no power to reject, defer or otherwise block money bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I notice that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aviation, said 'Hear, hear' to that.
—Indeed he did.
—We will see what he is saying later in his parliamentary career. Item 5 states:

SPEECH.PARA: To provide that the Senate may delay for up to six months, but not reject, any other proposed law.

TALK.START.PARA: —House of Lords.
—Item 6 states:

SPEECH.PARA: To provide that a government enjoying the confidence of the House of Representatives shall be permitted to hold office for the prescribed term.

The Minister at the table interjected, and correctly so, 'House of Lords'. The House of Lords is an hereditary system which I am glad to say we do not have in this country. It has a power to defer, but it has no other powers. Those powers were rightly-because it is a non-representative House-taken away from it many years ago. But what would be the consequence of a Senate which had power only to defer something for six months and no more? It would become an empty and sterile debating chamber and all effective political power would vest in this House, which means that all effective political power would vest in the Executive of the day and the Prime Minister of the day. There would be no checks, no curbs, no balancing of that power. That is the aim which the Australian Labor Party espouses and that is the underlying principle behind the proposal to alter the terms of senators.

I have referred to the importance of the House of review. I also refer to the Prime Minister's view of the Senate, expressed in the language which is characteristic of him-temperate, balanced and, one might even say, modest! I am reading from a quotation of him by Senator Robert Hill in the Senate which came from the Age of 16 December. The Prime Minister was quoted as saying:

I've had enough of this recalcitrant Senate blocking the will of the Government . I am not going to be in a situation . . . where we are dictated to as the democratically elected Government by the mish-mash of opposing forces in this country. If they think they can determine the pattern of the Government . . . they have another think coming.

That is most certainly a correct reflection of the views of the Prime Minister, this Government and the Australian Labor Party. It is not a correct reflection of the views of the people of this country. I remind honourable members of some of the things which could not be done had we got rid of the powers of the Senate in the way which has been suggested. For example, we could not have reviewed assets test legislation. We could not have rejected proposed laws which were called tax avoidance or tax dodging laws, which is the usual way of describing any laws that one wants to pass in the field of tax but which in fact have the effect of catching many innocent people. I suppose that consistent with this cutting away of the powers of the Senate it probably should not have committees. Committees can, after all, be most embarrassing to governments. They can investigate matters such as the Age tapes and allegations against Ministers. We all know that on both sides of the Houses. What do committees do? They act as a brake on the authority of the Executive.

I have no apologies on behalf of the Opposition in speaking against what is proposed. It is a step towards Labor's stated objective. That objective is, as I have said, to reduce the Senate to an empty and sterile debating in chamber. It is no wonder that Senator Evans wishes to desert that chamber for what he would think would be a happier clime. One would not, after all, want to cut the power from underneath one before one got out of the chamber in which one was going to exercise the power. The Leader of the Opposition has said that these proposals are a fraud on the people, and so they are. If they are to be seriously put forward to the people they could be put forward as separate questions and not in the middle of a general election so that the people could carefully consider and weigh the issues. But that is not being done and the political reasons for what is being done are just too obvious.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are considering two minor referenda proposals which are proposed to be put to the people. I was extremely disappointed by the contribution of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) who talked about a racket infested State, which, after all, does give him a living as the people in one electorate in that State send him to Parliament for better or worse. He was obviously not in the Liberal Party when illegal casinos flourished in Sydney. I was a member of the New South Wales Parliament from 1973 to 1976. Illegal casinos in Sydney flourished under the Liberal-Country Party Government of that time. Starting price betting flourished. It was an absolute disgrace that rackets were allowed to flourish. The honourable member for North Sydney has the hide to talk about New South Wales being a racket infested State.

SPEECH.PARA: I am proud to represent a constituency in Sydney which I think is the most beautiful city in Australia. I know that the people in my electorate are delighted to live in such a cultured city. I really feel that the honourable member for North Sydney should apologise to the citizens of Sydney for attacking that delightful city by calling it racket infested. He totally ignores the history of the corruption that went on in New South Wales for many years under Liberal-Country Party governments. It is a credit to Premier Wran that he closed the illegal casinos.

It is obvious that the Liberal Party has perceived in these referenda the possibility that the Australian people may vote to agree with the referenda and that somehow or other it may not benefit if the Constitution is changed. The Liberal Party does not believe in fairness. It believes that unless some situation favours the Liberal and National parties it should not be introduced into the Constitution. I do not really believe that the Liberal and National parties believe in democracy. They want checks and balances, when the Australian Labor Party controls both Houses. They want a complicated system. Yet, they know that the Senate was merely a rubber stamp when they were in government and controlled both Houses.

The honourable member for North Sydney talked about the Labor Party's platform. I, together with the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley), agree that there should be no blocking of money Bills by the Senate. I agree with the Labor Party's constitutional platform. But we are not debating the Labor Party platform in regard to constitutional matters and the people of Australia will not be voting on that. It is proposed that they vote on a referendum to make sure that elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives are held at the one time. Such an arrangement will save an enormous amount of money and reference has been made to those amounts this afternoon. It is also proposed that they vote to enable the transfer of powers between the State governments and the Federal Government and vice versa.

Every Australian remembers the appalling constitutional crisis that took place in 1975. It was the worst constitutional crisis that I have ever known. We remember the backlash against the then Governor-General. No one wants to see that situation repeated. I believe that the Liberal and National parties want a re-run of that frightening crisis and want our nation to be brought to the brink of anarchy. They really do not want the Australian people to have a say in referenda on what should happen in these minor matters such as holding elections at the same time.

We went through a period in the 1970s when election followed election, when the Liberal Party did everything possible to encourage candidates to stand for election to the Senate. Appalling allegations were made that the Liberal Party did this to make ballot papers inordinately difficult for infirm people and people without much English and ability to write a lot of numbers or to fill out a complicated ballot. It manipulated the system in an atrocious way as other speakers on our side have mentioned.

The legislation is of some significance because at present the term of office of a senator is six years. The proposal is that in future a senator will be elected for two terms of the House of Representatives, whatever period that is. Some countries, such as the United States of America and Costa Rica, have fixed dates for elections. However, the Australian people have always given some flexibility to the Prime Minister of the day in the setting of elections. In 1977, of course, Malcolm Fraser brought the election a year ahead of schedule because he wanted to have simultaneous elections, and the people agreed with that proposal. Then, in 1983 he did something that I could not really believe he would do; he put the elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives out of kilter. The referendum which is the subject of this legislation will ask the Australian people to ensure that elections must be held for both Houses at the same time. I note that a half Senate election costs $17.8m. I feel that the Australian people will not support such an appalling waste of money.

I was also disappointed with the contribution of the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Peacock) who also attacked New South Wales. Apparently, any State that has the courage to return a Labor government is in for vilification in this House from the Liberal-National Party. The Leader of the Opposition also had the hide to mention the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the Costigan report. If ever there was a report that embarrassed and threw the Liberal-National Party out of government, it was the Costigan report and the revelations about bottom of the harbour tax schemes. That report totally destroyed the credibility of the Liberal-National Party to collect taxes fairly. The Australian people will never forget that the Liberal- National Party allowed the allegations in relation to bottom of the harbour schemes to drag on for eight years.

I wanted to mention my good friend Mr Malcolm Mackerras whom I have known for many years. I appreciate that Malcolm is opposed to this proposal. I noted in the Sydney Morning Herald that he was able to crank up and drag the Liberal Party in behind him to support his ideas. But 1983 is in all of our memories. That was a cynical exercise in which the Prime Minister of the day called an election a year ahead of time. The poor honourable member for Flinders at the time was not even sworn in. He was elected in December 1982 and he was not even sworn in before we went to the polls. That was a cynical exercise by the Liberal -National Party of the day. This referendum, if the Australian people agree, will stop similar cynical exercises. We are putting this to the Australian people. There are too many elections. The people are browned off with elections. I believe that too many elections are a threat to democracy because people get fed up with compulsory voting. Particularly in the 1970s, many complaints were received by all members of Parliament and the media. People appreciate that elections are expensive.

Without wishing to delay the House this afternoon I call upon honourable members to support the proposal in these referenda which I believe are of relevance to the Australian people. The referenda will facilitate the holding of simultaneous elections and the transfer of powers from the States to the Commonwealth and from the Commonwealth to the States. If the Liberal-National Party agrees with State rights and State sovereignty it should support the referenda too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: — Having heard the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), who has just sat down, I can only presume that he just has not been around in Australia for the last few months. He does not seem to recognise that his own Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is talking about having a premature and unnecessary election, one that is being forced on the Australian people not because it is necessary--
—By Malcolm Fraser's earlier decision.

—What absolute rubbish. The Minister does not even know the consequence of this election which will be, presumably, a half Senate election. Those who will be elected to the half Senate will, of course, not take up their places until 1 July 1985. Why do we need to go to the polls before then? There is absolutely no reason to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitution Alteration (Terms of Senators) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Interchange of Powers) Bill, which are before us, are designed to try to ensure that the Australian people henceforth will have a Senate with the same term as House of Representatives members, so that it will not be necessary, we are told, to have the two Houses going out on different dates. The Prime Minister could very easily exercise his option to have an early election any time up to 30 May, perhaps 30 April if he wants to allow a bit of time up his sleeve. It would be quite practical in that way for the two Houses to be elected together, but there is no need to have the two Houses elected together. This is purely a subterfuge. Indeed, having looked at the two Bills I believe the con of the consensus is like the con of the two constitutional proposals. It is a con. It has been put in such a way as to deceive the Australian electorate. Frankly, the argument that it is necessary to change the Constitution so that we will avoid having different times of elections just does not hold water.

The coalition-that is, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia-opposes both Bills. We believe that the Australian people too will oppose them. When the referendums to which they give rise are put to the nation I am sure the Australian people will see them, as they do so many of the other actions of this Government, as being nothing more than a cynical exercise of power. We oppose the Bills for very straightforward and plain reasons. We are certain that our stand will be supported by a majority of Australians. These Bills, like so many of the Government's actions-indeed the Government itself-we believe are a fraud. The Constitution Alteration (Terms of Senators) Bill is not , as the Government has pretended, about fewer elections. It is about more elections. It is about reducing the power of the Senate. It is about increasing the power of the Prime Minister. The honourable member for Lowe suggested that there would be fewer elections. That just is not true. Indeed, quite the reverse would be the product of the support by the Australian electorate of these two measures.

The Constitution Alteration (Interchange of Powers) Bill is not, as the Government has pretended, an important step forward in constitutional reform. It is simply a device to throw a cloak of respectability over the Prime Minister's and the Government's attempts to shackle an unco-operative Senate and give further power to a Labor Prime Minister who already shows a dangerous willingness to believe in his own infallibility. These Bills were part of a package of constitutional reforms originally proposed by this Government and supported by the Opposition. The reforming zeal of this Government, or what there was of it, has, of course, long since been spent. What we are left with is a cynical, opportunist attempt to manipulate the referendum process.

There is only one reason for introducing these Bills. It is the Prime Minister' s blind determination to push the nation into an early election. If one looks at the faction fighting within the Australian Labor Party and the extent to which members of that Party are currently spending so much more time within the factions fighting one against the other than they are in governing the country, one can understand the Prime Minister's concern to get to the polls early before it all crumbles around him. Nothing and nobody have been allowed to stand in the Prime Minister's way. Labor's election promises, its policies in so many areas, have all been jettisoned. The Government has even thrown overboard any pretence to economic responsibility by bringing down a Budget a fortnight ago that for the sake of a few votes has put lasting recovery and a real increase in the living standards of Australians at very considerable risk. Now we have these Bills which, as I have said, represent a cynical attempt to manipulate the referendum process and the Australian electorate, and are an indictment of the Hawke Government's pretensions as a government of reform.

To demonstrate that I will take honourable members on a little tour of the background to these proposals. It all began back in April 1983 when the Attorney -General (Senator Gareth Evans), with a great flourish, announced a series of referenda, including one on fixed term parliaments, to be put to the people in August of that year. Legislation to implement those proposals was, in fact, introduced and, as part of its propaganda campaign, the Government made great play of the decision of the previous Prime Minister to go to the polls early in 1983. However, as we all recall, these proposed referenda were soon postponed. The great reforming Attorney-General was thoroughly and comprehensively rolled by his Cabinet colleagues, who suddenly came to see merit in the ability of a Prime Minister to call an election when he believed it was necessary.

From fixed term parliaments we went to four-year parliaments. Legislation for a referendum on this issue was brought into this House in the Budget session last year. It was accompanied by a Bill for a referendum on simultaneous elections for both Houses. The Opposition saw merit in these proposals because it believed they would help bring stability to government. The proposed four-year term was, we believed, an important move, for reasons which have been widely discussed both in this House and outside. It would enable governments to concentrate on the job in hand and particularly on rational and proper economic management, without the constant temptation of forthcoming elections. Indeed, we know that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) believes there are problems in the imminence of elections. We have been told by him that taxes have to be increased. A government cannot possibly plan in the long term if it is planning in the context of an early election. We were told that the attitude which the Minister for Science and Technology has used to bucket the planning within this Budget was part of the original concept for the introduction of these measures.

There could well have been objections to the Senate having a fixed eight-year term. We all remember the concern there was as to whether an eight-year term would not be unnecessarily long for a House of review. We certainly believed in a context where a fixed eight-year term was in mind that the proposal for simultaneous elections could be justified, for it would have reduced below that fixed eight-year term the term which those senators would have enjoyed. At that stage, these questions were to be put to the people in February this year. Had they been carried-as I have said, they were supported by the Opposition-there would have been no need for a half Senate election by 30 June next year and no need for an early election for this House to be considered. It was not long, however, before this flickering remnant of the Government's reforming zeal was extinguished. Even these reforms, mild as they were compared with the Government 's original plans, presented too great an obstacle to the great Prime Minister. He wanted an excuse to dump them. That excuse came when the Senate, quite properly, refused to allow the Government to spend $2.5m of taxpayers' money to publicise only its case in the February referenda and no funds at all on the opposing side.

This decision by the Senate-as I said, it was a very proper one-was misused by the Prime Minister as an excuse for not going ahead with the referenda. Now we have the final product of the reforming zeal of the Hawke Government. What is proposed, of course, is no reform at all. It is a fraud. The fraud is exposed in the very title of the Bill which is before us today. When it was introduced in the Senate its title was the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill. That title, however, has undergone a sudden change. It is now called the Constitution Alteration (Terms of Senators) Bill. That is what this Bill is really about. Let us forget all the nonsense about reducing the number of elections. That has absolutely nothing to do with it. This Bill is about making sure that a hostile Senate or, heaven forbid, even a relatively independent Senate presents the smallest possible obstacle to the wishes of this Prime Minister. That is what this Government is asking Australians to agree to.

At present, Prime Ministers who wish to call early elections have a restriction . Elections for the House of Representatives can take place at any time. The Constitution, however, provides fixed terms for senators. Thus if a Prime Minister calls an early election for the House, as the present Prime Minister seems intent on doing, he will be faced with the prospect of another poll later with the prescribed half Senate election. He is also faced with the prospect of continuing separate half Senate and House of Representatives elections unless a double dissolution is called to bring elections for both the Houses back into line. These restrictions act as a powerful brake on Prime Ministers abusing their power to call early elections. They also act as a powerful brake on the number of elections which Australians have to face. They mean that the Senate can perform its proper duties effectively, with a degree of security of tenure and independence of the whims of the Labor Prime Minister or indeed of any Prime Minister. This Bill is aimed at removing those restrictions. There would be two distinct results if the referendum proposed on this issue were carried. The way would be open for more elections. The independence of the Senate, and thus its power would be reduced and that of the Prime Minister enhanced.

The National Party believes that neither outcome is in the interests of the nation. That is why we, together with our coalition Liberal partners, oppose this Bill and will oppose the passage of the referendum on this issue. We were prepared to support a proper package of reform which coupled simultaneous elections with a four-year parliamentary term.

We will not-we cannot-support this cynical, opportunistic attempt to increase the power of the Prime Minister and to foist even more elections on Australians. We regard the interchange of powers proposal as simply an attempt to put a cloak of respectability over this move. The Constitution already permits the States to refer powers to the Commonwealth. They have not generally done so, for the very understandable reason that they prefer to exercise those powers themselves. This proposed referendum will not change that situation. It is not a demonstration of the Government's commitment to reform; it is a demonstration of its cynicism. The coalition opposes both of these Bills for the reasons I have given. It believes, further, that referenda should not, in general, be put to the people at the same time as an election. By doing so, the Government is preventing the people from focussing on the important issues involved. We believe that this aspect of the legislation before the House is also to be condemned.

In my view the two propositions that are being put to us at this time are not ones which should enjoy the support of the Australian people. In our view they are proposals which are cynically designed to increase and not reduce the frequency of elections. We believe the character of the proposals is designed not to enhance the power of the people; it is simply a product of the Prime Minister deciding that this is one way by which his power as Prime Minister can be enhanced and that of the Senate reduced. There is no justification in those circumstances for either this Parliament or the people of Australia giving this Government their endorsement on those two counts. For that reason I urge all Australians to consider very carefully the proposition included within these two referendum Bills and I urge them just as strongly to vote overwhelmingly against them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refrain from addressing in any great substance that part of the referenda proposals which relates to the terms of senators-the Constitution Alteration (Terms of Senators) Bill. It seems to me that that has been adequately and quite definitively embraced by my colleagues on this side of the House. The only comments I make in that context are the obvious ones relating to the significant costs involved to Australian taxpayers when there are continual elections either for half the Senate or for the full House or when those elections are extended to cover various referenda proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: The exact amount of money needed in those circumstances has already been addressed, although I thought it might be of some value to instance the number of elections that we have had in the last 20 years. In that time there have been 11 elections, only two having been combined elections. There have been three House of Representatives elections, three half Senate elections and three double dissolutions. If they were to remain out of phase, no fewer than seven separate elections would be due in the next 10 years-three for the House of Representatives and four half Senate elections. My colleague the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) indicated that in the context of a half Senate election the cost to the Australian taxpayer is in the vicinity of $17.8m. We have an Opposition which continually decries the various revenue methods embraced by this Government, so it seems to me to be somewhat contradictory that it is here proposing a course that would inevitably result in an increased cost, an extravagantly increased cost, to the Australian taxpayer which certainly cannot be supported in the context of current economic circumstances or, indeed, in any economic circumstances.

I indicated at the outset that I would prefer to concentrate on that part of the referenda proposals which relates to the interchange of powers-the Constitution Alteration (Interchange of Powers) Bill-and I intend to do just that. It is worth noting that both the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair)-both temporary leaders-addressed the interchange of powers proposal only in very limited detail . The central thesis to their submissions to this House was that the interchange of powers proposal is merely a camouflage, or a puff, in terms of getting through the other more substantive referenda proposal. I concede at the outset that, in terms of attaching some order of importance to those two referenda proposals, it is quite obvious that the terms of senators proposal is more important for a range of reasons. However, that ought not cloud the reality that the interchange of powers proposal is a very important part of the package and one deserving of support by the Australian community. Indeed, in no case has any member of the Opposition offered any substantive reasons why that particular proposal ought not be embraced by the Australian community. As I have indicated, it was opposed only in the context of their perception of it as allegedly being part of a camouflage, giving some respectability to the other referenda proposal that will be put. That seems to me to be an absurdity. Neither speaker for the Opposition addressed in passing the very fundamental reasons why the interchange of powers proposal ought to be supported.

What are the problems? Since the decision in the case of Hematite Petroleum Pty Ltd v. Victoria of 1983-more commonly known, of course, as the Victoria pipelines case-there has been renewed interest in the whole issue of referral of powers, not only from the Commonwealth to the States but also vice versa. In that case, as has been rightly pointed out, the major issue related to excise duties, a cause of much debate in terms of our legal and political systems over many years. The law report books are filled with various cases addressing precisely what constitutes excise duties. But in that case it simply seemed to me to present another example of Federal and State governments balancing their obligations and enabling certain financial issues to be addressed in terms of both what the Commonwealth wants and what particular States may desire. It seemed to me to be a good example of when referral of these sorts of powers may have been of some real value.

The reality, in terms of the second proposal before the House, relating to the interchange of powers, is that, unlike the position put by the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the Bill will definitely overcome any doubts which the States hold about the basis upon which references of power may be made by them to the Commonwealth. In fact, the Bill makes it clear that a reference given by the States will be revocable. That has been one of the ongoing causes of concern relating to referral of powers over the years. It may be given subject to conditions-another area of dispute over time-and include in that context conditions regulating the types of laws that can be passed under it and, further, that such references may be made for a limited period. Designations of matters by the Commonwealth Parliament will be subject to the same provisions as those relating to references by the States in relation to revocation, the power to impose conditions and other related matters.

Another part of the proposed referenda relates to Commonwealth places. Of course, this is not a matter of very great moment in terms of day to day politics, but in some areas of litigation it is quite a problem. Since the decision some time ago of Worthing v. Rowell and Muston Pty Ltd significant advances have certainly been made in this area, essentially by agreement between the Federal and State governments. Nevertheless, most observers agree that it is an area that still leaves open to considerable doubt the exact role of Commonwealth and State powers where they conflict in terms of Commonwealth places. Certainly, if we are given the opportunity to redress that problem we should embrace it.

The purpose of the proposal in paragraph (c) of proposed new section 108A(2) is to ensure that no exclusive powers of the Commonwealth are beyond interchange with those of a State. Again, this proposal is the result of discussion in the community over a very long period as to precisely what form of agreement should eventually be arrived at. Another important area was explicitly put in the Bill in response to the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition, who treated this proposal in a somewhat cavalier fashion. I refer to paragraph (d) of proposed new section 108A(2) which relates to the matter of the investing of a specified Federal court other than the High Court with State jurisdiction in matters of a specified kind. Since the decision in Fencott v. Muller the Federal Court of Australia can determine non-Federal issues forming part of a Federal controversy before the Court. That was a pioneering decision that very much reduced the jurisdictional problems facing Federal Court litigants.

The situation in the State Supreme Courts has yet to be resolved. Far from waiting for a High Court decision to resolve the issue, it seems to me to be important that it should be contained in part of the referenda proposals put before the Australian people. The object of these proposals is that the Federal Court should have power, where the ordinary tenets of justice dictate, to refer to State courts certain powers by way of remitter. As a natural corollary the proposal provides that State Supreme Courts may do likewise in similar circumstances; in such cases they may remit matters to the relevant Federal court.

I shall not go on in any greater detail. As I indicated at the outset I was concerned with addressing myself solely to the issue of the interchange of powers simply because it had not been addressed in any substantive way by any of the previous speakers. I see my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and I am reminded of part of his contribution to this debate which related to the costs involved in running elections. I have already addressed costs in terms of the sheer number of elections we have had and will have over the next 10 years. The honourable member for North Sydney instanced in his contribution the increase in the size of the Parliament. It seems to me that one can continue to put confusing arguments over time and they may or may not be embraced by members of the Australian community who are listening to this debate or who read newspaper reports or whatever on this subject.

It bears reiterating that the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), the relevant Opposition spokesperson on this matter in this House, proposed by way of amendment to the legislation setting up the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform that it have as a specific term of reference the matter of the size of the Parliament. So it was by way of an Opposition amendment that that matter was even brought before the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. Once the Committee was established the National Party of Australia-not, I might add, the Australian Labor Party because in our submission we made no reference to the proposed increase in the size of the House-made submissions in which it argued, I might add, very cogently, that the size of the House should be increased. For my part as a member of that Committee I was never strongly wedded to the concept although I must say that the arguments put forward had merit. Whilst we would concede on any day of the week that the decision to increase the size of Parliament may be seen as unpopular, it is a decision that simply had to be made in the near future, particularly in the context of the construction of the new Parliament House. For all those reasons, particularly those relating to the interchange of powers, I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Constitution Alteration (Terms of Senators) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Interchange of Powers) Bill because unfortunately I seem to be one of the few members of this Parliament today who have a genuine commitment to federalism and the democratic system of government which was established in our Constitution. I wish to address my remarks primarily to the Bill which is referred to as the Constitution Alteration (Terms of Senators) Bill. I note that this Bill now has a more honest title than it had when it was first introduced to this place, when it was referred to as the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government via the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has circulated to some limited extent a document which purports to put the case for these simultaneous elections. The whole case is a total fraud. The document states in part:

These measures are very important from the point of view of the quality of government in this country and of our capacity to govern effectively. None of them gives more power to the Commonwealth and none of them changes the present balance of power relationship . . .

That is patently untrue. This Bill proposes to remove the discretion of State Premiers with respect to the calling of a Senate election and to put the power into the hands of the Prime Minister. It represents a reduction in States rights . It represents an attempt to make the House of Representatives supreme over the Senate. The whole case is a fraud. I think it should be exposed as a fraud and I am amazed that the Government has succeeded so far in perpetrating what amounts to a miscarriage of justice without any responsible comment, apart from a comment made by Malcolm Mackerras, as to the implications for our system of government. It represents no more and no less than a grab for power. It represents political expediency on the part of the present Government to enable it to be in a position to call an election whenever and wherever it likes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did it represent when Fraser put it up?

—I would not refer to that. I think I would have a look at what Neville Wran did in New South Wales on 24 March before I started talking about expediency in government. For the honourable member's information, irrespective of what other honourable members on this side of the House may have said before, I have been and always remain implacably opposed to the proposal.
—All the rest supported it.

—I think that is a poor defence for what the Government is attempting to do to the system of democracy in Australia. The Constitution is not inadequate in what it proposes to do. There is no need to alter it because its back-dating provisions with respect to senators are deliberate. If they did not exist it would be possible to have a senator there for more than six years.

SPEECH.PARA: Something that should be considered is the history of Senate elections in Australia. Under a previous Labor Government the Premier of Queensland found it necessary to deny and then alter the provisions for calling a Senate election. Once this Bill is proposed and passed the rights of Premiers to control and agree to Senate elections will go out the window. It will become the prerogative of the government of the day to determine when an election will be called.

We saw the cynical use of such powers in New South Wales by the Premier of that State when he called an election on 24 March this year. He went to the Governor and maintained that he could not govern. He asked for an election, rushed back and went to the people, knowing full well that the whole thing was totally unnecessary. He called the election with minimum notice for the people and disenfranchised thousands of people throughout New South Wales. The Bill proposes to give the present Government exactly the same power. It amounts to an attempt by this Government to contrive a political situation which will perpetuate its power and implement the proposals contained in the Australian Labor Party platform and policy. I refer to its policy of centralising control and manipulation of government in Canberra rather than decentralising control to the States, where it rightly belongs.

What we see in this Bill is a determined attempt to centralise and to eliminate the rights of States. I am amazed that more has not been made of it in the Press . I am amazed that State governments have not objected to it and I am amazed that political commentators have not exposed it for what it is. I do not understand how the Attorney-General can justify using taxpayers' funds to publish this sort of document which purports to put the case for simultaneous elections. I have put questions on notice regarding how money was allocated, why the documents were not printed by the Government Printer and what has happened to them. None of those questions has been answered.

I find it amazing that the Government has been able to get away with making a statement which is patently untrue and which it has not in any way attempted to refute. What we have is a statement made under the authority of the Attorney- General that the Government cannot govern effectively unless this Bill becomes law. This country has been governed effectively since 1901 under the law as it presently stands. These changes do not give more power to the Commonwealth, but they patently give the Prime Minister and the Commonwealth Government the power to control the timing of House of Representatives and Senate elections and remove the rights of the State Premiers to influence those things. If that is not altering the balance of power between the States and the Commonwealth, I do not know what is.

I find it amazing that the Government can perpetrate such a fraud on the Australian people while pretending to be genuinely concerned with democracy. I recognise what will be the fate of this Bill: The Government will use its numbers on a party line vote to force it through. I sincerely hope that the people of Australia recognise what is being done to them and will resist it when the time comes to mark on the ballot paper their attitude to it. I can assure you, Mr Speaker, that I will be doing everything I can to ensure that this proposal fails.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-It is disappointing to have now opposition to the Constitution Alteration (Terms of Senators) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Interchange of Powers) Bill. That opposition was not apparent on previous occasions. The rationale of the former proposal, as indicated when it was first introduced, was to give effect to resolutions of the Australian Constitutional Convention at meetings in Hobart and Adelaide. It had strong cross-party support on those occasions. The Australian people must be somewhat mystified to find now that there is an objection to the proposal. At the Convention and also in this Parliament across party lines it was deemed to have a great deal of merit, as indeed it has.

SPEECH.PARA: Although elections are now out of sequence because of an earlier termination of a previous House of Representatives before its time, it is almost axiomatic that the Australian people when they express views as to who should govern the country in the House of Representatives should at the same time express views as to who their senators should be. The measure in no way detracts from the Senate. We are in the ridiculous situation, because of a failure to grapple with the rights of the Constitution, that if the Senate keeps exercising powers which we have often disputed, that is, the power to refuse Supply, we in the House of Representatives can be continually sent to the people without the Senate having to face the people to judge the merits of what has happened.

We nearly destroyed the Constitution in 1975. I make it very clear that if that position were repeated we would divide this nation. It is not possible to gauge the sort of tension and confrontation that could well develop as it did on that occasion, which was brought about purely for political purposes. When the Constitution was framed it was thought that the Senate would be a House of people who had no affiliation with political parties. How wrong were the founders of the Constitution! It is a party political House. It has proportional representation. As we recognise, because of that individuals or splinter groups can exercise influences. In the interests of the efficiency of democracy it is important that we have fewer elections. We are now facing the eighth or ninth election in the last 15 years. It is quite wrong to be now putting forward arguments that the proposals to be submitted to the people will in any way detract from the powers of the Senate. They do no such thing. A half-Senate election costs the taxpayer an extra $18m. I now advert to remarks made on previous occasions. I begin with those made by Mr Doug Anthony in October 1983. He said:
The referendum could be held when the next Federal election takes place . . .

One would hope that his successor in this place, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), might at least have adverted to that because at that stage Mr Anthony supported the proposals, as did a number of others.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has a very selective memory.

—The point has been made by my colleague, the Minister for Communications, that people seem to have selective memories on these occasions. We now hear arguments being put forward as to why we should not proceed with a referendum at this stage. But in earlier days, on 20 October 1983, Mr Anthony said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe also that the Senate should be accountable for any action it takes . . .

One way for the Senate to be accountable is for it to face election at the time the House of Representatives does. The Senate itself is due to face an election in a very short space of time. It is inconvenient to have elections at different times of the year when the issues that the people are asked to judge are the same. There will not be separate issues for the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Senate and the House of Representatives go to the people as political groups. We have the same policies. They are thrashed out by our respective parties and are usually on the economy or such matters. The people judge the issues accordingly. Because of proportional representation there are opportunities for splinter groups to have their representatives in the Senate talk about those matters. On 12 October 1983, Senator Durack said:
The Opposition acknowledges that a real problem has existed in Australia for the last 20 years and, in particular, since an early election was held for the House of Representatives in 1963.

Senator Durack there talked of simultaneous elections. I heard that in recent days he opposed them. Senator Durack in 1983 spoke about the real problem; it is a basic problem. The people of Australia do not want to have the frequent elections that have been thrust on them. On some occasions the Senate has refused Supply and on others Prime Ministers, because of what is deemed to be political advantage, have called elections, thus putting the Houses out of kilter. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) is on record as making a number of statements about the simultaneous elections proposal. He has also talked about the four-year proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Together.
—Yes, together. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In my view it is a sensible alteration . . .

Surely he is not now going to suggest it would not be a sensible alteration to have it on a simultaneous elections basis. A four-year term certainly would not prevent a Prime Minister from going to the polls before the end of that term. That was never the intention. We would love to talk about it, but public opinion and the States are opposed to it. We have to consider it from the point of view of what is feasible. The Opposition does not help to formulate public opinion by opposing the measure in the way it is now doing. It would have been far more beneficial to have talked about the issue. It has become a political issue again and the like of State Premiers and others will use this as they did before to try to defeat the referendum proposals. There is no point in now talking about the fixed four-year term; it has to be looked at in terms of the situation at that time.

The other difficulty is that the Senate itself is not prepared to talk about a four-year term or an eight-year term. There is no clear public opinion on that issue. The honourable member for North Sydney weakens his own argument when he says, as he did, that he hopes that the Australian people will accept the proposal. We think they will. We think there is logic in having simultaneous elections rather than having an election for the Senate on a different occasion from a House of Representatives election. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) on another occasion had this to say about simultaneous elections:
. . . it will mean that there will be fewer elections . . . there is no doubt that there will be a very significant saving in terms of money . . .

Whilst the honourable gentleman from North Sydney is entitled to say that he would favour a four-year term, I cannot see that the proposal is in any way weakened because of its simultaneous aspect. The honourable member made the point:
This will be welcomed by the majority of Australian people and will not, I think, injure the Senate's independence.

We are not talking about the period here; we are talking about the simultaneous aspect. I could not agree with the honourable member more. On that issue, we now see a complete about-face. The honourable member for North Sydney also said this in earlier days:
It is worth while remembering two things: First, the different system of elections which applies, in the Senate.
I wish I had read this earlier because the honourable member has said what I have said. He was talking about Australian Democrats when he said:
