Yet none of the representatives of that Party who stood in the last election or indeed the election before that got anywhere near being elected in the House of Representatives.

So it is a basically different concept of election and it is a question of the people having an ability to judge at that time. I am saying that what the honourable member for North Sydney said then still applies now.

The interchange of powers proposal is a very sensible and understandable proposition and I cannot see why anyone would want to object to that. A whole series of statements has been made suggesting that simultaneous elections may lead to more not fewer elections because without the restraint of a half Senate election occurring at three-year intervals, a Prime Minister can call an election whenever he wants to. Half Senate elections do not impose a restraint on a Prime Minister to call an early election; in fact the possibility of a separate half Senate election is more likely to be the cause of his doing so. On a number of occasions since the 1960s, an early House of Representatives election has been called in order to avoid the expense and inconvenience of a half Senate election. In other words, history shows that the trigger for an early House of Representatives election has commonly been the prospect facing the country of a separate half Senate election.

Another argument is that simultaneous elections will increase the power of the Prime Minister. As was pointed out by Mr Anthony before he retired from the House, the Prime Minister can already create the circumstances for a double dissolution and call out the whole of the Senate if he wants to. He has the power in effect to call a half Senate election at any time within the 12 months before the places of retiring senators become vacant.
The other argument is that this is part of a Labor Party campaign to destroy the Senate. That is quite ridiculous. The proposal has no effect on the powers of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is your platform.

—The platform has no restrictions at all about the Senate. That was done away with years ago. We now have a Senate in the platform. Cannot the honourable member see the position is that the Senate will be maintained? That is there.
—But it was in your last platform.
—Order!
—I am sorry, Mr Speaker.

—I think you should apologise; you are about 12 years behind. The other argument is: What is the advantage in abolishing so-called unnecessary separate half Senate elections when there have only been four since Federation? That assertion is misleading. It is true there have only been four separate half Senate elections since Federation but three of those have been in the past 20 years. We are really accelerating the pace. Out of 11 Federal elections in that time, only two have been simultaneous elections for the House and half the Senate. We are getting worse because of this problem of manipulation of the situation for political purposes, contrary to the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Another argument is that referendum proposals should not be put at the same time as an election. For the life of me I cannot understand that. Referendum proposals have commonly been put at the same time as an election in the past. There are significant cost savings. Indeed, when the previous referendum package was put before the Parliament some Opposition members argued that the referenda should be put in conjunction with the election. I have already quoted Mr Anthony as saying that as recently as 20 October last year.

Then there was the argument against the interchange of powers, that it is of minor significance and has been put up only to give a veneer of respectability. Let us face it: The interchange proposal is designed to foster greater co- operation between the Commonwealth and the States in relation to their powers and can have very significant results, particularly if one looks at it from the family law point of view and the question of adoption, custody and matters of that nature.

I am aware that time is pressing and all I want to say is that we in the Government are disappointed that the Opposition for paltry party political purposes has decided today to adopt a stance which was not in accordance with the high principles it espoused earlier. We think that the Australian people will judge this on its merits. It will be put to them and we hope it will be agreed to with the co-operation of all right-minded people. We do not want to go back to the days of separate elections. I do not think that adds to the strength of our democracy and it does nothing for the welfare of the nation. Accordingly I ask that the arguments put forward by the Opposition be rejected.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill as well as the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1984 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984, as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering the three measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are very important Bills because they are the first batch of Budget Bills to be debated in detail by the Parliament. I should say at the outset that, because these measures comprise part of the Government's Budget, it will not be our intention to vote against them at the second reading stage. I shall, however, be moving an in-principle amendment at the second reading stage dealing with certain aspects of the timing of the introduction of the proposed tax on Australian and imported wine. Because they are general sales tax Bills, the House is given the opportunity of debating in general aspects of revenue collection by the Government and matters relating to the revenue base.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members will be well aware, sales tax comprises a very significant proportion of the total revenue collections of the Commonwealth and in those circumstances it is entirely appropriate in debating a sales tax measure to say something about the revenue base not only of this Budget but also of future Budgets. Of course, that leads me unavoidably to what I see as the major problem the Government has created for the government of the day next year as a result of bringing down the Budget which was presented to this Parliament by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) a bare two weeks ago. The unassailable fact is that next year we will have in this country a major budgetary problem. This year 's Budget has been essentially built upon a fortuitous one-off surge in revenue collections which cannot conceivably be repeated next year.

I would like to spend a few moments tonight analysing that proposition and supplying some reasons why I believe that in the interests of a fairly short term political expedient this Government has created a quite worrying budgetary problem for next year. As I think I have said on another occasion, this might not be the first occasion on which an Australian government has fallen into that error. But that does not alter the culpability of this Government for the problem that it is creating for next year, nor will it alter the magnitude of the task that will face the government of the day next year in putting together the 1985-86 Budget. This year it is anticipated that total revenue collections will rise by no less than 10.7 per cent in real terms; that is, after we allow for inflation the total amount collected by the Commonwealth Government through this Budget will be 10.7 per cent greater than it was last year. On its own that does not sound very remarkable, but when we look back through the Budget Papers and find that that is the largest increase in revenue collections to have occurred on any occasion since the end of World War II, we realise that this year is special and we realise the significance of a government relying upon a special one-off increase in revenue collections on which to base a Budget and a Budget strategy. We also realise the problems that it stores up for next year.

Another statistic that I think ought to be mentioned and kept in mind in this analysis is that this year it is anticipated that provisional tax collections will rise by 44.7 per cent. That does not mean that everybody paying provisional tax will pay 44.7 per cent more, although undoubtedly some fortunate individuals , or unfortunate individuals, depending on how one looks at it, may be in that position. It means that the total proportion of personal tax collections coming from farmers, lawyers, businessmen and all the other people who pay provisional tax is this year going to be almost 45 per cent higher than it was last year. That is a phenomenal increase in anybody's language and I think compares with an average increase of something like 7 per cent or 8 per cent over the last 10 or 15 years. The reason we have that phenomenal increase this year is fairly easy to understand. It is because there has been a spectacular pick-up in the incomes of many farmers because of the end of the drought. They are not by any long term measure earning huge incomes; it is just that the previous year was so dreadfully bad because of the drought that any improvement this year is going to look good by comparison. Because of that improvement we have this quite extraordinary pick-up in provisional tax collections. But the significant thing which I keep coming back to, the problem that the Government has created for next year, is that there is no way on earth that we will get a 44.7 per cent pick-up in farm incomes in 1985-86.

As someone on my staff remarked in a very erudite article in the Australian a couple of weeks ago, 'You can only break a drought once', and of course next year we will not be getting the benefit of that 44.7 per cent revenue surge from provisional taxpayers; it will be back to the normal 8 per cent or 9 per cent which is the order of the day. So what the Government has done in the Budget is rely on a once only surge in revenue collections to lock itself into budgetary commitments that cannot possibly be met in future years without an enormous expansion in the size of the Budget deficit next year.

At Question Time today we were promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that, if his Government is re-elected at the election that will be held presumably before the end of this year, taxation levels will not rise next year. He gave that promise when he answered a question, and he cannot back away from that quite deliberate promise. He said: 'Overall taxation levels are not going to rise next year if my Government is re-elected'. He was unambiguous in saying it. If he really means that he has to answer a very simple question. I can promise him that he will be asked that question often enough in the weeks and months ahead. He has to explain to the Australian people how on earth he will reconcile the difference that must inevitably open up next year between his revenue base if he is re-elected and the expenditure commitments that he has locked this Government into, because next year we will not have a 44 per cent rise in provisional tax collections; next year we will not have a 10.8 per cent increase in tax collections in real terms over and above inflation; and next year we will not have those fortuitous one-off circumstances that have presented the Government with an opportunity this year which it has passed up and which I believe the Government and the community generally will live to regret that it has passed up.

The truth is that this year revenue collections increased by something approaching $9,000m. The Government has achieved a deficit reduction of about $1 .3 billion of that approximately $9 billion. What has it done with the rest? It has, in plain, simple, old-fashioned language, spent the rest of it. Instead of using the bulk of that $9 billion temporary, fortuitous, once only surge in revenue collections to bring about a reduction in the structural deficit, to bring about a reduction in those on-going commitments of the Government which cannot be attributed to high unemployment, to temporary factors that will go out of the system, it has spent the additional money. That is the worst possible thing the Government could have done. It might appear to be the smart thing in the short term; it might appear that it has done a Houdini trick by reducing the deficit and also providing a taxation cut, but that is almost unavoidable if there is a $9 billion rise in revenue collection. One has to be a bit of a mug Treasurer with $9 billion extra not to be able to give some kind of taxation cut and achieve some kind of reduction in the deficit.

But it is the magnitude of what the Government has done that really matters. The Government has applied something like 75 per cent of that once-off surge in revenue collections towards additional expenditure. That is what is going to come home to haunt the Australian community next year because next year we will not have that huge rise in farm incomes. In fact the Bureau of Agricultural Economics is forecasting that next year farm incomes will fall by 30 per cent on what they are this year. I hope that does not happen, but I think it will because, as I said a few moments ago, you can only break a drought once. So the Government has dug the budgetary-making process of this country into a very big hole next year.

If we go through the other sources of revenue we do not get a great deal of comfort from them. Anybody who took any notice of what Sheik Yamani said last night during the Copland Memorial Address would realise that crude oil levy receipts will not be a growing source of revenue for the Commonwealth over the next few years. If we look at income tax collections generally we have the ringing statements of the Prime Minister: 'We have reduced them and we will not increase the income tax burdens on the ordinary Australian taxpayer'. That is the claim that is being made. If we go through all the different revenue items we find that next year we will have a problem to which the Government has not addressed itself. This year it has increased expenditure by 6 per cent in real terms after 7.5 per cent in real terms last year. That means that under this Government the rate of increase in government spending is treble the rate that it was under the previous Government.

I know that there are many in the community who argue that the level of restraint on spending by the previous Government might have been better, but we were absolute paragons of virtue when it came to expenditure restraint compared with this Government. Obviously it has demonstrated that it does not have any stomach for expenditure restraint, so I ask the question once again: What is going to happen next year? It is all very well for the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to generalise but they are hard questions because when the government of the day, whoever it may be next year, gets the first advice on likely revenue projections it will have a very rude shock awaiting it. Instead of a nice, handsome, 44 per cent rise in provisional tax payments it will be told it is about 6 or 8 per cent. It will be told that its on-going expenditure commitments are rising by another 6 or 7 per cent over and above the rate of inflation because the Government has locked itself into ever-escalating expenditure programs. It has run around the country saying: 'We have committed ourselves to enormous increases in education expenditure'. This year health expenditure goes up by 40 per cent over and above what it was last year because the real cost of Medicare is finally coming home to roost.

So I get back again to the central question, and it is the great unanswered question of this year's Budget, and that is: What about the problem that the Government is creating for next year? It is not a sufficient answer for the Treasurer or the Prime Minister to say that this sort of problem has happened in the past. It may have, and if it has that is to the condemnation of those responsible. But it does not alter the responsibility of this Government, which brought down this Budget and which has created this problem for next year, to provide some kind of explanation.

In addressing some remarks to these sales tax measures I ask the fundamental question which so far has not been answered by the Treasurer, despite numerous questions by the Opposition to the effect: What on earth does the Government believe is to be done about next year's budgetary problem? How can it justify spending 75 per cent of new revenue collections which are not going to be repeated next year? I repeat that they are not going to be repeated next year. If I am wrong on that I would welcome correction from my friend the honourable member from Hunter (Mr Robert Brown), who no doubt will follow me at some stage in this debate. He normally makes very reasonable and sensible contributions to these sorts of debates but he will have to be at his reasonable and most sensible best tonight in order to get out of this one because no one can create money out of thin air; not even the honourable member for Hunter can claim to have the capacity to do that. I do not think anybody on the other side can claim to have that capacity. I would like to hear from the honourable member for Hunter how the Government will replace this amount. He will probably talk about growth because the Government is big on growth. It is the new virtue in the Australian Labor Party. It used to hate growth until it realised that unless there is growth and unless there are some profits it is very hard to employ people. Now it is very big on growth and it waxes very eloquent when it comes to growth.

While addressing the Confederation of Australian Industry the other evening the Prime Minister gave the sweeping undertaking that when he restructured the tax scale-he would not tell us how he would do so, and presumably it will be kept under wraps during the election campaign-it would not involve an overall increase in tax. He made this interesting statement: 'You do not need to reduce expenditure in order to reduce the deficit provided economic growth exceeds the rate of growth in government spending'. That sounds a fairly logical, simplistic , fair and reasonable statement to make. I can see the honourable member for Hunter is nodding assent to what his Leader said on that subject. The only problem is that the Government has got off to an awfully bad start because this year growth is projected to be 4 per cent according to the Budget Papers and spending is projected to be 6.1 per cent in real terms. On that sort of scenario the Prime Minister is confirming that next year the deficit problem will be worse than this year. So I advise the Government not to run that one very strongly unless it is able to produce a situation where each year the rate of growth of government spending is less than the rate of expected economic growth.

So far on average this Government has chalked up 6.5 per cent in real terms- that has been its strike rate-in increases in government spending in the two Budgets it has brought down. In order to validate the Prime Minister's proposition for each year that the Labor Government has been in power-in my reckoning that is two-it will have to have produced an average growth rate of more than 6.5 per cent. That is just not possible because next year we will fall back to 4 per cent. So I would not run that one. So the Government is left with some very embarrassing questions. It will really need to be a virtuoso performance from the honourable member for Hunter to provide some explanation of where the money is coming from.

I turn to those immortal words of the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), about which honourable members will hear plenty from us between now and polling day. He made a totally candid statement on The World Today program the week the Budget was brought down. He was lamenting the fact that he had not done too well at Budget Cabinet for his portfolio and how science really was not politically popular enough to merit a big increase in funding. He said: 'You know, ladies and gentlemen, the problem is that three or four months before an election the Government is not really game to bring in all those taxes it needs to bring in in order to fund its expenditure commitments'. My friend the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) may well shake his head, not at me but at his colleague, for what he said because--

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say that.

—Oh, yes, he did. The reality is that the Minister for Science and Technology was saying what everybody knows; that is, if the Hawke Government is re-elected it will have three options open to it. Given the fact that it has chalked up deficits in two years which are almost as great as the ones we chalked up in seven years and that it has produced deficits which are $3 billion to $4 billion higher than the largest deficit we ever produced, its first option is to live with an unacceptably large deficit next year. Its second option is to embark upon a program of expenditure restraint that it has never even contemplated as a Labor Government and which, of course, it will not have the courage to say anything about during the forthcoming election campaign. Thirdly, Barry Jones, the Minister for Science and Technology, really let the cat out of the bag when he said: 'We will have to put up taxes. We will have to impose all of the taxes that we are not game to talk about before the election campaign'. He said that in plain simple language. Of course, he was talking the truth. Out of the mouth of a candid, avuncular, nice, well-meaning Minister came these gems of wisdom. Of course, the Minister for Science and Technology was apparently rebuked by the Prime Minister. He was rebuked for his candour.
—For telling the truth.

—For telling the truth. For a Prime Minister who believes in integrity and all those other things that he regales us about from time to time it was a pretty interesting exercise because what his Minister was doing was really putting his finger on what was going to happen. The honourable member for Hunter knows quite well that if our revenue collections are going to go back to normal, if we are not going to have this temporary surge in provisional tax collections, if we are not going to have all of these other marvellous increases, of course we are going to have problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not the only person who is making these statements. Let me refer honourable members to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald, repeated in today 's Age, written by Max Walsh who, over the last few months, has hardly been one of the Government's most unrelenting economic critics. He has hardly won the Pulitzer Prize for criticising the Government over the last 18 months. What did he have to say? He had an article headed 'The Beginning of the End of the Hawke Government'. The burden of his article was that until the last Budget this Government had the right to claim some long term economic credentials. He said that in the last Budget the Prime Minister and the Treasurer passed up an opportunity to do something of a lasting nature about the structural deficit problem of this country. He pinpointed the very thing that from the night the Budget was brought down I have been talking about, and that is that it is built upon a fortuitous once only surge in revenue collections. The Government has done the worst possible thing with that windfall revenue gain-it has spent it. Once it has spent it, that is the end of it; it can never get it back. The Government has created an absolute nightmare of a Budget problem for next year. It is a decision that the Australian community will pay very dearly for in the future.

We have heard a lot of nonsense, cant and hypocrisy talked in this Parliament about deficits and national debts. The unassailable fact is, despite all the rhetoric of the Government, despite all the blustering of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister on the subject, that this Government in two Budgets has produced deficits of $8 billion and $6.7 billion. The largest deficit the last Government ever produced was $4.3 billion and nothing this Government can do will ever alter that. All the misleading, dishonest statements that are made by the Government to the opposite do not alter that fact. But those sorts of comparisons and arguments will be reduced to pigmy proportions by the deficit problem we will face next year because of the folly and the political expediency that has overtaken the Government in the framing of this year's Budget.

I remember when the forward Estimates were released this year-the forward Estimates, I might say, of expenditure because the Government, strangely, interestingly and illusorily enough, did not release the forward Estimates of revenue-we were told that the Government was going to fight very hard to contain the growth in outlays to 3 per cent or 4 per cent in real terms. That is what the forward Estimates said. I found in Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald an absolutely fascinating article written by Ross Gittins, an economics writer for the Sydney Morning Herald, a person whom I like immensely although I disagree with a number of the things that he says.

Here, let me say that I do not think over the last 18 months the Government has had warmer support from a leading economics writer in Australia than it has had from Mr Gittins, who is a true believer, as he will confess himself, in the prices and incomes accord. I suppose it is on that point that I depart from Mr Gittins. But I nonetheless read his material with very great interest. It is always well researched and he always argues a very tidy intellectual case. He made the very interesting observation that he thought the reason the Government did not release the forward estimates of revenue this year and therefore the forward projection of the Budget deficit when it started its Budget exercise was not that it was too high but that it was too low and that in fact the starting point for the Budget deficit this year was $5 billion. The Government, as he put it, 'struggled and laboured manfully' to reduce that $5 billion to $6.7 billion. There seems to me to be a great deal of compelling logic in what Mr Gittins had to say. He is not the sort of person to make that kind of observation lightly. So here we have the spectacle of this tight-fisted Government struggling against odds to get down the terrible expenditure problem that was facing it and it has been so successful that it has actually 'reduced' the deficit from $5 billion to $6.7 billion. So much for the expenditure restraint stomach of this Government!

I simply reiterate that this Government has created a Budget nightmare for next year. Its expedient, opportunistic use of this temporary, once only surge in revenue collections, its totally irresponsible and quite stupid decision to spend it instead of conserving and saving it, is going to come home to haunt the Australian community.
Before I sit down I ought to say something more specific about what is in the sales tax legislation. I ought to say something specific--

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wondering myself about that one.

—I am grateful for your normal tolerance, Madam Deputy Speaker. Your tolerance almost matches your charm on these matters. In the view of the Opposition there are problems with the wine tax proposal that the Government has put forward and my colleagues, in particular the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), who understands as well as and certainly not less than any other member in the House the problems of the Australian wine industry, will be having something to say in more detail. Even though, as I think I have said on another occasion, there are arguments in favour of taxation on all forms of alcoholic beverage, the fact nonetheless remains that the timing of the introduction of this tax could barely be worse.
—Appalling.

—As my friend the honourable member for Farrer says, it is appalling. Well may he say that because there are very considerable wine growing interests in some of the newly acquired areas of his electorate. He will no doubt give these areas the same quality of representation that he has given to other parts of his electorate. It is very appalling timing at a time when subsidised European wines are disrupting the Australian wine industry and when an inquiry is proceeding into the future structure of the industry. So we have major reservations about the timing of the introduction of this tax. We believe that the Government is giving insufficient consideration to other taxation measures which may provide something of an offset to the effect of the introduction of this kind of tax.
—No consideration at all.

—There has been no consideration at all, as the honourable member for Wakefield says. Consistent with the declaration I made at the commencement of my speech that we will not vote against the second reading of this measure, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the impact of the Government's new tax on wine, when taken in conjunction with changes in the taxation treatment of imports of wine, unreasonably and unfairly disadvantages the Australian wine producing and grape growing industry at a time when imports of surplus protected and subsidised European wines are disrupting the Australian wine industry and when there is an inquiry proceeding into the future structure of the industry'.

I hope that all members of the House, in particular those members of the Australian Labor Party who represent electorates in South Australia, will give consideration to this issue. It will be very interesting to see whether the rhetoric--

TALK.START.PARA: —And also the honourable member for Hunter.

—My colleague may well say 'the honourable member for Hunter'. He represents one of the great wine growing districts of Australia. He is normally a fine representative. I am sure the people of the industry in his electorate will want to know where he stands on this issue. They will want to know whether he supports the appalling timing of the introduction of this tax. No doubt he will think of some deft way of avoiding that question, as he has done with the broader budgetary problems which I canvassed earlier in my speech tonight. We do have reservations. We think that the Government's timing is bad. We think that this tax is inconsiderate. We think that it has severely disadvantaged the local grape grower and given an enormous advantage to imported wines. In those circumstances I warmly commend to the House the in principle amendment which has been preshadowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One would have been forgiven for being under the impression, while the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was speaking, that this was a general debate covering questions of the Budget. Of course, it is nothing of the kind. What we are in the process of doing at present is considering three Bills-the Sales Tax (Nos 1 to 9) Amendment Bills, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). Because the contribution of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was as wide ranging as it was, I wish to take up a number of issues before I proceed to deal in more detail with the specific provisions of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The point was made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the call was taken up by other members of the Opposition side that in order to reduce the deficit again in the next financial year the rate of growth of government spending must be less than the rate of real economic growth. That point has been made by them repeatedly. It was made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition again this evening. Underlying this general concern that has been expressed by members of the Opposition is that some of the surges in government revenue which were experienced during the last financial year and which will be experienced again in this financial year will not necessarily be reproduced in the following financial year. They believe that perhaps those surges in revenue will not be reproduced in the following financial year. They use that belief as a basis for asserting that as a result the Government, in preparing the next Budget, will find itself in very serious difficulties.

What those people fail to understand is that while those surges in revenue undoubtedly exist during the current financial year, the way in which that increased revenue has been used in the Budget has had the effect of absorbing that revenue. The assumption appears to be that in the next financial year that increased revenue will not be available. Of course it will be available. It will be available to finance the increased expenditure which this Government quite clearly has undertaken. Let me repeat that. The assumption appears to be that the increased revenue which has been available this year will suddenly disappear in the next financial year. That appears to be fundamental to the argument that has been advanced by members of the Opposition and in particular the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the shadow Treasurer.

One of the most incredible statements made by the Leader of the Opposition-I am anticipating future developments-the Deputy Leader of the Opposition during his most recent contribution was that the present Government has been responsible for the largest deficits in recent years. He referred to the realised, the actual, deficit during the last financial year, which was about $8 billion. He referred to the estimated deficit for the current financial year of $6.7 billion . Those figures pale into insignificance when one recalls the deficit that the former Treasurer, the present Deputy Leader of the Opposition, left for this Government to inherit. I refer to the notorious deficit of $9.6 billion. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, to his credit and to the credit of his own personal integrity-I have said this before and I have some respect for his integrity-attempted to make that known to the electorate during the week prior to 5 March last year. The then leader of the Government of the day, the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, refused to allow that information to be divulged.

The present Deputy Leader of the Opposition does not deny that that was the information which was given to him. He does not deny that on at least two occasions during that week he sought permission from the office of the then Prime Minister to announce that information publicly. He does not deny that the figure was $9.6 billion. Why then do members of the Opposition become so embarrassed when we continue to refer to the fact that we inherited such a disastrous economic and fiscal situation in Australia? They recognise that that is so. They admit to all of the detail. When we repeat and remind the Australian electorate that we inherited such a disastrous fiscal situation in Australia for some reason they feel that we are not being fair, we are not playing the game, we are misrepresenting the position, despite the fact, as I have indicated, that they never deny the essential facts which lie behind the $9.6 billion deficit that this Government inherited on 5 March last year.

What a remarkable, dramatic and magnificent result the Hawke Labor Government has brought about in terms of economic management. While I am not necessarily suggesting that the three Bills we are considering at present are a major or a significant part of that total fiscal, economic management, they do reflect the continuing need on the part of governments to examine, re-examine and restructure the general taxation system. Approaches of this kind will always necessarily be undertaken by governments. What we have to do is to look towards those governments which attempt to restructure the taxation system by bringing into the taxation system greater degrees of equity, fairness and justice.

This is in marked contrast to the way in which the taxation system was used by the previous Government as one of the tools in its political armoury and as one of its election campaign methods. Plenty of reference has been made to the notorious situation which existed before the 1977 election. The fistful of dollars was used as a bribe by the Government at that time, the Fraser Government, the coalition, the Liberal-National Party Government, in order to court favour, win support and secure votes from an Australian electorate which was very seriously misled on that occasion. I suppose the bait was successful. The votes were won. The Government was returned, but it took back the money. Of course, the fistful of dollars did not remain with the Australian electors for very long. There has been a remarkable transformation in the attitude, direction and objectives of taxation policy as far as this Government is concerned.

Of course, a particular characteristic of this legislation has attracted the most attention and has encouraged quite legitimate concern on the part of the wine industry, particularly that part of the wine industry in my present electorate in the lower Hunter, the producers of magnificent, premium quality, often expensive wines. That section of the Australian wine industry will be the most severely hurt as a result of the imposition of the 10 per cent sales tax. I would be less than honest if I did not indicate my personal disapppointment that the Government found it necessary to introduce that provision at this stage. I have expressed my disappointment, and it is a legitimate disappointment. I do not resile from that position; nor should I. But I indicate that despite the pedantry and the rhetoric associated with the wording of the quite dishonest amendment which has been moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, there is no suggestion that the Opposition, given the opportunity, would repeal this legislation. What it is really trying to do is to have a couple of bob each way. It is a change about which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was questioned when he addressed the National Press Club. He was asked about the wine tax and, in a report of his answer-the report puts these words in inverted commas, so apparently it is a direct quote-the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, responded by saying:
. . . 'there are good arguments for equal tax treatment of all alcoholic beverages'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The present Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the shadow Treasurer, the gentleman who just addressed this Parliament and moved what I have suggested is essentially a dishonest amendment to the motion for the second reading of this legislation. Of course, the Opposition would not reverse or repeal the legislation. What the Deputy Leader of the Opposition gave to the National Press Club was a statement of some substance. I think the whole industry appreciates that the only question with regard to the imposition of a tax on wine was not whether a tax would be imposed, but when a tax would be imposed. I would have preferred that it was imposed on some other occasion, but not because of any possible threat to me in my electorate. The electors in my electorate are the most discerning, the most perceptive electors in any electorate in Australia. They show magnificent political judgment. That is reflected by the fact that the present incumbent in the electorate of Hunter enjoys a majority of about 70 per cent.
—I am sure the honourable member's feelings are shared by every member of the House.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. You are more than generous and I echo the complimentary remarks that were made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in connection with your good self. I express concern, as I indicated earlier, about the way in which the taxation system was used as part of the political armoury of the present Opposition when it was in government. It used taxation rates, tax collections, tax concessions, the tax structure generally and the taxation machinery as its private province and as a means of dispensing patronage to its cronies and to the numerous pampered and privileged sections of the Australian economy which it basically represented. As a result of its seven years in government the Australian tax system became increasingly distorted, inequitable and unjust, and increasingly the burden was placed on those sections of the Australian community which were least able to bear that burden. For seven years that situation developed.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some sympathy for the former Treasurer because I know that his Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, increasingly cut off all of the options which were available to him. I have said before that he is honest. I know that if he were asked whether that was the position, he would have to say that that was the position. It left him like a bird without a feather to fly with. I am sure that it has occurred to the present Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the shadow Treasurer, that there is some evidence that the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) will make the same mistake. I prevail on the shadow Treasurer to ensure that that mistake is not made because if at any time in the distant future the Opposition is returned to this side of the Parliament-God forbid-I would not like to see it in a position where all the options that may have been available to it to increase the equity, fairness and sense of the taxation system were denied it.

By way of background I point out that the present sales tax legislation consists of a number of separate Acts. The Sales Tax Acts Nos 1 to 9 specify the rates at which sales tax is payable. Those Sales Tax Acts Nos 1 to 9 are then supported or complemented by Sales Tax Assessment Acts Nos 1 to 9, which provide the machinery for the assessment, collection and administration of the tax imposed. In addition to those two sets of Acts we also have the Sales Tax ( Exemptions and Classifications) Act. These Acts are referred to specifically in the three pieces of legislation that we are dealing with tonight. The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act formerly contained five schedules which listed the various classes of goods and the tax that was applicable to those classes of goods at the various specified rates. Schedule one, for example, listed all of those classes of goods that were exempt goods in relation to sales tax. The second schedule listed those which were taxed at 32.5 per cent. The third schedule listed those taxed at 7.5 per cent, and the fourth and fifth schedules listed those taxed at 20 per cent.

The present amendments, of course, provide for the addition to those schedules of another schedule, a sixth schedule, which will identify those goods which will be taxed at 10 per cent. Those goods are, of course, Australian produced grape wine. This wine tax must be seen in the context of a total package of taxation proposals on alcohol which are designed to rationalise the total arrangements. As I said before, I express some personal reservation about the timing of those changes. But it is part of a total package and I think it needs to be seen in that way. That total package includes low alcohol beer, the light ales. The excise has been reduced by 8c to 58c a litre. Very low alcohol beer- that beer which contains less than 1.15 per cent alcohol-could not previously be taxed as a soft drink because it was not a soft drink. It had a lower alcohol content than beer, so it could not be taxed as beer. In order to rationalise the absurdity of that position, the Government has provided in the Budget for the imposition of a sales tax of 20 per cent on very low alcohol beer-I think it is sometimes referred to as non-alcoholic beer-which is the same as the tax imposed on soft drinks.

The sales tax of 10 per cent on wine and on alcoholic ciders is perhaps the major provision in the Bills and the one which quite clearly has caused the greatest amount of concern. The excise collected from the tax that was applied last year on fortifying spirit is to be refunded in full. I know that there is some thought within the wine industry that an approach of this kind is much more appropriate than that which was adopted last year. The tax on fortifying spirit was sectional. It was discriminatory and I know that many of those interests within the wine industry which do not produce the fortifying spirit were of the opinion that an overall tax would have been more equitable. Of course, that is the effect of this legislation.

The previous 20 per cent sales tax on alcoholic non-grape wines has been lowered to 10 per cent. I wish to express some concern about the change relating to imported wines. Reference has been made to some of these imported wines coming from the European Economic Community which quite clearly are being dumped on the Australian market at present. I wish to express my concern that that is happening and that it is being tolerated. I understand that in the United States , for example, some Italian wines have been dumped at a price of something like $US4 a dozen. That is an absurd situation. If we are not very careful in Australia we will get to that situation as well. As a result of the change in sales tax on those imported wines which has been reduced from 20 per cent to 10 per cent and the Customs duty of 10 per cent which has been imposed to take the impost up to 20 per cent, we are placed in an unfair position in relation to sales tax on the wine we produce.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the exercise of self-congratulation that we have just witnessed from the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) precious little time was spent focusing on what is at the heart of the Sales Tax (Nos 1 to 9) Amendment Bills and cognate Bills we are considering tonight. It is not surprising that even a member as courageous as the honourable member for Hunter has been prepared to spend so little time focusing on these Bills because the cognate debate on these Bills is the culmination of 18 months of deception.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is in fact a bibliography of blatantly broken promises. It is a litany of misrepresentation on the part of the Hawke Labor Government. The seeds of the legislation we have before us tonight were sown in deceit. They took root in the political expediency that is so much a part of Australian Labor Party politics, and they blossomed at Griffith in February 1983 when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was prepared to stand boldly and say, 'Labor is pledged', pledged, mark you, 'not to introduce a sales tax on wine'.

It is easy for the Prime Minister, day after day in this Parliament just as we witnessed today, in his rasping and arrogant way to take to task the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) for statements he may have made while he was a back bencher. It is easy for the Prime Minister to use Question Time to throw back at the Opposition things he alleges it said. It is easy for the Prime Minister, as he did today, to play to the House and ask it to savour the delectable words he is about to repeat. But it was cynical and hypocritical of him not only to make such a statement today but also in February 1983, for the sake of political expediency, to say to the grape growers of Australia: 'Labor is pledged not to introduce a sales tax on wine'. Never was there a promise or an act so cheaply based. Never was there a commitment so lightly thrown away. That promise was given without any intention to honour it, and it was given by the present Prime Minister, that man of integrity who claims to lead this nation. That promise, given then and since broken twice, was nothing more than a cheap political stunt designed, the Prime Minister hoped, to win the seats of Kingston and Riverina. Unfortunately he was successful in Kingston and fortunately he was unsuccessful in Riverina.

This Prime Minister jets around Australia trailing his banner of consensus and integrity when in fact he has been prepared blatantly to mislead the wine grape growers and the citizens of this nation. Not once but twice has he broken the specific promise he made to the wine grape growers who make up the electorates principally represented on this side of the House. Where now is this much vaunted integrity? Where now is this much vaunted principle? 'O, what a tangled web we weave, when first we practice to deceive!' In this case the deception took place not once but twice. The first time was just six months after the Prime Minister made his promise when in the Budget of 1983 he brought down the disastrous 2J spirit impost. Not satisfied with one mistake, an admitted mistake , the Government has repeated the performance in the 1984-85 Budget of two weeks ago. Today the industry finds itself in a confused web of government unpredictability. Just after it had been promised by the Prime Minister that for the first time in its history it could be assured of three years of tax-free existence it discovered that that tax-free existence did not even last six months.

The Prime Minister in his dealings with the grape industry has proven to be utterly unprincipled. He was deceitful to the industry in Griffith, and he is guilty of having paraded consensus and reconciliation but of refusing ever to talk to the industry about what would be in its and in the nation's best interests. There was no consensus and no consultation with the grape industry prior to the introduction of the 2J spirit tax or prior to the introduction of these Bills that we are debating in the House tonight. It would seem that the Prime Minister's concept of consensus is: 'Consensus means doing it my way'.

This deception perpetrated on the industry at Griffith in 1983 is bringing an essential Australian industry, and an essential South Australian industry, to its knees. Just a glimmer of honesty would have helped the industry to feel that it could get some sense of purpose and predictability from the Government. But there has not been one iota of honesty. We have seen one expedient political step after another.

The honourable member for Hunter said: 'Well, I am uncomfortable about this legislation, but it has been done to rationalise our tax structure'. ' Rationalise', what a glorious word! It really tells us nothing at all. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) declared that the legislation had been introduced in the interest of equity. Equity! Any comparison between the beer and wine industry which the Treasurer has been so fond of barrelling out is quite erroneous. Do honourable members realise that in the egalitarian days of the Chifley Government beer attracted the same impost as spirits? In 1984 the beer industry is taxed at barely two-thirds the rate of spirits. Is this the sort of equity the beer industry and the Hawke Labor Government want to return to? Do the brewers again want the same tax impost as that which the spirit producers currently bear?

Any comparison between the brewing industry and the wine grape industry falls apart when one looks at the way they are structured. They bear little in common at all. The wine grape industry is made up of small businesses. It is labour- intensive. It is dominated by numerous wineries and wine grape growers. As we know, the beer industry involves big business and its turnover occurs inside a six-month period while the wine industry may well take seven years from wine production to maturation.

The 10 per cent tax contained in these Bills is a tax on a labour-intensive industry. Beer already has a large percentage of the Australian drink market. It is true that percentage is falling but it is not true to say that it is falling because there has not been a sales tax on wine. It is quite erroneous to believe that the wine industry does not pay taxes in any way. The wine industry is in one way or another a substantial taxpayer. It is true that a specific sales tax has not been imposed on it, but the brewing industry cannot say that the absence of a sales tax on wine is the reason that brewery sales have fallen. They have fallen principally because of the changing lifestyles of Australians and those further complicating features such as penalty rates for hotel staff, as the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) is well aware, and random breath testing. This Bill, far from achieving better brewery sales, is nothing more than a blatant attack on the very grape growers the Prime Minister had the audacity to say he would protect. Tonight the Opposition is saying that the timing of this particular tax could not be more wrong. It will be alleged that the timing of any tax is never right. The Opposition will agree. But the timing of this tax on grape growers in Australia could not be worse.

Madam Deputy Speaker, you will recall that last week I asked a question without notice of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). I asked the Minister whether incomes or employment prospects in grape growing areas have improved under his Government? The Minister stood up and answered in one word: 'No'.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least he told the truth.

—I thank the honourable member. I pay a tribute to the Minister for having been honest. But the honesty of the Minister is not in question. It is not a part of the debate tonight. We have acknowledged that the Minister was absolutely honest. The problem is that it is not his honesty that is in question ; it is his potency. The Minister for Primary Industry has in fact failed to score for the wine grape industry in Australia and has failed to score for primary producers. He is full of good intentions, but he has yet to deliver the goods.

SPEECH.PARA: The timing of this tax could not be worse. Let us look at the grape industry in Australia which is about to be subjected to this ill-advised tax. The dried fruit portion of the grape industry in Australia is currently subject to an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry, such is its dilemma. The brandy industry in Australia is almost non-existent, thanks to the Whitlam Government's decision to remove a provision provided under section 31A of the Act. The grape industry is currently undergoing reconstruction to enable it to adjust after the disastrous way it has been treated by the Hawke Government, the Whitlam Government and, I confess, from time to time by the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deplorably by the Fraser Government, deplorably!

—The honourable member for Hunter has refused to acknowledge it, but the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), has said that there are good reasons for an equitable tax treatment for alcoholic beverages. The Opposition does not retract from that. The honourable member for Hunter has conveniently hoped that we would retract; we do not. What we declare is not that what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said is wrong, but that now is not the time. In fact, it is difficult to envisage a worse time. The Opposition amendment currently before the House, the amendment to which I address myself, simply asks the Government to look again at the timing of his tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Thanks to what successive governments have done, thanks to the removal of the 31A provision, we no longer have a brandy industry in Australia. It was the brandy industry that provided the wine grape industry with a safety valve. Were there excessive dual purpose grapes that could not find their way into the dried fruit industry or the wine industry, those grapes could be moved into the brandy industry. There is no longer a brandy industry. Those dual purpose grapes are seeking a home in the dried fruit industry and the wine grape industry. The dried fruit industry door has been shut by export pressure, because the dried fruit industry is principally an export industry. Now the Hawke Labor Government is about to close again the wine grape industry door, having jammed it shut with the 2J spirit excise and prised it open again, it is callously about to slam it shut again. The honourable member for Hunter said that the 2J spirit excise was not all that well advised, but that the Government is going to refund the money. Frankly, big deal! The money will be refunded, but it will not be refunded with interest attached. It will be refunded, but it was collected inequitably. What is being refunded is a mere $6m. What is being collected from the 10 per cent wine tax from an industry already on its knees is estimated to be somewhere between $62m and $67m.

If there is one area to which I want to address the attention of the House tonight and one area that justifies our claim that this amendment ought to be passed and that the 10 per cent tax ought to be reconsidered, it is the area of imports of wine into Australia. When I addressed the House in the grievance debate last week, I said that the import area was a matter for major alarm. It is a matter for alarm because while 12 months ago something like 730,000 litres of wine were imported into Australia, in the last 12 months that figure has escalated to 1.3 million litres. This wine is coming into Australia as subsidised wine. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document that was provided by the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association that illustrates the changes for imported wine as a result of the Government's 10 per cent tax.
Leave granted.
