TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows that as a result of the changes to Customs duty and sales tax on imported wine in the documents that we are considering tonight, far from the Australian industry being protected, in reality imported wines go up a mere 6c a litre while Australian local wines go up by 10 per cent. In fact, it shows that the price of the imported product is virtually not changed, while the Australian wine has increased in price by 10 per cent. Therefore, Australian wine is disadvantaged relative to imported wine.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills before the House tonight are nothing more than documents to promote imported wine. They are nothing more than documents designed to burden already overburdened grape growers. They are an attack on a proud Australian industry which has always been competitive and which is, in fact, a major employer. They are an attack on an industry which has long been exposed to, and has encouraged within itself, competition, but which now faces imported subsidised competition which it cannot live with. There can be no comparison between the unprotected Australian grape growers and the threat of this legislation and the sort of protection that we give, for example, to the steel workers of Australia.

This Bill is a result of no consultation, no consensus. Even the Labor Premier of South Australia, Premier John Bannon, had but 20 minutes notice, he said, of what was happening in this House. He has been as critical as any member of the Opposition of the moves of the Government with these Bills. In fact, in an effort to be as accommodating as I could be of the Treasurer, and fearing that he was receiving advice from the wrong quarters, as early as June 1983 I wrote to him warning him of the consequences of taxing the wine. Clearly, that letter bore no fruit at all. What we are witnessing tonight has been tried in fact three times before-in 1942, 1970 and 1983. It is now to be tried again in 1984. On every occasion, so disastrous has a wine tax proven, it has had to be repealed.

Tonight the Opposition stands before the House with an entirely unambiguous stance. The honourable member for Hunter has conveniently and, I add, dishonestly said that the Opposition is not prepared to state its case. It is prepared to state its case. It is that, following the next election, we will repeal the legislation currently before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you had approval from the shadow Treasurer to say that?

—For the benefit of the honourable member for Hunter I will repeat the statement that the Opposition stands ready to repeal this legislation, if elected at the next election. We seek tonight to carry an amendment so that, in fact, the grape growers of Australia will be spared the thrust of this Bill prior to their being done irreparable damage. We are seeking to carry an amendment so that the legislation before the House no longer attacks the frail and burdens the disadvantaged. This amendment allows the Government not to proceed with the 10 per cent tax; to look again at the threat of imports to the wine grape industry; to look again at providing the wine grape industry with some form of protection in the form of stock valuation adjustment; and to look again at consulting with the industry as to how it might best be asked to bear what is seen to be its share of the tax burden.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleagues all support this amendment. The Liberal members from South Australia are united in their support of the amendment. It is interesting to note that in 1978 the tables in this House were turned when foolishly we were proposing a similar sort of exercise. On that occasion there were members of the Liberal Party Government who were courageous enough to cross the floor and vote in support of the grape growers. The challenge tonight to the Labor Party is this: Will the honourable member for Hunter and will the South Australian members of this House be prepared to show similar intestinal fortitude and cross the floor in the interests of the grape growers of Australia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to rise to speak in support of the Sales Tax (Nos 1 to 9) Amendment Bills, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) tonight. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has already made clear in the House earlier in the debate, these are the first of the Budget Bills to come before the House. As he took a considerable time to make some comments about the Budget in general, I feel that I must reply briefly--
—I was very pleased to see that each of the previous speakers did return to these Bills towards the end of his speech.

—I have a great deal of information to make available on the Bills, but I particularly wish to make some points on the comments of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition about the Budget. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition provided , in an indirect way, a warning to our Government that when framing our next Budget we should be careful about the degree to which we let Budget deficits in total work ahead for the 1985-86 Budget. He suggested that we had used an opportunity to reduce further Budget deficit. I have been pleased to hear, both in his speech and in a number of other speeches from members of the Opposition, an acknowledgement that if there are any difficulties in the context of framing the 1985-86 Budget they will be difficulties that face this Government and not the Opposition. We are pleased to stand on our record in terms of budgetary and fiscal management. Since March 1983 we have produced two Budgets which have been well received by the Australian economy and the people-
—They have been Budgets with the highest deficit in Australia's history.

—They have not been Budgets with the highest deficit in Australian history, as the honourable member for O'Connor has suggested. In fact, as I will indicate in a moment we have done a remarkable job in very difficult circumstances in bringing that deficit down. We are prepared to stand on our record. The Budget is the major economic tool of any government for creating economic management, economic decision making, employment growth, business profits and so on. In that sense it is important-it is imperative in a way-to look at what we have managed to achieve in the space of just two Budgets, compared with what the Opposition achieved in the space of seven or eight years of government and an equivalent number of Budgets.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that you, Madam Deputy Speaker, will recall very well the situation when we came to government, prior to framing our 1983-84 Budget. In 1982-83 real gross product had fallen by 2 per cent. Real manufacturing output had fallen by 11 per cent. Private investment in dwelling construction had declined by almost 25 per cent in the year in question. Also by the end of 1982-83 that private business investment was some 30 per cent lower than its pre-recession peak level and it was still falling. Of course, we all know that the labour market had deteriorated sharply. There had been a fall in employment of almost 2 per cent. Aggregate hours worked were falling rapidly and unemployment increased by some 250,000 people to more than 720,000. That was the situation when we took government.

In our 1983-84 Budget we provided the framework for sustained economic growth. The effect of that Budget has been in every way to generate economic growth throughout our economy. We have seen employment rise by some 250,000 jobs; we have seen interest rates fall by more than two percentage points; we have seen a consistency of wages and prices across the board through the very successful incomes and prices accord; we have also seen a significant fall in Australia's rate of inflation. That is the situation in which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition suggests to us that we should be looking with caution to future Budgets.

If we look at total tax revenues and the claim that has been made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, we find that total tax revenues in the 1984-85 Budget are estimated to increase by some 17.9 per cent. That is a significant increase. It largely reflects strong economic growth and it also indicates the full year effects of the Medicare arrangements and the prescribed payment system. Although that is a strong growth in tax revenues, we should note that the gross pay as you earn income tax collections will grow by a much more modest 10.7 per cent over the year and that both gross and net pay as you earn taxes after refunds will represent a smaller proportion of gross domestic product in 1984-85 than in either 1981-82 or 1982-83, the last two years of the former Government. We must put the claims of the Opposition in terms of this Budget deficit in that context . I will repeat it-gross and net pay as you earn income taxes will represent a smaller proportion of GDP in 1984-85 than in either 1981-82 or 1982-83, the last two years of the Fraser Government.

I make one final point on that matter. If we look at the total Budget situation and we exclude the Medicare arrangements, total Commonwealth tax revenues in 1984-85 are estimated to be equivalent to 24.7 per cent of GDP compared with 25 per cent under the previous Government. So there is no substance to the claims made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in terms of this Budget deficit. We have acted responsibly in reducing that deficit to a level of below $7 billion. We managed to reduce the previous Budget deficit from a projected $9.6 billion-a figure which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition readily affirms-and slice some $2 billion off that amount. We have managed again in a fiscally responsible way to reduce the Budget deficit for 1984-85.

The three Bills before the House are concerned basically with the taxation of wine. Within my electorate of Bendigo there are a large number of very high quality wineries. Within the Bendigo area itself there are such noted wineries as Balgownie and Chateau Leamon, and further north we have wineries such as Passing Clouds. It is called Passing Clouds because the clouds just keep passing over and it never rains. As a result it produces a delightful wine which has won many awards. The area that is proposed to be included in the new seat of Bendigo includes the Pyrenees wine making area of Victoria with such noted wineries as Taltarni, Mount Avoca and Chateau Remy; and the Stawell wine making area which includes the wineries of Bests, Boroka, Seppelts and Great Western. They all produce quality wine. All of those wineries have made a major contribution to tourism and to infrastructure development and economic growth in the area. As a consumer of those wines I can only say that I am exceptionally proud of their development over the last decade. Honourable members might be interested to know until 1906 Bendigo was Australia's premier wine producing area. At that time the grapes were destroyed by phylloxera and it has really been only in the last decade or two that we have seen a resurgence of wine growing in that area. As I say, I am proud of our wineries. They make a great contribution to the region and to the tourism structure of the area.

I now come to the question of a tax. Like my good colleague the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown), of course I am disappointed that the Government found it necessary in this Budget to introduce a wine tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —So are we.

—I note that the Opposition is also disappointed. I am pleased that there is some disappointment about this tax. The point does have to be made that whenever any tax is introduced, no one in the Government and I dare say no one in the Opposition likes seeing that tax introduced. But there are several reasons why this wine tax had to be introduced. The first is that it was inevitable that a wine tax would be introduced throughout Australia. Over recent years successive State governments have filled the vacuum created by there being no Federal tax. South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria acted last year to put a tax on wine because the Federal Government had not acted. Of course it is much better, if there is to be taxation, for it to be handled at a national level by the Federal Government.
—That is a very good point.

—The honourable member for Hunter says that is a good point. In recent years we have seen a wider range of taxes taken up by the States but in many cases it is preferable that those taxes be levied by the Commonwealth because that removes some of the distortions that can sometimes occur between the States with varying levels of taxes. So it was inevitable, and I am sure members of the Opposition acknowledge that. In fact, the Opposition's only amendment to this legislation concerns the timing of the tax. The fact that its only amendment relates to timing suggests that there is an inevitability about such a tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The other main reason a wine tax was introduced is that there are very strong arguments on the basis of equity. It has been mentioned previously in debate that if one compares the rate of tax that previously fell on wine compared with that which applies to other alcoholic beverages, it is fair to say that wine was virtually excluded from excise and taxation arrangements. It alone was excluded. I compare wine to beer, which is very heavily taxed. If we applied the rate of tax on beer to wine, we would have an 80 per cent tax on a bottle of wine and probably a 155 per cent tax on bulk or cask wine. They are very hefty levels of tax and certainly no one on this side of the House advocates them but there are fairly strong arguments on the grounds of equity for saying there was some inevitability about the introduction of a wine tax.

There is also the argument concerning equity that over recent years it has been possible, because of the distorting aspects of those taxes, to buy in many cases good quality wine at a cheaper price per part alcohol per bottle than beer. I refer particularly to much of the champagne that has come on to the Australian market in the last year or so. It is Australian champagne but in terms of a price per product, in terms of its alcohol content, it is coming on to the market at a lower price than beer. We all have to think seriously about whether that is desirable in terms of equity and overall resource allocation.

Consumers frequently put to me other comparisons concerning a wine tax. For instance, those who do not drink wine ask why wine should be free when beer is so heavily taxed, and why mineral and soda water is taxed at 20 per cent when there is no tax on wine.

Finally, it has to be said that the effect of heavy taxes on beer has had some effect on its consumption. Since 1976 beer consumption has fallen in real terms by 10 per cent, yet wine consumption has increased at a per capita rate, in real terms per annum, of about 7 per cent, giving an overall percentage increase of some 46 per cent since 1976-77. So wine has certainly done well. I encourage and support that development and believe, as I said, that it has made a great contribution particularly in my area to tourism and local economic development.

In regard to the question of timing, raised in the Opposition's foreshadowed amendment, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) was honest enough to say that there is always debate as to when is the right time or the wrong time to introduce a new tax. Of course there never is a right time. There can never be any right time to introduce a new tax on any industry and if a government is going to do it, if a government is going to decide to make that decision, it has to do it. We have made that decision and stick by it. I want to refer also to what I consider to be the somewhat cynical approach to this debate taken by some members of the Opposition. The honourable member for Wakefield stated categorically that the Opposition would repeal the wine tax. I can only be guided, as my good colleague the honourable member for Hunter is guided, by the remarks of the shadow Treasurer and former Treasurer of this country, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and honourable member for Bennelong. When asked by an Adelaide News journalist at the National Press Club on 29 August, the honourable member for Bennelong said:
I would have to agree with you that there are good arguments for equal tax treatment of all alcoholic beverages.

If we come down to being honest, he is saying that there are good arguments for equal tax treatment for all alcoholic beverages. He could implement such treatment only if honourable members opposite ever get back into government, and I do not think they will for many years. Let us examine his statement. The main tax is levied on beer. I have already said that the rate of taxation which applies to beer, which is consumed by many Australians, is 80 per cent. The tax we have introduced is 10 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the honourable member for Bennelong want 80 per cent on wine?

—I am asked by the honourable member for Hunter whether the honourable member for Bennelong wants an 80 per cent tax on wine. I do not know what rate of tax he would like to put on wine but he said that there are good arguments for equal tax treatment. If we put an 80 per cent tax on a $5 retail bottle of wine, its price would be jacked up to $9. I would then agree that that would devastate the industry. Of course it would. If we put a 155 per cent tax on cask wine, we would destroy that part of the industry too.

SPEECH.PARA: But let us look at the effect of this 10 per cent tax. What will it actually mean in terms of price? If we assume a 40 per cent mark-up on retail, a bottle that retails at the moment for $4-by most people's standards that would be a reasonable bottle of wine-would have a wholesale price of $2.40 and if we add a 10 per cent tax, which is equivalent to about 14 per cent on retail because it will be marked up, the net effect of the tax is to lift the price of that bottle from $4 to $4.56. That is the total effect. That is quite different from an 80 per cent tax which would lift it from $4 to nearly $8. We have to get up to the top end of the market and a retail price of $7 or $8 a bottle before the tax would add a dollar to the price.

Of course the effect on consumption is important. I acknowledge the concerns expressed about the effects that any tax might have on any industry and I acknowledge the concerns about the effects this tax will have on the wine industry. I can assure honourable members that I will be watching the effects of this tax very carefully. But in terms of the effect on demand, there have been a number of studies on the price elasticity of demand for wine. There have been studies by Tsolakis in 1982; by Clements and by Murphy. Tsolakis concluded that the elasticity of wine is -0.43. Clements estimated an elasticity of 0.43 and Murphy estimated an elasticity of -0.31. Based on those results we can assume that the price elasticity for wine is about -0.3 to -0.5. That means that the maximum effect which a 14 per cent increase in price would have on the demand for wine in Australia would be a reduction in consumption of 5 per cent. That is the maximum effect, on all evidence available to the Government.

To put that in context, it is very difficult to predict the future of the Australian wine industry. If we assume a continued growth of 7 per cent or 8 per cent in real terms per annum, as I think we should, no producer in Australia will be selling less wine than in the past because of this tax. In the last eight years there has been a growth in real terms of 8 per cent per annum. The worst effect that this tax will have is a reduction in demand of 5 per cent. We will still see an increase in demand for wine in Australia of more than 3 per cent in real terms. So producers will not be devastated. My final point is that wines for export, a growing sector of the Australian market, are totally unaffected by this tax. There will not be a 10 per cent sales tax on any wine produced for export. I think that is terrific for encouraging the development of export markets for Australian wine. I know that with the stronger economic conditions and the strong growth in wine production in Australia over recent years we will see increasing export of our wines in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to speak for long because I know that many honourable members want to speak on this Bill, particularly those whose areas depend on regional development. This Bill to impose a 10 per cent tax on wine will affect them very dramatically. I would like to take the House back to 20 February 1983 on which day I remember driving past the Yoogali Club in Griffith. I saw a great crowd gathered at the front. I was about to go into the club for a squash, as I usually do, but thought I had better not do so because it would be too difficult to get in. Then I realised what was going on. This was the famous deputation that the Australian Labor Party had sent to Griffith to make sure that it won the seat of Riverina. The Labor Party had thought that if the seat of Riverina fell it would be in government, so it brought all the big guns down to Griffith to see what they could do about the situation. As I recall , at that meeting were the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), at least two senators and the State Minister for Agriculture.
—He wouldn't help.

—No, he did not help at all. There were also a number of Labor Party dignitaries present. All those people were on the stage and a great crowd gathered in the hall. A speech was given which is now quite infamous. A number of promises were made in that hall on that day. Many of the people as they came out of the meeting said to themselves: 'At last we have a saviour of the primary industries of Australia. Wonderful promises have been made to us. We are right now. We are on the upward trail'. I will just recall one of the promises made then. It was a statement made by the honourable member for Wills, now the Prime Minister. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The wine industry is beset with problems. The industry is faced with a need to make bold decisions at a time of low profitability if the industry is to be in a position to meet the opportunities of the 1980s.
Labour has pledged not to impose a sales tax or an excise tax on wine.
That was not just a statement but actually 'a pledge not to impose a sales tax or an excise tax on wine'.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long ago?
—This was in 1983. To continue:

SPEECH.PARA: We will seek co-operation with the States to facilitate the establishment of grower regional councils. The Labor Government will examine the special problems faced by co-operative wineries and supplying growers.

The taxation disadvantages suffered by the wine makers with respect to stock holding will be objectively examined on the basis that wine making is a primary production process, not a manufacturing industry.

One of the things we have tended to forget tonight when talking about the wine industry is that it is primary production and not a manufacturing industry like beer production. I do not think anyone is really surprised that many of the promises made on that very hot day in Griffith were not kept. I have a book full of promises that were not kept. I will not go into all of these promises because there are so many of them that my 10 minutes would be up before I got through them, so I will leave them. My advice to members of the present Government is that, if they want to make a rural policy speech for the next election, they should not for heaven's sake go to Griffith or into the Riverina because I am sure that they would get a warm welcome which would not be the type of welcome they would expect.

In August 1983, not long after that promise was made, the excise on fortified spirit was brought in. It was $2.50 a litre, which was really $2.61 because it was indexed almost straightaway. It was only because of the great number of representations by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher), the honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron), myself and other Opposition members that that excise was nearly halved. It went down to $1.50 a litre. Of course, that was only a token gesture. I think the Government then realised the terrible mistake it had made. It had drawn one of these schemes out of a back cupboard but it did not go into it to see what effect it would have on the industry. I know that in the Riverina in particular, in South Australia, as the honourable member for Wakefield will agree, and in Victoria, as the honourable member for Indi and the honourable member for Mallee will agree, the Government almost destroyed the fortified wine industry. Fortunately just as it was about on its knees the Government decided to relent and did away with the iniquitous excise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Divine intervention.

—It could have been. It certainly was not because of any thinking on behalf of the Government. The Government realised the mistake and said: 'We will not have this excise. We will take it off'. Some of the people involved said: ' Gee, this Government is great. It has done a great job for us. It put an excise on. Now it has taken it off and it looks as though the Prime Minister at last will keep his pre-election promise. Everything will be rosy in the garden'. Of course, a number of the wine makers making fortified wines decided that they were not going to make fortified wines. They would fix the Government; they just would not make it. But some of those trying to employ people and to keep the wine industry going decided they would make it. After a great deal of representation by the honourable members I mentioned previously, fortunately it was decided that this excise would be refunded to those wineries on which this impost had been put. I know that as of last week certainly a number of those wineries still had not seen the colour of the money. I hope that there is 20 per cent interest on that money, as is imposed on those who do not pay their back taxes. I am looking forward to that.

SPEECH.PARA: The wine industry certainly had a little breathing space then. Those in the industry thought: 'We are right now'. Of course, then the Budget came down. What did we find in the Budget? When I first saw the Budget I thought: 'Hello, the Labor Party has done it again'. We remember that some years ago Mr Whitlam dropped section 31A. When I first became a member of the Parliament in 1980 the wineries still had not paid back the moneys owing because of the impost by the Government of that day. I just cannot work out what the Labor Party has against the wine industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor doesn't like farmers.
—I am sure of that. It is quite evident that Labor does not like farmers, the man on the land or small business of any type.
—They don't like the family.
—That is right.
— Order!

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is very difficult. I would like to tell the House a true story. I was in a place called Buronga, which is on the other side of the river from the electorate of the honourable member for Mallee. I went to speak to a market gardener there. He was working and I went to say hello. He was very upset. He was a gentleman of Italian origin, and we all know what good farmers those people are and how close they are to the land. He almost had tears in his eyes and he said: 'I had a bit of an argument with my son this morning. I was working in the glasshouse and around the farm and my son came to me and said : ''I hope you are not working like that for me from daylight to dark getting the return you are getting. If you are you can forget about it because there is no way I am going to work like you and get the return that you are getting. I would rather be one of those 1,500 people that Mr Hawke is putting on in the Department of Social Security and other departments. The life is a lot easier and you do not have to work as hard''.' This gentleman was very upset, and I think that really is the understanding of many people on the land. Let me mention some of the costs that are being imposed on the people on the land; there are so many that they will soon not be able to survive. The 10 per cent tax on wine is just one small indication of what the Government thinks of the people on the land. There is also a 15 per cent tariff on headers. We also have the deal that the Government did with the liquefied petroleum gas.
—What a shocker that was.

—It was a shocker; it was quick footwork and the Government dropped the $80 a tonne subsidy on LPG and then gave a little bit back. Everyone thought that was wonderful but the man on the land and in the country lost on that. There are excises on fuels, loss of markets through lack of government action overseas, strikes, increased prices and increased labour costs. Let me say that when there is a strike it is a looloo, and it is costing wheat growers and the people on the land. It is not only the primary producers but also the people in the provincial towns and cities who are having to pay for all of this. It is not good enough, and it is about time something was done about it. We are hearing so much about the prices and incomes accord, and I think it comes into the area of the 10 per cent sales tax also. The accord seems to me to be okay for big unions , big business and big government and, of course, it helps those governments who are big spenders.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the wine tax. A lot of people here are saying tonight that the imposition of a wine tax was bad timing. I am one of those people who are totally opposed to the wine tax. I know that the brewing industry has mounted a campaign in trying to have a tax imposed on the wine industry, and I can understand the beer industry's problem because it is taxed to a very high degree and I think it is about time that stopped. This Parliament seems to be talking all the time about adding taxes on. I think it is about time we started taking taxes off and stopped the big spending. If we would do that I think the nation would be far better off. I could not agree more with what a number of honourable members are saying here tonight: The timing is bad. We have troubles not only in the wine industry but also in the dried fruit industry. The honourable member for Wakefield, the honourable member for Mallee and myself were at a conference the other day when the troubles of the dried fruit industry were shown to be very great indeed. There is an overproduction there which could go into the wine industry. I have here a letter from the Australian Dried Fruits Association addressed to Mr Keating, the Treasurer. I must admit that I am deleting reference to grape spirit tax and inserting a reference to a tax on wine. The letter states:
Dear Sir,
The imposition of-
a tax on wine-
will place a financial burden on all grape growers, and particularly on the producers of Dried Vine Fruits.

The nature of the dried fruits industry, with its guarantee of equal returns on all fruit varieties delivered, means that the industry will be the ultimate recipient of most grapes diverted from the production of . . . wines. The Dried Vine Fruits industry is already experiencing a severe recession.

I know that the Treasurer in his Budget Speech said that a committee would investigate the problems within the wine industry. I wonder whether he is still talking about the committee that was promised during the election campaign and which was mentioned during a speech in Griffith. If it is, it is a long time coming. We keep getting these promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is too late; the tax is on.

—That is right. We have so many problems in the industry that I really think it is about time something was done. One thing that really surprises me is how Government members who are from the wine grape growing areas can stand up and support these Bills. That is the most surprising thing I have ever seen. Even Mr Bannon, the Premier of South Australia, had this to say under the heading 'Bannon astounded':

SPEECH.PARA: 'I am astounded that the Federal Government could have made this decision given the arguments that have been put before it over the past 12 months in relation to this industry,' . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he a Labor Premier?
—He is Labor to the bootstraps. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: During the debate in the House Mr Bannon said he had not been told there would be a tax until 20 minutes before the formal Budget announcement.
He said he had complained 'very vigorously' in discussions with Mr Hawke yesterday morning.

It was hard to estimate in precise terms the immediate effect of the tax. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics had predicted a 4 per cent drop in sales in the short-term and 'over time' 13.5 per cent.
Here is the crunch, Mr Deputy Speaker:
'If that happens then that would cause very severe problems indeed,' he said.
The Department of State Development in the past had suggested that 300 jobs could be lost in the short-term and 1300 in the long-term.
I would say that that position would also be reflected in the Riverina.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Maranoa.

—And Maranoa, as the honourable member for Maranoa says. Finally, I quote what the President of the Wine and Brandy Producers' Association, Sir Don McWilliam, told the Bulletin. He said that many problems facing the grape growing and wine industries could be resolved if they were 'left alone' for five years and the setting of minimum prices for grapes in South Australia was ended.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress that. It is time that many industries were left alone. With high taxes and imposts from the Government in particular, the prices that the producers have to pay for their fertilisers, sprays, water, rates and everything is cruelling primary industry, and the wine industry is no exception. It is time they were left alone. I am sure that if the wine industry had been left alone, if the committee had been set up when the Government said it would be, it would not have the problems it has today.

I totally oppose this 10 per cent tax. I go along with the amendment and I would like it to be on record that I oppose any tax on wine. I do not agree that the Government can say that because there is a tax on other alcoholic beverages wine has to be taxed. It is like saying: 'If I cut my arm off, you cut yours off too'. That is no reason at all. I would just like my feelings to be known. I totally support the amendment and I am sure that all members of the Opposition also support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I put my name forward to debate these relatively minor Bills, the Sales Tax (Nos 1 to 9) Amendment Bills, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2), I intended to speak about the inequity in the excise system, about the sales tax avoidance issue in terms of sales tax for exporting and reimporting, and particularly to make some comments about the reduction in the excise on low alcohol beer. Then I saw the list and discovered there were eight speakers from the Opposition, so I went through the Bills again thinking: 'Gosh, eight speakers. They will be finding some things that I must not know about'. I could not find what they were looking for so I thought I had better sit in and listen. I thought I must not miss a single word because obviously there will be a lot of gems of wisdom about things that are not apparent. I have now sat through three speeches and I ask honourable members to consider what has been said.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous Treasurer spent 25 of his 30 minutes talking about the Budget in general, and he was the lead speaker. I thought that if the issue warranted eight speakers the Opposition would make its lead speaker talk about the issue and the secondary speakers could go off on tangents. We have not yet had a reasoned argument about the legislation. There has been no mention of the tax avoidance issue or of the reduction in low alcohol excise. All we have had has been a lot of ranting and raving. In fact the last speech was, without doubt, a campaign opening for the seat of Farrer, not the seat of Riverina. Clearly it was aimed at Farrer. At the campaign speech for the seat of Riverina in February of last year another promise was made, the promise of a million dollar loan to the Leeton cannery, which the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) handed over. He did not mention that promise tonight. That million dollars was handed over by him as promised by Mr Hawke in that campaign speech in February 1983. There was not one mention of that promise being kept, and being kept promptly and properly.

Mr Deputy Speaker, what we have had is rather unfortunate. I would have thought that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, would show us the areas in which he has credibility, such as immigration. Mind you, he was four months too late, but still the credibility was there. But for him to start speaking about promises, projections, Budget deficits and the like just does not wash with the Australian community. Very clearly his record over five years as Treasurer has sunk in very profoundly. The man lacks credibility. He lacks capacity and standing in the Australian community on economic matters. His record is such that it is not to be respected or believed. In fact, in the last few days of the election campaign in 1983 when word was about that the $6 billion projected deficit was shonkey, the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was publicly forced to back down and say: 'Mind you, we assume that they have told us the truth'. He has since proven that that was a false assumption. In effect that whole campaign was based on a set of deceitful and false assumptions and premises put forward by the government of the day. Those who had access to information misled not only the public but also the then Opposition. In fact, as I said, it was not with any great relish that the then Opposition had to give a warning in the last few days of that campaign which was based on what was happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this to do with the wine tax?

—I am speaking about a 25-minute speech on this legislation-25 minutes of rhetoric from a discredited ex-Treasurer. It is obvious why he is the ex-Treasurer. The fascinating part of the 25-minute speech was this final comment: 'Well, we are not really opposed to the idea or the concept-it is only the timing'. It is quite clear that the Opposition cannot oppose these amendments in principle because they are sound amendments. All that it can put forward as a campaign topic is timing. Of course, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) made the fascinating comment: 'We all agree that with taxation any timing is bad; however, this is worse than most'. That is a fascinating piece of mental arithmetic. The mental gymnastics involved are quite fascinating. That particular gentleman suggests that he is the one who knows when is best or when is worst. I find that quite interesting because the shadow Treasurer in his comments a few weeks ago did not mention timing. He mentioned only the equity as being a reasonable thing to put forward. Suddenly, timing is important. Of course, the irony is that no member of parliament would oppose the proposition that taxation increases of any kind are always difficult. One of the problems of this country has been the shirking of responsibility by those who have occupied the treasury benches for 31 of the last 35 years. As a result we have perhaps one of the most secular and most discriminatory revenue raising systems in the world because they always avoided the difficult issues. I think we are seeing tonight just how and where this has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought that my colleague the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) put forward some very interesting and sound arguments. They were arguments that in fact I would have expected the Opposition to put forward if the data were different. Clearly the data is such as to white-ant its capacity to put forward any constructive argument. The fact is that no facts can be put forward which substantially demolish this legislation. The timing is the only argument that the Opposition can put forward. I think we will hear more about timing in the months ahead when the Opposition tries to avoid its responsibility and tries to duck-shove around what it would do based on the record of what it has not done in the past.

I also find fascinating the suggestion by the honourable member for Riverina-I should call him the new honourable member for Farrer-that as a result of his Party's representations the fortified wine tax was halved. In other words, on the one hand the Opposition is helpless and powerless against this dreadful Government and, on the other hand, the tax was halved last year because the Opposition is so effective. The Opposition cannot have it both ways. It is either ineffective or powerless or it is effective. If the Opposition were effective this tax would not have to be imposed because it would have found grounds as to why it should not be imposed.

Let us get to the real issue of the fear the Opposition is creating with regard to the import of wines. The import of wine is a serious matter, as is the import penetration of any Australian market. The fact is that the import problem will not be solved by not applying sales taxes or varying sales taxes. If imported wine is being subsidised by other governments appropriate action is available. Not one speaker tonight has raised the question of actions available to deal with dumped goods in Australia. If wine is being dumped, why has not one of the three Opposition speakers who have taken part in this debate suggested that positive courses are available? In fact, quite separate machinery is available to deal with tariff-import penetration. One does not use sales tax in competition with imports if the imports are being unfairly brought into the country or unfairly costed. There is machinery under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to address that. Why has not that matter been raised? Why has it not been mobilised? All the ranting and raving on the other side is in fact just that. Honourable members opposite have not addressed the question of import penetration. If this is a serious matter-and I suspect it is-let us address it in a positive and constructive way and not use it as some half-baked excuse as to why the wine industry should not in fact be dealt with equitably within the alcoholic beverages industry.

Speaking of equity, I notice in recent days the fascinating paradox that the excise increase in the last Budget of about 2.5c on a schooner of beer caused quite a massive outcry in the brewing industry and in the hotel industry in particular. In fact, I notice last week a suggestion that the 3c a schooner decrease in the excise on low alcohol or light beer is in fact too small to pass on. In other words, it is not substantial enough to pass on to the consumer whereas the increase last year, which was slightly less, was in fact the cause of major concern and created a major outcry. I am most disappointed that the hotel industry has not seen fit to convey back to the consumer one of the benefits of the recent Budget, which is a positive incentive to try to reduce the alcohol content in liquor that is being consumed.

We on this side of the House of course must express disappointment because any taxation revenue raising will not be easy for any government but that is no reason why we should run away from the issue. The amendments put forward in this legislation are in fact serious ones because they seek to remove anomalies in tax avoidance then produce an incentive for people to consume lower alcohol beer . They bring into the taxation area wine consumption, which is important. The Opposition has trumpeted its support for a consumption tax for a long time. This is a consumption tax. In that sense this tax is very equitable when compared with other taxation. When we bring a consumption tax forward the Opposition suddenly says: 'Hey, you should not-it is the wrong time'. Yet, we heard a 25- minute speech on how this Budget will increase the structural deficit and cause massive problems in the next Budget. But at the same time the Opposition opposes the introduction of an equitable consumption tax that in fact contributes to revenue. I find the contradictions most apparent and I do not doubt that the Australian public will find them equally apparent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in the parallel that the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) drew in relation to the question of the tax on wine and the desirability of it not being on the basis that the tax was desirable but simply because it was a new tax it was not a matter that the Government itself should run away from. Taking his analogy to its logical conclusion, one would equally expect him to be standing up in this place arguing in favour of a capital gains tax about which we hear from time to time, simply because it is a new tax and something that the Government should not be running away from. I suspect that because a capital gains tax is likely to affect far more people and is not a sectional tax in the way in which the wine tax is which is likely to impact in specific electorates, it will not be a course to which the honourable member will address himself at least before an election.

SPEECH.PARA: Some comments were made by Government members who preceded me about the speech of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). They have suggested that it was perhaps somewhat unusual that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition addressed himself to the wider budgetary references in his address tonight. I would simply say that if one looks at the Government's timetable for consideration of legislation one would appreciate why the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would have addressed himself to the wider budgetary implications of this legislation and other aspects of the Government's Budget because, quite frankly, considerable hours were to be allocated this week for discussion of the Appropriation Bills. It will be appreciated by you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and other honourable members that under the new program that has been submitted to us Budget Bills and other Bills are being brought in and the discussion of appropriation generally is not proceeding. The obvious implication from that is that the Government is desirous of getting its legislation through and is not providing for proper discussion of the Budget itself. The Government is doing this to facilitate its objective of getting to the polls with as little discussion as possible of the Budget and the important issues that are involved in it. I do not apologise and I am sure the Deputy Leader of the Opposition does not apologise for addressing the wider implications of the Budget in this opportunity to discuss the first Budget Bills that have been introduced by this Government.

The legislation at which we are looking relates to what is known as broadly based indirect taxation. We are dealing with a number of sales tax Bills. I wish to address myself to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill. That Bill covers a number of matters. It picks up some particular questions relating to the Government's new tax on wine. The only extent to which I will refer to the wine tax is simply to note that there was a time when the area that I represent claimed some credit in relation to wine growing. I was formerly the member for Parra- matta. We took great pride in the district. Parra - matta was the first place in which wine was grown in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first place for criminals.

—It was the first place in which many things took place. Flight was one matter which was mentioned. There was also the matter of wheat. Many agricultural products were first grown in Parramatta. In my electorate of Dundas there is the very well known and highly regarded James Ruse Agricultural High School which is of great agricultural fame. The character of the electorate has changed over time, with the exception of the James Ruse school. We do not have the same grape growing or wheat growing industries. We have other industries. For that reason I will address myself to the sales tax implications of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act because it does impact upon my electorate and upon particular businesses that operate from my electorate. I hope that the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), who is at the table, will take note of the points I intend to make in the short time allotted to me. I hope that the Minister and his colleagues will give consideration to amending further this Act of Parliament at the first available opportunity. If they do not, no doubt I and my colleagues will give consideration to this question after the election.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter I raise concerns the plight of some 20 companies in Australia which manufacture souvenirs and stuffed toys with musical movements, particularly the koala. In item 43 of the second schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act we find that musical boxes and other goods incorporating musical movements are covered. Products falling into this category are taxable at the rate of 32.5 per cent. Yet similar items which do not have musical movements are taxed at the rate of 20 per cent. Historically, musical movements have always attracted the highest sales tax category there is. The musical movement component in the manufactured item is only a small part of the production cost of the finished article. Yet because the manufacturer seeks to make his product more attractive to the market he is penalised to the tune of an extra 12.5 per cent.

I have been told that seven companies in New South Wales are involved in this industry; two in South Australia; six in Victoria; three in Queensland and two in Western Australia. It is estimated that those companies employ directly some 2,000 people. That is certainly not a major industrial group, but nevertheless it is an important industry. In view of the emphasis that has been placed on the growth in tourism and ancillary services the manufacture of these items is an increasingly important industry. I hope that honourable members will take note of the state of this industry which estimates that its work force has probably halved over the last five years or so. The information I have is that this has occurred as a result of the way in which the industry has been discriminated against, as a result of the differential arrangement in the way in which the sales tax is levied on the koala, depending upon whether it has a musical component incorporated in it.

The industry would like to see items manufactured here, with or without musical components, attracting the same rate of tax. At a time of heightened national spirit, when all Australians are looking towards our bicentenary celebrations in 1988, surely it behoves the Government to look closely at this matter. Manufacturers are able to show that koalas which include a musical movement-I have some here which I will show honourable members-which play tunes such as Waltzing Matilda are definitely of more appeal to both local and overseas tourists than those without a musical movement. However, the additional cost resulting from the 12.5 per cent sales tax on the musical component puts them well behind in sales competitiveness. That is the reason their sales have dropped. There has been a reduction in the number of people involved in the manufacture of these novelties. Musical movements such as I have described are not manufactured in Australia. There is limited scope for the establishment of such production. Many of the koalas and similar items are hand made. Manufacturers estimate that between 50 per cent and 75 per cent of their costs are labour charges. Government action to alleviate the problem I have raised would certainly assist the manufacturers in stabilising employment prospects and security within the industry and should, therefore, appeal to a government which purports to be concerned about increasing unemployment.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I have with me a musical movement. Perhaps like the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) you can see that it is only a fairly small item. I am sorry that it is playing. I had not wound it deliberately. That item is covered. It can be incorporated fairly easily in a bear. As honourable members can see, the koala with the red ribbon is the one that has not had the component incorporated in it. The koala with the blue ribbon has had the musical component incorporated in it. The people who have the opportunity of making a choice would, I think, take the one that has a musical component in it if it could be incorporated for a lower price.

I understand that the component costs about $1.36. If the manufacturer chooses to use that item in his production he increases the price of his koala. The koala with the blue ribbon would have a price of something of the order of $9 over the price of the koala with the red ribbon which does not have a musical component incorporated in it. In 1983 a size 8 koala without a musical component retailed at $22 while a koala with a musical component carrying the extra 12.5 per cent sales tax was priced at $29. For visitors to Australia who are on a budget the difference of $7 is considerable. Certainly it is enough to sway them to the cheaper product despite the fact that they would perhaps prefer the model with the musical component incorporated in it. I hope that the Government will review the differential pricing of these products. I hope that the sales tax can be levied at the same rate and not at a higher rate simply because one item has a musical component included in it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been an interesting debate tonight. I had the impression that most of the time would have been spent discussing the merits of the specific pieces of legislation. If not that, I would have thought there would have been a discussion in general terms about the desirability or otherwise of an extension to the indirect tax base. That would have seemed to be the logical way for the debate to proceed given the current consideration of the whole issue of broadly based consumption taxes and so on. But we seem to have had a range of peculiar digressions, the last one being the most bizarre of all, when we had a discussion of soft toys with musical movements, which I thought might have been part of the Opposition's internal deliberations to find a new leader after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: The broad issues associated with the imposition of the new tax and its impact on the wine industry have been addressed. There has been some discussion about the effects that the introduction of this tax will have on the consumption and sale of wines. Again, I find it extraordinary that members of the Opposition, the overwhelming majority of whom would presumably want to put people in prison for consuming marihuana, are being so terribly upset about the introduction of a tax or an impost which they fear will bring about a reduction in the consumption of a product which, accordingly to all available medical evidence, is demonstrably more harmful to people's health than marihuana. It is an amazing and an astonishing double standard and one which will never cease to amaze me. In speaking on this legislation, I am in the fortunate position of not actually representing a wine producing electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good consumers.

—By the same token, as the honourable member for Hunter points out, Balmain, which is part of my electorate, is renowned for its activity at the consumption end of the industry. Unless we have a debate about whether the tax falls primarily on the producers or the consumers, which is an interesting point to pursue, arguably I do not have quite the same need to defend the wine industry and its current production levels as do, apparently, those honourable members who represent wine producing electorates.
—I thought the Gucci marxists might be concerned about the price.

—That is what I was saying; not that there are any of them in the Australian Labor Party in the Sydney electorate. This legislation is not a major part of the Government's budgetary processes or economic strategy. It represents a marginal extension of the indirect tax base, a new product brought within the ambit of the wholesale sales tax and some rationalisation of the rates at which taxes are levied on different forms of alcoholic beverage. There is a range of other provisions within these pieces of legislation, but I will talk about that in general terms.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to look at the whole issue of indirect tax. It is one illustration, I guess, of the extension of the indirect tax base where it is unclear what will be the effect on the equity of the overall tax system. The general presumption-and it is a presumption that is embodied in the prices and incomes accord, which is the centrepiece of this Government's economic approach- is that there is a general aversion to the idea of extending the indirect tax base. This matter, as I am sure most honourable members would be aware, was debated at the National Conference of the Party. The fear within the trade union movement is that a broad based consumption tax would reduce the overall equity of the tax system. When this issue is generally discussed it is normally couched in terms of a very broad based overhaul of the tax system that would include the introduction perhaps of a broad based consumption tax, along with some other forms of new taxes which aim to restore a degree of equity in the tax system which was lost by the introduction of a new type of indirect tax. That implies the introduction of taxes on capital gains, wealth or wealth transfers. That is the sort of broad issue that must be considered.

It is unclear in this case what would be the effect of the introduction of a wine tax and whether it would impact mainly on those people who consume cask wine or those who consume bottled wine. Obviously, there is a significant differentiation between the sort of people who consume those two types of wine. It is unclear whether in effect one would be taxing a luxury good or a good with a widespread consumption. It is an interesting illustration of the point that extension of the indirect tax base is not necessarily a bad thing in equity terms.

I will make some brief remarks about the contribution of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to this debate. Again, it was a contribution that seemed to pertain only in the most marginal sense to the actual substantial matters that are before the House. He took the opportunity to launch into a wide -ranging attack on the Government's macro-economic strategy as outlined in the Budget that was brought down two weeks ago. In some ways it was a little difficult to follow his argument. He seemed to talk about a number of different things. On the one hand he focused on the fact that estimates of the growth in real outlays, which are estimated to be 6.1 per cent in 1984-85, outstrip the projected real growth in the gross domestic product. Of course he ignored, as he did the other week in his question to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the fact that the introduction of Medicare is a one-off factor in which there has been the transfer of what was previously a private consumption expenditure to the public sector, which therefore produces a one-off boost in the size of outlays. If one is trying to draw any broad conclusions, that is not really valid. As the Treasurer pointed out at the time, if we take out the introduction of Medicare, the growth in the real outlays figure falls from 6.1 per cent to 3.9 per cent which is roughly in the same range as the growth in GDP, as projected in the Budget Papers. Even without doing that, we are looking at a marginal increase in outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product from 30.5 per cent to 31.1 per cent; in other words, a 0.6 per cent increase, a very marginal increase if we look at the proportions that apply to other comparable advanced countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. It is not an exceptionally large figure. To draw some broad inference that disaster waits around the corner as a result of such growth is simply ludicrous.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition seemed to hint at a quite separate point- that is, the issue of the deficit. He referred to the one-off boost in receipts arising from the very rapid growth in provisional tax receipts and so on, which is certainly true. That is a one-off factor. But it does not therefore follow that the problems with the Budget deficit will become intractable next year. What needs to be borne in mind is that hopefully the economy will continue to move closer to a full employment position over time. The projections that have been made about growth in output and employment growth suggest that that will happen. If that occurs, we can expect a continued decline in the so-called cyclical component of the Budget deficit. Hopefully, that would mean a reduction in the overall Budget deficit. Even though the very substantial receipts growth that we will see in this financial year might not be repeated in subsequent financial years, it does not necessarily follow that, taking all things into consideration, we will see a blowing out of the Budget deficit which, as I say, is a separate point from the first point made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

I also make the obvious point that the tax cuts that have been introduced do not entail any movement in the threshold areas in the tax scale. They also involve the introduction of a new 48 per cent band, which, assuming that inflation continues at some level, implies that the normal effects of the fiscal drag of people moving into higher tax brackets would result in the recoupment of some of that tax cut. Possibly, that is not the sort of thing that one should say. Nonetheless, if one is looking at the broad picture down the track, there is no particular reason to suppose that the problems associated with the Budget deficit will become intractable.

I will conclude at this point because we have been told to cut back our remarks so that the leg- islation will be passed tonight. I have canvassed some points relating both to the legislation and to some of the arguments and points that were put in the course of the debate. As I said, some of them bore only the most marginal relationship to the specific pieces of legislation that are before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Government has said that it is committed to economic growth. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) promised on 20 February 1983, in a desperate bid to win a couple of federal electorates that 'Labor will not introduce a wine tax'. It is difficult to understand how it has allowed itself to be coerced by the brewing lobby, in a desperate attempt to raise money to pay for its high spending programs. This tax is an act of stupidity. In the near future it will be seen to be so. As with the infamous fortified wine tax which had to be removed because it was destroying the industry, so I believe will this tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) earlier in the debate expressed concern about this tax and attempted to justify its implementation. I challenge them both to show their real concern for their electorates, to cross the floor and vote against this legislation. They have outstanding large and small boutique winemakers in their areas, but of course they will not cross the floor. They have signed their social manifesto. In the 12 years that I have been in this place I have yet to witness one member of the Australian Labor Party crossing the floor on any issue . Because of this they simply just cannot represent their electorates. Their electorates will be most severely affected by this tax as will the electorates of many members of the Opposition. The honourable member for Bendigo also mentioned an outstanding Australian product, that outstanding champagne, Great Western, but this legislation clearly indicates to me that the socialist Government members on the other side of the House much prefer Bollinger to Great Western. In my view they have certainly developed a preference for the French rather than for the Australian grown wines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Champagne socialists.

—That is exactly right. I believe this legislation will have the effect of increasing the percentage of imported wines that are consumed in this country, wines which now have a 10 per cent advantage on our local product which they did not have prior to the Budget. Successive Federal governments have recognised the fragility of the entire wine industry for years and have avoided threatening its long term viability through taxation. One previous attempt to impose a similar tax on wine failed and was subsequently repealed. The 10 per cent sales tax will have an adverse effect on the industry at a time when it is faced with overproduction of grapes, intense competition and diminishing returns . The tax will severely reduce wine sales without promoting an increase in beer sales. It will threaten employment in the wine industry and will exacerbate the plight of grape growers. Of course, it will increase dumping of overseas wines especially from the European Economic Community wine lake.

SPEECH.PARA: This tax will result in a fall in consumption of an estimated 40 million litres of wine per annum, equivalent to the grape growers throughout Australia of some 50,000 tonnes of grapes. The honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) mentioned that this tax was only marginal. Of course it is only marginal to the 15 million consumers in Australia but it is not marginal for the few thousand grape growers who will have to pay up to $62m a year extra tax because of this measure. The grape growing industry, which the Industries Assistance Commission has identified as being in a disastrous state, will be placed in jeopardy. Average grape production in Australia amounts at present to some 800,000 tonnes of which up to 100,000 tonnes is already surplus production channelled into dried fruit production and presently exported at a massive loss. The only alternative use for these grapes is increased wine production, and this outlet will now be denied the grape growers of Australia.

Grape production in Australia is located in a number of decentralised rural communities and the economic hardship caused by the sales tax on wine will be disproportionately borne by these communities. The grape industry is a vital source of employment for some 7,300 people employed in the grape growing sector and for another 5,600 in wine production, with thousands more employed in distribution and retailing. The devastating consequences of any recession in the Australian wine industry will be felt more strongly in South Australia, Victoria , New South Wales and Western Australia. These States have defended a burgeoning industry against the selfish, short-sighted attacks of those who place their own needs above the long term stability of a valuable industry.

This new wine tax, as I have said, is expected to cost the industry up to $62m in a full year. I am concerned that there will be a massive loss in production and a short fall in revenue to the Government. This will make the Government realise its stupidity, as it did with the ill-conceived fortified wine tax and it will be forced to reduce this severe impost. The decision to refund tax collected under the fortified wine tax had to be made or double taxation would have been imposed on the wine industry. We have now seen the Hawke Government in its two years in office introduce two taxation measures to the detriment of thousands of small grape growers. One does not have to believe members of the Opposition to see how disastrous the effect will be on the industry. I will quote from a letter that the Premier of South Australia has written to the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating). The letter states:
I wish to express the deepest concern about the unexpected decision by the Federal Government to introduce a general sales tax of 10 per cent on wine.

This decision will not only be regressive in terms of its effect on the industry but will have a discriminatory impact on South Australia and the regional economy of the Riverland in particular. These arguments have been put before and were reflected in your press statement of 22 June 1984, announcing the removal of the excise on grape spirit.

I am astounded that the Federal Government could have made this decision given the arguments that have been put before it over the past twelve months in relation to this industry. Particular aspects of this tax that seem to have not been properly evaluated in making your decision are:
1. The discriminatory impact on this State-
the Premier could have said 'on all wine growing areas of Australia'-

which is likely to occur because of reduced Australian wine sales and hence grape intake following the 10 per cent sales tax impost. South Australia produces over half of the wine made in Australia and harvests more than half of wine grapes grown.

2. In view of the well-authenticated existence of vast 'wine-lakes' in European Economic Community countries and their heavy subsidisation of wine exports, it is surprising to read at page 21 of your speech:
'This reduction in protection is not expected to result in any significant increase in wine imports.'

No one on this side of the House could have better put the effects on the grape growing industry as did the Labor Premier of South Australia. I believe the Government has compounded its stupidity, at the same time as it applied an impost, by announcing that an inquiry would be undertaken into the problems of the grape industry. I would have thought that an inquiry into the problems of the grape industry should have come before imposing the impost. Mr Deputy Speaker, I conclude simply by saying--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should note the occupant of the Chair or I might be forced to take some action.

—I am sorry, Mr Speaker, I had not seen the changeover. Mr Speaker, I conclude by saying that this Government should immediately introduce anti- dumping action against dried vine fruit, wine and spirit imports from the EEC. It should immediately introduce trading stock valuation adjustments for stocks of alcoholic beverages, particularly where they must be seen as the result of federal legislation, for example, the maturation of brandy. I believe the Government must immediately instigate a conference so that the local alcoholic beverage industry-wine, beer and spirits-can negotiate a rational and equitable tax policy both for domestic production and imports to include consideration of the imposition of State liquor taxes. What the grape growing industry in this country needs is a predictable policy. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has estimated that horticultural farm incomes in 1983-84 will fall from $209 to $153 per week.
—How much?

—From $209 per week, which is well below what is estimated to be the poverty level in this country. I believe that these figures indicate that it is hardly the time to further burden grape growers with even more taxation. I represent thousands of small grape growers. I do not necessarily support this impost on the consumer but I do believe the consumer can probably bear it. I am absolutely certain that the grape growers cannot bear it. For that reason I totally oppose the legislation, and we will repeal it when we are in Government.

INTERJECT.PARA: I make it clear that this is an area I know a lot about, having been an owner of hotels for a long time. I will come to that area shortly. REDGATE WINES
of
MARGARET RIVER
wish to announce
THE CESSATION OF PRODUCTION OF PREMIUM WINES
as a result of economic sabotage to the wine industry in general and to the small grower in particular emanating from THE FISCAL POLICIES OF THE FEDERAL GOVT. contained in the last budget.

The message was to Australian winegrowers, particularly the people of the Swan Valley, who changed their vote and voted out a Liberal candidate in the State election. Burke stands condemned--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to the Prime Minister as such.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr TUCKEY

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to the bumper sticker. He was not the Prime Minister at that stage, he was Hawke.
