INTERJECT.PARA: There is another issue that has not been touched on very greatly tonight. I am terribly disappointed that the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety, the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), has left the House. I believe she has a genuine interest in saving people's lives on the road. She has a complete and total lack of knowledge of what alcohol in beer means. The other day when I got up and attacked the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) when he sanctimoniously talked about the great interest that this Government has in road safety-he was, of course, referring to its penurious $2. 9m expenditure on road safety promotion-I asked him why it was necessary to increase the cost of low alcohol beer. He knows so little about it that he thought I was talking about the 3 per cent alcohol beer that this Government has reduced the excise on. Three per cent alcohol beer has a lower alcohol content than 5 per cent or 6 per cent alcohol beer which is the most popular drink in Australia. But the new beer produced, known as Swan Special Light, which is the subject of these Bills, and which is to be taxed at 20 per cent, is just below 1 per cent in alcohol content. That is achieved by a special process. The process is one of taking normal 5 per cent or 6 per cent alcohol beer and with the aid of a vacuum process evaporate the alcohol content. It is real beer. The honourable member for Lilley said the other day that it is not real beer. The Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, so stupidly said, 'It is not real beer; I refuse you the right to market it as beer'. The best thing in the world that could be achieved for Australia and the road toll is to convince every Australian not only that it is real beer, but also that they should all drink it . If they did drink it, as has been confirmed and is now publicly advertised, they would drown themselves in the stuff before they could achieve a 0.05 or a 0 .08 blood alcohol level. If anybody suggests that they could not do that with beer with a 3 per cent alcohol content, they should think again. It takes a little longer to get drunk, but one can still achieve all the criminal activity on the road with the aid of 3 per cent alcohol beer as one can with 5 per cent or 6 per cent alcohol beer.

This Government has done two things; it has compounded the problem. It has reduced the price of a beer that can still cause danger on the roads and it has increased the price of a beer that does not cause such danger. The compounded problem is that the Government has created a financial disincentive of 10 cents a can, roughly 20 cents a large bottle, against drinking the product that would save lives on the road because it is impossible to drink it and be a drunk driver. But then, of course, Premier Wran--
Mr Fisher-But there's profit in it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr TUCKEY

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, yes. There is profit in this. There is $6m a year profit to the Government in this. Of course, out of that it is taking $2.9m for road safety promotion. We would not need road safety promotion in many respects if we could create circumstances where people had an acceptable drink on social occasions which did not affect their driving ability. That is what I am talking about with that particular beer. But as I said, the Premier of New South Wales would not even accept it. He would not have it declared a beer. He did not want people to want to drink it. He would rather that they drink 3 per cent beer so that he could send out his constables on to the roads because he has another great revenue component from the fines he can collect from some people who accidentally take that extra glass.

INTERJECT.PARA: So there is a real problem in this regard and one for which the Government can take equal blame. It can count the deaths on the road from here on in and claim a percentage for itself because that is what it will mean. I think this is a disastrous situation and one which shows completely the economic tunnel vision of the Government. It never thinks of the real costs. As a member of the Road Safety Committee I heard figures such as $200m a year thrown around as the real cost to the Australian people of road accidents. Of course, there are many costs there. I appreciate that this is all the time I have to speak tonight, but I think it was worth raising those few points.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to express my concern and the concern of all South Australian members on this side of the House about the effect that these taxes will have on the wine industry throughout Australia and particularly in South Australia. It should be remembered by the House that just before the last election the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said clearly and unequivocally in Griffith that he would not impose a sales tax on wine. I do not think that a statement could be much clearer, but despite that promise, the Government appeared to be determined to break its word and it did so in the first Labor Budget. In that Budget the Government imposed a tax on fortified spirit. The Opposition at the time warned of the disastrous consequences of that tax and when our warnings rang true the Government first reduced and then dropped the tax. Now, big heartedly, it says it will refund the revenue collected. The question I ask is when? Perhaps the Minister for Housing and Construction and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford), who is at the table, in wrapping up the debate will give an indication of when that revenue will be refunded.

SPEECH.PARA: After the first sortie into this field by the Government one would think that it would have learnt a lesson--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are slow learners.

—Indeed, as the honourable member for Wakefield rightly says, unfortunately for the wine industry this Government appears to have more than its fair share of slow learners. After the first sortie the wine industry is still feeling the effects of that tax. One would think that the Government could not be so foolhardy as to rush back into the chaos it had created and impose another tax at this time, but unfortunately for the wine industry that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the timing of the imposition of this tax. What will be the effect on the wine industry? I refer to a document from the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association which estimates lost sales to wine makers of 40 million litres per annum in the long term and reduced intake of grapes from grape growers of 65,000 tonnes which would result in lost income to grape growers of $ 15.6m per annum. That is the effect that the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association believes this tax will have directly on wine growers and wine makers in Australia.

In addition the situation facing the dried vine fruits industry is very pessimistic with the prospect of surpluses and the loss of export markets. Not only is the industry faced with losing export markets, but now the opportunities to sell to wine producers have been killed off as a result of this Government's wine tax. The Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association's figures clearly show that wine producers will not be increasing their intake of grapes this year , but will be reducing it. The dried vine fruits industry is facing a very serious situation and, as the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) said, has now had another door slammed in its face.

The timing of this tax is even worse when one considers the plight of this industry, given the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimate over the last two years that the real farm cash operating surplus for horticulturists has dropped from $290 a week to an estimate this year of $153 a week. The failure of this Government to appreciate the direct and indirect effect of this tax is horrifying. Not only is the timing disastrous, but also the tax itself, imposed on domestic wine producers and advantaging importers, is quite wrong.

The effect of the tax will be that imported wine will continue to be landed at around the same price as before, while the price of Australian wine has been increased by 10 per cent. In the face of increasing dumped wine imports, the growing wine surpluses in the European Economic Community, the subsidised EEC production and the protection against competition in the EEC, the Government has moved to increase the competitive advantage of wine imports. This outrageous action highlights the Government's total failure to comprehend the consequences of its action. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has admitted this discrimination against domestic producers. I quote from an article in the Australian Financial Review of 23 August which states:
He--
that is, the Minister for Primary Industry-
conceded that the introduction of a 10 per cent levy would reduce the effective level of protection against imports from about 34 per cent to 25 per cent . . .
The article continues:

The general manager of Montrose Wines, Mr John Swann, claimed Mr Kerin told a Wine Press Club function in Sydney last June that at least five year's warning would be given before the Government imposed any tax on wine.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has lost track of time.

—It must have lost track of time. I wonder just what statements issuing out of the mouths of Ministers of this Government can be believed. Before the last election the Prime Minister said there would be no wine tax. Now we have seen the Government impose two wine taxes. The Minister for Primary Industry said before the election that there would be no wine tax. Subsequently he said if there were, the wine industry would be given five years notice. Obviously, Ministers of this Government cannot be trusted. Their word is not their bond.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister and the Government have not been so forthright about the consequences of their action, but the Budget Papers are more revealing. The Budget Papers forecast that the new Customs duty on imported wine will raise $3m this year and $4m in a full year. The same Customs duty on imported wine in 1982 -83 would have raised around $2.8m. The revenue increase therefore is from $2.8m to $4m for a full year. What does that indicate in relation to the expected imports of wine? Clearly it indicates that the Government believes there will be a 40 per cent increase in imports of wine as a result of the discriminatory action against local wine producers. The resulting reduction in domestic wine sales will hit hardest in the areas which can least afford it, for example, the Riverland in South Australia. The Government belatedly heeded the warnings of the Opposition and the industry in its previous attempts to tax this industry. It must act immediately to withdraw this untimely tax.

Finally I raise a matter of serious concern regarding the campaign suddenly launched before the Budget by the beer industry in favour of a tax on wine. Normally such a campaign would be launched in the formulative stages of the Budget. Why this year was it launched almost on election eve? One can only guess that it was a Government inspired campaign to soften up the electorate before the untimely tax was imposed. I repeat that the Government has broken its promise to the wine industry; it is up to its neck in skulduggery and for the sake of the thousands of people who will suffer as a result of this untimely tax , it must be repealed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that it is late in the evening and that I have been allowed a little time during this debate on the Sales Tax (Nos 1 to 9) Amendment Bills and cognate Bills. There have been many good contributions from both sides of the House. The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) and others who have vast areas of vines within their electorate have indicated a great deal of sympathy for the plight of the wine grower today. I do not want to canvass the matters that have been canvassed so adequately by honourable members on both sides tonight other than to make a couple of points. The first point that I do not think anyone has raised is that the growing of vines for the production of wine is a primary industry. It involves planting and cultivating vines and nurturing them for five to seven years before full production is achieved. It is not like turning on the tap or the vat at the local brewery or soft drink factory. It is one of those primary industry areas in which something has to be grown for a number of years before full production is reached. To put a tax on wine is like putting a similar tax on beef, grain or lamb. Why do we not tax any of those primary industries that go through the same machinations to get to a production stage?

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that the important segment of quality wine production comes from the south of Western Australia-from Margaret River in the far south-west and the Plantagenet Shire in the lower Great Southern region. I have represented Margaret River since I entered the House in 1972. Plantagenet remains in the seat of O'Connor, though it is very much a part of the Albany region which I will once again represent after the next election. From the outset I must stress that the uncaring ignorance displayed by this Government affects not only the wine growers but also the whole local economies of the two major parts of the seat of Forrest. This can apply to any part of Australia too, and to the electorates of honourable members who have spoken tonight. Wine production in the south-west and Great Southern areas is very much a pioneer primary industry. Its relationship to large scale alcohol manufacture and hence to the rationale of the new 10 per cent sales tax is tenuous in the extreme.

Less than 20 years ago, in 1965, the first vines were planted at Forest Hill and Plantagenet. The following year we saw in the Margaret River area the beginning of the Vasse Felix vineyard. The pioneers of the south west wine industry took a shrewd punt on the similarity of the climate with that of the Bordeaux area in France. The relative coolness of this part of the State assists in the development of quality wines. The record since 1966 has not disappointed those pioneers, despite problems with birds and other natural pests. Top international awards, for our chardonnays particularly, speak for themselves.

Wine growing is a relatively labour intensive industry which provides seasonal employment for many young people who otherwise might not find work. Moreover, it has become the focus of a growing tourist industry. Visits to celebrated wineries are often the highlight of trips to the south west. Other industries such as arts and crafts have been able to grow in tandem with this development. Of course tourist promotion by wineries is a means of boosting sales through tastings but a general impact on the local tourist industry must be acknowledged . As much as 15 per cent of profits, in other words 15 per cent of the quantity of wine a vineyard produces, can be used in that kind of promotion. When a sales tax of 10 per cent is imposed at the wholesale level and is thus levied on wines used in tasting, something has to give. If nothing else, if the Government persists with this tax it should consider lifting the tax on the 10 or 15 per cent of the product used by vineyards for wine tasting.

Wine tasting in my electorate has led to a vastly improved tourist industry in the area. This tax must concern all vineyards that have cellar sales and cater for tourists in this manner. The vast majority of the wine they use is reject wine. The bottles may be chipped at the top or something may have happened to them in the production process. There is nothing to do with such wine other than to dispose of it or use it for tasting. But under this wine tax, the wine used for those tastings will be taxed. I think that will be a great disincentive for wineries to be involved in that area. The effect on tourism will be swift should the wineries be forced to restrict or even cancel their tourist promotion activities, as some have already done in the Forrest electorate.

In a more general sense, a 10 per cent sales tax and price rise naturally has a greater relative impact on more expensive quality wines such as those produced in the seat of Forrest. The extra dollar on the price of a bottle of chardonnay could well dissuade the middle or lower income consumer. The extra 40c on the price of a cask of riesling will trouble him far less. The Hawke Government has wilfully ignored the estimate of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics that a 10 per cent price rise in the retail price of wine will cut sales by 5 to 7 per cent in the short term and by 13.5 per cent in the long term. Such an impact will fall more heavily on the small, quality winery. It will put many out of business. These percentage figures translate to a projected drop of over 41 million litres of domestic wine production for this financial year, affecting an industry with 12,000 jobs Australia-wide. The close relationship to tourism that I know to be so real in the south-west extends to other areas of Australia. The Hunter Valley is our top international tourist attraction. People do not go there to gaze at the coal. However, a few years of the Hawke wine tax might leave coal as the sole tourist attraction.

It should not be thought for a moment that the 10 per cent sales tax on wine is the main concern of the coalition parties. The Hawke Government dealt its second major blow to the wine industry when it reduced the differential between Australian wines and imports. However the decision may be dressed up, the previous 20 per cent sales tax on foreign wines now becomes a duty of a mere 10 per cent, with both the imported and local product thereafter attracting the same 10 per cent sales tax. Protection is therefore cut by half. The Government correctly points out that under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade sales tax must not vary between imported and domestic products. It has not explained why it did not retain the existing protection by imposing a duty of 20 per cent rather than 10 per cent on imported wines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member seek leave to make a personal explanation on the basis that she has been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed to correct the misrepresentation.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) during this debate misrepresented me by claiming that I had said that drinks such as Export Light were not real beer. I wish to correct this because in his speech he also implied that as Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety I condoned support for a move which was against the interests of road users. What I said was that brewed drinks with less than one per cent alcohol, such as Export Light, were technically soft drinks tasting and looking like beer. I wish to make it clear that I encourage consumption of such drinks as an excellent and responsible alternative. They will still be priced competitively with soft drink and I encourage their consumption.
—Order! The honourable member is now going beyond correcting a misrepresentation.
—I was trying to correct not just that sentence but also the implication and tenor of the speech that went further into the road safety area.

—I remind the honourable member, who occasionally occupies the chair of the House, that the purpose of indulgence is to correct misrepresentation and not to extend it. I ask her to round off her explanation.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I am trying to make that correction. As Chairman of that Committee, I make it clear that, regardless of this misrepresentation, I support the reduction of excise on light beer which has a higher alcohol content than Swan Special Light and Export Light but which is significantly lower than standard beer. The Federal Government's incentive to beer drinkers is a clear contravention--
—Order! The honourable member is flouting the indulgence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Construction and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate, I thank all honourable members who took part for their contributions. There was one specific question from the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) about the refund of the tax on fortifying spirit. I can tell him that the necessary amendments have now been made to the Excise Regulations to allow these refunds to be paid to the persons due to receive them. They could submit their applications to the Collector of Customs in the State in which they have their business at any time from now on. We will seek to process those applications as quickly as possible. It must all be completed by 30 June 1985, so I hope that people will get their applications in quickly.
—But will they be paid?

—I am sure that they will. It will be a mark of the good faith of the Government that they will be paid as quickly as we can process those applications for refunds. I need only otherwise draw attention to the second reading amendment foreshadowed by the Opposition to the next Bill. I notice that the Opposition, in the wording of that amendment, has been very careful not to say that it is against the tax. It has drawn attention to the competitiveness with imported wine that has resulted from these changes. There is very good reason for this. A number of members of the Opposition, some in very influential positions, recognise that this tax was inevitable and that the sooner it was applied the sooner the necessary adjustments and restructuring in the wine industry would take place.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is also very concerned about the competitiveness of the imported wine. We want to make absolutely certain that the industry readjusts so that it is competitive with those imports. We want to make sure that that will happen sooner rather than later. As a great trading nation we have to take notice of our obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which was one of the reasons why the measures turned out as they have. It limited our actions. However, we shall continue to monitor the situation very carefully and we will once again give all the encouragement and help we can to the restructuring so that the Australian wine will be competitive. We are confident that that will happen and that the wine industry will pursue the necessary actions to put its house in order so that it is competitive with imports. Of course, the Government will be opposing this foreshadowed amendment, which is mere rhetoric.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As time goes by it seems the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and his Department are paying less attention to the need for an efficient and humane health service and occupying themselves more and more with the exciting and enjoyable game of worry-the-doctor. The word 'worry' in the name of the game carries two of its common meanings; that is, causing uncertainty and despondency, and snapping at and sinking teeth in whenever possible. The game is really great fun for a socialist Minister and, I must admit, has some enthusiastic spectators in the community. It is also true that some doctors deserve to be worried. But in the course of the game the Minister and his bureaucrats tend to forget their real job; that is, making sure that Australia has an efficient and humane health service. I shall instance one recent example of this.

SPEECH.PARA: When a general practitioner refers a patient to a specialist there is a special form to be filled in. Without a properly completed referral form, Medicare will not pay its share of the bill for the specialist consultation. The requirements for the form are laid down in section 10 (2) of the Health Insurance Regulations . Unfortunately, the printed form supplied by the Department to general practitioners does not comply with the regulations. The form shows three things the general practitioner can ask the specialist for.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Is it in order for former senators to read speeches in this place?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The first is an opinion, the second is immediate treatment and the third is continuing management of the present condition. On the same form below that appears the words: 'Strike out item(s) inapplicable'. The plain meaning of this is that a general practitioner can refer a patient to a specialist for any one, or any combination, of these courses of action. However, the regulations imply that the general practitioner must specify one and only one of them. The sensible approach would be to notify doctors of the discrepancy in the form and immediately set about changing either the forms or the regulations. In fact, it would be preferable to change the regulations for reasons I will come to in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Health Department's approach was to send in the Gestapo-that is the abbreviation for 'die gesundheitstaatspolizei'. These people raided the surgery of a constituent of mine who is a distinguished consultant surgeon. They left the impression that they were policemen, not just Health Department bureaucrats. They accused my constituent of medifraud for treating patients whose general practitioners had not literally struck out, by drawing a line through, two of the three options on the referral form. By this interpretation there would hardly be a single specialist in the country who has not committed medifraud and who is not liable, under the legislation, to five years gaol.

That is worth a hundred points in the game of worry-the-doctor, but in real life it just shows up the stupidity of the system and the vindictiveness of the Minister and his Gestapo. Remember, the cause of the trouble is that the form and the regulations are not complementary. What is worse, if the regulations were strictly enforced, specialists would time and again have to decide whether to break the law or to deny patients proper treatment.

If a patient was sent for 'an opinion', and the opinion was that 'immediate treatment' was essential, the specialist could not give that treatment. He would have to send the patient back to the GP to be referred again to the specialist with a new referral form-if the patient lived that long. A patient sent to a cardiologist for 'an opinion' might have a heart attack in the consulting room. The consultant is allowed to save his life-in fact he is duty bound to save his life-but if he tries to get medical benefits for it, that is Medifraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian International Eye Bank and Research Foundation-AIEBRF-has campaigned for eight years for a network of non- profit community based eye banks in Australia to provide corneal grafts. It is a charity registered in New South Wales and among the sponsors are Sir Douglas Nicholls, Kamahl, overseas identities and the founder-President, Mr Stanley Fitzroy-Mendis II, who is in the Gallery tonight, of the Medical Centre, 103 Young Street, Sydney. He has been occupied for 14 years as director of a family company in the United States of America and Australia which is active mainly in pathology laboratories registered with the Federal Government. He has donated some $60,000 of his family's resources over six years to promote the concept and has visited eye banks in most countries except the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and China. He proposed last year a restaurant complex in Sydney to raise funds for eye banks and a venue for conferences. This was rejected for support as a community employment program project.

SPEECH.PARA: The then New South Wales Health Minister, Mr Brereton, offered to investigate the proposal on 24 November 1983 in a letter reference 83/7806 to Sir Douglas Nicholls, and there has been no further decision. Police are investigating records of 7,500 patients' eyes illegally removed after their death since 1956. The Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists was told by Sir Douglas on 7 December 1983 that the AIEBRF was renewing its appeal for support for the project. Previous responses from the Royal College were in effect to claim that there were already sufficient facilities. For example a letter to Mr Fitzroy- Mendis on 9 May 1978 states:
There have already two excellent eye banks in existence in Sydney-one at Sydney Eye Hospital and the other at Lidcombe.

An affidavit signed by Leslie Phillip Vorbach states that he worked as medical technician at Lidcombe from 1956 to 1978 and removed eyes at the morgue on directions of Drs Carter, Shirley Sarks, Scarf, Hooper and Hale and on request of eye doctors Hart, Hipwell, Gregory, Butcher, Williams, Selwar, Milverton, Pickering, Thompson, Shirley Sarks, Du Temple, King, Chabra, Ong, Kennedy, Professor Hollows, Bulman and Kappagoda. He sought no permission from any person other than the doctors concerned and believes no permission was obtained before his instructions. About 1,000 of the eyes, he states, were supplied to Dr Shirley Sarks who did research at Lidcombe. He supplied documents to Mr Fitzroy- Mendis and Professor Leo Landhuis, President of the Eye Banking Association of America, after the 1980 launching of the AIEBRF at the Wentworth Hotel in Sydney in 1980, and these documents were kept confidential until the failure of the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists to reply to the 7 December 1983 letter.

On Sunday 27 May this year 60 Minutes produced the documentary evidence that eyes were illegally removed. Following this telecast, a phone call to 60 Minutes from a two-month previously retired technician of a teaching hospital in Sydney was to the effect that the illegal practice continues in all major hospitals. There is documentary evidence that two eye doctors, Roger McGuinness and N. Banks of Sydney, treated Mr Stanley Fitzroy-Mendis II with chlorocort for a mild follicular conjunctivitis after which his visual acuity was reduced so much that he was medically advised not to drive or write. An optometrist noted: 'Corneal surface deficiency'.

A letter to the Medical Journal of Australia on 14 April 1984, at page 510, repeats a warning previously published in 1964 and 1982 against using chlorocort or its active ingredients and similar combinations of corticosteroids with antibiotics and calling for Federal action. The response of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is printed on the same page. Some derogatory allegations have been made in reference to the pending divorce of Mr Stanley Fitzroy-Mendis II. I have seen documentary evidence from independent specialists which leaves no doubt in my mind that these allegations are malicious defamation . In the light of the recent development of medifraud in many countries, one can only speculate on the motives of some doctors who have thrown suspicion on so many of their colleagues by participating in illegal practices which have been covered up by eminent eye specialists. The only offspring of Mr Stanley Fitzroy- Mendis II-

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Has has attention been drawn to a full page advertisement on the back page of the National Times in the 16-22 September 1983 issue for a 'Modulion Home Oxygen Regeneration System' and other 'Bionic Products'; if so, does his Department have any evidence to support such products; if not, will he draw the attention of the Trade Practices Commission to this apparent breach of the law.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. I have also noted that the advertisement was approved by the Australian Publishers' Bureau which is the body that approves advertisements in the print media in accordance with the Voluntary Code of Advertising drawn up by the Media Council of Australia.

My Department has insufficient evidence to support some of the claims made for these products. Companies are allowed to import negative ion generators into Australia provided no therapeutic claims are made regarding their use. The National Health and Medical Research Council at its 94th Session reiterated earlier recommendations adopted at the fifty-second and subsequent sessions, that:
'the is no reliable evidence to indicate that negative ions promote health;
some negative ion generators produce unacceptable levels of ozone;
the generators are of no intrinsic value in dust control;

and Council believing that insufficient medical evidence is available on the therapeutic value of ionisers in the treatment of patients with asthma, hay fever, allegies and respiratory conditions, recommends their use should not be encouraged.'

The attention of the Australian Publishers' Bureau has been drawn to my Department's views on the use of negative ion generators and it is unlikely that similar advertisements will be approved again in those newspapers which are members of the Media Council of Australia. In these circumstances I would not propose drawing the matter to the attention of the Trade Practices Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 6 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to state (a) whether the Victorian Health Commission Planning Division this year reported on average 2.85 teeth decayed, missing or filled-DMF -in five-year-old children and 3.56 DMF in seven-year-old children using school dental services and fluoridated water, (b) whether seven-year-old children at Ballarat, Victoria, without such services of fluoridated water, have an average of 3.46 DMF and (c) what the difference was in hours of care per child by the South-Australian school dental scheme in fluoridated compared with non- fluoridated areas in the first eight months of 1982.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to an article in the Medical Journal of Australia of 11 February 1978 which claims a 78 per cent improvement in the teeth of North Sydney children between 1961 and 1974 due to fluordiation.

(3) If so, was this improvement (a) 60 per cent or 7.5 per cent per year in the pre-fluoridated period 1961-68, (b) 0.5 per cent per year for 1968-72 and (c) assessed in 1972-74 only in 2 per cent of the child population including schools with above average numbers of sound mouths.
(4) Were the 1968 DMF averages in this study equal to those of children at Tamworth, New South Wales, who had used fluoridation for nine years.

(5) Does he endorse the recommendation of (a) Cooper Laboratories Pty Ltd to expectant mothers to take 3.3 milligrams of sodium fluoride daily in non- fluoride areas and 1.65 milligrams daily in fluoridated areas or (b) Protea Pharmaceutical Pty Ltd that sodium fluoride crosses the placental barrier and is not to be used during pregnancy, if so, why; if not, why not.
(6) What steps are taken to ensure that flaws, inconsistencies and errors in fluordation assessment, promotion and information are detected, prevented and published.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) No. The Victorian Health Commission's Planning Division reported that in the period January to September 1982 Victorian children aged five and seven years had mean dif indices-deciduous teeth decayed, requiring extration or filled-of 2.83 and 3.56 respectively. These figures referred to children using both fluoridated and non-fluoridated water. The mean DMF indices-permanent teeth decayed, missing or filled-for children aged five and seven years were 0.02 and 0.71 respectively.

(b) Seven-year-old children at Ballarat, Victoria, were reported has having an average of 3.46 dif teeth. The Victorian Health Commission made no attempt to separate Ballarat children according to their use or non-use of fluoridated water. Some children living in non-fluoridated areas would have spent part of their lives in fluoridated areas, and vice versa.

(c) The South Australian Health Commission has advised that in fluoridated areas in the first eight months of 1982, children required 0.97 hours of treatment by dental therapists compared with 1.15 hours in non-floridated areas. However, the Commission pointed out that in non-fluoridated areas dentists provided a great proportion of treatment than in fluoridated areas so that the difference in total treatment time would have been greater than stated above.

Futhermore, the South Australian Health Commission has advised that the treatment time per patient was assessed by assigning time-units to each item of dental care. In fluoridated areas the average filling would tend to be smaller and require less time than in non-fluoridated areas. This method of assessment would tend to understate differences between the two groups.

(2) Yes. However it was reported in the article that 78.6 per cent of children in northern Sydney in 1974 did not require teeth filled, compared with 8.1 per cent in 1961. The reasons for improved dental health were stated to be that ingestion and application of various types of fluoride, improved oral hygiene and diet, and more regular treatment.

(3) (a), (b), (c) It has not been possible to reconcile the statistics in the question with those presented in the article. However, the article reports that a considerable improvement in dental health took place before fluoridation of water in Sydney in 1968.

(4) The article concerning dental health of children in northern Sydney does not present information about mean DMF indices. It is understood that this information is not available. However, the article contains the following statement: 'The caries-free figure of 58 per cent in these northern suburbs in 1967 was equal to the figure obtained in Tamworth after nine years of fluoridation of water supplies'.

(5) (a) The National Health and Medical Research Council has not recommended fluoride supplements during pregnancy because they have not been shown to be effective in reducing dental caries of the child. I support this point of view.

(b) The fluoride tablets marketed by Protea Pharmaceuticals Pty Ltd contain 20 milligrams of sodium fluoride, and are for use in the treatment of osteoporosis and some other bone abnormalities. In view of the high fluoride content of the tablets they should not be used during pregnancy.
(6) The National Health and Medical Research Council examines new evidence and allegations concerning the use of fluorides in the control of dental caries.
In addition, my Department and other health authorities, including particularly the World Health Organisation maintain a close examination of the use of fluorides in the control of dental caries.

Recommendations and pronouncements of the National Health and Medical Research Council are circulated widely in the reports of Council's Sessions. These reports are distributed to health authorities and organisations, universities and other tertiary education bodies, and various libraries; they are also available to the media.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have plans been made with, or through the Australian Tourist Commission for a domestic tourism promotional campaign; if so, what plans.
(2) Has a national committee been formed to devise the campaign; if so, what industry bodies or individuals are members of the committee and is the Australian Federation of Travel Agents a member.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Federal and State Governments and the tourism industry have joined forces in mounting a domestic campaign to encourage more Australians to see more of their country and to see it more often. The campaign is being co-ordinated by the Australian Tourist Commission and was launched nationally on 22 March. It consisted of a television commercial featuring Paul Hogan and a 100-page information and motivational booklet entitled 'Australian Made Holidays' published as a supplement to the April edition of the Australian Women's Weekly. So, 1.2 million copies of the booklet have been distributed in this way, with a further 800,000 copies being made available through travel sellers around Australia.

Reaction to the Television commercial and the 'Australian Made Holidays' booklet has been very positive and there are real signs that the public is responding to the motivational thrust of the campaign. The level of inquiries to advertisers in the booklet is an indication of the high impact being achieved by the campaign.

(2) Following a Tourist Ministers' Council-TMC-directive in May 1983, the Australian Standing Committee on Tourism ASCOT, in consultation with the Australian Travel Industry Association ATIA, established a domestic tourism committee to develop and implement an integrated domestic tourism marketing and awareness campaign.
In its initial year, the Committee has comprised:
1 representative of the Australian Tourist Commission-Chair
2 representatives of the States South Australia and Western Australia
1 representative of the Australian Federation of Travel Agents.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether some States have increased their budgets for tourism promotion in 1983-84, including a 97 per cent increase in New South Wales.
(2) Has the Australian Capital Territory tourism promotion budget fallen in real terms by 11 per cent.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to the view of prominent members of the Canberra community that the industry in Canberra is sick and tired of seemingly hollow promises of improvements to the Tourist Bureau's structure, convention centres, new airport facilities and improved road and rail links that will never eventuate; if so, what steps does he intend to take to rectify this problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am able to say some States did increase their budgets for tourism promotion in 1983-84. On the information I have, the increase in New South Wales is calculated at 95 per cent-that is, an increase from $1,023,000 to $2,000,000. These figures are for the allocation described as tourism promotion and advertising in the budget of the New South Wales Department of Leisure, Sport and Tourism.

(2) Yes, the Australian Capital Territory tourism promotion budget has fallen in real terms by approximately 11 per cent; that is, the specific allocation to the Canberra Tourist Bureau which is operated by my Department. However, the promotion of tourism to the national capital is being fostered in a number of ways. The Government's decisions in respect of major national institutions such as the new Parliament House and the Museum of Australia and the approval of the hotel-convention centre have been taken consciously with the aim of focussing national and indeed international attention on Canberra. The Australian Capital Territory will also benefit from the Government's greatly increased support for our national tourism promotion body, the Australian Tourist Commission. The Commission's budget was almost doubled to $19.5m, for 1983-84. It is promoting the attractions of Australia with greater effect not only overseas but also, with the introduction of the Domestic Tourism Campaign in March this year, to Australians themselves. Canberra, now one of our major tourist destinations, must benefit from this. Finally, the Australian Capital Territory tourism industry has shown in recent times that by combining its forces it can achieve a significant voice for Canberra in the holidaying market. The Canberra Tourist Bureau, the Canberra Visitor and Convention Bureau-which also receives assistance from the Government-and other bodies representing elements of the industry through their concerted efforts have produced a steady, healthy visitor growth during the 80s.
(3) Yes. However, because of the neglect of the previous Government, we had to give priority to housing, welfare, and land servicing in the 1983-84 Budget.

At my direction, my Department has recently made a submission to the Public Service Board for an upgrading and reorganisation of its tourism administration, to enable it to meet the increasing demands placed on it.

Improved road access to the Australian Capital Territory will be facilitated by the Australian bi-centennial roads development program. In respect of rail links , I draw the honourable member's attention to the introduction of XPT services to Canberra in August 1983. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Assistance to Private Business by Department of Defence Support

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Support, upon notice, on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What (a) financial, (b) technical and (c) other forms of assistance, are available from the Minister's Department to private business.

These funds are allocated to individual major defence equipment acquisition projects and to miscellaneous minor tasks. They are also utilised to conduct studies on the feasibility of production in Australian industry of defence equipments, the research and development for which has been conducted in Department of Defence laboratories.

1 (b) Technical-General technical advice is provided to interested industry which seeks to be involved in defence equipment acquisition and in technologies of defence interest. This advice is given in parallel with discussion and negotiation associated with the investment of AIA funds mentioned above.

1 (c) Other-A directory of defence and offsets oriented industry is maintained to inform overseas suppliers who have an obligation to place work in Australia. The directory identifies most relevant Australian firms and their capabilities or products.
Day to day contact by the Department is maintained with local and overseas industry.
A continuing schedule of industry seminars is maintained in Australian capital cities and regional centres.

Details of proposed Department of Defence major equipment procurements are promulgated through an extensive mailing list to local and overseas industry. The services of the Department of Defence Support's overseas representatives and offices in Australian Embassies and High Commissions overseas are utilised to maximise this distribution.
The Commonwealth purchasing policy of preference to Australian-New Zealand made goods, is applied.

2 (a) The Department's central office or regional offices located in the major capital cities are the contact points for industry seeking involvement in Department of Defence major equipment procurements and technologies of defence interest. For items 1 (b) and 1 (c) there are no specific requirements to be met. Other than the purely informational forms of assistance, the prospects for involvment by industry are determined again on a case by case basis and after discussion with the particular firm.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article 'From OPEC to ODEC' in The New Republic, 28 November 1983.

(2) If so, is he able to say whether (a) Wall Street and other private bankers are lending 20 times their capital assets for indefinitely extendable periods, largely to the Third World, with no more significant security than short term borrowings from OPEC countries and the capitalist expectation that developed Western bloc countries will underwrite defaulters by incurring inflationary government deficits to protect private banks at the expense of national reserve banks and Western taxpayers and (b) Third World citizens are being squeezed into famine to meet International Monetary Fund lending conditions.

(3) Will Australia reject the irresponsible approach of socialising losses and capitalising gains for private financiers before again underwriting or participating in any extension, renewal or replacement for IMF or World Bank agreements and rely on the Reserve Bank of Australia and not the IMF or World Bank for future advances to meet international trade, aid and loan requirements; if not, why not.

(4) Will he produce, with other Ministers, proposals for public information, discussion and participation in view of irresponsible, anti-socialist, elitist and unsound economic/financial mis-management.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) I understand that it is the case that a number of private banks in other countries have exposures in developing countries which exceed their capital bases. I am unable to comment on whether the private banks expect their lending to developing countries to be underwritten by developed Western bloc countries. Any such expectation would certainly appear to be dubious security. The current situation is that these banks, far from having their lending specificially underwritten by Western governments, have chosen to reschedule repayment obligations and, in conjunction with institutions such as the IMF, extend new loans (rather than to occasion default) to a number of developing countries experiencing difficulties in repaying external debt. I cannot offer any specific comment on what security the private banks have on these loans. However, presumably the main security for lending to governments and government agencies is represented by the credit rating and past performance of the governments concerned and the export-earning capacity of the borrowing countries .

With respect to short term borrowings from OPEC countries, it seems extremely unlikely that private banks would regard these borrowings as security against Third World borrowings given that they are not assets of Third World borrowers. In any case, OPEC deposits have represented only part of the supply of funds to international banks and, in aggregate, those deposits are now no longer increasing due to the substantial current account deficit of the oil exporting developing countries as a group.

(b) A number of the developing countries experiencing difficulties in servicing their external debts have borrowed funds from the International Monetary Fund. Most borrowings from the Fund are subject to economic policy conditions which are designed to restore the balance of payments and more general economic viability of the borrowing countries. With regard to any question of Third World citizens being 'squeezed into famine' to meet IMF lending conditions, there are three points which should be made:
IMF lending has proved to be a catalyst for additional private bank lending;

Without IMF loans, adjustment programs by countries experiencing severe debt servicing difficulties would have to be implemented over a far shorter period. This would usually involve a drastic cut in imports, the level of domestic economic activity and, as a consequence, living standards over the short term. In that sense, IMF loans can be regarded as easing the conditionality which would otherwise be imposed by the market;

In many cases the need for balance of payments support from the IMF arises largely due to the inappropriate economic policies of the countries concerned. If IMF lending to such countries were unconditional it would merely postpone, rather than correct, a balance of payments crisis. At some later date, far more stringent adjustment policies, with even greater effects on living standards, would be necessary.
(3) I know of no basis for any suggestion that the IMF and World Bank take the approach of 'socialising losses and capitalising gains for private financiers'.

The question also raises the issue of relying on the Reserve Bank of Australia, rather than the IMF or World Bank, for future advances to meet international trade, aid and loan requirements. This suggests that the Bank could be regarded as an alternative to those international bodies for the provision of assistance by Australia to Third World countries. It is a view I would not accept.
The Government regards the IMF and World Bank as having pre-eminent roles in providing balance of payments support and longer term aid and fully supports their efforts.

Where balance of payments support is involved, Australia prefers the provision of such support to be multilateral, via institutions such as the IMF, rather than bilateral. Balance of payments support provided on a bilateral basis would:

Normally require support by a number of countries and involve extensive coordination efforts amongst those countries. Such arrangements are difficult to put in place and frequently result in duplication of effort and greater inefficiencies;
Tend to be politicised, rather than being provided on objective economic criteria as at present. This could be to the disadvantage of smaller and poorer countries; and
Make it extremely difficult to apply appropriate economic policy conditions and to require adherence to agreed repayment schedules.

The net effect of the bilateral provision of balance of payments support would therefore be to reduce the efficiency of the international monetary system. However, with respect to the provision of foreign aid it could be noted that Australia does provide about 74 per cent of its official development assistance on a bilateral basis. This mainly reflects our particular strategic, political and economic interests in the region. This aid is allocated through the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, in consultation with relevant departments. My colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, tabled the report of the high-level committee set up by the Government to review Australia's aid program on 7 June 1984. This report considers, inter alia, the desirable balance between bilateral and multilateral aid and the role of international agencies in the delivery of Australia's aid program.

(4) The meaning of this part of the question is unclear. I would draw the honourable member's attention, however, to the regular publications programs of both the IMF and the World Bank which explain the role of these institutions in assisting their member countries cope with current pressures. Particular publications of relevance include their respective annual reports, the IMF Survey (published fortnightly) and the quarterly Fund/Bank Journal, Finance and Development.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Attorney-General say whether the Commissioner of Taxation is experiencing or anticipating problems in attempting to collect outstanding tax from large tax avoidance participants and promoters where the individuals have, over a period of time, divested themselves of income-earning assets and other assets to family trusts.

(2) If an individual organises his assets in this way can he still retain effective control over the trust assets by way of being (a) the appointor of the trust, (b) a shareholder and/or director of the trustee company, (c) the trustee of the trust or (d) named as guardian of the various beneficiaries.

(3) If an individual goes bankrupt in this situation can the trustee of the bankrupt estate have recourse to any controlled assets where it could not be proved that the divesting was done with the specific intention of defrauding creditors.

(4) Can a bankrupt be a beneficiary of a trust and simply request the trustee of the family trust to refrain from making any distributions of income to the bankrupt during the period of the bankruptcy; if so, is it possible for a bankrupt to have control over assets valued at many hundreds of thousands of dollars and have the income produced by these assets directed to other beneficiaries such as other family members, allowing the bankrupt to refrain from making payments to the creditors of the bankrupt estate.

(5) Have family trusts proliferated during recent years; if so, are any changes proposed to the Bankruptcy Act to ensure that interests in family trusts are available to creditors and particularly the Commissioner of Taxation.

(6) Can the Attorney-General say whether professional advisers have been advocating the method referred to in this question as a means of avoiding paying the Commissioner of Taxation if a tax scheme ultimately fails.

(7) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the 'West Australian' of 20 July 1983 alleging that in the bankrupt estate of a K. MacKenzie, an ear, nose, throat specialist, the Official Receiver accepted contributions of $1000 per month from an income of $160,000 per year; if so, does the Bankruptcy Act limit contributions in these cases to such a low level.
(8) Is it a fact that a person who is bankrupt can maintain an extravagant lifestyle receiving amounts such as $160,000, less tax of approximately $86,000 and contributions of $12,000 to the estate.

(9) Are steps available to creditors to force the bankrupt-where the conditions of section 149 of the Bankruptcy Act have not been breached by the bankrupt-to make contributions to his estate for a longer period; if so, what steps.
(10) Do present provisions of the Bankruptcy Act allow bankrupts with large incomes to remain bankrupt for only three years with the creditors receiving only minimal distributions.
(11) Is any action proposed to ensure that the apparent available abuses of the Bankruptcy Act are stopped; if so, what action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that he has experienced problems, and anticipates problems in other cases, in collecting outstanding tax from tax avoidance participants where individuals have over a period of time divested themselves of assets to family trusts.

(2) Yes. It is possible for an individual to retain some control over assets transferred by that individual to a trust. The degree of control exercised by the individual in any given case will be determined by the provisions of the trust instrument.

(3) Yes. Section 120 of the Act enables the trustee to take action to set aside a settlement of property made within two years before the commencement of the bankruptcy, regardless of whether there is or is not an intention to defraud creditors. However some settlements, for example, settlements made in consideration of marriage, or a settlement upon a purchaser made in good faith and for valuable consideration, are exempted from the operation of the section. Certain other settlements made within five years before the commencement of the bankruptcy, and not involving an intent to defraud, can also be set aside unless the parties to the settlement can prove that the settlor was at the time of making the settlement able to pay all his debts without the aid of the property settled and that the settlor's interest in the property passed to the donee upon execution of the settlement.

(4) Trusts known as discretionary trusts for maintenance are encountered occasionally by Official Receivers. If there is an absolute discretion in the trustees to apply the income for the maintenance of the bankrupt, his family or any of them in such manner as the trustees see fit, then the Court will not interfere with the bona fide exercise by the trustees of their discretionary power. If the arrangements involve a fraudulent disposition within the meaning of section 121 of the Bankruptcy Act, however, that section would apply and the fraudulent disposition would be void as against the trustee in bankruptcy. Section 120 of the Bankruptcy Act may also apply, and this is referred to in the response to part 3 of the question. Accordingly, the answer to the question is yes in that the trustees may, in certain circumstances, exercise their discretion to direct income away from a bankrupt beneficiary.

(5) Bankruptcy administration does not maintain records of the kind which would be needed to answer the first part of the question. As to the second part of the question there are no proposals at this time to amend the Bankruptcy Act specifically to address the issue of family trust, but see the answer below to part 11 of the question.

(6) The Attorney-General is aware of one case involving possible collusion between a debtor and his financial advisor with a view to the concealment of assets from the debtor's creditors in a subsequent bankruptcy. The persons involved in this affair are the subject of proposed and pending proceedings, both of a criminal nature and of a civil nature, directed to recovery of the assets for the benefit of the creditors. The Attorney-General is not aware that such behaviour is a common practice. The Commissioner of Taxation has advised he has no evidence that professional advisers have been advocating arrangements for the predominant purpose of preventing recovery of debts by creditors. However, the Commissioner advises there are indications that this is at least a secondary consideration.

(7) Yes, the Attorney-General's attention has been drawn to the affairs of Dr K . I. MacKenzie who was declared bankrupt on 22 July 1980. The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that he also is aware of the case.

In that case the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Perth and another creditor made application under sub-section 149 (3) of the Bankruptcy Act to enter an objection to the discharge of the bankrupt from the bankruptcy. On 19 July 1983, Smith J. of the Supreme Court of Western Australia found that a prima facie case had been made out that the bankrupt was able or was likely, within five years from the date of the bankruptcy, to be able to make a significant contribution to his estate. Secondly, the conduct of the bankrupt in the period before his bankruptcy was unsatisfactory in that he had contributed to this bankruptcy by rash and hazardous speculation. Thirdly, that within the period of six months immediately preceding the presentation of the petition upon which he became bankrupt, when unable to pay his debts as they became due, he gave an undue preference to some of his creditors. His Honour said that he was not seeking to make, nor did he make positive findings in relation to other allegations which would be fully dealt with when an application for discharge from bankruptcy is made. In the meantime, action is in train to seek a further contribution from the bankrupt's income to the trustee for the benefit of creditors under section 131 of the Bankruptcy Act.

In response to the second limb of the question, the Bankruptcy Act does not ' limit contributions' to any particular level. Rather, the Act provides-by section 131-that subject to any order of the Court pursuant to sub-section 131 ( 2), a bankrupt who is in receipt of income is entitled to retain it for his own benefit. This provision is discussed in more detail in the response below question (8).

(8) The Bankruptcy Act provides that certain property of the bankrupt, styled ' divisible property', vests in the trustee in bankruptcy. The trustee then is obliged to realise the divisible property and distribute the proceeds amongst the creditors. The Act provides that, subject to any order of the Court pursuant to sub-section 131 (2) of the Act, a bankrupt who is in receipt of income is entitled to retain it for his own benefit.

Case law has established that the level of contributions from income which is reasonable is a subjective assessment in each case. The amount of income which the bankrupt may retain for his own benefit is dependent on the bankrupt's occupation and station in life. Each case must therefore be considered on its own merits. Consequently the question of what is an 'extravagant lifestyle' is a question to be determined having regard to all the circumstances.

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that it is his view that in a number of cases bankrupts have been able to maintain an extravagant lifestyle, paying what is considered to be a minimal contribution of income to the trustee for the benefit of creditors. In a number of such cases, the trustee of the estate of the bankrupt has been indemnified by the Commissioner to enable action to be taken to seek an increased contribution of income from the bankrupt under section 131 of the Bankruptcy Act.

(9) The effect of discharge from bankruptcy is to release the bankrupt from all provable debts, subject to certain specified exceptions, eg. a liability under the maintenance agreement or maintenance order. There is no power to compel a bankrupt to make contributions from income following discharge. In the event that the Court has made an order under sub-section 131 (2) appropriating portion of the bankrupt's income for the benefit of the creditors then such an order ceases to have effect upon the discharge of the bankrupt. This is provided for by sub-section 131 (5) of the Act. This provision was inserted as recently as 1980, by Act No. 12 of that year, in order to remove any doubt that may exist as to the law in this area.

(10) Historically, bankruptcy is based upon the distribution of the bankrupt's divisible property among his creditors. As mentioned in the answers to preceding questions, this source of money may, in limited circumstances, be supplemented by contributions from income. These circumstances are very limited as, subject to an order of the Court pursuant to sub-section 131 (2) of the Act, a bankrupt who is in receipt of income is entitled to retain it for his own benefit. Regarding discharge from bankruptcy, case law has made clear that it is the intention of the Bankruptcy Act that a bankrupt be entitled to automatic discharge from his bankruptcy after the expiration of 3 years from the date of his bankruptcy unless one or more of the four grounds specified in sub-section 149 (4) exists.

(11) As stated in answer to (5) above, there are no proposals at this time to amend the Bankruptcy Act specifically to address the issue of family trusts. However, the Commissioner of Taxation advises that he proposes to challenge arrangements of the kind referred to in the Question if he is so advised by Counsel. Accordingly consideration may need to be given to amendment of the Bankruptcy Act in the light of the outcome of these proposed challenges.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 28 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many mobile telephones (a) have been rented from Telecom Australia since they were introduced, (b) were in use as at 30 November 1983 and (c) have been returned to Telecom after the initial rental period.
(2) What were the charges applicable to mobile telephones as at (a) 1 January 1983, (b) 1 July 1983, and (c) 1 December 1983.
(3) Does Telecom pay any licence fee to his Department as do other operators of a similar service.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Bona Vista: Priorities for Use of Public Housing

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Bona Vista, a National Trust mansion in South Yarra, Victoria, been empty for over 10 years in possession of Telecom and, at one stage, was it occupied by low income homeless persons.
(2) Will he ensure, with his colleagues, priorities for use of public housing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom vacated Bona Vista, from an operational viewpoint, in June 1977 and a caretaker vacated the premises in about December 1978. The property was occupied by squatters from 4 September 1983 to 7 December 1983. The property has been sold recently by Telecom to a private purchaser.

(2) The Minister for Housing and Construction has informed me that he is concerned to provide as much public housing as possible. As a first step, the Federal Government has substantially increased funds available for such housing under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

The Minister has written to the Minister for Administrative Services urging that suitable surplus Federal staff dwellings be allocated to public housing where practicable. It is understood, however, that there is limited scope for using such dwellings for this purpose. The stock of civil departments staff housing totals less than 3,000 nationwide, and much of it is in isolated locations. Surplus dwellings are identified and usually re-allocated fairly quickly. The Minister for Housing and Construction has also urged the State governments to ensure that surplus State owned dwellings are used for public housing where possible.

The Department of Housing and Construction is represented on the inter- departmental committee on vacant servicemen's housing. Servicemen's dwellings owned by State housing authorities are returned to the States for use as public housing when the dwellings are no longer required by the Services.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Philippines Women: Entry to Australia as Fiancees of Australian Citizens

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 5 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many women from the Philippines have entered Australia in the last 12 months as fiancees of Australia citizens.
(2) Does he envisage any future social problems occuring as a result of this practice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During 1983, 537 female fiancees, who stated on arrival that their country of last residence was the Philippines, entered Australia as settlers. Both Australian citizens and permanent residents can sponsor fiancees, however, the numbers in each of these sponsorship groups are not separately identifiable.

(2) The entry of fiancees is a standard component of the immigration program. As far as people from the Philippines are concerned, like any other small fairly recently arrived group, they sometimes face special problems.

The Department monitors the settlement experience of all migrant groups and adjusts and directs its services accordingly. For people from the Philippines support extends from specific counselling at the interview stage and in group sessions to printed information. My Department is also developing an audio- visual program aimed at alleviating settlement problems.
Under the grant-in-aid and migrant project subsidy schemes funding has been provided to examine settlement issues and develop specific welfare services for the Filipino community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 5 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What consultants have been engaged to work for the Minister or the Minister 's Department since 1 April 1983.
(2) What is the name of each consultant, or if a company or partnership, the name of the corporation or partnership.
(3) For how long was each consultant engaged.
(4) What fee is to be or has been paid to each consultant.
(5) What special background and experience does each consultant possess to enable the consultant to undertake the engagement.
(6) Was the merit principle applied in each case; if so, in what manner.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is provided below.

ANSWER.PARA: Points (1) to (6) No consultants have been engaged to work for me since 1 April 1983. The first column lists the consultants who have been engaged to work for the Department of Administrative Services since 1 April 1983. The second column indicates, as appropriate, in man days the period for which each consultant was engaged. With regard to the Australian Survey Office, consultants are selected from a panel period contract and work is done on a fixed price basis irrespective of the number of man days involved. The third column lists the fees paid and the fourth column provides information on the background and experience of each consultant. The final column notes the basis on which each consultant was engaged.
Consultants engaged by the Department of Administrative Services are generally selected in accordance with guidelines issued by the Public Service Board for the engagement of consultants.

Owing to the large number of consultants engaged by the Australian Survey Office their selection procedures have been standardised. The selection of consultants is based on the Survey Office's 'Procedures for Engaging Contractors for Surveying Services'. Details of these procedures are as follows:
Firstly, all contractors who fulfil certain conditions and apply for inclusion are placed on a panel period contract.

Where projects are under the public tender threshold the primary selection criteria is the availability of contractors who can provide satisfactory service in a particular geographical region. Contractors are placed on lists, in order of tender number, for each region. These contractors are then approached in turn with offers of work. This ensures that over a period all contractors are given the opportunity to carry out work for the Survey Office.

For projects over the public tender threshold firms on the panel of contractors are invited to submit a quotation if they have the necessary resources and facilities to carry out the project concerned. Details of these resources are provided with the initial application for inclusion on the panel of contractors. Factors considered include: size; preferred working area; technological capabilities; previous record in terms of work standard and proven ability to meet target dates.

Tenders are evaluated using the 'weighted scoring' technique to determine which tender offers the best value for money. Consultants are rated against certain criteria such as ability to meet target dates, performance and experience. Weights, which are dependent on the particular critical requirements of the project, are then applied to these criteria to determine the lowest effective cost. In all cases the weights are established and placed on file before tenders are let.

Consultants engaged by the Australian Survey Office of the Department of Administrative Services are approved by the Public Service Board and it has now been established that this approval can be anticipated following approvals during the Budget process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Civic Library is open only on Monday to Friday from 8 .30 a.m. to 5.30 p.m.; if so, is the library closed on Saturday, particularly Saturday morning, because the public buildings, of which it forms a part, are closed and there is an unwillingness to provide heating or cooling to the library independently of the rest of the building.
(2) Are members of the library staff willing to work on Saturday morning.
(3) Has the closure of the library on Saturday morning in the last nine months occasioned considerable inconvenience to the residents of Canberra.
(4) Has his attention been drawn to particular complaints of the blind, who need more lengthy access to the library, of the particular inconvenience that has been occasioned to them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the Civic Library, Canberra City, recommenced Saturday opening from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. on 9 June 1984. Prior to that, problems associated with the air-conditioning system caused great discomfort to both the staff and users of the library. An approach was made by my Department to the Department of Administrative Services to operate the air-conditioning on Saturdays and, as a result, the situation was rectified.
(2) Library staff are willing to work on Saturday providing the air- conditioning functions at a satisfactory level.

(3) Some complaints about the closure of the Civic Library has been received. It should be noted, however, that the other libraries operated by the Canberra Public Library Service have been open on Saturdays as follows:
Belconnen 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Dickson 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Kingston 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Erindale Centre 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Woden Town Centre 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Kippax Interim Library 9 a. m.-1 p.m.
