QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Attorney-General take steps, as a matter of urgency, to investigate and have referred to the Ministerial Council the financial loss and hardship inflicted upon insureds with loss-based claims flowing from the collapse of the Bishopsgate Insurance Company.

(2) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to (a) recent Press reports of the findings of the liquidator into this company, (b) the decision of Mr Justice Needham in the New South Wales Supreme Court in the case of the Dominion Insurance Company of Australia and the Companies Act-Australian Law Reform Commission, Report No. 20, page 212-and the effect of this decision on the problems facing the liquidator, and (c) Press reports that this decision is being challenged by the liquidator of the company in the Victorian Supreme Court .

(3) Is it a fact that, having regard to the wording of the section of the Companies Code and that the section was re-enacted in identical terms after this judgment, it will be difficult for this appeal to succeed.

(4) Irrespective of the outcome of the appeal will the Attorney-General, as a matter of urgency, examine the effects of this decision and this appeal on the question of the availability and distribution of re-insurance funds for these insureds, rather than ordinary unsecured creditors.
(5) Will the Attorney-General examine the particular section of the Companies Code to see what amendments can be made to protect insureds with loss-based claims.

(6) Is it a fact that the terms of the agreement setting up the Co-operative Companies and Securities Codes, do not affect the exercise of the powers to legislate on insurance and bankruptcy matters in conformity with the Constitution without the need to seek the approval of the Ministerial Council; if so, will the Attorney-General give urgent consideration to the enactment of legislation to give insureds with loss-based claims priority over all unsecured creditors; if not, will he refer to the Ministerial Council my private Member's Bill for the 'Winding up of Insurance Companies' for its urgent consideration and implementation, notwithstanding the reference to the ALRC on insolvency.

(7) In view of the exceptional nature of this case as reported in an article headed 'Bishopgate's Trail of ruined Lives' in the Australian of 17 February 1984, and in the light of the economic disaster needlessly inflicted on people because of this collapse, will the Attorney-General take immediate action to see what legislative amendments can be made to empower the liquidator to take steps to mitigate the suffering being inflicted on the insureds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (6) There appears to be two alternative options which the Government could adopt to give greater financial protection to policy holders in the event of the failure of a general insurance company. The first involves the establishment of a guarantee fund to minimise losses to policy holders, as was recommended in the Law Reform Commission Report on Insurance Contracts ALRC 20. The Treasurer has this proposal under consideration.

The second, more limited approach, which is contained in the honourable member' s proposed Bill, is to accord a priority to policy holders' claims over the claims of other unsecured creditors in the winding up of a general insurance company. Depending on the outcome of the Treasurer's consideration of the Law Reform Commission's guarantee fund proposal, it may be appropriate for the Government to consider the more limited option of giving a preference to policy holder creditors in the winding up of a general insurance company.

As to the method by which the latter proposal could be implemented, regard must plainly be had to the fact that the Commonwealth is party to the formal Agreement with the States, and it would be inappropriate to deal with matters which fall within the Agreement other than in accordance with its provisions. Any proposal which would vary the priorities which are to apply to the winding up of a company is covered by that Agreement and the Commonwealth would be required, in fulfilling its obligations under clause 46 of the Agreement, to raise the matter with the Ministerial Council. Should that take place, I would arrange for the honourable member's Bill to be taken into account by the Ministerial Council in the course of its examination of the matter.

(3) to (5) With regard to the question of the availability of re-insurance proceeds, it would not be appropriate for me to comment on the actual decision of Mr Justice Needham in the Dominion Insurance Case. However, the Ministerial Council currently has under consideration proposals which would make specific provision for the distribution of re-insurance proceeds in the event of the winding up of an insurance company. At its meeting on 24 May 1984, the Ministerial Council agreed that the draft amendments should be referred for comment to the General Insurance Consultative Committee, a body whose members are appointed by the Treasurer to provide advice to the Government on matters relevant to current or prospective insurance legislation and on government policy proposals with significant implications for the insurance industry. The Ministerial Council will further consider the proposed legislative amendments after the consultations with the General Insurance Consultative Committee have been completed.

(7) I am aware of the hardship that has been caused, not only to the policy holders, but also to the other unsecured creditors by the failure of the Bishopsgate group. As I have indicated, the Government is examining the case for legislative amendment to apply to any future insurance company failures. However , it would not be appropriate to intervene in the current liquidation of these companies by introducing legislative amendments which would, where there are necessarily limited assets available for distribution, have the effect of retrospectively increasing the entitlements of one group of creditors at the expense of reducing those of another group.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

(2) How many additional staff and casual employees have been employed by the ABC since July 1982 and at what additional annual cost in terms of (a) salaries, (b) superannuation, (c) long service entitlement and (d) other.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1983-84 budget handed down in August 1983 included an appropriation of $288.832m for the ABC. This figure was based on prices current at that time. The relevant figure for 1982-83 was $274.175m.
Subsequently, as part of the additional estimates process, the ABC sought an additional $19.87m. Negotiations resulted in an eventual agreement for an additional $12.5m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are employees of Australia Post public service employees; if not, what are they.
(2) Are Australia Post employees entitled to a holiday additional to Christmas Day and Boxing Day in the Christmas week; if so, when and by whom is this granted.
(3) Are all public service and statutory authority and private company employees under the Minister's direct or indirect control, entitled to this additional holiday.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Australia Post staff are appointed to the Australian Postal Commission Service or engaged as temporary employees under the Postal Services Act 1975.

(2) The Postal (Staff) By-Laws provide for the observance, in the Commission Service, of a number of public holidays each year, specifying particular days and authorising the Commission to approve up to a further four days. One of those four days is an additional holiday during the Christmas/New Year period. The actual day varies according to postal service considerations in each State.

(3) Department of Communications-The Public Service Board has determined that Christmas Day and the following day (Boxing Day) shall be observed as holidays in the service. The Board has the power to declare that any other day shall be observed as a holiday in the Service and usually so declares one other day in the Christmas week.

Telecom Australia-The Australian Telecommunications Commission determines, pursuant to the Telecommunications (Staff) By-Law 40, that Telecom employees are entitled to a holiday additional to Christmas Day and Boxing Day in the Christmas week.

This holiday is usually observed on the day immediately following Boxing Day; however, where Christmas Day falls on a Tuesday the additional holiday is granted on the Monday immediately prior to New Years Day.
The practice followed by Telecom in granting the holiday is similar to that of the Public Service Board and other statutory authorities.

Aussat-Aussat Pty Ltd is currently negotiating terms and conditions to be incorporated in awards with Unions which are seeking coverage of company staff. Provision will exist in the final awards for a so called 'additional public holiday'. This holiday may be taken at any time during the year following agreement between Aussat Pty Ltd and the particular union. This award provision is consistent with established practices in Federal awards applicable to private industry (for example the metal industry) and has a parallel, the provision of a union 'picnic day' in most New South Wales State awards.

Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia), Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, Special Broadcasting Service-Staff of OTC (A), ABT and the SBS are employed under the Public Service Act 1922 and therefore holiday entitlements for staff of the three authorities are as determined, from time to time, by the Public Service Board.

Australian Broadcasting Corporation-ABC staff are entitled to a holiday additional to Christmas Day and Boxing Day in the Christmas week under ABC Staff Rule 86 which states 'Public Holidays'-The same days will be observed as public holidays by officers and employees of the ABC as are observed as public holidays in the Commonwealth Public Service in the locality at which the office or employee is stationed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Company Directors Charged with Serious Criminal Offences

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 March 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that a company director who has been charged with serious criminal offences may continue to act as a director pending the determination of those charges.

(2) Will the Attorney-General investigate the feasibility of amending section 227 of the Companies Act so as to allow the National Companies and Securities Commission-NCSC-to seek an injunction to restrain a person who has been charged with serious offences from acting as director or from otherwise participating in the management of a company pending the determination of the charges.

(3) Is it currently possible for the NCSC to take action under section 574 of the Companies Act to ensure that a person who has been charged with serious offences is unable to meddle in the affairs of a company pending the determination of the charges.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Companies Act 1981-the Act-does not provide that a person will be prohibited from acting as a director of a corporation for the reason only that he has been charged with committing an offence. I have indicated previously in my answer to part 2 (c) of your question No. 476 (see Hansard, 28 February 1984, page 92), that section 227 of the Act does not prohibit a person from acting as a director on the grounds that he has committed an offence unless that person has been convicted.

Since I gave that reply, the enactment of new section 227A has extended the scope of the prohibition beyond the need to obtain a conviction. That section provides that an application may be made to the Supreme Court of a State or Territory for an order prohibiting a director, secretary or principal executive officer of a corporation from taking part in the management of a corporation where the person has acted dishonestly or carelessly in the performance of his duties, or where he has himself repeatedly breached, or has failed to take reasonable steps to prevent the corporation from repeatedly breaching companies and securities legislation.

I should also point out that the Act contains other prohibitions on persons acting as directors for conduct not connected with the commission of an offence. By virtue of section 562 such a disqualification may be imposed by a Supreme Court where the person has taken part in the management of several failed companies where the manner in which the affairs of the companies were managed was responsible for their failure. Proposed amendments contained in the exposure draft of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) (No . 2) Bill 1984, which have been released for public comment, will also enable the National Companies and Securities Commission to prohibit the common director of a number of failed companies from taking part in the management of a corporation without the leave of a Supreme Court.

(2) I have noted the honourable member's views. However, as I have indicated, the Act already to a considerable extent gives effect to the view that persons who have demonstrated their unsuitability or incapacity to take part in the management of a company should be disqualified from acting as directors. I would not propose extending the prohibition further on the sole ground that a person has been charged with an offence. There are fundamental questions concerning the presumption of innocence involved in the imposition of such an unqualified restriction on a person.

(3) Section 574 is not directed to the question of whether or not a charge has been laid against a person, or to the involvement of a charged person in the affairs of a company generally. Under the section, the NCSC may seek an injunction, among other things, to restrain a person from engaging in conduct which constitutes an offence against the Companies Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 29 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the trunk line telephone system out of Batemans Bay, New South Wales, is so overloaded that the Telecom Australia complaints section at Nowra has advised complaining subscribers not to attempt to make trunk calls until after lunchtime, particularly on Mondays; if so, what is being done to overcome this problem.
(2) Is it a fact that a new exchange building has been ready for over two years , but the equipment is housed in old sheds adjoining the building; if so, when will the equipment be installed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) At present telephone subscribers in Batemans Bay are serviced by portable exchanges which are nearing full capacity and trunk line outlets are sometimes congested during peak business periods. Telecom adopts a policy of encouraging customers to make social calls during off-peak periods whenever possible to leave equipment free for business calls during business hours. For this purpose, Telecom offers cheaper off-peak call charges.

Work has started on the installation of a new exchange, at a cost of $1.35m, in the permanent building which was erected some years ago in anticipation of this requirement. The new exchange will be commissioned by the end of November 1984. In addition, Telecom has commenced network up-grading work to improve access from Batemans Bay to the trunk network. Because of delays in the supply of equipment, the up-grading work is not proceeding as quickly as originally scheduled, but it is being implemented progressively as equipment becomes available and will also be virtually completed by the end of November.
The completion of these two projects should result in a satisfactory grade of service during normal business hours.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 30 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether in the United Kingdom there is an enterprise allowance which consists of an advance to an unemployed person of up to one year's value of the unemployment benefit for the purpose of setting up a small business.

(2) Is it the intention of the Government to set up a similar scheme in Australia; if not, will the Government consider either (a) encouraging the banks , particularly the Commonwealth Development Bank, to make loans of a similar amount for similar purposes or (b) permitting local governments to use some wage pause or community employment program funds for similar loans.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is an enterprise allowance scheme operating in the United Kingdom under which assistance is provided to unemployed people wishing to establish their own business. The allowance is a fortnightly payment, payable at a flat rate regardless of marital status, family size and number of dependants. It does not represent advance payment of unemployment benefit entitlement. Further details of the scheme are contained in the December 1983 issue of the Social Security Journal, published by my Department.

(2) My colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is currently examining the scope for introducing a scheme in Australia aimed at helping unemployed people establish themselves in self employment or small businesses. At this stage it would be premature to discuss specific funding mechanisms.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether franchise banking has been introduced in Queensland.
(2) Has he given consent under section 66 of the Banking Act for these businesses to use the name 'bank'.
(3) Are these businesses required to place special reserve deposit funds with the Reserve Bank of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Arrangements in Queensland for operating the offices in question are on the basis of a relationship of principal-and-agent.
(2) On this basis, the need for the Treasurer to give consent under Section 66 of the Banking Act to the use of the work 'bank' in relation to these businesses does not arise.

(3) Deposits accepted by the agent on behalf of the bank are part of the total deposits of the bank and are subject to the provisions of the Banking Act, including provisions relating to Statutory Reserve Deposits.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Service Stations in the Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 2 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the views of the Australian Capital Territory Automobile Chamber of Commerce that the number of service stations in Canberra is excessive.
(2) Is this view accepted by the Government.
(3) What weight is given to this view in considering applications for or the siting of new service stations in Canberra.
(4) If the view is formed that a new site is required in a particular location to meet new needs, is consideration given to a corresponding reduction in another location where outlets are excessive.
(5) Does the Government consult with the Chamber on any new locations and corresponding reductions.
(6) Did the Government consult with the Chamber on planning another service station in Belconnen; if so, what was the result of those consultations.
(7) Has his attention been drawn to the Chamber's view that while there may be a surfeit of service stations in Belconnen, there may be a real shortage in Tuggeranong.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) I am advised that the sale of a second service station site in Belconnen was first proposed in 1980. Following representation from the Australian Capital Territory Automobile Services Association the then Minister withdrew the site for sale and asked the National Capital Development Commission to review its policy in relation to service stations in consultation with the Association.
This led to a review of the standards. In the case of the Town Centre, the provision of a minimum of two service station sites in Belconnen is consistent with the revised policy.

(4) The policies allow for a change in land use where a service station is no longer viable. This provides a mechanism for a reduction in the number of service stations where the number of outlets is excessive.
One service station lease has been changed under these policies and another is close to being changed.

(5) and (6) I am advised that the NCDC was in contact with the Australian Capital Territory Automobile Chamber of Commerce and oil companies operating in the Australian Capital Territory during the preparation of the revised Policy on Service Stations. There was industry agreement to the Policy but the Australian Capital Territory Automobile Chamber of Commerce has maintained opposition to the release of a second service station site in the Belconnen Town Centre.
(7) Yes, the shortage of service station sites in Tuggeranong is recognised and sites at Erindale and Chisholm are due for release this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 2 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Did he state at the 2nd Supplementary Licence Seminar held at Sydney on 2 February 1984, that the direct broadcasting from satellite review will probably begin in earnest during 1986, that is when planning of the second generation of Aussat satellites begins; if so, was he inferring (a) that there will be no DBS until the second generation of domestic satellites is in service, and, if so, when will this be, and if not, when will DBS be permitted for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and commercial television, (b) that the third satellite presently ordered as a standby for the first two or for post-1985 launch could be replaced by a more flexible satellite, and, if so, will this be defined as a first or second generation satellite, and (c) that DBS by definition is a direct unencoded signal, and/or an encoded signal with permission for groups or individuals to decode the signal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) I was not implying that there will be no form of direct broadcasting from satellite (DBS) until the second generation of domestic satellites. The ABC Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service (HACBSS) will be a DBS service, and this is scheduled to commence operation in late 1985. The Government will, within the next few months, further consider the issue of commercial television services to remote areas and this is likely to involve consideration of a DBS service to isolated homesteads. At this stage I am unable to indicate when such a service could be provided. My comments were intended to indicate that any other use of DBS will have to be considered as part of planning for satellites to replace the first generation satellites.
(b) The third satellite ordered as a standby is identical to the two in-orbit satellites and as such is considered a first generation satellite. See answer to (a).
(c) DBS is a broadcasting service transmitted by satellite capable of direct- reception by individuals using satellite receiving dishes. See answer to (a) and (b).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 3 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the average waiting time for elective surgery.
(2) What procedures are classified as elective surgery.
(3) How many patients are waiting for each procedure.
(4) What is the average waiting period for each procedure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am unable to answer the honourable member's question as the information requested is not available to my Department.

The responsibility for the provision of surgical procedures rests with the State and Territorial health authorities. However, an approach was made by my Department to each authority to obtain the information sought. While all authorities have not yet replied, the responses received are limited and have led to the conclusion that the information sought cannot be provided in the form requested.

This state of affairs exists because there is no standard system to record information; the limited information available does not cover all hospitals in a State and there are difficulties in classifying procedures as 'elective'.
If the honourable member wishes to pursue a particular aspect, I will endeavour to answer him to the extent that information is available.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Equal Opportunity Programs: Department of Social Security

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes to existing equal opportunities programs have been made in the Minister's Department since the 1983 general election in regard to (a) aims: (b) assessment procedures, (c) methods of ensuring that the aims of the program have been met, (d) procedures for union involvement and/or consultation in the program, (e) the involvement of the Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau and (f) the priority rating of the program within the Department.
(2) What is the cost of the Department's programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Social Security does not have a formal Equal Employment Opportunity-EEO-Program at present. To date EEO objectives and activities have been undertaken as part of the Department's ongoing programs.

In order to provide a focus for equal opportunity activities, the Department in early 1984 sought approval from the Public Service Board for the creation of a Branch for this purpose. The Public Service Board gave approval for the Branch in June and a recruitment process for the Branch Head position, (an Assistant Director-General Level 1), and for an EEO Co-ordinator at the Director, Class 11 level, is in train. A first task of these positions will be the oversight and development of an Equal Employment Opportunity Program for the Department as required by the Public Service Reform Act 1984.

(2) Equal employment opportunity practices are an integral part of the ongoing activities of the Department and their cost is not known. Some costs will be identifiable once the Branch Head position referred to in (1) has been filled and specific EEO programs developed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Equal Opportunity Programs: Department of Education and Youth Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 5 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes to existing equal opportunities programs have been made in the Minister's Department since the 1983 general election in regard to (a) aims, (b) assessment procedures, (c) methods of ensuring that the aims of the program have been met, (d) procedures for union involvement and/or consultation in the program, (e) the involvement of the Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau and (f) the priority rating of the program within the Department.
(2) What is the cost of the Department's programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) In 1984 a draft equal employment opportunity EEO management plan was produced to outline the ways in which the Department would take steps to eradicate discrimination and promote equality in employment. This plan is currently being circulated widely amongst staff and staff associations for comment. It represents a comprehensive and co-ordinated approach to EEO in the Department. The final version of this plan will be produced following this consultation.

(b) The proposed strategies and objectives contained within the draft EEO management plan specify target groups, action required, responsibility, target dates and evaluation procedures. In addition a statistical data base is to be established against which objectives can be assessed.

(c) Significant mechanisms have been established to ensure that the aims of the EEO program are met. These include the establishment of Departmental, National and State EEO advisory committees and the designation of EEO co-ordinators across the Department. The Deputy Secretary of the Department is the director of EEO and an EEO unit has been established. Staff at all levels have also been consulted on the aims and objectives of the program and their views will be incorporated into the final EEO management plan.

(d) An EEO committee consisting of departmental staff Association representatives has been established. This committee will ensure that the views of staff associations are fully considered in EEO policy development and implementation.
(e) The Public Service Board EEO Bureau has been fully consulted on all aspects of the Department's EEO activities.
(f) The EEO initiatives have been accorded high priority by the Department.

It is expected that most EEO Strategies will amend systems and procedures and develop practices capable of being carried out within existing staffing resources. However, some additional costs have been identified. These specific costs which can be identified are estimated to be as follows for the 1984-85 financial year:
$ EEO Unit Staffing 59,000 Staff Development Programs on EEO issues 16,000 EEO Committee costs 22,000

In the 1983-84 financial year the EEO unit costs were approximately $55,000. The above costs do not include items such as telephones, photocopying and other administrative items which are included in general Department appropriations and for which the EEO component cannot be readily identified.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Equal Opportunity Programs: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 5 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes to existing equal opportunities programs have been made in the Minister's Department since the 1983 general election in regard to (a) aims, (b) assessment procedures, (c) methods of ensuring that the aims of the program have been met, (d) procedures for union involvement and/or consultation in the program, (e) the involvement of the Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau and (f) the priority rating of the program within the Department.
(2) What is the cost of the Department's programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The aims of my department's equal employment opportunity-EEO-program have not changed in substance. They are:

to ensure that applicants for positions are not discriminated against on the basis of sex, race, colour, ethnic origin, birthplace, descent, marital status, lifestyle, lack of facilities, prejudice, bias or attitudes;
to ensure that affirmative action is taken with regard to jobs, working environment, welfare and counselling facilities to enable an equal employment opportunity policy to be implemented.

(b) and (c) A position of EEO Officer at a senior classification in the Third Division is being created in the Management Division of the Central Office of my Department to develop and implement an agreed policy across the Department. Implementation will include, of course, assessment and evaluation procedures.

(d) The consultative mechanism being developed in conjunction with relevant staff associations will be used, among other things, to involve both management and staff associations in policy development and implementation.
(e) My Department continues to discuss matters with the Public Service Board's EEO Bureau.
(f) The EEO program has a high rating within the management priorities of my Department.
(2) Costs to the overall program are not readily quantifiable.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Equal Opportunity Programs: Department of Housing and Construction

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 5 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes to existing equal opportunities programs have been made in the Minister's Department since the 1983 general election in regard to (a) aims, (b) assessment procedures, (c) methods of ensuring that the aims of the program have been met, (d) procedures for union involvement and/or consultation in the program, (e) the involvement of the Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau and (f) the priority of the program within the Department.
(2) What is the cost of the Department's programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The primary aim of the Department's EEO program is to eliminate discrimination and ensure equality of opportunity for all persons employed or seeking employment with the Department. Against this aim the Department's strategy was firstly to remove any discrimination in recruitment. Over the past year the emphasis has shifted to concentrate on the removal of all discrimination in advancement, training and staff attitudes.

(b) and (c) The Department has an EEO Policy Committee which is chaired at Deputy Secretary level. The Committee has responsibility for providing advice on EEO matters, fostering acceptance of EEO principles, and monitoring the overall program.
The Committee has recently been enlarged to better reflect the importance of women's issues and the regional perspective.
(d) An established staff-management consultative group has been the forum for discussion of specific items of the program.

(e) The involvement of the EEO Bureau of the Public Service Board has increased as a result of new Government initiatives. The EEO Bureau has provided advice on the form, direction and progress of new programs and a forum for discussion on current EEO issues.

(f) The Department has committed greater staff resources in the EEO area at both central office and regional level in response to Government initiatives. It has recently conducted a pilot series of seminars. It is proposed these seminars , after final development, will be held for all senior staff of the Department.
(2) The direct cost of the program in 1983-84 falls into the following areas:
EEO segments are included in a wide range of other training-development programs. It is not possible to separate this component of those courses.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Equal Opportunity Programs: Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 5 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes to existing equal opportunities programs have been made in the Minister's Department since the 1983 general election in regard to (a) aims, (b) assessment procedures, (c) methods of ensuring that the aims of the program have been met, (d) procedures for union involvement and/or consultation in the program, (e) the involvement of the Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau and (f) the priority rating of the program within the Department.
(2) What is the cost of the Department's programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism was created on 11 March 1983. Since then, various personnel policies and programs appropriate to the Department's needs have been developed and introduced.
The Department's equal opportunity policy and program is in an advanced stage of preparation.
(a) The program will consist of a number of specific measures which aim to apply equal employment opportunity principles to appointments, transfers, promotions and other personnel policies.

(b) In order to assess aspects of the Department's equal employment opportunity policy, a data base is being developed to provide details of distribution of female and male staff by classification and employment category. Other information will also be compiled in relation to recruitment, promotion and staff development patterns.
(c) Progress in the implementation of the equal opportunity program will be monitored by the Departmental Executive on a monthly basis.
(d) The draft policy statement and program when completed will be circulated for staff and staff association comment and responses received will be taken into account.
(e) To date, it has not been necessary to draw on the expertise of the Public Service Board's Equal Employment Opportunities Bureau in any major way.
(f) The introduction of an Equal Employment Opportunities program and policy has medium to high priority in relation to the development of other personnel policies.

(2) The development of a draft equal employment opportunity policy and program has taken, to date, approximately 4 work weeks of clerical officers' time. The further development and implementation of the program will involve consultation with staff and staff associations, attendance at conferences and other training/ development opportunities and further clerical time. It is not possible to estimate the cost of these activities at this stage, however it is unlikely to be less than 12 work weeks.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Equal Opportunity Programs: Department of Communications

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes to existing equal opportunities programs have been made in the Minister's Department since the 1983 general election in regard to (a) aims, (b) assessment procedures, (c) methods of ensuring that the aims of the program have been met, (d) procedures for union involvement and/or consultation in the program, (e) the involvement of the Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau and (f) the priority rating of the program within the Department.
(2) What is the cost of the Department's programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department has incorporated the principles of equal employment opportunity into its personnel management policies and, though it operates no specially designated equal employment opportunity program, it places special emphasis on observing these principles in its day-to-day operations. Since March 1983, my Department has upgraded its staff consultative procedures and equal employment opportunity issues are considered as a part of these arrangements. It has also expanded the capacity of its Human Resources unit. It is currently considering whether it needs to take further action to promote the interests of any of the potentially disadvantaged groups within the Department's field of responsibility.
(2) The activities of the Department in this area are dealt with as a part of its day-to-day business and it would not be possible to accurately cost them.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Equal Opportunity Programs: Department of Territories and Local Government

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 5 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes to existing equal opportunities programs have been made in the Minister's Department since the 1983 general election in regard to (a) aims, (b) assessment procedures, (c) methods of ensuring that the aims of the program have been met, (d) procedures for union involvement and/or consultation in the program, (e) the involvement of the Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau and (f) the priority rating of the program within the Department.
(2) What is the cost of the Department's programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) My Department has issued a policy paper stating that all people employed by or seeking employment with the Department should have equal opportunity to be selected, and receive equitable treatment in all employment related issues. The policy objective includes the removal of discriminatory barriers against particular groups or individuals, the provision of special programs to overcome problems faced by disadvantaged groups, and the creation of a working environment and employment practices in which all employees are treated equitably.

(b) An interim Equal Employment Opportunities Committee was established to consider interim policies and procedures. following the report put out by this committee my Department has issued an EEO Policy statement. An equal opportunities sub-section has also been established, and is staffed by Clerk Class 9 and a Clerk Class 8 officer.

(c) Review is an integral part of the process of implementing and operating the Equal Employment Opportunity program. My Department's EEO committee structure also serves to monitor the progress of the program.
(d) Consultation regarding the most appropriate forms of union participation for implementing and monitoring the EEO program is planned for the near future.
(e) The Public Service Board has been consulted at all stages of the process, and their EEO Bureau provides resources for the implementation of policies and programs.
(f) My Department has accorded the program a high priority rating as evidenced by the allocation of resources.
(2) I am advised that the current major cost associated with my Department's program is the salaries of the Equal Opportunities sub-section staff, which are:
Other costs associated with the program are difficult to estimate at this early stage of implementation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 1 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Was there a derailment, on or about 28 March 1984, on the Tasmanian Region of Australian National AN, approximately 3.5 kilometres from Western Junction station, if so, (a) was this due to a defect in the permanent way, (b) had this defect been reported by guards of AN on 26 and 27 March 1984, (c) why was no action taken to rectify this dangerous situation and (d) what was the cost of the derailment to AN in (i) lost train running time, (ii) manpower and equipment in re-railing, (iii) wages of personnel used in repairing the track and (iv) repairs to damaged equipment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A derailment occurred on 28 March between East Tamar Junction and Western Junction.
(a) The derailment was due to a defect in the permanent way.

(b) and (c) The defect that caused the detailment was not reported prior to the derailment. However, on 26 March a track defect measuring vehicle on that section of the permanent way located and rectified another defect approximately 200 metres from the point of derailment on 28 March.

(d) The cost of the derailment in lost train running time was $160. The cost of manpower and equipment in re-railing was $300. Wages of personnel repairing the track were $1,000. There were no costs in equipment repairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 1 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: What were the results of discussions he, or his Department, had with the Northern Territory Government on proposals to include the people of the Cocos ( Keeling) Islands in the electoral division of the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's proposal to include electors on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island in the Northern Territory electorate for Federal election and referendum purposes has been the subject of correspondence between the Prime Minister and the Northern Territory's Chief Minister.

The Prime Minister first sought the views of the Chief Minister in December 1983. Following an exchange of correspondence, the Prime Minister advised Mr Everingham in a letter dated 17 May 1984 of the Government's concern that the two Territories should receive proper Parliamentary representation at an early date. The Prime Minister said that, because of constitutional difficulties with linking the Territories to an existing State, and because the Australian Capital Territory was clearly inappropriate on the grounds of remoteness and lack of community of interest, it had been decided to link both territories with the Northern Territory.

The Cocos (Keeling) Islands Self-Determination (Consequential Amendments) Act 1984 amended the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to incorporate the Territory of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands as a district in the Federal division of the Northern Territory. The amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 came into effect on 25 June 1984, the date on which the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Self- Determination (Consequential Amendments) Act 1984 received Royal Assent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to my repeated requests for a reference to the Australian Law Reform Commission on crime committed through, or in connection with, the use of computers-question Nos. 128 and 5062, Hansard, 13 September 1983, page 720, and 9 November 1982, page 2935 can the Attorney-General now say whether a reference will be approved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: At its meeting on 25 May 1984 the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General considered a paper in which the desirability of uniform legislation on computer crime was discussed. Ministers agreed that uniform legislation was desirable for the purposes of penalising the appropriation or use of computer data without lawful authority or excuse including the destruction, concealment of falsification of computer data. Ministers also agreed to report to the Standing Committee on results of investigations being carried out in their States and that a report on those investigations would be made at the next meeting.
In these circumstances a reference on this matter to the Law Reform Commission would not be appropriate at this time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 1 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which areas of the Eyre Peninsula, South Australia, (a) are not covered by (i) Australian Broadcasting Corporation and (ii) commercial television broadcasts and (b) do not receive an acceptable signal.
(2) What action is the Government taking to overcome these deficiencies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) With the exception of a coastal strip approximately 30 km wide, from Port Augusta to Port Lincoln, and the area embracing Ceduna, Poochera and Port Kenny, the remainder of Eyre Peninsula does not receive acceptable television signals. The Port Augusta-Port Lincoln coastal strip is served by two groups of National translators and a similar grouping of commercial translators operated by Spencer Gulf Telecasters. Ceduna, Poochera and Port Kenny do not have a commercial network of translators.

(2) I am aware of the television reception difficulties in the area of the Eyre Peninsula and I have asked my Department to consider the establishment of some additional National translators for this region. Planning for these translators is still in progress and inclusion in the ongoing construction program will be considered in the context of the funds available. The additional services being planned are expected to provide an additional 10,000 Eyre Peninsula residents with access to ABC television. Expansion of commercial television is dependent on proposals being received from parties interested in providing new services or extending existing services. At this stage no detailed proposals have been received.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 1 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to the confusion created by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's determination of Australian content for the 'C', or children's category, because of the Tribunal's failure to provide clear guidelines as to what will qualify for a classification; if so, what is being done to overcome this uncertainty whereby, with no present provision for classification at the concept or pilot stage, a television company could spend over $100,000 on a children's program and then have it rejected by the Tribunal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Tribunal released on 2 April 1984, its report and determination in respect of the children's television standards. This report contains a detailed explanation of the criteria for 'C' classified programs. The criteria, substantially the same as those published by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in May 1979, are set out below:
(a) is designed specifically for children older than five years and younger than 14 years,
(c) is well produced technically and artistically,
(d) can be easily understood and appreciated by children,
(e) fulfils some special need of children,
(f) contributes to the social, emotional or intellectual development of children,
(g) is appropriate for Australian children, not assuming too much of the culture, dialect or environment of some other country, and
(h) is not outdated in content or in technical or artistic production.

A provisional classification may be awarded where material at the concept script development stage is submitted to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for assessment. Children's Television Standard 10 sets out the proposed new provisional classification arrangements, which are similar to those applying at present. The purpose of those arrangements is to give guidance to producers at the earliest possible stage, to prevent waste of funds or effort. For most children's programs, a provisional classification is made on the basis of a written proposal accompanied by a pilot episode or a videotape indicating the nature of the program.

The provisional classification may be awarded for three months or for a longer period as determined by the Tribunal member delegated to determine applications on the basis of the prevailing production circumstances and following advice from the Children's Program Committee. In the event of the delegated member not classifying the program there is a right of review to the full Tribunal.

In addition, the Committee regularly meets with the program producers to assist them in understanding the requirements and their application to programs they are developing. The program producer may at any time before the expiry of the provisional classification submit the completed program-or representative sample episodes-for a full 'C' classification. The provisional 'C' concept is designed to assist producers in being able to ensure that programs they are developing ultimately meet the 'C' classification requirements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 1 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress is being made to overcome the very poor to non-existent Australian Broadcasting Corporation FM radio reception at Shepparton, Vic.
(2) Will a separate FM station or translator be constructed for the Shepparton area; if so, when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The transmissions of the ABC frequency modulation-FM-station in Bendigo may be received in Shepparton but are not of broadcast quality. A translator would be necessary to provide FM transmissions of an adequate broadcast quality.

(2) The National Broadcasting Service Planning Committee (NBSPC) which makes recommendations to me about sites to receive new or upgraded ABC facilities including translators, is currently considering the possibility of establishing FM translators at a number of locations. A recommendation has not yet been made by the Committee in respect of a translator to serve Shepparton.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Radio and Television Programs on Uranium

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 1 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: What radio and television programs has the Australian Broadcasting Corporation broadcast in 1984 to date which could be defined as (a) pro-uranium and (b) anti -uranium, including interviews of people who are for or against uranium mining and exports, nuclear disarmament and nuclear power generation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on information supplied by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The ABC does not categorise its programs into 'pro' or 'anti' uranium but prefers to leave this subjective judgment to its viewers and listeners. Programs are not made with the intention of being either for or against any issue.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Telephone and Phonogram Operators Association

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Com- munications, upon notice, on 1 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the terms of the agreement between the Australian Telephone and Phonogram Officers' Association and Telecom Australia.
(2) Prior to the agreement, how many telephonists were to be retrenched over a period of years.
(3) How many telephonists will now be retrenched.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Consistent with Telecom Australia's policy of providing employment opportunities for Australians in telecommunications, the terms of the Agreement between the Australian Telephone and Phonogram Operators' Association and Telecom Australia include the following:
Agreed conditions of employment to cover the relocation, redeployment, retraining and retrenchment of staff who are surplus to requirements.
A process for communication and consultation on new and expanded operator assisted products.

In handing down an order certifying the agreement on 13 March 1984, Commissioner Johnson of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission commended the parties approach to the settlement of the dispute:

The Commission wishes to commend the parties for the efforts which have obviously gone into the construction of the document and settlement of some severe outstanding industrial problems. The achievement of the parties by way of conciliation is consistent with the emphasis and responsibility placed on parties by this member of the Commission; the parties are accordingly asked to receive the Commission's appreciation of their efforts and to convey to their principals the approval of the Commission of the actions of the parties which have brought about this settlement and the express hopes of the Commission that this example may lead to similar action in other somewhat troubled areas. It connotes a high degree of improvement of industrial relations between the parties and the Commission expressly commends the parties for this reason.

(2) Prior to the Agreement, a telephonist staffing surplus of 2,500 to 2,800 by 1987 had been estimated. However, the number to be retrenched, that is, those telephonists not able to accept offers of relocation to another manual assistance centre, was not estimated.

(3) Under the terms of the agreement, staff identified as surplus will be offered opportunities and assistance for relocation or redeployment within Telecom under an active management program. The only telephonists to be retrenched will be those who do not accept these offers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 30 April 1984 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to my question No. 137 (Hansard, 23 August 1983, page 127) does he recognise that, over the last decade, Lebanon and its people have been subject to appalling loss of life, division, and the deterioration of order throughout the country.

(2) Is he able to say whether (a) the reconciliation talks in Lausanne in March 1984 failed to produce any concrete results, (b) no regional power can impose its will in Lebanon at the expense of any other regional power, and (c) no group within Lebanon can become the client of a foreign power without provoking internal bloodshed and disorder.

(3) Will he call for the internationalisation of Lebanon by creating a neutral disarmed Lebanon backed by United Nations guarantees and a multinational force for as long as it is needed and support any moves which would (a) ensure that Lebanon would be free from external interference in its internal affairs and (b) permit the Lebanese people to achieve a national reconciliation free from the consequences and complexities of disputes that arise elsewhere, and which are not of Lebanon's doing.
(4) Will he give urgent consideration and support to this initiative, patterned on the Austrian model, being a constructive initiative to bring peace and order to the people of Lebanon.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Successive Australian governments have expressed their deep concern with the human tragedy which has taken place in Lebanon since the outbreak of civil war in 1975 and have urged all parties involved in the fighting to seek a negotiated settlement. Both the previous and present Governments have made significant contributions towards assisting the reconstruction of Lebanon and providing humanitarian assistance to the people affected by the war.

(2) The reconciliation talks in Lausanne formed part of a difficult and lengthy process towards a peaceful settlement. They were followed in May by the formation of a Government of National Unity under Prime Minister Karami which contains the leaders from all the major Lebanese factions. The Government of National Unity has agreed on the implementation of new security arrangements within Beirut and has made progress towards the reconciliation of political differences among the various factions. The visit of the Vice President of Syria , Mr Khaddam to Beirut on 18 June was a significant step in helping to achieve agreement on the proposed security arrangements.

The Australian Government has consistently called for the withdrawal of all foreign forces in Lebanon which are not there at the express request of the Lebanese Government. We believe that the actions of some external groups have exacerbated the internal conflict within Lebanon and that the Lebanese people should be free from such outside interference and that the sovereignty of the Lebanese Government should be restored over the whole of Lebanon.
(3) and (4) I refer the honourable member to my answer to his question No. 137 of 12 May 1983 (Hansard, 23 August 1983, page 127).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 2 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which therapeutic devices are subject to the Therapeutic Goods Act.
(2) Are heart valves specifically subject to that Act.
(3) To what existing standards does the Act require compliance.
(4) Are there any plans for the Department of Health to monitor devices and alerts, and is the Therapeutic Goods Act applicable for that purpose.
(5) What is the expected date of commencement of the data base designed to monitor pharmaceuticals.
(6) Will there be any increase in funding for the National Biological Standards Laboratory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The definition of therapeutic use included under the Therapeutic Goods Act is broad and most therapeutic devices would be included within its provisions.
(2) Heart valves are considered to be therapeutic goods for the purposes of the Act but no standard has been defined to which heart valves would be subject.

(3) The Therapeutic Goods Act requires that goods comply with the provisions of the latest edition of the British Pharmacopoeia. The Minister for Health may also specify a standard in relation to goods for therapeutic use by reference to other publications, including a publication by the Standards Association of Australia, or by determining a standard for specific goods. In this regard a number of Australian standards have been published as Therapeutic Goods Orders but to date the emphasis has been given to pharmaceutical type products.

(4) My Department currently monitors hazard alerts on medical devices from a number of overseas sources and co-ordinates recalls if indicated. Provisions of the Therapeutic Goods Act are not applicable for the purpose and such recalls are thus undertaken on a voluntary basis with the co-operation of industry.

(5) Therapeutic Goods regulations were gazetted on 5 April 1984 providing for the collection of specific data about pharmaceuticals for human use. Notices have been served on industry to provide this data which is now being received. The entry of this information into a computerised data base will commence shortly.

(6) I have proposed a number of new initiatives for consideration by the Government in the budgetary context which could result in increased funding and resources for the National Biological Standards Laboratory. These proposals must of course compete with other Government priorities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 2 May 1984:

(8) Were any members of the train crew injured in the accident.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

ANSWER.PARA: (3) (a) 5 FW (b) 13 FE Derailed were 2 FW, 7 FE.
(4) (a) $3,000. (b) $4,000. (c) The repair of wagons is pending and costs have not yet been determined.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 4 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the European Space Agency, on 5 March 1984, launched the world's largest communications satellite, Intelsat V F-8, in geostationary orbit from near-equatorial French Guiana providing telecommunications among 28 countries.
(2) Is he also able to say whether the launching site of this satellite gives a 17 per cent greater payload than Cape Kennedy, United States of America.

(3) Will he confer with colleagues on the possibilities of an agreement with especially eastern hemisphere countries for a joint peace and development, remote sensing, information and communications satellite program based on a near -equatorial launching site.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Intelsat V (F-8) satellite is as large a communications satellite as any which has yet been launched.

It is the eighth satellite launched in the Intelsat V series. Six of the eight were launched from the Kennedy Space Centre at Cape Canaveral in the United States of America, and two have been launched by the European Space Agency which launches from the Guiana Space Centre at Kourou in French Guiana. Intelsat V (F- 8) will form part of the total system of 15 Intelsat satellites which collectively provide communications for virtually all of the countries of the world.
(2) The size of the payload which can be placed into a geostationary orbit by a given launch vehicle is higher for launch sites which are closer to the Equator.

Information published by Arianespace, the organisation which controls launch operations at the Guiana Space Centre, states that the payload for a given launch vehicle placing a satellite into a geostationary orbit would be about 14 per cent greater for a launch from the Guiana Space Centre-located at 5* North Latitude-than the payload if the same launch vehicle were used from the Kennedy Space Centre-located at 28* North Latitude. Payload, however, also depends on launch vehicle design and overall National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which launches satellites from the Kennedy Space Centre, currently has the ability to place greater payloads in a geostationary orbit than the European Space Agency launching from the Guiana Space Centre.

(3) Australia is a founding member and strong supporter of Intelsat, an international organisation which has been in operation since 1964 to provide a global commercial telecommunications satellite system to which all countries- members and non-members alike-would have access. The advantages of such a system have been widely recognised and 108 countries are now members. Of particular importance to Australia and neighbouring countries in the Pacific and Indian Oceans is that Intelsat provides affordable access to all users by rate averaging thin and heavy routes. Intelsat also recently approved a 'low density' satellite service-designated 'Vista'-which has been developed with a view to meeting the communications needs of remote communities-especially in Pacific island groups. Intelsat thus provides an excellent satellite communications service to both Australia and countries in the region.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 4 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the criticism of hundreds of smaller country newspaper proprietors over the failure of his Department to place advertisements with them for the 'Enrol to vote' campaign.
(2) Will he ensure that, in future, advertisements be included in these papers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The matter has been brought to my attention.

(2) In placing Commonwealth advertising the basic aim is always to achieve the most efficient communication of the message to the required audience with the most cost-effective use of the available funds.

It is therefore not possible to guarantee that advertising for all future campaigns will be placed in all newspapers. However, the Government fully appreciates the role played by country newspapers and they will continue to be considered for advertising whenever appropriate.

In the case of the 'Enrol to Vote' campaign of the Australian Electoral Office- now the Australian Electoral Commission-research showed that the target audience was principally in the main metropolitan centres. This meant that greater attention had to be paid to these centres in the media schedules.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the prevalence of fire blight of apples in New Zealand and that apple trees have no resistance to the disease.
(2) Will he ensure that no apples are imported into Australia from any area of New Zealand which is not known to be 100 per cent free of the disease.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Fireblight disease of apples was first reported from New Zealand in 1921. Its severity and occurrence in New Zealand are currently being investigated by New Zealand plant quarantine authorities. It is known that different varieties of apple vary in their resistance to the disease ranging from very susceptible to highly resistant.

(2) The importation of apples from New Zealand is presently prohibited except from districts in which the disease is not known to occur. As the distribution of the disease in New Zealand is not known, this effectively prohibits the importation of New Zealand apples. I do not propose to vary these restrictions unless there is new scientific evidence which could demonstrate that apples cannot carry the disease organism.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many householders are included (a) in and (b) on the periphery-within 5 kilometres-of, the present study area near Bathurst-Orange, New South Wales, being considered as part of the Army Training Facilities Project-ATFP.
(2) Will he consider redrafting the present study area to excise a significant number of small rural holdings such as Clifton Grove near Orange and Mt Rankin near Bathurst.

(3) Will he immediately excise Hill End from the present study area in view of the information provided in the document issued by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, November 1983, entitled 'ATFP-NSW, Guidelines for the Preparation of an Environmental Impact Statement'.

(4) What arrangements exist (a) in other rural and provincial centres throughout Australia for grazing rights and (b) with local government bodies in other parts of Australia for maintaining roads and other local infrastructure, in areas occupied for military training purposes.

(5) In respect of the present study area of the ATFP (a) how many approaches, either written or verbal, have been made to the Department of Defence offering property for sale to the Army and (b) can he indicate whether banks have withdrawn finance to property owners as a result of areas being designated for study.
(6) What rating arrangements does the Department of Defence make with local government authorities for land occupied for training purposes or for housing military staff in urban areas.
(7) What is the attitude of the Singleton community to the proposed transfer of Army facilities from their area.
(8) What is the present attitude of the New South Wales Government to the ATFP.
(9) Can he advise how the consultancy firm Dames and Moore engaged in the ATFP will assess the impact of the proposals on the superfine wool industry in the Bathurst-Orange area.
(10) What organisations in the Bathurst-Orange area have so far expressed positive support for the ATFP.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Study areas were approximately delineated in locations agreed with the New South Wales Government, of sufficient size to allow consideration of options for siting particular elements of the proposed training area, for example, impact areas. In the case of Bathurst-Orange, the study area was over double the approximate area indicated for Army's 'Schools Complex'-that is, 160,000 hectares. Basic statistics about the study areas as such, for example, numbers of householders, have not been compiled, essentially because they would have no relevance to assessing effects of establishing the Schools Complex.
(2), (3) A consultant has been tasked to recommend a potential site for a schools complex, in one of the three locations agreed with the New South Wales Government, which:
contains no, or few places of ecological or historic importance;
would satisfy Army's location , terrain and vegetation requirements; and
would, with appropriate land management, be able to sustain continuous training activities.
I am not prepared at this stage to prejudge issues which the consultant's report is expected to address.

(4) (a) Grazing leases have been authorised in parts of other military training areas, for example at Puckapunyal, Victoria, where this is practicable and consistent with their military use. Leasing arrangements are managed for the Commonwealth by the Chief Property Officer, Department of Administrative Services in the State where the military training occurs.

(b) The Commonwealth recognises a responsibility in certain circumstances to contribute to the maintenance of access roads and associated local infrastructure not under its control, which are used by Defence or other Commonwealth traffic. The Commonwealth provides funds to local government for the nominated roads, to cover additional costs due to wear caused by Defence vehicles.
(5) (a) My Department has been offered two properties from within the present ATFP study areas and two from outside these study areas.

(b) I have no knowledge of banks withdrawing finance to property owners as a result of areas being designated for study. As the Commonwealth is obliged under the Constitution to provide just compensation for any assets it acquires, it is not clear why finance would be withdrawn for such reasons.

(6) For Defence or other Commonwealth property, the Commonwealth recognises claims by local government authorities for payments equivalent to local rates for services rendered exclusively by the rating authority, such as water, sewerage, electricity or garbage services. These procedures also cover general rates where: the Commonwealth's tenant or lessee contributes as part of a rental an amount deemed to be in lieu of rates; or, the property is used by the Commonwealth or a Statutory Authority as a commercial enterprise; or, the Commonwealth is recovering-in whole or in part-its costs of providing the facilities and services in respect of the property; or, where the property is used solely to domestic purposes. Consideration is also given on a case by case basis to claims which do not strictly meet the above criteria and to appeals by local government authorities against the Commonwealth's initial determinations.

(7) The Singleton Shire Council has requested that the Army remain in Singleton . The Council expressed concern that any reduction of Service personnel would have a detrimental impact on the Singleton regional economy.
(8) the New South Wales Government continues to support the ATFP studies.

(9) Dames and Moore intend to assess the impact of the proposal on the superfine wool industry in the study region by evaluating the effect which alternative location options would have on the value of wool produced.

(10) Support for the continuation of ATFP studies in the Bathurst-Orange has been expressed by the Bathurst-Orange Development Corporation, the Orange City Council, the Bathurst City Council and Army Base Support Group Orange.
