QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: What changes to the telegram service is Telecom planning to institute and when will any changes be implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Telecom has no plans to change the nature of the telegram service. However, it is planning to improve the efficiency of the service by replacing the obsolete electro-mechanical telegram switching network-TRESS-with a more modern system, based on the telex network, using visual display screens and teleprinters. The replacement program is planned to commence in Western Australia during 1985, and in all other States during 1986.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 10 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the quarantine regulations on certain types of cheese still in place; if so, (a) what are these regulations and (b) which types of cheese and which countries are involved.
(2) Is it a fact that the French company SAFR-Picon, is air-freighting cheese varieties to Australia with a shelf life of only 45 days.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The quarantine requirements for imported cheeses are set out in Proclamation 88A and Animal Quarantine Regulation 69A. They remain in force.

Cheeses exported from countries other than New Zealand, Canada, United States of America, United Kingdom, Ireland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, Japan are subject to 120 days quarantine on arrival in Australia-less, in certain circumstances, the period of transport to Australia.

Cheeses normally subject to such quarantine may be exempted if the Director of Quarantine is satisfied that the manufacturing processes are sufficient to inactivate the virus of foot and mouth disease.

Exemption as above is authorised by a Permit System and is dependent on, inter alia, the pasteurisation of the milk of origin (or other acceptable heat treatment) and the acidity levels achieved during manufacture, particularly at the time of maturation. Subject to these standards having been achieved, there is no necessity for a prescribed 'shelf life'.
(b) All types of cheese are involved. The countries are as in (a) above.

(2) Quarantine records show that several cheeses manufactured by the French company Societe Anonyme Fromageries Picon have been exempted by Permit from quarantine because they are processed cheeses which during manufacture have been heated to at least 90*C. Some of these cheeses are imported by air. Their shelf life is not relevant in the quarantine context.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 10 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Director, any member of staff, or any member of the Council of the Australian National Gallery contact the Editor or any member of the staff of management of the Bulletin magazine following the publication in that magazine on 17 April 1984 of an article on the Gallery.
(2) If contacts were made (a) who made them, (b) to whom were they made, and (c ) what were the details discussed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the right honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am advised by the Administrator of the Australian National Gallery that to the best of his knowledge the only contacts made were as follows :
The Gallery's Public Relations Manager rang the Editor of the Bulletin magazine the day after the article was published to ask for the deadline for receipt of material in response to the article.
A telexed response was prepared by the Gallery and sent on 12 April 1984. This response referred to a number of significant errors of fact contained in the article.

On 13 April 1984 the Gallery's Administrator spoke to the Editor of the Bulletin advising that, on reflection, the Gallery did not wish to enter into a debate about the article and asked that the telex be withdrawn. The Editor agreed not to proceed with publication of the Gallery's response.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Classification of Words

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 10 May:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that since 1 March 1984 words have been classed as being no longer acceptable for use by Australian Broadcasting Corporation broadcasters; if so, (a) who (i) originally recommended and (ii) officially confirmed that the words be not used and (b) what are the words and (i) why are they no longer acceptable and (ii) what substitute words have been proposed.
(2) What disciplinary procedures will be involved to ensure the correct words are used.
(3) Will people interviewed by the ABC be expected to conform to this code, and will there be editing of interviews to ensure that any such offending words are not broadcast.
(4) What authority has the ABC to change what is standard or acceptable English in this country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) (i) (ii) At its meeting on 17 April 1984, the ABC Standing Committee on Spoken English-SCOSE-adopted guidelines for non-sexist language. These guidelines did not class any word as unacceptable for use by ABC broadcasters but rather suggested that certain words be avoided where they were inappropriate .

(b) (i),(ii) A copy of pages 1 to 7 of the SCOSE minutes of 17 April, setting out the non-sexist guidelines, has been provided to the honourable member. Copies have been provided to the House of Representatives Table Office for distribution to other interested honourable members and are reproduced at the end of this answer.
(2) None. The SCOSE document was issued for guidance and discussion.

(3) No. The ABC naturally hopes people appearing in its programs will refrain from deliberately sexist language. However, the Corporation acknowledges that it has no real control over the choice of language used by the public. Interviews will not be especially edited.

(4) The ABC claims no authority to change what is standard or acceptable English in this country. It must be recognised, however, that language changes and it would therefore be inappropriate for the national broadcaster to ignore community moves against discrimination in language.
STANDING COMMITTEE ON SPOKEN ENGLISH MINUTES
This meeting was held on Tuesday, 17th April at 9 a.m. in Roland Redshaw's office, 10th Floor, Upper Forbes Street, Sydney.
Professor Arthur Delbridge; Dr John Bernard; Ms Pepita Conlon; Mr Patrick Kirkwood; Mr Robert Peach; Mr Roland Redshaw; Mr Gordon Scott; Dr Ian Wolfe; Ms Angela Michaelis; Ms Elsa Atkin.

Recommendations of sub-committee on non-sexist language-The sub-committee's Guidelines for Non-Sexist Language were approved subject to some redrafting. The redrafted form accepted by the Committee is as follows:
STANDING COMMITTEE ON SPOKEN ENGLISH NON-SEXIST LANGUAGE GUIDELINES

All ABC broadcasters should use language that avoids sex discrimination and other forms of discrimination. These guidelines have been prepared to assist broadcasters in the use of non-sexist language. The examples used reflect usage in recent ABC programs which appears to be exclusive or discriminatory.
1. Avoid the use of words that imply that a particular group is all male or all female unless it is
(a) 'The men in government will be voting on the bill next week.' 'The nurse will find her role increasingly complex in the modern hospital.'
These instances wrongly imply that everybody in a particular group is of the same sex. It is better to say:
'The nurse will find his or her role . . .'
(b) 'When you and your wife go to the pictures . . .'
Broadcasters should be aware that this is addressed only to the males in the audience. One of the following may be more appropriate.
'When you and your partner go to the pictures . . .
'When you and your spouse go to the pictures . . .
'When you go to the pictures with your wife or husband . . .
'When you and your husband go shopping . . .' assumes that the listener is female, and can be rewritten in the same way.
2. Avoid the use of he as a generic pronoun
'It's all your average Australian really wants. He'll go to any length to get it.'
'The doctor will find that after the introduction of 'Medicare' he may have to bulkbill.'
'The driver will be paying more for his petrol after tonight's budget.'
Traditionally, and particularly in legal contexts, the pronoun he has been used generically. This situation is changing, and it is better:
to recast the sentence into the plural, or, as is often possible without damaging the sense,
The examples above can be rewritten:
'It's all your average Australian really wants. He or she will go to any length to get it.'
'Doctors will find that after the introduction of 'Medicare' they will have to bulkbill.'
'Drivers will be paying more for (their) petrol after tonight's budget.'
'A woman reporter asked the Prime Minister . . .'
(a) 'The girls seem anxious to go: that upsets the social balance, as too many young men remain.'

Language used to designate and describe females and males should treat and sexes equally. Parallel language should be used for women and men. In the example above, if the assumption is that the two groups are of roughly the same age, the sentence should be rewritten:
'The girls seem anxious to go: that upsets the social balance, as too many boys remain.'
or, 'The young women seem anxious . . . too many young men remain.'
'Michelle Ford . . . Michelle said . . .' but 'Kim Hughes . . . Hughes said . . .
In the use of honorifics like Mr and Ms, consistency should be maintained. These examples should become:
'Sam Jones and Mary Smith' or 'Mr Sam Jones and Ms Mary Smith . . .'
'Michelle Ford . . . Ms Ford said . . .' and 'Kim Hughes . . . Mr Hughes said . . .'
or, 'Michelle Ford . . . Ford said . . .' and 'Kim Hughes . . . Hughes said . . .'
In sporting contexts, the last of these would be preferable.
(c) 'The Premier and his attractive blonde wife . . .'

Descriptions should also grant equal respect to women and men. Emphasis on the physical characteristics of women is generally not appropriate where men are described in terms of professional or other achievements. It is better to say:
5. Avoid sexist stereotypes and demeaning language
'Speak to the girl on the switchboard.'

Stereotypes offer many assumptions, little information and no originality. They tend to be expressed in cliches, which the broadcaster should avoid anyway. Stereotypes of women are often demeaning as well. Those with a serious commitment to feminism regard the use of 'women's libbers' as trite and insulting. The 'girl on the switchboard' is probably an adult, and may be a man. 'Nat King Cole's little girl' is in her thirties. Avoid stereotypes by using a simple word. Why not:
'Here's Nat King Cole's daughter, Natalie' or 'Here's Natalie Cole'?

If there is no reason for distinguishing the sex of a person in marked endings, such as sculptress, poetess, authoress, or if in doing so the person described would be demeaned, then the marked ending should be avoided.
Terms such as aviatrix, ambassadress, place women into a separate section of their particular discipline, occupation or role.

Each time a women's sex is unnecessarily and irrelevantly highlighted, it perpetuates and reinforces the outdated attitude that woman is to be considered first as female and second as a person of talent or skill. So 'newspaper proprietress, Juanita Nielsen' should be 'newspaper proprietor, Juanita Nielsen' and 'sculptress Nancy Rieben' should be 'sculptor Nancy Rieben'.
Actor, poet, sculptor, etc., should be used except where an institutional preference or the personal preference of the woman concerned is for actress, poetess, sculptress, etc.
Flight attendant appears to be displacing air hostess and steward, and should be used where possible.
Where reference is to be made to a position, a quality or an action that might apply to either sex, terms that seem to include only one sex should be avoided where possible.
(a) Often the sentence can be recast.
'The chairman of the meeting was Mr Brown',
'A spokeswoman/spokesman for the union said that . . .
or, 'Mr Brown was in the chair',
'Jenny Brown/George Brown, for (or on behalf of) the union, said that . . .'
(b) Alternatively, a sex-neutral term may be substituted.

It may be possible to use a more specific word (e.g. financier for businessman, grazier for man on the land) where that would suit the context. Or there may be a close non-sexist alternative to the original word. An appropriate choice might be made from the following list, although NOT ALL ARE SYNONYMOUS.
anchorman presenter, host, compere, anchor, anchorperson.
businessman executive, owner, person in business, person in small business, investor, financier, or, in the plural, businesspeople, business community.
chairman convenor, president, head, chair, chairperson.
founding fathers founders, forerunners, forebears, ancestors, first fleeters.
man (verb) staff, operate, use, drive, work, attend.
mankind humanity, humankind, human beings, human society, civilisation, human race, people.
man on the land rural person, landowner, farmer, grazier, vigneron, et cetera or, in the plural, rural community, rural people.
man of letters writer, intellectual, scholar, author, cultured person.
man of science scientist, physicist, biologist, et cetera.
one man operation one person operation.
policeman police officer, detective, police cadet, or, in the plural, police.
sportsman sporting competitor, athlete, player, sportsperson, or, in the plural, men and women in sport.
weatherman weather reporter, weather presenter, meterologist, weather bureau.
working man, workman worker, working person.
The Committee recognises that the programs of the ABC call for a range of styles from the most formal to the colloquial. The spirit of these guidelines ought to be applied in all styles.
Reports of the ABC's use of language
The three reports received were discussed. A sub-committee comprising Mr Kirkwood and Mr Redshaw was formed to consider how they best might be used.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 29 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that on 19 August 1982 the Deputy Public Service Arbitrator Mr L. A. Booth, requested the Commonwealth Public Service Board to correct salary anomalies for professional engineers employed in the Commonwealth Public Service ; if so, what action has been taken by the Public Service Board to correct these anomalies.
(2) Is it also a fact that this Department is having great difficulty in attracting and retaining skilled and motivated professional engineers because of salary and classification anomalies.

(3) What action is the Department taking to reclassify the grades of professional engineers employed within the Department to bring them more into line with levels of responsibility and salary in comparable work areas elsewhere .
(4) What number of professional engineers (a) are engaged on a temporary or contract basis and (b) have worked for total periods of service in excess of 12 months within the Department.
(5) Are temporary or contract staff subject to any police or security clearance .

(6) It is a fact that his Department has insufficient permanent professional engineers to meet the function and role of his Department as presented to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure in April 1978.

(7) Does his Department at present employ sufficient permanent staff to design and construct Sydney's second airport when the site is chosen without seriously imperilling its ability to handle client department requirements Australia-wide.
(8) Why were a number of professional engineering positions abolished in his Department pursuant to notice published in the Public Service Gazette No. 38 dated 22 September 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)Yes; anomalies involving engineers or related designations have not been found to exist in the Department of Housing and Construction.

(3) The Public Service Board defines the responsibility for each of the five classification levels in the engineer structure. It is also responsible for changes in the salaries at each of these five levels; in pursuance of that responsibility it consults with staff and professional associations and normally makes representations in the arbitral process.

The Department's engineering structure and its deployment of engineers is in a continual state of change to cope with variations in the volume and nature of work. The process of change includes the creation/abolition of positions of variations to the levels or duties with a view to ensuring that staff are employed at classification levels appropriate to its responsibilities arising from an approved project, works or program of works.
(4) (a) As at 1 June 1984, the Department had 70 temporary and contract engineers.
(b) Of these 15 have been engaged for a period in excess of 12 months.
(5) On projects or parts of projects of national security assessment, my Department seldom uses temporary or contract staff and then only if they are security cleared.
On projects involving commercial security risks, where normal burglar possibilities might arise, both temporary and contract staff are utilised. These persons are supervised by permanent staff.

(7) Typically such a project would be catered for by forming teams comprising existing staff experienced in aerodrome pavements and building works together with private consultants. These teams would probably be supplemented by some additionally recruited staff and by the use of contract personnel to meet peaks as they occur in the design process.
The extent and number of in-house staff to be deployed into the project team would depend upon other approved Government building and engineering projects existing at that time.

(8) In line with then Government directives, my Department increased its use of private consultants on design workload through the second half of the 1970s and the early 1980s. The resulting reduction in overall staff requirements at the lower end of the five class engineer structure led to the abolition of long term vacant positions of Engineer Class 1 and Class 2, in accordance with Public Service Board policy.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Emergency Helicopter Pad: Concord Repatriation Hospital

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 30 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: When will a permanent lighting system be installed for the emergency helicopter pad at Concord Repatriation General Hospital, N.S.W.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, in association with the Minister for Aviation, has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Concord Repatriation General Hospital primarily provides treatment to veterans and other repatriation beneficiaries but also plays a dual role as a major emergency hospital for the New South Wales community.
It is in its emergency role that the hospital's helipad and existing portable lighting guidance system are intended for use.

The helipad at Concord Repatriation General Hospital is currently equipped with a rotorstrobe navaid guidance portable night lighting system designed and developed in Australia. The Department of Aviation advises that, while this system may be of some assistance to helicopter pilots conducting emergency night landings and take-offs, it is not suitable for routine flight operations. The Department further advises that as the use of the Concord helipad at night is very infrequent and in emergencies can be used under its mercy flight provisions , no plans to install a permanent lighting system are presently under consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the closer economic relations arrangements for margarine.
(2) What subsidies or other forms of government assistance are available for New Zealand exports of margarine to Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Trans-Tasman trade in margarine is subject to the general terms of the Australia New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement. There are no special arrangements for margarine under this agreement.

(2) There are a number of New Zealand Government assistance measures presently available to New Zealand exporters which may be used in relation to margarine subject to meeting the necessary conditions. These measures include export performance taxation incentives (EPTI), export market development taxation incentives (EMDTI), export program suspensory loans (EPSL), export suspensory loans, sales tax refunds, import licensing concessions. Under the Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement, New Zealand is committed to phase out the performance-based export incentives in trans-Tasman trade by 1987 commencing with a 50 per cent cut in entitlements next year. This will affect the eligibility of margarine exporters to claim export performance taxation incentives and export suspensory loans on exports to Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What products did he refer to as 'high quality exports to Australia' following the meeting with Mr Haferkamp of the European Economic Community.
(2) Why has access for these products to Australia been given greater emphasis than access for Australian products to the EEC.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The questions relate to my media release of 21 March 1984 following the Australia/Economic Community ministerial consultations on trade and related issues which were held in Canberra.
The answer to the first question is that the phrase 'high quality Community exports to Australia' refers to exports of textiles, clothing and footwear-TCF- and passenger motor vehicles.
The answer to the second question is that the media release does not give greater emphasis to access for these products to Australia than it gives to access for Australian products to the EEC.

The major part of my statement is in fact taken up with Australia's concerns in relation to agricultural trade. For example, after introductory paragraphs, the first substantive paragraph states 'the consultations were wide ranging, a major focus from the Australian side being agricultural trade issues, including access to the EC and Community subsidy practices in third markets'. Subsequent paragraphs develop further Australian concerns with access into the EC for agricultural products.

The penultimate paragraph of my media release states 'it was also recognised that it would be necessary to continue discussing difficulties of access for both sides and especially for high quality Community exports to Australia and the operation of non-tariff barriers'. This paragraph is part of a section of my statement dealing with trade in manufactures. The Community for its part has concerns about the operation of tariff quota and import licensing systems in relation to its high quality exports of TCF and passenger motor vehicles. Australia has also expressed concern to the EC about the operation of non-tariff barriers such as export franchise restrictions and administrative obstructions to its exports of manufactures to the EC.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce , upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Australian Bureau of Statistics or its predecessors record any Aboriginal population figures on a State or Territory basis prior to 1967; if so , will he now release those figures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Statistics on Aboriginals have been produced and released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (and its predecessors) prior to 1967. The most comprehensive sources are the censuses of the Commonwealth held in 1911, 1921, 1933, 1947, 1954 and 1966. Data on Aboriginals for States and Territories were published in the Statistician's report for each census. However, the degree of coverage and information obtained varied substantially.

The 1966 census was the first in which an attempt was made to enumerate the entire Aboriginal population. At all earlier censuses, Aboriginal people living outside settled areas were not counted. Data collected on Aboriginals in the 1966 census were published in two bulletins: 'The Aboriginal Population of Australia-Summary of Characteristics' and '1966 Census of Population and Housing -Volume 1, Part 2-Race'.

Prior to the first Commonwealth census in 1911, statistics on Aboriginals were obtained by censuses conducted by State government bodies. In addition, some data on Aboriginals were collected regularly by State government bodies after the first Commonwealth census. The best source for such data is the monograph by Dr L. R. Smith 'The Aboriginal Population of Australia' published by the ANU Press in 1980.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to statements by Swedish diplomat Sverker Astrom and Prime Minister Olaf Palme, former chairman of an international commission on disarmament and security, that a global legislative and security system, to outlaw war, is the only way to world security, that is, a form of government with federally defined powers over international security matters.
(2) Has he any evidence to indicate that Sweden has a better record of security than nations involved in arms races in recent centuries.
(3) Will Australia pursue common cause with Sweden in a peace race, as actively as military aid to and alliances with less successful nations in the field are pursued.
(4) Will the Government run a campaign to inform Australians of this supreme issue and the need for a world constituent assembly to set up an alternative to confrontation at the United Nations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am of course aware of the fact that many distinguished people around the world advocate various forms of world government as a means of resolving the security and other problems of mankind. That is a noble ideal but it is not, in the Government's view, a practical basis for Australian foreign policy in 1984. As most advocates of world government recognise, securing international agreement to establish an effective supra-national authority would be considerably more difficult and problematic than everything else which has been attempted in international relations to date and would in no way circumvent the problems and conflicts which afflict existing international institutions.

Moreover, I cannot accept a proposition to the effect that a commitment to world government is the only way to world security. Instead the Government believes in tackling present day problems with energy and determination bringing to bear in this endeavour all the resources available to the Australian Government.

I am glad to say that we work closely in this enterprise with many other countries. The Australian and Swedish governments co-operate particularly closely in seeking to bring about effective international agreements for disarmament and for assistance to the economic development of poorer countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the recognition of the danger of national military sovereignty by the constitutions of (a) France, preamble, paragraph 15, (b) West Germany, articles 24 and 25, (c) Denmark, article 20 and (d) Japan, article 9.

(2) Will he seek amendments to the Australian Constitution to provide for progressively pooling Australia's military forces and belligerency powers under international auspices along with those of other nations ascribing to the need for comprehensive obligatory international arbitration of international disputes within a system of international law binding on inhabitants of Australia and having precedence over federal law as a requirement for lasting collective security and increased international co-operation; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware of the foreign constitutional provisions cited by the honourable member.

(2) No. The Government does not intend to initiate moves for constitutional amendment to provide for the progressive pooling of Australia's military resources under an international body, for Australia's further accession to compulsory arbitration of international disputes, or for self-execution of international law in Australia.

On the first point it is the Government's policy to maintain Australia's involvement in the security system administered by the United Nations, based on principles of national sovereignty and participation by consent.

On the second point, since 1954 Australia has been party to the Optional Clause of the Statute of the International Court of Justice [Art 36 (2)], providing for the compulsory jurisdiction of the Court in international legal disputes.

On the third point, while customary rules of international law may, in some circumstances, become a part of Australian common law, the usual practice is for the Federal parliament, where desirable, to incorporate rules of international law by Statute.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice , on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn by Mr Phil Ward of Epping, New South Wales, editor of Adventist News, to the fact that he (a) knows the identity of those who claim to have disposed of Azaria Chamberlain's body, (b) has been unable to persuade them to confess for fear of jail and (c) has notified the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory whose police Mr Ward suspects of manufacturing evidence in order to discredit the magistrate who castigated them at the inquest.
(2) Will the Attorney-General call for an amnesty to anyone, not involved in the killing, who can throw light on disposal of the body, in the light of the Cruise murder in New Zealand.
(3) Is the Northern Territory the only part of Australia where infanticide results in a sentence other than psychiatric treatment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My attention has been drawn to the allegations made by Mr Ward in relation to his investigation of the Chamberlain case.

(2) The handling of this or any other offence against the laws of the Northern Territory is the responsibility of the Northern Territory authorities, and it is not possible for me to intervene in the manner suggested.

(3) Infanticide is a special statutory offence, which exists in New South Wales , Victoria and Tasmania. The penalties set down for the offence in those jurisdictions are, of course, maximum penalties. While it would always be open to a court, in the exercise of its discretion when sentencing a woman convicted of infanticide, to provide for some form of pyschiatric treatment, the penalties available cover other possibilities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether (a) Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Japan will participate with US-sponsored RIMPAC exercises from 28 May to 30 June 1984, (b) these exercises will culminate with the co-ordinated shelling of Kaho'olawe and (c) native Hawaiians have protested at this destruction of land of cultural significance recognised by the United States national register of historic places.
(2) What will be the Australian involvement in destroying this island.

(3) What international treaties and conventions including ANZUS and the International Court of Justice findings concerning French nuclear tests and environmental conventions applicable in South West Tasmania have relevance to this action.
(4) Will he urgently review Australia's commitment to these exercises.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes. (b) The exercise included naval gunnery support firing on Kaho' olawe Island range. (c) Yes.
(2), (3) and (4) Australian Defence Force units participating in RIMPAC 84 did not use the range facilities on Kaho'olawe Island.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Australia consider Swiss standards when preparing guidelines or regulations for importation, labelling or conditions of use of agricultural chemicals.
(2) Is he able to say how Australian controls differ from Swiss standards regarding the use of Ciba-Geigy's pesticide Galedron.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I presume the question relates to the product Galecron, not Galedron.

In the case of the pesticide Galecron based on the chemical chlordimeform there are no Swiss registrations. This is not unexpected because the compound is utilised only on cotton and no cotton is grown in Switzerland. Though chlordimeform is approved for such use in Australia it is available only to licensed aerial operators under conditions which preclude the possibility of operators or bystanders being exposed.
For a fuller understanding of the issues involved in these questions the following information is helpful.

Chlordimeform was discovered in the early 1960s and was developed by Ciba-Geigy and Schering AG as a novel insecticide/acaricide. Prior to September 1976 the product was registered in Australia and many other countries for the control of various insect and mite pests on cotton, pome fruit, stone fruit, vegetables, tomatoes and strawberries as well as for the control of cattle tick. The toxic action of chlordimeform on insects and mites is by direct contact and vapour activity against both mobile stages and eggs.

In September 1976 Ciba-Geigy and Schering AG suspended production sales and registrations of all products containing chlordimeform world-wide. This decision was based on interim findings of a lifetime mouse feeding study. In the development of chlordimeform prior to marketing a wide range of toxicology testing had been completed on a range of laboratory animals. These studies showed no adverse effects. However, in the subsequent mouse feeding study chlordimeform caused a dose-related increase in a particular type of tumour at high feeding levels. A lower dose of chlordimeform produced no tumours even at the end of the two-year feeding study.

During 1976 and 1977 research programs conducted by the manufacturers in several countries demonstrated conclusively that exposure to chlordimeform, when applied by air, could be minimised and in most cases maintained below the limits of detection by the use of additional but reasonable practical precautionary measures at application sites. Based on these studies the manufacturers considered chlordimeform could be re-introduced for use on cotton in Australia with usage strictly limited and controlled in the initial season to demonstarte that negligible exposure would result. Following evaluation of the new scientific data by health and agricultural authorities the product was registered and re-introduced to New South Wales in the 1978-79 cotton season. Authority was expanded to include Queensland in 1979-80.

The precautionary measures introduced for handling chlordimeform were aimed at reducing the possibility of dermal exposure to the chemical during mixing, loading and marketing operations. Detailed operating instructions and guidelines were issued to all authorised users and all persons involved in the application of chlordimeform have been regularly monitored to determine whether they have carried out the precautionary measures as indicated by the absence of traces of chlordimeform from their urine.

The use of chlordimeform based products has been subject to annual review in Australia and that review has been based heavily on the urine monitoring results from the previous season. This type of monitoring is carried out in most, if not all, countries where chlordimeform is used for the treatment of cotton. Experience over the six seasons during which these controls have been in place has shown that the exercise has been successful. Because of the success of the operation and the experience gained it has been agreed that the compulsory monitoring of operators will be replaced by a voluntary scheme where, if an operator potentially exposed to chlordimeform wishes to submit a urine sample, the analysis will be performed and the results will be communicated back to the operator. This allows individuals to monitor their occupational hygiene and handling practices and puts the onus on the operator to act carefully and responsibly.

In addition to the application manual issued to all licensed applicators, label bear explicit recommendations for the safe handling of chlordimeform based products including specific directions for the use of appropriate protective clothing.
All of these steps were initiated by the manufacturers but each step was subject to detailed evaluation and approval by the appropriate health and agricultural authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he say whether the Dalkon shield was voluntarily withdrawn from sale by the manufacturers in 1974 in the United States of America but not in Australia; if so, what data were made available to Australian authorities, and when, by those manufacturers as to the hazards of the shield and the reasons for the withdrawal.
(2) What standards (a) apply or (b) are contemplated to govern therapeutic imports other than pharmaceuticals.
(3) What international discussions are proceeding on ethical standards for suppliers of goods to our country when another country has discontinued such supply for health reasons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In mid-1974 the local distributors of the Dalkon shield, A. H. Robins Pty Ltd, advised my Department of the voluntary suspension of marketing of the device in the USA following reports, in that country, of second trimester septic abortion associated with its use. Withdrawal of the product from the Australian market was not undertaken, or requested, at that time in view of the absence of reports of similar incidents occurring in Australia. However, letters were circulated to doctors in Australia by A. H. Robins in July 1974 and by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee-ADEC-in October 1974, inviting submission of details of any similar local adverse effects. In February 1975, the ADEC concluded the available information was insufficient to allow any firm conclusion to be reached. Meantime, A. H. Robins voluntarily suspended sale of the Dalkon shield in Australia as from 18 January 1975, pending the implementation of changes to the presentation of the device.

(2) (a) and (b) No standards currently apply to therapeutic goods other than pharmaceuticals, but I have proposed a number of new initiatives for consideration by the Government in the budget context which could lead to some controls over medical devices. These proposals must, however, compete with other Government priorities.

(3) I am not aware of any international discussions on ethical standards for suppliers of therapeutic goods to our country specifically, but in the pharmaceutical field there have been two international conferences of drug regulatory authorities, co-sponsored by the World Health Organisation, in which Australia has participated, where agreement has been reached on urgent notification of other national agencies in the event of serious adverse effects relating to drugs coming to attention. Furthermore my Department monitors hazard alerts on medical devices from a number of overseas sources and co-ordinates recalls, if indicated, on a voluntary basis in co-operation with local importers .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What decisions were reached at the Joint Industry Consultative Committee- JICC-between Australia and New Zealand Dairy Industry representatives held on 10 May 1984.

(2) Was action taken on the increasing imports from New Zealand of ice cream, skim milk powder and casein, referred to in the answer to question No. 1201 ( Hansard, 29 May 1984, page 2398); if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As I indicated in my response to question No. 983 (Hansard, 28 February 1984, page 120 refers) the JICC comprises representatives of the dairy industries of Australia and New Zealand, with Government representatives attending only in an observer capacity. I am advised by Mr M. L. Vawser, the leader of the Australian delegation to the JICC meeting held on 10 May 1984, that the following subjects were discussed and agreements reached.

Both delegations expressed grave concern at the continuing overproduction of milk throughout the world, in particular in the European Economic Community and United States of America, at a time when there is little, if any, total market growth. The delegations were convened to see the rapid rise in world stocks and the consequential dampening effect this has had on world export prices.

Both delegations noted that Australia and New Zealand would be ending the 1983- 84 season with relatively higher levels of stock of the major manufactured products than normal and that this would create pressures to place that additional stock in the new season. It was also noted that, for the season, both the Australian and New Zealand dairy industries are predicting at least a maintenance of the current level of milk production in each country and this in turn would generate higher than desirable levels of product for the export market. The delegations agreed that, in these circumstances, close liaison would be required between the two industries to avoid aggravating the downward pressure on market returns.
Both delegations agreed to co-operate as closely as possible in monitoring developments in the international market for butter.

The delegations agreed that the current International Dairy Arrangement under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade-GATT-formed a valuable part in maintaining some semblance of rationality in world market activity and stressed the importance of the GATT minimum pricing arrangements at their current levels in placing a floor in the world marketing price. Both delegations agreed to resist any moves to lower the GATT minimum prices.

Some concern was expressed by the New Zealand delegation at the slow-down in the rate of growth in the Australian cheese market in 1983 (3 per cent compared with 8.9 per cent in 1982) and discussion took place on the measures which have been implemented by the Australian dairy industry in an endeavour to generate a higher level of growth. This aspect will be monitored and efforts will continue to be made to add further to that growth. In accordance with the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding on Dairy Products attached to the Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement, it is expected that exports of cheese to Australia from New Zealand will increase by some 400 tonnes in 1984 to approximately 6,400 tonnes. It was noted that there had been a significant reduction in New Zealand exports of edam to Australia and this trend was considered likely to continue throughout 1984. The New Zealand delegation advised that the New Zealand Dairy Board's-NZDB-recent takeover of a major Australian cheese importing and marketing company would assist it in the orderly marketing of New Zealand cheese in Australia.

In general, both delegations agreed that the forthcoming 1984-85 season would be one of extreme difficulty for the industries in both Australia and New Zealand, given the continuing upward trend in milk production and declining world prices. The two industries agreed to continue close consultation to take advantage of any marketing opportunities which might arise in the interests of maximising the returns to dairy farmers on both sides of the Tasman.

(2) I am advised by the Leader of the Australian delegation that the Australian side expressed concern at the continued low pricing of New Zealand ice cream and related products. Whilst it was acknowledged that imports of New Zealand ice cream were very low relative to the size of the Australian ice cream market, exceptionally low pricing of New Zealand ice cream, iced confection and ice cream mix were a disruptive influence in the Australian ice cream market. The NZDB advised that it was still investigating the matter. The Australian delegation provided the NZDB with comparative retail pricing information, compiled by the Ice Cream Manufacturers' Federation of Australia, to assist in the NZDB's assessments.

I am advised that the apparent increase in imports of skim milk powder from New Zealand reflects the inclusion of powdered ice cream mix under the statistical item for skim milk powder while the casein imported from New Zealand is of a specification which is not produced by Australian manufacturers. I understand that there has been no complaint to the ADC or to my Department from Australian manufacturers regarding the volume or pricing of New Zealand casein.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: What would the insurance cover for the successful launch of the first two Aussat satellites have cost if taken out (a) 12 months ago and (b) now.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from Aussat, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Aussat's intention is to finalise launch insurance arrangements during the course of this calendar year, that is, about 6 months before first launch. As yet a firm quote for launch insurance has not been received. Accordingly, it is not possible to quantify the cost of launch insurance for Aussat's first two satellites if taken out 12 months ago, since no firm quotes were available. Furthermore, it is not possible to quantify the cost of launch insurance now, since no firm quotes are available.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Salvaging of Maralinga and Emu Atomic Test Sites

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who received the salvage rights for the Maralinga and Emu atomic test sites and what was the extent of the salvage rights.
(2) Was there any government or departmental supervision of salvaging; if so, what form did the supervision take.
(3) Were there tenders called for the salvage rights; if so, what were the terms and conditions of the tender and how many (a) individuals, (b) companies and (c) organisations made applications.
(4) Was any special arrangement entered into for salvage rights with the Yalata mission; if so, (a) what were the arrangements, (b) who made them and (c) on whose behalf were they made.
(5) Over what period did the salvaging take place.
(6) Has the salvaging been concluded.
(7) How many people were involved in the salvaging and how many of them were Aboriginals.
(8) Were any (a) health checks conducted and (b) health records kept of people involved.
(9) Were records kept of the sale of salvage; if not, why not.
(10) Was radioactive or contaminated materials or equipment (a) salvaged and (b ) sold.

(11) Is it a fact that Mr E. Dutschke was involved in salvaging equipment and materials from the Maralinga and/or emu sites; if so, did he have either (a) experience with handling radioactive equipment or (b) suitable measuring instruments to determine whether or not materials were radioactive.
(12) If Mr Dutschke was involved in salvaging, did he (a) keep records and (b) issue receipts for money received from salvaging; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Aboriginal Lands Trust of South Australia granted salvage rights for the Maralinga village to the Yalata Community Incorporated. Salvage rights extended to all of the buildings and improvements, fixtures, fittings, equipment and chattels in the Maralinga village and to eleven fuel storage tanks at Watson . Details of the terms and conditions of salvage are contained in the agreement.
No formal salvage agreement was entered into for the Emu site.

(2) No. Supervision of the salvage operation at Maralinga was the responsibility of the Manager of the Yalata mission and his officers. Close liaison was maintained with the range commander and the authorities at Woomera.
(3) Yes, tenders for Maralinga buildings were called by the Yalata community. Records were maintained by the Yalata community at the time.
(5) and (6) Salvage of materials at Maralinga began in 1974 and was largely completed by 1980. Some buildings are retained at Maralinga by the Commonwealth under the terms of the salvage agreement.
(7) Details of people employed during the salvage operation were kept by the Yalata officials. The salvage agreement provided for preferential employment of Yalata people.
(8) No. The South Australian Health Department and the Range Commander advised the Yalata community that the Maralinga Village materials presented no risk to health.
(9) Yes, records were kept by the Yalata community of materials salvaged from the Maralinga village and subsequently sold.

(10) Despite some instances of materials being wrongly prepared for salvage-for example, copper cable-the Manager of the Yalata community at the time was not aware of any radioactive or contaminated materials having been removed from Maralinga by the salvage operators. Some materials removed from the forward areas were done so at the specific request of authorities at Woomera. Assurances were given by these authorities about the safety of these actions and instructions provided about areas to be avoided.

Recently, in response to public concern, tests have been conducted by the South Australian Health Commission on materials and equipment known to have come from Maralinga and now located in the South Australian towns at Yalata, Ceduna, Coober Pedy, Barmera and Loxton. No evidence of radioactive contamination has been found. The Department of Defence has carried out similar tests on material at Salisbury, with the same result.
(11) Yes Mr Dutschke was involved in salvaging materials from Maralinga but not Emu.

No, on the basis of assurances from relevant authorities Mr Dutschke neither had, nor was required to have, any experience with handling radioactive equipment or instruments for measuring radioactivity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1046, Hansard, 2 may 1984, pages 1965 -6, concerning the development of an electro-magnetic gun-EMG-program being developed under an Australia-United States memorandum of understanding, can he say whether Australia and the United States have had a bilateral co-operative agreement for the technology development of hypervelocity and electromagnetic guns and launchers for approximately the last three years.
(2) Is this agreement in the process of being renewed; if so, what are the terms of renewal.
(3) Is the agreement between the Australian Department of Defence and the United States Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.

(4) In the development of the EMG (a) has the Australian National University been involved in developing a power source and (b) has the Materials Research Laboratory in Melbourne helped pioneer the development of the technology.
(5) Is he able to say whether the United States Pentagon recently acknowledged this EMG program and described it as being an excellent co-operative effort.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My answer to the honourable member's earlier question No. 1046 in this House was not concerned with the development of an electromagnetic gun. Rather, it acknowledged work being performed by my Department in co-operation with the United States Department of Defense on research into the technology of electromagnetic launchers.

This matter has stimulated considerable interest in this Parliament with the honourable member for Hindmarsh having asked two supplementary questions on notice in this House-Nos 1488 and 1492-Senator Chipp having asked one question without notice, Senate Hansard, 10 May 1984, page 1929, and two questions on notice-Nos. 910 and 911 on 29 May 1984. Also, Senator Macklin chose the first reading of the Live-Stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and cognate Bills-Senate Hansard, 7 June 1984, pages 2742-2744-to deliver a lengthy speech on this same general subject.

For the record, the Materials Research Laboratories in my Department commenced its current research program on electromagnetic launchers in 1979. The bilateral arrangement on this subject between Australia and the United States of America commenced in 1980. The prospective military implications of this technology mentioned in the United States-Australia bilateral arrangement relate only to tactical conventional warfare.
All the research work performed by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation in my Department is oriented towards solving problems for the Australian Defence Force.
Co-operation with allied countries and the ensuing sharing of results frequently saves us a great deal of money.

The timing and significance of the Australian National University contribution to this work is of some interest. The theoretical basis of propulsion using travelling electromagnetic fields has existed since early this century. However, its practical application has been greatly facilitated by work which commenced some 30 years ago at the ANU and led to the development, by the mid-1960s, of a novel form of homopolar generator. Much later, this came to the notice of the DSTO and, separately, the United States Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. It was largely as a result of this development that the proposal for a co-operative R and D program between Australia and the United States of America on electromagnetic guns and launchers and pulsed power conditioning was put forward by the United States of America in 1980. The ANU work was not conceived with any defence applications in mind.
With this explanation the answer to the first part of the honourable member's question is in the affirmative.
(2) Yes. The agreement is being considered for renewal on essentially the same terms as in 1980.
(3) The arrangement is between the Australian Department of Defence and the United States Department of Defense.
(4) (a) Yes. See the response to part (1) above.
(5) Yes. It reflects great credit on the capability of DSTO in my department that its achievements in this area of research have been acknowledged so readily by US authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he say whether (a) the United States of America and (b) Australia (i) are and (ii) have been, using Cocos Islands as a staging post for any military aircraft; if so, for what purpose is the airfield on the Cocos Islands being used.
(2) How many visits to the Cocos Islands have (a) United States and (b) Australian Defence Force aircraft made in each of the last five years and this year up to the date of reply to this question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) For many years up until August 1982 United States Navy P3 maritime reconnaissance aircraft occasionally used Cocos Island airfield as a stop-over point en route to Australia or when undertaking ocean surveillance missions.

(b) Royal Australian Air Force aircraft have used Cocos Island airfield on a periodic basis for many years. Royal Australian Air Force P3 maritime reconnaissance aircraft use the airfield as a stopover point during routine patrols in the Indian Ocean. There are also occasional visits by RAAF special purpose transport aircraft carrying ministerial and official visitors and C-130 transport aircraft in transit to other destinations.
(2) The number of visits by Australian and United States Defence Force aircraft over the past five years is shown in the following table:
VISITS BY MILITARY AIRCRAFT TO THE COCOS ISLANDS 1979-1984

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1046-Hansard, 2 May 1984, pages 1695- 6-in particular, concerning the Australia-United States memorandum of understanding, can he advise how many other programs are being carried out under the auspices of the memorandum of understanding on co-operative research and development.
(2) How many of these programs are of a defence or military nature and what are they.
(3) What Australian Government departments, universities and other institutions are involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the United States/Australia memorandum of understanding on co- operative research and development of 1968 there are currently eight programs being carried out.

(2) All of these programs are of a defence or military nature. The title and nature of two of these programs are classified by agreement between United States of America and Australia and are not available for public release. The remainder are programs on:
(a) Influence of the environment on the properties of fibre composite materials .
(b) Electromagnetic guns and launchers and pulsed power conditioning.
(c) Low cycle fatigue in aircraft engines.
(e) High frequency over the horizon radar.
(3) The Australian Department of Defence alone is involved in all these programs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the concerns of the British and Australian people about their civil rights with regard to the divulgence of information relating to nuclear testing at Maralinga, Emu and Monte Bello and support and backup services to the United Kingdom atomic tests.

(2) Can the Minister give assurances that those people who wish to give information to the Government or government sources regarding the atomic tests in Australia, will be exempt from legal action by either the British or Australian Governments; if not, can the Minister say under what (a) conditions and (b) circumstances divulgence of information by both military personnel and civilian personnel can be given to the Government or government sources without fear of legal reprisal by either the British or Australian governments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Minister for Resources and Energy has invited anyone who has information which they believe may be relevant to the Government's investigations to write to him or his Department.

Although provisions of the Crimes Act 1914, the Atomic Energy Act 1953, the Public Service Act 1922 and regulations, and the respective Service Acts and regulations control the disclosure of official information by Commonwealth officers, service personnel and other persons, clearly no legal action will be taken against people responding to the invitation to provide information of assistance to the Government's investigations.
In relation to the policy of the British Government the British High Commission issued a Press release on 29 May 1984, the text of which follows:

'Since the return of the Maralinga test site to Australian control in 1968, the strict security which applied to the UK atomic test program in Australia has been relaxed considerably. Any persons, particularly British exservicemen resident in Australia, who took part in any of these tests and who have information concerning their individual health, are entirely free to make such information available to the Australian authorities. If they have other information about which they may have doubts as to whether it remains classified , they should contact the British High Commission in Canberra.'

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government's position on the United States Reagan Administration's proposed ballistic missile defence system, referred to as the strategic defensive initiative-SDI-or 'star wars' been announced; if so, what is it.
(2) Is it a fact that the SDI when deployed will break the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile-ABM-Treaty.
(3) Will the SDI, by using nuclear pumped X-ray lasers, break the treaty against the deployment of nuclear weapons in space.

(4) If the Government is in opposition to the 'star wars' program, why is Australia co-operating with the United States Government on research and development of electro-magnetic launchers which the Pentagon and he have admitted are proposed for anti-ballistic missiles systems, in the 'star wars' program.
(5) If the Government does not oppose the 'star wars' program, how does it explain its commitment to arms control given that the 'star wars' program is intended or will negate the ABM Treaty.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The SDI is a long term US research program designed to examine the potential for new technologies to provide defence against ballistic missile attack. The Australian Government understands the genuineness of the pressures of concern that led the United States to undertake this research program-in particular the attractions of an approach which seeks to prevent nuclear war by placing increased emphasis on defence rather than threatening a devastating nuclear counter-attack-but is concerned about the possible implications of SDI for outer space arms control and the maintenance of a stable strategic balance between the superpowers. The US Government has been made aware of Australian concerns.
These concerns have also been expressed to the Soviet Government which is also believed to be undertaking research programs on possible space weapons.

Australian Ministers have expressed on a number of occasions the Government's concern that outer space is the coming arena of superpower competition and have called for the prevention of an arms race in outer space. Military activity in outer space is already circumscribed through several existing arms control agreements. The Government supports strengthening this arms control regime through further verifiable agreements.

Australia is an active participant in the consideration of outer space issues in the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva. It is encouraging the Conference to think through the longer term implications of recent developments relating to outer space before irreversible steps are taken. It urges all countries, especially those with space capabilities, to work in good faith to avoid an arms race in outer space.

(2) At this stage the SDI is confined to a research program and a decision on whether to develop and deploy such a system is not expected until the early 1990s. The 1972 ABM Treaty and its 1974 protocol ban the development, testing and deployment of all ABM systems and components that are sea-based, air-based, space-based or mobile land-based. Although the treaty allows the development and testing of fixed land-based ABM systems and components, including those based on other physical principles (such as lasers and particle beams) it also requires that specific limitations on such systems would be the subject of discussions between the parties to the treaty in accordance with Article XIII of the treaty and agreement in accordance with article XIV of the treaty.

Research on the technologies involved in ballistic missile defence is not in conflict with either superpower's obligations under the ABM Treaty-the Government understands that the Soviet Union is also conducting an extensive program of research and development into the possible application of new and existing technologies for such purposes-but raises questions as to its longer term viability. A decision by either superpower to proceed beyond research would have implications for the current ABM Treaty and clearly would require discussions between the parties to the treaty. The Government understands that, in this context, the United States has proposed government-to-government discussions with the Soviet Union on the implications of these technologies which both sides are exploring.

(3) Nuclear-pumped lasers are only one of a number of possible technologies being examined under the SDI research program. The question as to whether a nuclear-pumped laser would constitute a 'nuclear weapon' or be more akin to a nuclear power source currently used in some space vehicles, could not be considered until the details of any proposed operational systems are available.
Any nuclear explosion in space would contravene the 1963 Partial Test Ban Treaty, to which both the United States and the Soviet Union are parties.

(4) The Australian Government is co-operating with the US Government in research and development of electromagnetic launchers because it believes that such research has potential benefits for the Australian Defence Force. The specific project arrangement covering this co-operation relates to anti-armour, air defence and artillery weapons that are of direct interest to Australia, and not to any possible strategic or space applications.

(5) The Government does not believe there is any inconsistency between its position outlined in (1) and (2) above and its commitment to arms control as most recently expressed in statements by the Prime Minister on 6 June 1984 and the Foreign Minister on 4 July 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are electronic machines imported by New Zealand buyers from Australia subject to an import duty of 25 per cent plus sales tax of 40 per cent.

(2) Is the sales tax component of 40 per cent placed on the final formula for the article arrived at by (a) the cost of the machine, (b) the insurance paid on the machine and (c) the freight charged on the machine.

(3) Is a similar formula used by the Australian Customs Service when placing duty and/or excise on similar machines being imported by Australian buyers from New Zealand; if not, does the formula used by New Zealand customs authorities place the Australian exporter at a disadvantage in trans-Tasman trade.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of parts (1) and (2) the New Zealand High Commission advises electronic machines attracting a sales tax rate of 40 per cent in New Zealand are office machines, classified under headings 84.51, 84.52, or 84.53 of the New Zealand Customs Tariff; photocopying and thermo-copying apparatus, classified under heading 90.10; automatic data processing machines and units thereof, magnetic or optical readers, machines for transcribing data onto data media in coded form and machines for processing such data, being goods classified under heading 84.53 of the Customs Tariff. None of the above machines attract a duty of 25 per cent when of Australian origin-indeed, except for guillotines and paper shredders (duty rate 10 per cent), they are all duty free when of Australian origin.

Sales tax is generally paid on the price at which the goods are sold by a licensed wholesaler in terms of the Sales Tax Act 1974. When the machines are imported into New Zealand by a person who is not a licensed wholesaler, sales tax is leviable on a value calculated from the sum of the following amounts:
(a) the value of the goods for the purposes of customs duty;
(c) the amount or proportionate part thereof paid to the Crown for the issue of an import licence;
(d) the amount paid to transport the goods to New Zealand and to insure the goods for such transport and;
(e) 25 percent of the sum of the amounts referred to in (a) to (d) above.

This formula is intended to provide a measure of equality on the value for sales tax purposes of imported goods, irrespective of the status of the importer , by establishing a notional wholesale value.

In respect of part (3) Australian ad-valorem duties are calculated by reference to the customs value of the dutiable goods. The customs value is determined in accordance with an International Agreement, to which both Australia and New Zealand are parties, and in general is based on the price of the goods with a limited range of adjustments. The Agreement allows parties the option of including or excluding overseas freight and insurance in the customs value. Australia does not include these costs.

Electronic office machines entering Australia in the main fall to headings 84. 51, 84.52, 84.53, 84.54 and 90.10 in the Australian tariff. When imported from New Zealand such machines presently are free of import duty.
Australian sales tax is levied on a value which is 120 percent of the sum of:
(a) the value of duty of the imported goods;
The sales tax levied is in accordance with the Sales Tax Assessment Act (Number 5) of 1930. In the case of electronic office machines the rate of sales tax is 20 per cent.
On the basis of the foregoing information it would seem that Australian producers of electronic office machines are not disadvantaged in Trans-Tasman trade vis-a-vis their New Zealand counterparts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there an organisation within the Launceston workshops of Australian National-AN-called the Combined Unions Committee-CUC; if so, (a) which unions form its membership and (b) what is its authority within the management of the AN workshops.

(2) Has management recently denied work to employees in the workshops area because the employees being placed in that area are members of a union not affiliated to the CUC; if so, has management accepted this decision and denied employees of AN the right to employment in the workshop area because of union membership and not based on ability to do the work.
(3) Has the management of the Tasmanian Region of AN failed to carry out the rulings of management in the Launceston area and accepted the CUC's demands.

(4) Do the rules governing work in the Launceston workshop area state that a person shall work where directed and, if the order is refused the person shall be suspended from duty; if so, were employees of one union, refusing to work with employees in another union, suspended from duty by management.
(5) Is this inter-union dispute affecting the revenue of the Tasmanian Region of AN.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is an organisation within the Launceston workshops, but it is known as the Combined Railway Union's Committee-CRUC-
(a) Australian Metal Founders and Shipwrights Union-AMFSU-Electrical Trades Union-ETU-and Australian Railways Union-ARU;
(b) The Committee does not have any authority in the management of AN's Launceston workshops.

(2) No. However the CRUC placed bans on such employees and as a consequence AN has been subjected to intermittent work bans since August 1983. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was notified of a dispute at that time, and several hearings have taken place without resolution. There has been no discrimination against any group of AN employees to the advantage of others. AN' s approach has been and will continue to be to take all possible steps to meet each situation in a responsible manner and endeavour to resolve problems in an unbiased way.

(4) An undertaking was given to Mr Commissioner Cross during Arbitration proceedings that AN would not exacerbate the situation by suspending employees who were acting in accordance with a union ban. It was agreed by all parties at the Arbitration proceedings that the unions be given some time to resolve the matter amongst themselves. However this has not occurred to date.
(5) The Tasmanian Region of AN has lost revenue because of this inter-union dispute.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Queensland Government Guidelines for Contact with Commonwealth

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 1 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to directions from Queensland Government instrumentalities to officers of departments and semi-government authorities, including some with major federal funding components, to the effect that no officer may undertake any commitment to Australia or participate in inter- governmental committees advising a Federal Minister without Cabinet authority and must notify the State Co-Ordinator-General immediately if asked by the Federation to accept responsibilities which could conflict with their State responsibilities; if so, has he sought from the Queensland Premier clarification of reciprocal guidelines calculated to implement concepts of co-operative federalism rather than moves towards secession and cold war among governments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It is for each Government to determine the way in which its relations with other Governments will be conducted.

As far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned, we have, since coming to office, consistently followed a policy of seeking co-operation and constructive negotiation with State Governments on matters of mutual interest and concern. This policy has been pursued at all levels, including forums such as the National Economic Summit and Premiers' Conferences/Loan Council meetings, Commonwealth-State Ministerial Councils, and meetings of officials. It will continue to be our guiding principle in all forms of Commonwealth-State contact.
It is, of course, reasonable to expect that there would be a reciprocal spirit of co-operation from the States and indeed we can usually count on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) I refer the honourable member to the statement made by the Prime Minister in this House on the 6 June 1984 on the general purpose and functions of the joint defence facilities in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 4 June 1984:
