ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Members are appointed to the Australian Manufacturing Council-AMC-on the basis of their capacity as individuals to contribute to the Council's principal function which is to provide broad-based advice to the Minister on matters relating to manufacturing industry. To ensure that the Council was in a position to provide such advice, nominations for membership were sought from a wide range of interested groups including employer and employee organisations, government, consumer groups, and academic and research bodies.

(2) Members of the AMC do not receive payment for their participation in work of the Council. They are however eligible to claim travelling expenses and overnight accommodation expenses where this is necessary to attend meetings. To date the AMC has met twice, on 26 April and 18 June 1984, and four claims for travel/accommodation totalling $2,131.10 have been processed. Further claims are expected.

(3) A formal Secretariat for the AMC has not yet been established. Secretariat services have in the interim period been provided from within the Department's existing resources. For this reason it is not possible to identify the total operating cost of the AMC.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he say whether West Irian and East Timor were incorporated illegally into Indonesia because of the failure of Indonesia to allow and/or arrange internationally supervised acts of self-determination.
(2) Can he also say whether West Irianese dissidents are forcibly repatriated by Papua New Guinea without access to international refugee organisations.
(3) Does Australia differentiate in representations to other nations on behalf of dissidents according to the military or ideological alignment of the governments concerned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Indonesia's claim to Irian Jaya arose after the Indonesian Republic achieved independence in 1949. The Indonesian claim was based on the grounds that Irian Jaya had always been an integral part of the Dutch East Indies and, as the successor state to the Dutch East Indies, it should have sovereignty over the territory.

In 1950 negotiations between the Netherlands and Indonesia concerning the status of Irian Jaya broke down, and eventually the matter was submitted to the United Nations General Assembly in 1954. Following further inconclusive diplomatic manoeuvres and armed conflict between the Netherlands and Indonesia, the Netherlands agreed to transfer the territory to the United Nations on 1 May 1962. Administration of Irian Jaya was subsequently transferred to Indonesia in May 1963.

There was a provision in the transfer for an 'Act of Free Choice' to be held under the United Nations auspices. A plebiscite took place in 1969 which was found to result in a vote in favour of integration with Indonesia.
Like the great majority of the international community, the Australian Government recognises Irian Jaya as an integral part of the Republic of Indonesia.

Concerning East Timor, you will be aware that during my visit to Indonesia in April 1984, I noted on behalf of the Australian Government that East Timor had been incorporated into the Republic of Indonesia, but expressed the Government's deep concern that an internationally supervised act of self determination had not taken place. The Indonesian Government maintains that the status of East Timor as a province of Indonesia was decided in a vote on integration held in East Timor in July 1976.

(2) The Government has been monitoring developments along the Indonesian-Papua New Guinea border closely. As regards the repatriation of people from Irian Jaya who have recently crossed the border and are now in PNG, the Government has noted assurances by PNG's Foreign Minister, Mr Namaliu, to the PNG Parliament that those Irianese who have a well-founded fear of persecution because of their involvement in dissident activities in Indonesia should be allowed to stay in PNG for the time being.

Regarding the role of international refugee organisations, the Government is aware that the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees UNHCR has been in contact with PNG and Indonesian authorities concerning the Irianese border crossers. To date, the PNG and Indonesian authorities have preferred to seek arrangements for the repatriation of the border crossers between themselves . In the Australian Government's view, it is necessary that the solution to the problem of border crossers should take full account of the important humanitarian considerations that are involved.

(3) The Government makes representations on human rights on behalf of dissidents in countries across the political and geographical spectrum, including Indonesia. While in each case the Government's approach is adjusted to achieve the most effective result in the relevant circumstances, this does not in any way diminish the Government's commitment to see internationally recognised human rights standards universally protected and promoted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 June 1984:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am very conscious of the financial difficulties facing RPH stations around Australia.

As the honourable member may be aware, in announcing RPH services in 1978, the then Minister indicated that it was expected that RPH stations would be financially self-supporting. For various reasons including the fact that RPH frequencies are off the primary broadcasting band and that many print handicapped persons are on low incomes, it has become evident that RPH stations are experiencing significant funding difficulties.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Rural and Religious Departments

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Australian Broadcasting Corporation still proceeding with its re- organisation which will result in the downgrading of the rural and religious departments; if so, has the ABC responded to the criticism from many Australians against this ill-considered action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. There has been something of a concerted campaign, emanating from inaccurate press reports, by various interests concerned that the Religious and Rural Departments will be downgraded as a result of the ABC's re-organisation. The ABC has assured me that this is not the case.

I am advised that, under the new structure for the ABC, approved by the Board of Directors, the Religious Department will become a separate unit in both radio and television with a functional head, who will cover both media. The specialist identity of the Religious Department will therefore be maintained and religious programs will continue to have an importance place in ABC schedules.

The previously integrated Rural Department has also been separated into radio and television groups. Administrative structures, which were relevant 30 years ago-before the ABC operated a television service-are no longer appropriate. In preparation for the introduction of a second regional radio network, the ABC is also planning to establish a number of new regional offices and studios as extra commitment to rural listeners.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How is it expected that farm equipment and livestock will be valued, under the assets test, when an application is made for a pension by a farmer.

(2) In the case of a drought or rural depression and the market for an, at cost , $10,000 header or tractor is non-existent, other than at a give-away price, is he able to say whether (a) the farmer's 'real market' value will be accepted or (b) the theoretical depreciated value will be required, and the final determination of the full catalogue of equipment on the farm will be potentially subject to an independent valuation; if the latter is correct, who will make this valuation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Farm equipment and livestock will be valued under the assets test at their current net market value-the value of those assets after deducting any debts owing on them.

(2) A farmer will be able to advise his estimate of the current net market value of his farm equipment irrespective of its initial cost. The market value of the equipment as advised will be accepted unless a professional Government valuer, when making a random check of values advised, considers such an estimate of value to be out of line with evidence of current market values. Any debts outstanding on the equipment will be deducted from the current market value. If dissatisfied the pensioner will have the right to lodge an appeal against the values taken into account.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that the Minister's Department, in the assessment of assets for the payment of a pension under the Government's new income and assets test scheme, will continue the practice of ignoring eligible assets given away, rather than sold, by the applicants, after 5 years; if so, how will the gift be assessed for each of the five years if the applicant dies and the spouse applies for a pension.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the proposed legislation a person may dispose of assets of up to $2,000 per year-single-and $4,000 per year-married couple-without adequate financial consideration through such means as gifting. The value of assets disposed of without adequate financial consideration in excess of these limits is to be deemed the property of the donor. The value of such deemed assets is to be depleted by a flat 10 per cent per year so that it will be completely disregarded 10 years after the act of deprivation. In the case of a married couple, half the value is to be maintained against each pensioner.

Upon the death of one of a married couple the treatment of any outstanding value will depend upon which partner legally owned the asset concerned. If it was jointly owned, half the outstanding value would continue to be maintained against the survivor. If owned wholly by the deceased pensioner, no amount would be maintained against the survivor; conversely, if it was solely owned by the surviving pensioner, the full amount outstanding would be maintained against that person.

In relation to new claimants for pension, the Department will have regard to the disposal of assets in the five-year period prior to the person's application . However, no regard will be had to amounts disposed of prior to 1 June 1984. There will also be provision to shorten the five-year period where the applicant could not reasonably have expected to become eligible for a pension, for example , where due to an accident a person qualifies for invalid pension.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Compensation for Effects of Delay in Postal Deliveries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 7 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Does any provision exist to offer any consolation or compensation to a Canberra man who posted a cheque for $500 to help his daughter in Melbourne with a deposit on a house which was a 'good buy' but which she subsequently lost because the cheque took 11 days to reach her.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice provided by the Australian Postal Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The postal by-laws preclude the payment of compensation for loss incurred as a result of delay in the transmission or delivery of a postal article unless:
(a) the article was lodged in Australia for transmission by registered post to a place in Australia;
(b) the article would, in the normal course of transmission, have been delivered not less than seven days before the occurrence of the event for which the contents of the article were required; and
(c) before the article was delivered and before the need for the contents occurred, the claimant reasonably obtained substitutes for the contests.

If those conditions are met, compensation would be limited to the reasonable costs incurred in obtaining a substitute for the contents of the delayed article . Depending on the postal service used, a refund of postage may be payable.
Australia Post will be pleased to inquire into the cause(s) of the delay in the instance referred to if the sender provides details of the lodgment and delivery of the article and the service used.

(2) Can he explain the discrepancy between this delivery and when mail from the United Kingdom addressed to the same pensioner takes only 6 days to deliver.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, from information provided by the Australian Postal Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) It is not clear whether the question refers to an isolated instance or a series of events. However, it is understood, from advice provided by Mr Lloyd's office, that the cheques in question are posted at the Perth GPO on alternate Wednesdays, at around 2 p.m. Australia Post's service standard between Perth and Bendigo for delivery of ordinary mail posted on Wednesday at the Perth GPO is two working days, provided the article is posted by the advertised closing time of 6 p.m. Standard articles so posted should be delivered in Bendigo on the Friday.

Australia Post has established procedures for inquiry into claims of lost, damaged and delivery delayed mail. Details of allegations are fully investigated by Australia Post including operational aspects of transportation and sorting. Confirmation of particulars of posting and delivery is required. The allegation in this question is one which would involve inquiry into postal operational aspects and details of postings, et cetera, should be referred to Australia Post for such inquiry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 7 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made with the appointment of Community Affairs Officers, and a Principal Community Affairs Officer to consider complaints against the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
(2) How many complaints have been received and have there been any from members of Parliament.
(3) Is the Prime Minister eligible to use this procedure to lodge complaints against the ABC; if so, will he draw the Prime Minister's attention to this facility.
(4) Is it the intention of the Managing Director or the Corporation Board to refer all future complaints to this facility or will the Prime Minister continue to have privileged direct access.

(5) Will he reconsider his opposition to an independent United Kingdom type complaints commission for the ABC and the commercial stations, particularly now that Sir Zelman Cowen has recently supported the concept.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ABC appointed a permanent Principal Community Affairs Officer, Mr Don Dunoon, on 25 June. The position was advertised widely earlier in the year and has been filled for some months by temporary appointees until Mr Dunoon was able to take up duty.

The Board of Directors at its 29 June 1984 meeting approved the progressive establishment of a Community Affairs Officer in each State, (including New South Wales) and Territory as vacancies occur within approved staff ceilings.

(2) Two complaints, meeting the statutory terms of section 82 of the ABC Act, have been accepted by the ABC and have been investigated. The first was from the honourable Barry Jones, MP, Minister for Science and Technology, and claimed misrepresentation of fact in a television program. The second complaint, from a private citizen, concerned an alleged invasion of privacy.
(4) The Prime Minister has no privileged access.

(5) The Government has undertaken to conduct a review of the complaints procedures available under the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act after the report of the Principal Community Affairs Officer PCAO to Parliament in 1984 on the first year of operation of the procedures. This review will take into account the PCAO's report and any other relevant information.

(2) Will (a) interest and (b) storage costs be underwritten by a change in form of expression of underwritten values from a gross to net basis, as requested by the Australian Dairy Industry Conference; if not, is the Government aware of the serious complications for the stability of domestic market prices for dairy products if export market prices reach General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade minimum levels and interest and storage costs are not underwritten.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I announced on June 27, 1984 the Government's decision to continue present underwriting arrangements for dairy products to cover the 1984-85 season. The levels to apply for 1984-85 are as follows:
Butter 1,885 Cheese 1,721 Skim-milk Powder/Buttermilk Powder 846 Casein 2,126 Wholemilk Powder 1,228

(2) The Government decided that underwriting for 1984-85 should be on a gross basis. Dairy underwriting will cost the Australian taxpayer about $12m in respect of the 1983-84 season and, if the Australian Dairy Corporation's estimates for 1984-85 are proven correct a similar amount for that season. Changing underwriting from a gross to net basis would have further increased the size of likely government contributions. If export market prices reach GATT international dairy arrangement minimum levels and Australian exporters cannot make sales, the marketing arrangements will be under pressure whether or not interest and storage costs are underwritten by the Government. The decision to continue underwriting for 1984-85 indicates quite clearly the Government's commitment to maintain a viable, economic and efficient dairy industry.

(2) Is it also a fact that the tender is for supply over a three-year period at a fixed price for the period; if so, why is a fixed price over three-years being insisted upon in view of the Government's support for indexed wage increases in line with rises in the consumer price index for the remainder of the working population.
(3) Will he have the Authority immediately rescind this unreasonable tendering condition; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Yes. Formerly, contract prices were indexed to the CPI. The Authority, however, decided that tenders for the next three-year period-1984-86-should be at a fixed price. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 7 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that in 1970, when the previous excise on 2 J spirit existed, all relevant premises were bonded and payment of the duty was made at the time of clearance from bond for sale of the fortified wine in which the spirit had been used; if so, is the same procedure now used for the 2 J spirit excise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Excise duty was levied on spirit used in the fortification of wine from 1901 up until 1970 when a general excise on wine was introduced. Excise duty on fortifying spirit was not re-imposed when excise was removed on wine in 1972, but was introduced in the 1983 Budget. The Government removed the excise on this spirit on 22 June 1984.

In the period 1901-1970 excise was collected at the time the fortified wine entered the market-place. It was possible to apply this system of revenue collection during that period as there was a consistent return of revenue and changes in rates were infrequent.

With the imposition of the excise in 1983 it was recognised that if the revenue was to be paid at the time the fortified wines entered the market-place, there would be virtually no revenue return for two to three years and significant administrative problems would have arisen with the application of indexation, in determining the precise duty liability. For these reasons the duty was liable at the time of fortification and was collected under the Customs weekly settlement arrangements.

In the period between 1901 and 1970, Customs needed to control the fortified wine until it was delivered for home consumption. Any premises storing such product pending duty payment were required to be licensed Customs premises for the storage of under bond goods.

Under the arrangements existing between 23 August 1983 and 22 June 1984, all premises using spirit to fortify Australian wine were subject to Customs control . However, there was no Customs interest in the fortified wine and it could be stored, moved and sold without any Customs controls being necessary.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Excise on Spirit: Effect on Australian Wine Industry

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 7 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the introduction of the excise on 2J spirit made any change in the structure of the Australian wine industry in fortified wine producing areas; if so, what are the changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The effects of the imposition of the excise on fortifying spirit, in the 1983 Budget, have been monitored by the Government. Information obtained from the major fortified wine producing regions indicated that the excise had produced a significant reduction in grape intake for fortified wine production, a reduction in, or cessation of, production of fortified wines by wineries, and the closure of a grape spirit distilling plant. No major grape surplus occurred as the impact on grape growers was masked by an increase in table wine production, largely to replenish depleted stocks because of the particularly low 1983 vintage.

The Government accepted that the excise had been a factor contributing to the current difficulties of the industry and removed the excise with effect from 22 June 1984. In announcing the decision, the Treasurer indicated that removal of the excise should assist a substantial restoration of fortified wine production and that the Government will closely monitor developments in the industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 7 June 1984.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that, on 16 November 1983, the Acting Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce said, when referring to the excise on 2 J spirit used in fortified wine that the purpose of the reintroduction of the excise was to lessen excise avoidance possibilities, simplify administration and yield revenue; if so, has the Government achieved any or all of those three objectives and (a) in what way and (b) to what extent.
(2) Are these three objectives equally applicable to (a) 2M (b) 2N (c) 2D and ( d) 2Q spirit; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Acting Minister did make the statement on 16 November 1983.
It should be pointed out that the Government removed the excise duty on fortifying spirit on 22 June 1984.
Whilst the excise has now been removed, the Government was in the process of achieving its three objectives.
However little purpose is now seen in commenting further on this matter.

(2) As far as excise items 2M, 2N, 2P and 2Q are concerned, they are all free items (as now is 2 J-fortifying spirit) subject to meeting specific end use requirements. The Department of Industry and Commerce will continue to maintain its controls over these goods to minimise excise avoidance and wherever possible , simplifying its administrative requirements. Revenue is only a consideration if the spirit is not used for the expressed concessional purpose.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 7 June 1984:

(a) to facilitate the drawback on excise duty on fortified wine lees which are subsequently re-distilled and
(b) to permit the exemption from duty of grape spirit used in (i) wine for religious purposes and (ii) reduced alcohol wine.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

(i) whilst it was the Government's intention to amend the regulations, this is no longer necessary following the decision to remove the duty on fortifying spirit;
(ii) grape spirit is not used in the production of reduced alcohol wines and no amendment is necessary.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sale of Australian Alcoholic Beverages at Australian Airports

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 7 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the answer to question No. 615 (Hansard, 9 November 1983, page 2456) , why does the Government not give priority to the duty-free sale of Australian alcoholic beverages at Australian airports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Duty free shopping facilities at Australian international airports are provided for the convenience of the travelling public and generate substantial Commonwealth revenues by way of fees for authority to trade on airports. The Commonwealth oversights all facets of the operation of the facility to ensure the maintenance of the highest possible standards for the travelling public.
The shops are operated by private enterprises, selected following public tender action. Stocking policies are a matter for the business judgment of the operator , who responds to consumer demand.

A range of Australian alcoholic beverages are available at airport duty free shops and compete on their merits with international brands. It should be noted that a number of Australian alcoholic beverages, notably wines, are not subject to duty and sales tax and thus there can be no price advantage in purchasing these lines at an airport duty free shop.

It is of course, normal practice for manufacturers and distributors of alcoholic beverages to conduct in-shop promotions of particular product lines, and this is a common occurrence at airport outlets. Should Australian industry representatives wish to undertake similar promotional activities, they could contact the proprietors of the airport shops.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Excise on Spirit: Cost of Collection

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 7 June 1984:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There has been no variation in the cost of administering the collection of revenue from the excise on fortifying spirit as compared to previous years when no duty was collected.

This is because the excise item for fortifying spirit is a concessional one and departmental controls are therefore essentially applied to ensure that the spirit is used to fortify Australian wine. If it is not so used, the spirit currently attracts a rate of duty of $20.90 per litre of alcohol.
Whilst the duty was removed on 22 June 1984 departmental controls will still need to be maintained to ensure the spirit is used for the concessional purpose of fortification.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: European Economic Community: Import Meat Requirements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 7 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that on 15 April 1983 he announced the visit of eight veterinary reviewers from the European Economic Community to inspect Australian export meat plants following changes to the EEC's import meat requirements.

(2) Will he arrange (a) a reciprocal Australian review team to visit the EEC to inspect the quality of EEC exports to Australia of alcoholic beverages and dairy products and (b) an Australian import inspection service to monitor the quality of imports to Australia of horticultural and dairy products including alcoholic beverages; this service to be paid for by the countries exporting the goods to Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. A team of eight veterinary officers from the EEC arrived in Australia on 15 April 1983 to inspect Australian export meat plants following changes to EEC's fresh meat directives governing imports.

The Australian industry was aware of the changes and the implications they held for continued eligibility of their plants to export to the EEC. Consequently, both industry and Government regarded the visit as being of utmost importance for Australia's continuing trade in meat and offal with EEC countries.

While in Australia the mission inspected meat establishments which had nominated for inspection and prepared a list of plants which they considered eligible to handle meat for shipments to the EEC markets.
(2) Within Australia, the States and Territories have responsibility for administering domestic food laws including ensuring that imported foods comply with the appropriate food standards.

Apart from the application of quarantine regulations and Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, there are no comprehensive Commonwealth inspection arrangements for imported foods either at the place of manufacture or point of entry. Commonwealth involvement is largely limited to the administration of quarantine control, tariffs and prohibited imports rather than the inspection of imported produce.

The whole subject of food laws in Australia has been raised within the Australian Agricultural Council and it has been recommended that more attention needs to be given to the policing of Australian food law to ensure compliance of both domestic and imported foods. Action is in train in this regard.
The Council also considered that the legislation covering foods for domestic and export markets and for imported foods should be aligned as far as practicable.

At this stage the major concern is to achieve greater uniformity of action on foods sold in Australia, whether of local or imported origin. The question of reviewing food manufacturing conditions in overseas countries exporting to Australia is not at this time seen as a practicable alternative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 April 1984 (Hansard, page 1247), Mr Millar asked me a question without notice concerning the categorisation of private hospitals. I undertook then to give the honourable member a more detailed answer:

ANSWER.PARA: The classification of private hospitals into categories was not introduced until Medicare, consequently the reference to restoration of individual hospitals to their former categories is quite wrong.

The reason for the variation of the original categories of eight private hospitals in Queensland on 23 March 1984 was that I had approved and had gazetted amended categorisation guidelines. I would mention that the original guidelines had the support of the State Health Ministers, as do the amended guidelines. The amendments had the effect of broadening the criteria for category two hospitals which of course enabled me to reclassify some hospitals.

As both the Commonwealth bed day subsidy to private hospitals and the health insurance benefits are paid in accordance with the determined category for each hospital, and as the amended guidelines only have effect from 22 March 1984-( determinations for the individual hospitals were effected on 23 March 1984)- there is no scope for backdating any payments to hospitals.

It is likely that some of the Queensland hospitals may have been penalised financially by the uncooperative attitude of Mr Austin, the Queensland Minister for Health. He had the opportunity before Medicare started, and all the time since, to recommend to me that particular hospitals be reclassified, and failed to do so. The gazetted guidelines give me a discretionary power to accept such a recommendation regardless of the criteria requirements. Mr Austin refused to support any reclassification of Queensland hospitals, except in those cases where I initiated the changes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to (1) an article in the Australian Financial Review of 15 February 1984, relating to the introduction of electronic funds transfer (EFT) and (b) a call by the Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission, Mr Justice Michael Kirby, for comprehensive federal legislation to deal with issues raised by EFT such as consumer rights of data access and challenge privacy and data security and the need to update the law of cheques for the age of EFT.
(2) If so, will the Attorney-General refer this issue to the Law Reform Commission for report as a supplement to its recent report on privacy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Indeed, I mentioned the numerous issues that are arising in relation to EFT in answering a recent question without notice by Senator Crowley (Senate Hansard, 24 March 1984, p. 795).

(2) No. The Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) in its 1983 Report on Privacy has already adverted to the privacy implications of EFT and has drawn attention to the need for privacy protective standards to be considered at the earliest possible stage of EFT system design and to be built in from the outset (para 441 of Report). My Department has in hand the consideration of the draft privacy legislation that the ALRC has recommended. I hope to be able to introduce that legislation in the near future and some aspects of it will have relevance to EFT developments. I refer the honourable member in this connection to my answer to a question without notice by Senator Bolkus in Senate Hansard, 15 June 1984, p. 3135.

Also, my colleague, the Treasurer, has established an interdepartmental working party to assess whether more formal arrangements than presently exist (including , if appropriate, legislation) covering the rights and obligations of users and providers of EFT are necessary, and if so, the scope of any such arrangements. All Commonwealth Departments with an interest in developments in the EFT field, including my own, are represented on the working party as is the Reserve Bank. Given my Department's active consideration of the ALRC Report on Privacy and the establishment of the working party on EFT, it would not be appropriate to refer the matter to the Law Reform Commission.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Equal Opportunity Programs: Department of Health

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Uranium Industry: Industrial Safety Procedures

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 2 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Does his answer to question No. 1043 (Hansard, 2 May 1984, pages 1706-7) mean that the Australian Ionizing Radiation Advisory Council and most serious discussants of the Tamplin and Cochran 'hot particle' thesis since 1975, reject the U.S. Committee on Biological Radiation report of 1980 as not being a serious discussion of this theory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Report of Biological Effects of Inhaled Radionuclides (B.E.I.R.) of 1980 is certainly a serious discussion of the 'hot particle theory'. It confirms the conclusions of the B.E.I.R. panel which reported on the hot particle theory in 1976.

This subject is also addressed by the International Commission on Radiation Protection (I.C.R.P.) in its publication No. 31, May 1979, on biological effects on inhaled radionuclides. The report states that 'the hot particle issue has been addressed by numerous scientists and scientific bodies, all of which conclude that a hot particle effect with respect of fatal lung cancer has not been demonstrated in either human beings or experimental animals'. This is supported by 13 references. Following discussion the I.C.R.P. report then states : 'The task group concludes that the risk of lung cancer from inhaled radiation particles will be greatly overestimated if based on hot particle concepts'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say what (a) sovereign states and (b) UN instrumentalities invited (i) Israeli, (ii) US, (iii) Syrian, (iv) Pan-Arab and (v) other forces into Lebanon.

(2) What notice did or will Australia give to the governments involved of Australian concern at the by-passing of UN Charter provisions requiring (a) non- violent bilateral and multilateral measures before resort to force to resolve disputes and (b) a UN peace-keeping force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (ii) At the request of the Lebanese Government, troops from the United States, together with contingents from France, Italy and the United Kingdom, formed a Multi-National Force which was deployed in Beirut in August 1982. This Force withdrew in February 1984.

(iii) Syrian forces intervened in the Lebanese civil war in 1976 in support of the government of President Franjieh. They were subsequently merged with the Arab Deterrent Forces (ADF) which was formed at a meeting of the Arab League in Cairo in October 1976.

The ADF comprised troops from Syria, Saudi Arabia, Sudan, the United Arab Emirates and the two Yemens. The purpose of the ADF (which was largely made up of Syrian troops) was to establish and maintain a cease-fire between the various factions in Lebanon. Its presence in Lebanon was with the agreement of the Government of Lebanon.

All elements of this Force, except those of Syria, were withdrawn from Lebanon by mid-1979. The Arab League's last six-month mandate for the ADF expired on 27 July 1982 and the future of the ADF was considered at the Arab League Summit in Fez in September 1982. The summit was informed of the 'Lebanese Government's decision to end the mission of the ADF' and agreed that the Lebanese and Syrian governments should negotiate to end the mission of the ADF, 'in the light of the Israeli withdrawal for Lebanon'. I understand however that no such formal negotiations have taken place.

(iv) Two United Nations peace-keeping forces are at present in Lebanon, with the agreement of the Lebanese goverment. They are the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) established under the authority of the Security Council in 1978 and the United Nations Truce Supervisory Organisation (UNTSO).

(v) There are approximately 80 unarmed French observers currently in Beirut. Their role has been to assist the Lebanese Authorities in supervising the cease- fire along the 'Green-Line'. They are in Lebanon with the agreement of the Lebanese government.

(2) The situation in Lebanon has been one of continuing concern since 1975. The UN has sought to play a role through UNIFIL and UNTSO, but without being able to prevent continuing hostilities. The Australian Government has consistently supported the United Nations in this peace-keeping role, and has supported Security Council resolutions calling for all parties to the conflict to cease all military activities within Lebanon. The Government has also, on numerous occasions, expressed its grave concern about the presence in Lebanon of foreign troops, especially since the Israeli invasion in June 1982, and has called for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon which are not there at the request of the Lebanese Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say when (a) the French Government first announced its intention to conduct nuclear tests at Mururoa or adjacent areas and (b) these tests began; if so (i) how many tests have taken place, (ii) on what dates, (iii ) with what yields and (iv) in what form did each test take place.
(2) What are the Government's estimates as to the number and type of tests France is likely to carry out at Mururoa during the next 12 to 24 months.
(3) Is he able to say whether (a) France conducts nuclear tests at any other site and (b) France's contribution to Western deterrents could be maintained without such a test program.
(4) On what dates have Australian uranium sales to France taken place and what were the quantities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) Information held by my Department does not indicate precisely when the French Government first announced its intentions to conduct nuclear tests at Mururoa Atoll. Nuclear testing at the French Pacific Tests Centre on Mururoa Atoll began in July 1966.

(b) (i) Since France does not announce when it has conducted a nuclear test, details about the number, nature and yield of nuclear tests conducted at Mururoa Atoll vary from source to source. The following information is based on details contained in the yearbooks of the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) and in the Report of the group of scientists from New Zealand, Australia and Papua New Guinea that visited Mururoa Atoll in October/November 1983. The data on underground tests at Mururoa Atoll contained in the latter Report was obtained largely from the New Zealand Seismological Laboratory with additional data calculated by the Australian Bureau of Mineral Resources (BMR) from the body wave estimates and identification located by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) and the International Seismological Centre (ISC).
According to the above sources a total of 104 nuclear tests have been conducted by France in the South Pacific of which 41 were in the atmosphere and 63 underground.
(b) (ii-iv) Details of the dates, yield and form of each test is as follows:
FRENCH ATMOSPHERIC NUCLEAR TESTS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC
FRENCH UNDERGROUND NUCLEAR TESTS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC

(2) France does not release information on planned nuclear tests. The number of nuclear tests conducted annually at Mururoa Atoll has, over recent years, averaged about eight. The Government has no reason to believe that this pattern is likely to change significantly over the next 12 to 24 months. The Government also expects that French nuclear tests will continue to be conducted underground .

(3) (a) Currently French nuclear tests are conducted only at Mururoa Atoll. France does, however, have a second nuclear testing site at Fangataufa island which is 50 km from Mururoa. The last nuclear explosion conducted at Fangataufa was on 26 November 1975 (see table above).

(b) The Government does not accept that the maintenance of the western deterrent requires any country to conduct nuclear tests in the South Pacific. In any event, the Government's view is that a universally adhered to comprehensive test ban treaty (CTB) which would ban all nuclear tests by all states in all environments would help to inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons by making it impossible to test nuclear explosive devices. It would also help to prevent the development of new nuclear weapons. A CTB would therefore be a major contribution to the strengthening of the security of all countries.

(4) I am advised by the Minister for Trade who has responsibility for the commercial aspects of Australian uranium exports that on 26 August 1981, Queensland Mines Limited executed a uranium sales contract with Electricite de France, providing for the delivery of 2,600 short tons U308 over the period 1982 through 1988. This is the only Australian uranium sales contract covering supply to France approved by the present or previous Governments.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Ban on Use of Phosphates in Detergents

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 7 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a recent decision by the Switzerland Government to ban the use of phosphates in detergents from January 1986.

(2) Have any studies been conducted in Australia which have investigated the effect of phosphates on surface waters such as rivers and lakes, from the use of detergents or fertilisers containing this substance.

(3) Is it a fact that an excess of phosphates causes an overgrowth of algae which can be environmentally harmful; if so, will he take steps to investigate the Switzerland decision with a view to introducing such a ban into Australia and widening it to include fertilisers if necessary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I was not previously aware of this development.
(2) Yes. There have been comprehensive studies in Australia of the effects on inland waters of excess nutrients, such as phosphates.

(3) Excess phosphates, combined with other nutrients, can cause environmentally harmful growth of algae in water bodies. This condition of excess, unbalanced growth is called eutrophication. Detergents represent only one source of phosphate. More is contributed from diffuse sources through run-off and erosion. Banning phosphate in detergent would have little general effect. Better land management and agricultural practices, leading to less loss of fertility from soil, may be more effective in improving water quality. Studies continue in this direction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 29 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the (a) purpose, (b) cost, and (c) personnel saving of the distributed customer records information system (DCRIS) to be installed by Telecom.
(2) Has the installation been delayed; if so, (a) what was the original date, ( b) what is the expected date and (c) what is the cause of the delay.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) DCRIS is a computer based system which Telecom proposes to use in its District operations to improve the convenience, speed and efficiency of handling customers' orders for its products and services. It will facilitate Telecom's dealings with customers in a similar way to which modern computer-based reservations systems have done for the airlines.

(b) The estimated capital cost for the first District is $5.6m, which includes a licence fee and the provision of hardware and software. Further contractual costs for National implementation would amount to about $26m. Telecom expects the benefits through increased productivity, greater efficiency and improved service to the customer to more than justify the costs.

(c) On a national basis, it is estimated that some 1500-1700 fewer positions, mainly in clerical grades, will be required for processing orders compared to the needs of the present paper-based system. Telecom's business growth will give counter-balancing employment. At the proposed completion of implementation of DCRIS in 1988, Telecom's overall staff level is expected to be about the same as at present. Clerical staffing will be within 3 per cent of the current level but there will, of course, be changes to functions.
Telecom is paying particular attention to ensure that its staff are well cared for. For example, I am advised that:
No permanent staff will be retrenched because of DCRIS.
Readjustment of staffing levels will be managed over an appropriate period.
Redeployment will be voluntary so far as practicable.
Retraining will be provided for staff moving to other jobs.

In keeping with its standard practice when introducing major new technology, Telecom is engaged in detailed discussions with Staff Associations whose members would be affected by the introduction of the DCRIS system.

(2) Yes. (a), (b) and (c) Telecom initially planned to introduce DCRIS at about the end of 1984 but more detailed programming has indicated that the project is larger than originally anticipated. Telecom informs me that it wishes to introduce DCRIS in the first Telecom District about mid 1985. Current Telecom planning envisages DCRIS in use Australia-wide by about the end of 1988.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 1 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What procedure was adopted by the ABC for the recent appointment for each of the following people, and what is their position, salary and term of appointment: (a) Mr Tony Bond, (b) Mr Mark Aarons, (c) Mr John Cassidy and (d) Mr Malcolm Long.
(2) If the procedure was different for any or all of these appointments, what is the usual procedure, and why was the procedure changed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on information supplied by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Bond, Mr Aarons, Mr Cassidy and Mr Long were already ABC staff members before their current appointments or promotions. Details of their positions, salaries and terms of appointment are as follows:

(a) Mr Tony Bond: The Board of Directors, at its meeting of 28/29 July 1983 decided to create an independent Secretariat to provide advice. The Board created eleven short-term positions and recommended to the Acting Managing Director that Mr Bond (then interim staff representative of the Board) be appointed as the Co-ordinator of the new Secretariat. The position is set at Clerical Officer Class 11. Mr Bond's appointment was made by the Acting Managing Director. His temporary appointment is for a two year period, as from 1 August 1983. His total annual salary is $38,143.

(b) Mr Mark Aarons: The Board of Directors determined that a number of Project Officers would be attached to the Board Secretariat. These positions were advertised and appointments were made following interview. Mr Aarons was one of the successful applicants. His position is that of Research Officer, Board Secretariat. His temporary appointment is from 5 March 1984 until 31 January 1986 and his total annual salary is $34,353.

(c) Mr John Cassidy: Mr Cassidy was promoted to the position of Executive Producer, Radio Talks and Documentaries, Victoria. The position was advertised in the normal manner and Mr Cassidy was the recommended applicant for promotion. His promotion is to the permanent staff and his total annual salary is $30,445.

(d) Mr Malcolm Long: The position of Controller Radio 2 became vacant following the retirement of its previous occupant. It has been filled by a number of acting Controllers pending the ABC's reorganisation. However, the ABC decided to advertise the position in the normal way. Mr Long was selected for promotion to the position. Because the Selection Committee unanimously recommended his promotion and the Board had accepted the recommendation, it was decided that Mr Long should act in the position until his promotion was confirmed.

Mr Long's provisional promotion was the subject of an appeal, but the situation has been overtaken by the ABC's restructuring in which the position of Controller Radio 2 will be abolished. Mr Long will continue to perform the duties associated with the position until appointments are made to newly-created senior positions. Mr Long's total annual salary is currently $52,551.

(2) Normal procedures were used in the appointments of Mr Aarons and Mr Cassidy ; applications were called and recommendations made. In Mr Bond's case the appointment was by recommendation of the Board of Directors.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Use of Satellite in Search and Rescue Operations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 30 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What role has the (a) Natural Disasters Organisation and (b) Marine Operations Centre had in the planning of the use of satellites, such as SARSAT/COSPAS, for more cost effective search and rescue operations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice received from the Department of Defence and the Department of Transport, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Natural Disasters Organisation has no role in search and rescue operations. It has not been involved in planning the use of satellites therein.

(b) The Marine Operations Centre, now the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre has had no part in the planning of the use of satellites, such as SARSAT/ COSPAS, for search and rescue purposes. However, there is close liaison between the Department of Transport and some of the nations involved in developing the system of satellite alerting and the use of the system in the Australian search and rescue area is under consideration.

The use of satellites for alerting search and rescue authorities to maritime distress situations together with accurate geographical positioning is currently being evaluated jointly by Canada, France, USA and USSR, with Norway, United Kingdom, Finland, Bulgaria and Brazil participating in the test program. The evaluation program of the satellite systems is scheduled for completion by the middle of this year with the results expected to be available within a few months of completion.

SARSAT/COSPAS and the communications system INMARSAT are all satellite systems under consideration by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) as part of its Future Global Maritime Distress and Safety System. Australia has participated in discussions on this subject at meetings of various Committees and Sub-Committees of IMO.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the International Atomic Energy Association need advance permission before inspecting a nuclear power house.
(2) What (a) strengthening and (b) weakening of IAEA and other safeguards has been made in Australia's regulation of uranium mining and export since 1975 and why.
(3) What proposals does Australia have to maintain or change this position.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Safeguards procedures such as inspection arrangements for nuclear facilities, including power reactors, are provided for in agreements negotiated between the International Atomic Energy Agency and its member states. These arrangements set out the rights and duties of the Agency and the member state in relation to the application of safeguards. Part of this involves the Agency's inspection rights. These include providing advance notice in most cases although the timing of inspections is a matter for the Agency. Normally the IAEA arranges that its inspectors are present during crucial operations (for instance, the annual discharge and reloading of the fuel of a light water reactor, or when the operator is taking a physical inventory of all nuclear material in a facility).
(2) (a) Australia's nuclear safeguards requirements since 1975 include:

selection of customers, with a minimum requirement that non-nuclear weapon state customers be parties to the Treaty on the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons and have concluded a NPT safeguards agreement with the IAEA;
all customers to conclude a bilateral nuclear safeguards agreement with Australia specifying peaceful non-explosive use;
Australian uranium to be covered by IAEA safeguards, both in nuclear weapon and non-nuclear weapon state customers, to verify such use;
physical protection of transferred nuclear material;
prior consent for retransfer, reprocessing and high enrichment of supplied nuclear material;
sanctions in event of non-compliance with designated provisions of the nuclear safeguards agreement;
administrative arrangements to ensure effective control including accounting for AONM.
In order to assist the IAEA and strengthen international non-proliferation controls, Australia has also:
signed on 22 February 1984 the 1980 convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material;
undertaken in cooperation with the IAEA programs of research and development designed to assist the IAEA to apply increasingly effective safeguards;
provided Australian experts for service with the IAEA Secretariat including the safeguards inspectorate;

made available since 1979 the Director of the Australian Safeguards Office to serve in a personal capacity on the IAEA Director-General's high-level Standing Advisory Group on Safeguards Implementation (SAGSI);
associated itself in 1978 with the Guidelines for the Export of Nuclear Material, Equipment or Technology of the Nuclear Suppliers Group 1975/78;

actively contributed to various other international projects to enhance the nuclear non-proliferation and safeguards regime, including the Hexapartite Safeguards Project 1980-83 on centrifuge enrichment plant safeguards, the IAEAWorking Group on Reprocessing Plant Safeguards 1979-81, the clarification in 1984 of equipment for gas centrifuge enrichment and reprocessing technology to be subject to export and other controls in accordance with the 1974 Zangger understandings, and projects Recover and Transeaver 1980-82 (trials of remote safeguards verification systems for nuclear facilities and nuclear material in transit).
(b) The ASTEC Inquiry has indicated some areas where nuclear safeguards may be augmented but none where Australian policy has operated to weaken IAEA safeguards.

(3) The Government has demonstrated its commitment to enhancing international nuclear safeguards. In May 1983 I reaffirmed Australia's support for the IAEA and its safeguards system to Dr Blix, the Director-General; and this was confirmed when Dr Blix visited Australia in March 1984. The Government approved in 1983 a three-year program of assistance to the Agency in safeguards research and development. The Government also commissioned in 1983 an independent inquiry by ASTEC into Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle including nuclear safeguards arrangements. The recommendations of the ASTEC Inquiry including those relating to nuclear safeguards and the resolution on uranium policy adopted by the 1984 ALP National Conference are currently under active consideration by the Government. The Government's objective is to subject all future exports of Australia's uranium to the most stringent supply conditions, and to augment the effectiveness of the IAEA safeguards system and other nuclear controls arrangements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 2 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say which countries have domestic citizenship policies which discriminate against some of their citizens on one or more of the grounds of (a) race, (b) colour, (c) creed or (d) for some other reason and what form does that discrimination take.

(2) Is he also able to say which countries have immigration policies which discriminate against (a) migrants and (b) visitors on one or more of the grounds of (i) race, (ii) colour, (iii) creed or (iv) for some other reason and what forms does that discrimination take.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I would wish to remind the honourable member that while it may be possible to provide accurate, factual answers to these questions in relation to some countries, the time and work involved to assemble such a mass of material does not make a substantive reply a practical proposition. Further, I could not be confident that in the end a comprehensive report of the kind sought by the honourable member, which would require making judgments about all countries, could be prepared.

I would draw the attention of the honourable member to the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination which, in Article 5, obliges State Parties to ''undertake to prohibit and to eliminate racial discrimination in all its forms and to guarantee the right of everyone without distinction as to race, colour or national or ethnic origin, to equality before the law . . .''

As at September 1983 this instrument had been ratified or acceded to by 121 governments which report to the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination on their compliance under the Convention. The reports of State Parties are public documents and would serve as a useful reference in providing the information sought. If the honourable member is seeking information on any particular countries I would be happy to assist further.

Further information may be obtained from the recent U.S. State Department ' Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 1983'. The section in each country report on ''Freedom of Movement Within the Country, Foreign Travel, Emigration and Repatriation'' would be of particular interest to the honourable member in obtaining specific answers to his question. This document is available from the Parliamentary Library.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a recent London Times claim that (a) 455 drug charges, most resulting in discharge from duties, were preferred last year against some of the approximately 30,000 American forces personnel based at 100 military sites in Britain, (b) 14 servicemen at the Greenham Common base were recently charged with drug offences, (c) 1726 of 5324 US servicemen were removed in 1980 from nuclear weapons work, most for drug abuse and (d) about a quarter of US troops in 12 months' service in Europe, including more than 2 out of 5 of young, low-rank men, admitted apparently regular drug taking; if so, can he confirm these claims.

(2) Has his attention also been drawn to a report in the Vanguard of PO Box 25, East Brighton, Vic., of 11 April 1984, that a senior psychologist believes this incidence of drug abuse will increase the risk of a serious incident.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 May 1984:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

In accordance with these provisions of the Act, all States and the Northern Territory have sought funding for urban public transport projects under this element of the Program. The first urban public transport projects were approved by the then Minister for Transport and Construction, the Hon. R. J. Hunt, MP, on 8 February 1983 when he agreed to $10.346m being directed to the Kingston- Beenleigh rail electrification project and six passenger interchanges in Brisbane. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 29 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Moomba pipeline lies adjacent to the area being investigated by the Department of Defence in the Cobar district for military manoeuvre purposes; if so, what precaution does the Government propose to take to protect (a) the pipeline and (b) those living in the area from any damage during military manoeuvres.
(2) What are the distances required on either side of the pipeline as a 'safety zone' to ensure that the pipeline would not be damaged by military exercises.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Defence was for some time investigating an area in the Cobar district for military manoeuvre purposes. The proposal gave rise to a number of alternative land use considerations including the possible closing-off of access to mineral resources and the safety of operations of the Moomba-Sydney pipeline which traverses about 150 km of the proposed area.
The Government announced on 23 July 1984 that it had ruled out the area under consideration because of conflicting land use pressures.
(2) In the light of the Government's decision these considerations do not apply .

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 30 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many passengers (a) embarked and (b) disembarked at Darwin Airport from international flights operated by (i) Qantas, (ii) Garuda, (iii) Royal Brunei and (iv) any other airline in each of the years 1981-82 and 1982-83.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 31 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an experiment in 1976 when Egyptian children were hired to expose themselves to cotton field aerial spraying with the Swiss pesticide Galedron containing chlorodimeform (CDF) which was later linked with cancer and which has been banned from use in Switzerland since 1976 and in other European countries at various times.

(2) Has Australia taken steps to object to the use of this pesticide in Bolivia , Colombia, Honduras, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala cotton fields where farm workers are reported to accumulate CDF levels 50 times the World Health Organisation recommended safe limit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am informed that a pesticide containing Chlordimeform was used in Egypt for a period up to 1976, at which time it was withdrawn. There have been media reports in Europe that the alleged experiment referred to took place but I am not able to confirm the accuracy of such reports. An evaluation of Chlordimeform by the International Agency for Research on Cancer in 1983 said: 'No data was available on the carcinogenicity of Chlordimeform to experimental animals. However, results of experiments in mice provide sufficient evidence that para- chloro-ortho-toluidine, a metabolite of Chlordimeform, is carcinogenic to experimental animals. No relevant data on humans was available. The available data are insufficient to evaluate the carcinogenicity of Chlordimeform to humans '.

According to the International Register of Potentially Toxic Compounds, Chlordimeform is currently banned for production and use in one country (the Soviet Union) but is permitted in a number of others subject to varying degrees of restriction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 4 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Barry telephone exchange in New South Wales been removed from the Neville zone and added to the Blayney zone thus enabling local call access to both Orange and Bathurst from Barry; if so, when.

(2) Is it a fact that when Hobby's Yards exchange was closed, customers gained local call access to both Orange and Bathurst because of the linkage between Hobby's Yards and the Barry exchange; if so, do adjoining rural properties have discriminatory levels of local call access.

(3) Is it also a fact that Sydney subscribers have local call access to more than 2 million subscribers, Hobby's Yards subscribers have access to 31 exchanges and nearly 20 000 subscribers and Trunkey Creek subscribers access to local calls is limited to 11 exchanges and 1 628 subscribers.

(4) Is he able to say whether there is a strong community of interest between Hobby's Yards and Trunkey Creek; if so, will he ensure that a 'point off our' is created between Blayney, Neville, Bathurst and Rookley zones to allow local call access to Bathurst from Neville and Trunkey Creek in order to remove this anomalous situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) On the closure of the Hobby's Yards exchange which was located in the Neville charging zone, subscribers were transferred to the Barry exchange which is situated in the Blayney zone. As all subscribers to an exchange are charged according to the charging zone in which the exchange is situated, the former Hobby's Yards subscribers gained local call access to both Orange and Bathurst.

It is assumed that the honourable member is referring to the fact that this action resulted in subscribers residing on adjoining properties who are connected to exchanges located in different charging zones being charged at different rates on calls to certain centres, for example, Bathurst. However, this situation is common throughout Australia and is in accordance with the normal zoning principles by which all call charges are determined.

(3) A Sydney subscriber in the inner metropolitan (02) zone has local call access to approximately 1.2 million subscribers; a Barry Exchange subscriber has local call access to 36 exchanges serving about 20,000 subscribers; and a Trunkey Creek Exchange subscriber has local call access to 18 exchanges serving more than 2,000 subscribers.

(4) Telecom recognises the community of interest between Hobby's Yards and Trunkey Creek and local call access is available between these centres. However, this community of interest has no bearing on the charges applying to calls from the Neville zone in which the Neville and Trunkey Creek exchanges are located. As indicated in the reply to (2), Telecom does not regard the situation as anomalous as charging arrangements in this area are in keeping with the general principles of zoning applied throughout Australia. Telecom does not propose to alter the zoning arrangements along the lines suggested as subscribers similarly placed in other areas would naturally want the same consideration.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Townsville and Rockhampton Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 June 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Broadcasting Corporation closing its television studios at Townsville and Rockhampton, Qld; if so, will the ABC review the decision or negotiate on the issue.
(2) If so, (a) with whom will it negotiate and (b) what are the (i) terms and ( ii) timetable of the review.

(3) Is it a fact that all ABC regional radio and television news will cease when the satellite television service begins; if so, will this be in 1988, as reported in the press, or earlier when the satellites are launched.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The decision by the ABC is based on the policy of providing a national television service, not a regional one. The current regional television services in Rockhampton and Townsville are the result of a decision to provide an early television service to the area. The cost of studio facilities and staff is estimated at $1,500,000 annually, which is considered a disproportionately high allocation of ABC resources to present a small amount of local television. The ABC decided that the reorganisation of the two regional studios would coincide with the conversion of its television and radio networks to a satellite distribution system. This would enable the ABC to reallocate those resources used for local program production in Rockhampton and Townsville within the new system.

(2) Senior ABC management representatives attended a meeting on 30 May 1984 in Canberra with Members of Parliament from North Queensland to explain the background and reasons for the Board's decision.

ABC staff organisation and unions were informed before the decision was publicly announced. The decision will result in redeployment of staff, but not necessarily redundancies. A comprehensive retraining program will be undertaken for staff affected by the proposed changes in Rockhampton and Townsville and other centres.

(3) No. The satellite is not intended to be a means of replacing programs currently provided by the terrestrial networks but to distribute those programs more efficiently and flexibly. The ABC has made a conscious decision to increase its regional radio services through the planned second regional radio network and additional regional radio studios. There will also be an enhanced State-wide television coverage. Any change would not occur before early 1986.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 7 June 1984:

ANSWER.PARA: The features described in the honourable member's question cannot be provided by a special type of telephone alone. They can only be provided in association with special signalling arrangements in the public switched telephone network.

Telecom is aware of trials of this type of telephone/network arrangements being conducted in the USA and is keeping abreast of developments with a view to the possible introduction of a similar service in Australia.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Repatriation of Plutonium to United Kingdom

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does a document marked 'SECRET', dated 29 November 1978, from the Minister for National Development, Canberra, indicate Australian Government acceptance of U.K. proposals to repatriate a half kilogram of plutonium from Australia to the U.K. with maximum secrecy to avoid port entry difficulties.

(2) Is it a fact that Australian law, including international law or conventions to which Australia is a party, requires that the nature of cargoes, including plutonium or uranium, be declared on request to port authorities.
(3) Is he able to say whether international law was breached by the U.K. in repatriating plutonium.
(4) What safeguards are provided to ensure that no such breach occurs in future .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Customs Act requires that the nature of cargoes, including plutonium or uranium, be reported to customs before any clearance of the vessel can be granted. The Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, under the Customs Act, prohibit the export of goods such as plutonium and uranium unless approved by authorised persons.

The Commonwealth Navigation Act 1912, Marine Orders Part 41 (Cargo and Cargo Handling-Dangerous Goods) requires notice of intention to ship dangerous goods, including radioactive substances, to be given to the Regional Directors of the Department of Transport at least 48 hours before the goods are loaded on ships.

The Commonwealth Navigation Act 1912, (Cargo-Hazards Prevention) Regulations require that any quantity of a radioactive substance shall not be loaded onto or unloaded from a ship at a port unless an inspection has been made by a marine surveyor of the Department of Transport, and he has approved the loading or unloading or the Regional Director of the Department of Transport has approved the loading or unloading.

State marine and port authorities have promulgated regulations which require notification of the arrival of ships which have radioactive substances on board. They also require notice of intention to load such goods onto ships.

There are also provisions in the Air Navigation Regulations to the effect that a civil aircraft shall not carry goods such as uranium or plutonium except with the permission in writing of the Secretary to the Department of Aviation and in accordance with the conditions specified in the permit.

(3) I would draw the honourable member's attention to paragraph (d) of the British High Commission's note of 4 January 1979, which forms part of the document to which the honourable member refers. This states, inter alia, that:

'The United Kingdom authorities will have responsibility for safe and secure transport of the material from Australia to the U.K., including its cost. The United Kingdom should also be involved in supervising the packaging of material at Maralinga to ensure that it meets appropriate containment standards both for its transport within Australia and subsequently.'
I am not aware of any breach by the United Kingdom of these responsibilities under Australian law, or of its responsibilities under international law in respect of the consignment concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 24 August 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Mr Ted Wilshire a former member of his staff; if so, in what capacity did he serve and when.
(2) Has Mr Wilshire now applied for a vacancy within the Department of Trade and is this vacancy within the Second Division of the Department.

(3) Did other recent applications for a position in the Second Division go before an interviewing panel of 2 departmental officers at First Assistant Secretary level and an officer from the Public Service Board, also at First Assistant Secretary level.

(4) Did the panel interviewing Mr Wilshire consist of one Trade Department Officer at First Assistant Secretary level, one Public Service Board officer at First Assistant Secretary level, one representative of the ACTU and one representative of the MTIA; if so, why was the interviewing panel varied in the case of Mr Wilshire.
(5) Is Mr Wilshire a former researcher for a trade union; if so, what is the name of that trade union.
(6) Why was a representative from the ACTU included on the selection panel.
(7) In how many other interviews this year has an ACTU representative been included on the selection panel.
(8) When will a decision be made on Mr Wilshire's application.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Mr Wilshire was seconded from the Amalgamated Metal Foundry and Shipwright's Union for twelve months from February 1981 to February 1982 as a Ministerial Officer, Grade II.

(2) Mr Wilshire was appointed as a Clerk (Class 11) in the Department of Trade with effect from 27 February 1984. The advertised vacancy was not restricted to officers of the Public Service and, accordingly, the Public Service Board was represented on the selection committee. Mr Wilshire has subsequently sought promotion within the Department.

(3) Following a restructuring of the Department of Trade in May 1984, a number of vacancies at various levels within the Second Division were advertised. Selection committees were formed to conduct selections for each position. Each committee generally comprised two Departmental officers and a nominee of the Public Service Board of appropriate Second Division status, depending on the level of the relevant vacancy.

(4) Yes. Departmental selection committees are constituted to ensure that the background and experience of members are relevant to the duties, functions and responsibilities of the advertised vacancies. Representatives of the ACTU and MTIA were sought for the committee considering applicants for the newly created position of Principal Adviser, Business/Union Consultations, because of the importance of the position to the implementation of the Prices and Incomes Accord and increased emphasis within the Department on exports of manufactured goods and services. Precedents exist in relation to the participation of persons from outside the Public Service on selection committees for the filling of vacancies in the Public Service. Such instances can reflect, for example, the need to draw on special expertise and/or experience not readily available from within the Public Service.
(5) Yes. Amalgamated Metal Foundry and Shipwright's Union.
(8) At the time at which a decision is taken to substantively fill the relevant vacancy.
